title: Towards Generalizable Deepfake Detection by Primary Region Regularization
authors: Harry Cheng, Yangyang Guo, Tianyi Wang, Liqiang Nie, Mohan Kankanhalli
publish: ACM Transactions on Multimedia Computing, Communications, and Applications
abstract: The existing deepfake detection methods have reached a bottleneck in generalizing to unseen forgeries and manipulation approaches. Based on the observation that the deepfake detectors exhibit a preference for overfitting specific primary regions in input, this paper enhances the generalization capability from a novel regularization perspective. This can be simply achieved by augmenting the images through primary region removal, thereby preventing the detector from over-relying on data bias. Our method consists of two stages, namely the static localization for primary region maps, as well as the dynamic exploitation of primary region masks. The proposed method can be seamlessly integrated into different backbones without affecting their inference efficiency. We conduct extensive experiments over five widely used deepfake datasets - DFDC, DF-1.0, Celeb-DF, WildDF, and FFIW with seven backbones. Our method demonstrates an average performance improvement of 6% across different backbones and performs competitively with several state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Channel-Informed RIS Analysis and Optimization Using Hybrid Ray-Tracing and Full-Wave Simulation Framework
authors: Ziqi Liu, Sean Victor Hum
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: This paper introduces a hybrid approach combining ray-tracing (RT) and full-wave numerical analysis to evaluate and optimize reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (RISs) in deterministic channels. Unlike traditional methods relying on statistical models, our approach integrates RT for deterministic channel mapping and finite element method (FEM)-based simulations to assess RIS impacts in realistic, site-specific scenarios. A non-diagonal impedance matrix is formed to link channel transfer functions to RIS tunable load impedances, accounting for mutual coupling between unit cells and enabling precise optimization for enhanced communication performance. A varactor-based RIS operating in the sub-6 GHz frequency band is designed and fabricated, with extensive simulations and real-world measurements conducted in single-input single-output (SISO) and single-input multiple-output (SIMO) scenarios. A measurement-based closed-loop optimization process further refines RIS configurations. Results demonstrate substantial signal strength improvements, with strong agreement between simulations and measurements, confirming the practicality and effectiveness of the proposed method for advanced RIS-enabled communication systems.

title: Communication Efficient Federated Learning with Quantization-Aware Training Design
authors: Xiang Fang, Li Chen, Huarui Yin, Xiaohui Chen, Weidong Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Machine Learning in Communications and Networking
abstract: Model quantization is an effective method that can improve communication efficiency in federated learning (FL). The existing FL quantization protocols almost stay at the level of post-training quantization (PTQ), which comes at the cost of large quantization loss, especially in the setting of low-bits quantization. In this work, we propose a FL quantization training strategy to reduce the impact of quantization on model quality. Specifically, we first apply quantization-aware training (QAT) to FL (QAT-FL), which reduces quantization distortion by adding a fake-quantization module to the model so that the model could perceive future quantization during training. The convergence guarantee of the QAT-FL algorithm is established under certain assumptions. On the basis of the QAT-FL algorithm, we extend the discussion of non-uniform quantization and the adaptive algorithm, so that the model can adaptively adjust the parametric distribution and the number of quantization bits to reduce the amount of traffic in training. Experimental results based on MNIST, CIFAR-10 and FEMNIST datasets show that QAT-FL has advantages in terms of training loss and model inference accuracy, and adaptive-bits quantization of QAT-FL also greatly improves communication efficiency.

title: Hybrid-driven Disc-shaped Autonomous Underwater Vehicle with High Maneuverability and Gliding Capability: Design and Experiments
authors: Haoda Li, Zhihang Jin, Jin Huang, Zichen Liu, Xianyu Peng, Zhikun Wang, Ying Chen
publish: IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters
abstract: This paper presents the mechatronic design and implementation of a hybrid-driven disc-shaped autonomous underwater vehicle (HD-AUV). The hybrid-driven system integrates a buoyancy adjustment system and propeller thrusters, enabling the HD-AUV to achieve both high maneuverability motion and energy-efficient gliding. These capabilities correspond to two distinct motion modes: AUV mode and glider mode. In AUV mode, the HD-AUV leverages the rotational symmetry of its disc-shaped design to achieve four degree-of-freedom (4-DOF) motion control. This configuration, supported by four propeller thrusters, facilitates high-maneuverability actions, including fixed-point hovering and in-place turning. In glider mode, the integration of rotatable dorsal fins and horizontal propeller thrusters enables the HD-AUV to transition seamlessly between diving and ascending phases without the conventional mass-shifting mechanisms used in torpedo-type gliders. Numerical simulations are conducted to evaluate the steady glide performance of the HD-AUV, focusing on lift-to-drag ratios and hydrodynamic coefficients. Comprehensive pool experiments, encompassing multi-DOF maneuvers and gentle gliding, demonstrate the exceptional locomotion capabilities of the HD-AUV and validate the accuracy of the proposed dynamic model. These hybrid motion modes hold significant promise for underwater operations in complex seafloor environments.

title: Equal-Time-and-Magnitude Shaping Enhanced ADRC for Precise Liquid Handling in Biglide Parallel Robotic Systems
authors: Toan Le Duc, Thi-Van-Anh Nguyen, Quy-Thinh Dao, Ngoc-Tam Bui
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Parallel robots are increasingly used in automation thanks to their high stiffness, accuracy, and reduced moving inertia. Among them, the Biglide parallel robot offers a promising architecture for material handling tasks. However, transporting liquid-filled containers with such systems introduces significant challenges due to sloshing dynamics. Sloshing can degrade positioning accuracy, prolong settling time, and even cause spillage, making effective vibration suppression essential. In this study, Active Disturbance Rejection Control (ADRC) is applied to the Biglide robot to ensure precise trajectory tracking under uncertainties. With its real-time disturbance estimation and compensation capability, ADRC improves both tracking accuracy and system stability. To further attenuate sloshing-induced vibrations, particular emphasis is placed on the Equal-Time-and-Magnitude (ETM4) input shaper, which provides strong robustness to modeling errors while maintaining excellent vibration suppression. For comparison, conventional shapers such as Zero Vibration (ZV) and Zero Vibration and Derivative (ZVD) are also implemented. Simulation results confirm that the combined ADRC–IS scheme, especially with ETM4, delivers a reliable and effective solution for vibration-sensitive liquid transport in parallel robotic systems.

title: SNI-SLAM++: Tightly-Coupled Semantic Neural Implicit SLAM
authors: Siting Zhu, Guangming Wang, Hermann Blum, Zhong Wang, Ganlin Zhang, Daniel Cremers, Marc Pollefeys, Hesheng Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: We propose SNI-SLAM++, a tightly-coupled semantic SLAM system utilizing neural implicit representation, that simultaneously performs accurate semantic mapping, high-quality surface reconstruction, and robust camera tracking. Our system tightly integrates visual appearance, geometry, and semantics through five key components: (i) We introduce hierarchical semantic representation to allow multi-level semantic comprehension for top-down structured semantic mapping of the scene. (ii) To fully utilize the correlation between multiple attributes of the environment, we integrate appearance, geometry and semantic features through cross-attention for feature collaboration. This strategy enables a more multifaceted understanding of the environment, thereby allowing SNI-SLAM++ to remain robust even when single attribute is defective. (iii) We design an internal fusion-based decoder to obtain semantic, RGB, and Truncated Signed Distance Field (TSDF) values from multi-level features for accurate decoding. (iv) We introduce a semantics-coupled tracking framework that tightly incorporates semantic constraints for camera pose estimation in neural implicit SLAM. This framework leverages the multi-view consistency of semantics to construct a pose graph and perform semantic loop closure optimization, enabling robust tracking. (v) We propose a feature loss to update the scene representation at the feature level. Compared with low-level losses such as RGB loss and depth loss, our feature loss is capable of guiding the network optimization on a higher level. Our SNI-SLAM++ demonstrates superior performance over all recent visual SLAM methods in terms of mapping and tracking accuracy on the datasets of Replica, ScanNet, TUM-RGBD, and ScanNet++, while also showing excellent capabilities in accurate semantic segmentation and 3D semantic mapping.

title: Spatial Attention-based Convoluted Gazelle Neural Network (SACGNN): Advanced Clutter Removal Across Diverse Surfaces_supp1-3634200.pdf
authors: Santhosh Kumar Buddepu
publish: N/A
abstract: The presence of clutter in ground penetrating radar (GPR) images obscures or distorts the responses of subsurface targets, significantly impacting the accuracy of detecting and identifying targets. Current clutter removal approaches often result in residual clutter or deformation of target responses, especially when confronted with intricate and uneven clutter in real-world GPR signatures. To address this issue in clutter removal under realistic conditions, this research introduces the Spatial Attention-based Convoluted Gazelle Neural Network (SACGNN). SACGNN is trained on large-scale dataset designed to reflect real-time conditions and incorporates a residual block into its spatial attention-based architecture. This integration enhances its ability to suppress clutter and restore target reflections on surfaces like homogeneous, rough, water, and grass surfaces. Tuning the SACGNN using the gazelle optimization algorithm excels in clutter removal by offering faster convergence, maintaining a balanced exploration-exploitation trade-off, and enhancing robustness across various data patterns.

title: A Pulsed Tumor Treating Fields Protocol to Improve Glioblastoma Therapy
authors: Yanpeng Lv, Shihan Lu, Haodong Wang, Jianhua Zhang, Chuanliang Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Biomedical Engineering
abstract: Tumor Treating Fields (TTFields) utilize alternating fields (AC fields) within 100–300 kHz and electric field strengths above 1 V/cm for glioblastoma (GBM) treatment. However, the electric field is often reduced to a relatively low value (below 1 V/cm) due to the unavoidable thermal effects induced by Joule heating on the patient's skin. Objective: This study proposes a pulsed TTFields to enhance therapy effect, while reducing thermal effects. Methods: This work designed a TTFields generator to output 200 kHz AC fields. Cell experiments were conducted to compare cell viability between pulsed and conventional TTFields. A gel platform was used to measure temperature rises under clinical parameters of TTFields. A realistic head model with a tumor was simulated to analyze electric field and thermal distributions. Results: The designed generator can output two separate TTFields signals with 100 V voltage amplitude and 2000 mA current amplitude, meeting clinical trial requirements. Pulsed TTFields (10% duty cycle, 3.37 V/cm) achieved significantly lower cell viability (53.07%) than continuous TTFields (1.07 V/cm, 84.76%) while maintaining similar temperature rises. Gel experiments confirmed comparable temperature rises for both protocols. Simulations on a realistic head model demonstrated that pulsed TTFields achieved broader tumor coverage (electric field >1 V/cm) compared to continuous TTFields under equivalent thermal conditions. Conclusion: Pulsed TTFields can generate higher electric fields in targeted regions, significantly inhibiting cell proliferation while reducing thermal risks compared to continuous TTFields. Significance: The proposed pulsed TTFields may provide an optimized treatment method to enhance GBM therapy efficacy.

title: A 3:1 Bandwidth Bifilar Helix with Monolithic Self-supporting Feed
authors: Jori M. Platt, Ljubodrag B. Boskovic, Dejan S. Filipovic
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: An over 3:1 bandwidth self-supported bifilar helix with a monolithically integrated coaxial filter line feed is introduced. Low impedance mismatch and consistent radiation patterns featuring high beam symmetry, polarization purity, and directivity with low side lobes are achieved over 6-18.5 GHz. This performance is accomplished by deploying several geometrical modifications including tapered termination of the helix, increased wire thickness, and a dual pitch angle structure. The antenna is designed for and manufactured with the digital light processing (DLP) three-dimensional (3D) printing technique. DLP 3D printing enables monolithic integration of an air-filled coaxial filter line which also mechanically supports the helical filaments and ensures smooth transition to connector. Excellent agreement between measurements and simulations demonstrates the robustness of the proposed design and its utility for diverse applications across commercial and defense sectors.

title: Online Optimization of Robust Polarized Beamforming for Smart Skin Antenna Array
authors: Zhibin Chen, Zhikun Chen, Yuxi Zhu, Jingchao You
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: The smart skin antenna integrates with the carrier height, and polarization provides refined recognition capabilities, both of which combine to achieve maximum aperture and improved degrees of freedom. However, the beam performance of skin antenna depends on strain measurement data, and real-time monitoring will introduce errors, causing steering vector mismatches that degrade beam performance and polarization accuracy. To address this challenge, an online optimization method is proposed to achieve robust polarized beamforming in smart skin antenna array. The strain measurement data is used to develop a reconfigurable antenna model online via the modal method. Building on this foundation, the improved feature subspace (IFS) method estimates the actual steering vector in real-time. The estimated steering vector is then integrated with second-order cone programming (SOCP) algorithm to achieve online optimal robust polarized beamforming for smart skin array. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method not only enables real-time reconstruction of the optimal robust polarized beamforming but also significantly improves the overall performance of the smart skin array. The optimizations in beamwidth, pattern gain, and polarization matching exceed those of previous studies, highlighting the engineering potential of smart skin arrays in robust polarized beamforming.

title: Genetic-Firefly Algorithm Based Approach in Image Steganography
authors: Narimen Hafsi, Hanaa Hachimi, Djamel Benterki, Yacine Slimani
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: The proliferation of data exchange over the Internet has heightened the importance of secure communication, making data protection a critical challenge in the field of digital communications. As digital content becomes increasingly vulnerable to tampering, there is a growing demand for robust mechanisms to ensure data authenticity and integrity. In this context, steganography has emerged as a viable alternative to traditional methods such as cryptography and watermarking, offering enhanced data confidentiality by concealing information within cover media. This paper proposes a steganographic technique based on an hybridaztion of two algorithms, Genetic algorithm and Firefly algorithm, aimed at optimizing the embedding process to achieve high imperceptibility. The method involves selecting a carrier image whose least significant bits exhibit a high degree of compatibility with the payload (secret image), thereby minimizing perceptual distortion in the resulting stego-image.

title: Cosmic radiation exposure calculation for domestic flights departs from Fez
authors: Dounia Bathoum, Slimane Semghouli, Abdelmajid Choukri
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: This study aims to estimate the risks associated with the cosmic radiation dose received by crews and passengers on internal flights departing from Fez. The methods used are SIEVERT and the mathematical model which provides an estimate of the effective doses based on flight parameters are the flight duration, the atitude, the laltitude. The total cancer risk and genetic effects were estimated according to the ICRP. The effective doses determined by the SIEVERT and the mathematical model for the departure airport of Fez to the different national destinations are as follows: The measured dose values ranged from 0.40 µSv to 0.90 µSv and the calculated effective dose values ranged from 1.44 µSv to 2.21 µSv. The risk of cancer with aircrew members and passengers computed ranged from 17×10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−5</sup> to 28×10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−5</sup> and 30×10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−6</sup> to 53×10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−6</sup>. And also, the risk of effects genetic with flight crews and travelers computed ranged from 3×10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−5</sup> to 5×10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−5</sup> and 7×10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−6</sup> to 12×10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−6</sup>. The results of the calculation differ with the measurements for internal flights from Fez. To mitigate the risk of potential health effects, safety measures must be taken to lower the dose.

title: Towards a behavioral model of hybrid leadership in Morocco: between performance, human relations and cultural roots
authors: Farah Asmaa, Daoudi Sara
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: This study takes a close look at eight behavioral dimensions of leadership within what we might call a hybrid organizational reality. The dimensions are grouped under two big orientations, though in practice the boundaries are not always so clear. On the one hand, task-oriented leadership covers issues like performance management, autonomy, digital integration, and, of course, innovation. On the other hand, relational-oriented leadership deals more with support, cohesion, spiritual guidance, and what I described as emotional regulation through a certain strategic distance. Methodologically, the research did not follow a straight line. It started with a qualitative phase, based on semi-structured interviews with Moroccan leaders from very different sectors, and only later moved to a more structured survey for quantitative validation. The interviews were analyzed thematically, sometimes with overlapping categories, to bring out behaviors that feel rooted in local culture. The survey phase helped check whether these patterns hold up statistically, giving evidence of both consistency and validity. Taken together, these steps led to a model of hybrid leadership adapted to Moroccan sociocultural realities. It combines elements that look universal with others that are very specific to local practices. The model does not claim to be perfect, but it does aim to offer useful insights for developing leadership in today’s complex, multicultural, and increasingly digital work environments. It seems especially relevant for organizations trying to juggle hybrid work setups, intergenerational dynamics, and cultural pluralism.

title: A Comparative Study of RNN Improved Algorithms for Rolling Bearing Life Prediction
authors: Heng Zhang, Chaoyong Ma, Lijun Yan, Miaorui Yang, Yonggang Xu, Kun Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: Confronting non-stationary vibration signals and extended temporal dependencies in rolling bearing prognostics, this work assesses Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks, an enhanced RNN variant, and a CNN-LSTM fusion model. Key degradation features are first characterized by ten time-frequency domain statistical indicators. Next, the training set labels, corresponding to the full lifecycle of the bearings, are defined in chronological order. Finally, the degradation features are fed into the LSTM and CNN-LSTM models to compare their predictive performance. Experimental results reveal that the CNN-LSTM model significantly outperforms the standard LSTM in high-noise scenarios due to the convolutional layer's ability to extract robust spatial features, despite incurring longer training times. In contrast, the LSTM model demonstrates more efficient training under low-noise conditions and exhibits reduced fluctuations in later-stage predictions. These findings illustrate the matching law between model characteristics and operational conditions: while CNN-LSTM is more suitable for industrial scenarios characterized by high noise and complex features, LSTM is preferable for real-time prediction tasks with limited computational resources.

title: Dynamic SLAM Based on Instance Segmentation and Enhanced Geometric Constraints
authors: Haibo Wu, Chao Yang, Yu Zhang, Xian Wang, Xuan Wang, Rongzhen Luo
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: Autonomous driving has gradually become a research hotspot in recent years, the limitations of traditional visual SLAM systems in dynamic environments are becoming increasingly prominent. To overcome this limitation, this paper propose YGM-SLAM, an enhanced SLAM framework built upon ORB-SLAM3. It integrates a lightweight YOLOv11-Seg model for real-time semantic mask generation and dynamic keypoint removal. In addition, In addition, we propose a depth-aware adaptive thresholding mechanism and integrate it into the multi-view geometry framework, enabling robust identification and removal of feature points associated with dynamic objects while maintaining reliable static observations. Evaluation on highly dynamic sequences from the TUM dataset demonstrates that YGM-SLAM enhances localization performance, reducing ATE by more than 88.24% compared to ORB-SLAM3.These results demonstrate its strong practicality and potential for deployment in real-world dynamic environments.

title: Transient Thermal Analysis of Laser Cladding Process on Curved Substrates
authors: Qikai Zhuang, Xiuhua Men, Peng Zhang, Mingyu Li, Yongzhi Pan, Hai Wang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: In this paper, the transient thermal behavior of cylindrical surface laser cladding is studied. A full three-dimensional finite element model was established to quantify the influence of curvature effect on the evolution of the temperature field. Based on the finite element simulation platform, a transient heat conduction model integrating life-and-death element technology and surface adaptive heat source loading algorithm was developed. By simulating the cladding process under different curvature radii, it is found that the temperature peak is strongly positively correlated with curvature. There is a critical radius threshold in the cladding process of cylindrical cladding matrix. This model provides a theoretical basis for the optimization of laser remanufacturing process for high-curvature parts (such as shafts and bearing housings). By suppressing the overheating zones and thermal stress concentration, the service reliability of repaired parts can be significantly improved.

title: Automatic Ultrasonic Field Scanning and Processing System based on LabVIEW
authors: Xinze Liu, Zhenxiang Ji, Jie Jin, Tianyi Yan, Jinglong Wu, Dingjie Suo
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Complex Medical Engineering (CME)
abstract: Energy detection before transcranial ultrasound therapy is the core link to ensure safety and therapeutic effect. The ultrasonic sound field scanning system introduced in this paper realizes the automated three-dimensional sound field scanning through hydrophones, a three-axis moving platform and a computer control architecture. The upper computer of the system adopts a hierarchical design: LabVIEW controls the movement of the motor (including linear and planar modules), and MATLAB processes the sound pressure data and generates international standard reports. The automatic testing process is accomplished through three layers. The first layer connects the control program with the front-end user display interface; the second layer realizes the automatic acquisition of voltage signals at each point within the acoustic field through the cyclic switching of states such as triggering acquisition, signal storage, position judgment, and motor drive; the third layer provides independent functional support for the second layer. This achieves low-cost, high-precision, and automated three-dimensional ultrasonic acoustic field scanning, significantly reducing costs while ensuring the accuracy of the test results.

title: Online Monitoring and Intelligent Acquisition Method for Power Equipment Data based on IEEE 802.11 Standard
authors: Yang Yang, Mengjie Liu, Jintao Qi, Weijia Ren
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: Aiming at the problems that existing acquisition methods cannot obtain all data information and cannot identify non - normal data, wireless communication technology based on IEEE 802.11 Standard is introduced in this study to conduct research on an intelligent acquisition method for online monitoring data of power equipment. This method first designs the data acquisition mode for online monitoring of power equipment, uses wireless communication technology to achieve data communication and processing, then conducts intelligent data acquisition, and realizes multi - modal data storage. Finally, experiments are carried out to verify the advancement of the proposed method. Comparative experiments show that the new acquisition method can collect all monitoring data and mark non -normal monitoring data, which has great application value.

title: Hybrid Deep Learning for Hyperspectral Imaging: Merging 1D and 2D CNNs for Enhanced Land Cover Mapping
authors: Assia Nouna, Soumaya Nouna, Ilyas Tammouch, Abdelamine Elouafi
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: This paper sets out the creation of a dual convolutional neural network system that combines both one-dimensional and two-dimensional deep learning models. The 1D CNN takes individual pixel spectral data to build essential spectral features while the 2D CNN examines local area pixels to extract spatial information. The system obtains complete knowledge of hyperspectral data by combining the output signals from both neural network branches. The Pavia University benchmark dataset tests demonstrate that the hybrid 1D2D CNN architecture outperforms conventional machine learning approaches, including k-nearest neighbors (KNN), support vector machines (SVM), and Random Forest (RF), in terms of classification accuracy. Our method outperforms KNN by using both spectral and spatial information and surpasses SVM and RF because it employs two separate branches for spatial feature extraction. The fusion methodology leads to better classification precision and enhanced resistance to spectral noise as well as improved outcomes for class-overlapping situations. The results show that deep learning combined with spectral-spatial feature fusion effectively maps hyperspectral land cover.

title: Beyond Empirical Limits: Accurate Electromagnetic Modelling of Drug Delivery Sensor
authors: Tijana Dimitrijevic, Jisun Im, Ana Vukovic, Phillip Sewell, Cristopher Tuck
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Technologies, Systems and Services in Telecommunications (TELSIKS)
abstract: The paper presents design and analysis approach for an electro-magnetic biosensor for drug release modelling. The sensor resonant frequencies are analyzed using simple empirical formulae and compared to the results obtained using a full wave numerical solver. The sensor-antenna set up was then fabricated and tested and results compared with simulation.

title: Genetic Algorithm Combined with Sequential Quadratic Programming for Efficient Reliability-Based Optimization of Reinforced Concrete Bridges
authors: Najib Zemed, Hanane Moulay Abdelali, Toufik Cherradi, Kaoutar Mouzoun, Azzeddine Bouyahyaoui
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: Reinforced concrete (RC) bridge design under uncertainty requires advanced strategies that balance reliability and efficiency. This study presents a hybrid Reliability-Based Design Optimization (RBDO) framework combining the global search capability of Genetic Algorithms (GA) with the local refinement of Sequential Quadratic Programming (SQP). To reduce computational cost, an ensemble of surrogate models, Kriging, Support Vector Regression (SVR), and Radial Basis Function (RBF), is used to estimate failure probabilities at each step. An active learning approach further improves accuracy by focusing evaluations on critical regions. This GA+SQP scheme enables efficient and robust navigation of complex, highly non-convex design spaces while ensuring target reliability levels. Applied to RC bridge components, the method identifies optimized geometries that minimize material use without compromising serviceability or structural reliability over long-term performance. The proposed approach offers a practical solution for designing durable and cost-effective structures, particularly when accounting for long-term degradation effects and uncertainties in structural behavior.

title: An Embedded Real-Time Localization System for Transient Sounds Based on a MEMS Microphone Array
authors: Jiale Zhu, Xiaoqin Liu, Yashan Li, Xing Wu, Minhao Ma, Jianlong Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: This paper details the design and implementation of an embedded, real-time localization system based on a micro-electro-mechanical systems (MEMS) microphone array to address the demand for real-time detection and localization of transient sound events within complex acoustic environments. A novel transient sound detection algorithm is proposed, integrating a dynamic threshold with a four-state finite state machine (FSM) to enhance detection robustness under conditions of low signal-to-noise ratios and non-stationary noise. This objective is accomplished by dynamically updating the noise baseline with an exponentially weighted moving average model and utilizing the FSM state transition mechanism to characterize the waveform evolution of transient sounds. For sound source localization, the system utilizes the generalized cross-correlation with phase transform algorithm to estimate the time difference of arrival. Through acceleration strategies, including the selection of optimal microphone pairs and the pre-computation of a constant matrix, the computational complexity is significantly diminished while maintaining localization accuracy. The system is architected around an STM32H743 microcontroller, which integrates an 8-channel MEMS microphone array for synchronous data acquisition, and enables wireless communication with a host computer via an ESP8266 module. The experimental results indicate that the proposed transient sound detection algorithm exhibits excellent performance in non-stationary noise environments. The accelerated sound source localization method has been shown to achieve effective localization with an average single-localization time of merely 26 milliseconds, thereby satisfying the real-time processing demands of the embedded system. This research provides a low-cost, high-efficiency technical solution for the monitoring of transient sound events in scenarios such as security surveillance and industrial equipment anomaly detection.

title: Charging-Simultaneity-Coefficient Estimation Considering Electric Vehicles Charging Behaviors
authors: Chongbo Sun, Mengke Du, Yi Song, Yudi Ding, Kai Yuan, Shijie Huang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: The increasing penetration of electric vehicles (EVs) necessitates a corresponding expansion of charging infrastructure. Thus, it is crucial to assess the sufficiency of these charging infrastructures under various charging scenarios to guide future capacity planning and evaluate EV flexibility. Specially, the impact of diverse EV user charging behaviors on aggregated charging curves is investigated under two representative scenarios: fast and slow charging. First, probabilistic model for EVs charging behaviors that reflect actual user patterns is generated through Gaussian Mixed Model (GMM). Next, A Monte Carlo framework is employed to model the stochastic nature of EV arrivals and charging behaviors. Furthermore, the aggregated EV charging curves, derived from an estimation method of charging simultaneity coefficient (CSC), is extended. Several results on actual province are applied to check the validity of the proposed model.

title: Time Delay Analysis and Dynamic Performance Verification of Valve Base Control Unit Simulation Test System for Voltage Source Converter High Voltage Direct Current
authors: Xiaogang Tu, Yantao Lou, Junhui Ren, Zhisun Song
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: Hardware-in-the-loop (HIL) simulation test is a common method to verify the Valve Base Control Unit (VBC) function of Voltage Source Converter High Voltage Direct Current (VSC-HVDC) converter. This paper analyzes the structure of VBC HIL simulation tests, compares the chain delays of different test systems, and demonstrates that the full-chain test system could meet the requirements of VBC test. First, the system architecture of the HIL simulation test is analyzed. Next, the delays of the actual converter valve are compared with those of different simulation test loops, leading to the proposal of an optimized solution for the simulation test loop. Finally, a dynamic performance test is conducted using a full-chain test system set up in the laboratory, and the results are compared with actual project data. The comparison shows that the full-chain solution meets the requirements of VBC test.

title: Energy Storage Configuration Optimization Strategy for Industrial Users Considering Demand Charge Savings
authors: Yiming Cai, Xiangle Zeng, Bin Liu, Zhijian Liang, Zhonghai Wang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: Against the backdrop of the current two-part electricity tariff system, this paper develops a model for optimal energy storage configuration strategy. The model aims to maximize the economic benefits over the entire lifecycle of the energy storage system through demand management and peak-valley arbitrage, thereby reducing industrial production costs. This paper considers the maximum demand charge pricing rules and analyzes the potential of energy storage deployment in reducing peak load and minimizing demand charges. An optimal energy storage configuration strategy is proposed based on a two-layer decision-making model, where the upper-layer model optimizes capacity and power ratings to maximize lifecycle benefits, and the lower-layer model determines daily charging/discharging strategies based on upper-layer results to achieve short-term profit maximization. Using typical load data from a factory in Guangxi region, this study validated the effectiveness of the proposed model. The results demonstrate that energy storage systems can significantly reduce demand charges and optimize load profiles. This provides quantitative guidance for large industrial users on energy storage configuration and holds significant practical application value.

title: Data-driven decoupling and dimensionality reduction technology for distribution network aggregations
authors: Chunsheng Zhou, Jing Peng, Fujun Qi, Yuxiang Liao, Jinqi Zhang, Wen Wang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: In response to the increased randomness and volatility in power grid operation caused by the rising penetration rate of new energy under the "dual carbon" goals, a data-driven decoupling and dimensionality reduction technology for distribution network aggregators is proposed. Firstly, the limitations of traditional power grid dispatching models in terms of new energy and DC transmission are pointed out, highlighting the risk of insufficient regulation resources and "hollowing out" in the receiving end power grid, and emphasizing the urgency of integrating distributed resources into the dispatching system. Then, flexibility resources are efficiently managed in the form of clusters based on the power supply range of substations, and the flexibility of clusters is quantitatively evaluated to ensure the coordinated utilization and optimized operation of resources. To address the computational efficiency bottleneck caused by time-coupled constraints in power system optimal dispatching, a data-driven decoupling and dimensionality reduction method is innovatively proposed. This method learns the dimensionality reduction constraints from historical or simulated optimal operation strategy data through reverse optimization, effectively reducing the constraint dimension while maintaining the integrity of the original constraints. Finally, the significant effect of the proposed method in reducing the constraint dimension and its good approximation of the original constraints are verified through case studies, providing an efficient and feasible solution for power system optimal dispatching.

title: Traversability Analysis for Vehicle in Unstructured Road Based on Semantic Segmentation and Environment Geometry
authors: Haoyuan Zhang, Liyong Wang, Zhongqiu Lu, Qinghua Su, Yue Song, Ximing Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: In unstructured road, the unmanned vehicles should accurately perceive and comprehensively analyze the surrounding terrain and ground attributes for guarantee the safety. Currently, common traversability analysis methods generally rely on single sensor data, which cannot fully integrate the ground attributes and geometric features of the terrain in off-road environments. This limitation results in weak anti-interference ability and poor robustness in environment perception, thereby affecting the traversability analysis performance. Hence, this paper proposes an innovative approach for solving above challenges. Firstly, it improves the robustness of the environment sensing process by fusing data from multiple LiDAR sensors. Then, it achieves sensing of the road-ahead ground attributes via road-surface semantic segmentation. Finally, it constructs a localized, dense traversability map to visually analyze the road-ahead. The experimental results show that the elevation maps and traversable layers generated by the proposed method are improved in terms of detail and accuracy. This helps unmanned vehicles achieve more effective and stable perception ability and navigation basis in off-road or complex environments. This method demonstrates outstanding traversability analysis performance and can accurately analyze the road status.

title: Research on False Data Injection Attack Detection Methods for Intelligent Distribution Networks
authors: Rao Fu, Da Li, Xin Xiong, Jiannan Wang, Hang Jin, Shuwen Cui
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: To address the challenges of low detection rate and high false detection rate faced by current detection methods for false data injection attacks in intelligent distribution networks (IDNs), this paper innovatively proposes a detection method based on dynamic/static state estimation bias. Firstly, the principle of false data injection attacks (FDIAs) in IDNs and their impact on the system were analyzed in depth. Then, dynamic state estimation (DSE) models and static state estimation (SSE) models were constructed separately, and a FDIAs detection model was established based on the deviation between the two. At the same time, a complete detection process was designed. Finally, through simulation analysis, starting from multiple key indicators such as detection rate and false detection rate, the method proposed in this paper was comprehensively and meticulously compared and verified with existing typical detection methods. The results strongly demonstrate that the method proposed in this paper can significantly improve detection accuracy while significantly reducing false detection rates, providing strong guarantees for the safe and stable operation of IDNs.

title: Research on the Construction Technology of Real-Time Simulation System for Variable Speed Pumped Storage
authors: Xiaojian Yao, Dingcai Pan, Zhijiang Liu, Shuyong Li, Zhiwu Xiong, Qiqi Qian, Bo He, Xuehua Lin
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: To address the stability challenges of power grids with high penetration of renewable energy, this paper investigates key technologies in constructing a real-time simulation system for variable-speed pumped storage. By integrating the RTDS real-time digital simulation system with the GTFPGA hardware architecture, a multi-time-scale collaborative modeling method is proposed, enabling high-precision simulation of the full dynamic process from microsecond-level electromagnetic transients to hundred-millisecond-level hydraulic effects. An innovative approach utilizing digital I/O devices and standardized communication protocols (IEC 61850, GOOSE) is adopted to optimize hardware-in-the-loop interface design, effectively overcoming the complexity of traditional simulation system circuit boards and high data interaction latency. The constructed real-time simulation platform for variable-speed pumped storage units integrates multiple devices, including a monitoring system, AC excitation control, and protection devices. Its reliability is validated through steady-state and dynamic performance tests. Research findings indicate that this system provides effective technical support for optimizing control strategies of variable-speed units and evaluating their grid integration performance, thereby facilitating the efficient utilization of renewable energy and the low-carbon transition of power systems.

title: Nonlinearities Modeling of Different Shunt Measurement Techniques in PMSM Drives
authors: Omar Tarek Elkawokgy, Abdelmomen Mahgoub
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Power Electronics and Renewable Energy (CPERE)
abstract: Nonlinearities affect motor operation, particularly at sensitive working points and low speeds. Although various compensation techniques have been proposed to address these effects, it is commonly assumed that the impact of shunt-based current measurement is negligible. This paper investigates the role of shunt measurement in introducing distortions during low-speed PMSM operation, analyzing single-shunt and dual-shunt configurations. Switched-model simulations reveal that inverter switching non-idealities dominate at low loads, but at rated loads, shunt resistance becomes a critical factor, significantly influencing harmonic distortion and system stability. In dual-shunt setups, a DC offset of approximately $0.85 \%$ and a dominant second harmonic at $1.5 \%$ of the fundamental were observed, indicating phase imbalance. Moreover, a suitable selection of shunt resistance values is shown to mitigate these effects and reduce the reliance on complex software-based compensation methods such as wide-bandwidth current controllers. For single-shunt configurations, the analysis reveals a distinct increase in torque ripple, reaching approximately 120 mNm, in addition to the appearance of strong even-order harmonics dominating the harmonic spectrum. These results emphasize the importance of considering the measurement architecture when designing PMSM systems for low-speed applications to achieve improved stability, reduced torque ripple, and enhanced overall performance.

title: Freezing Desalination : A Bibliometric Study of Trends in Emerging technologies
authors: Oumaima Rhandari, Soukaina Bakkass, Driss Khomsi, Naoual Semlali Aouragh Hassani
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: "Desalinating seawater is crucial for satisfying the rising demand for drinking water. This study conducts a bibliometric analysis of recent scientific publications to identify the emerging trends in desalination processes. Bibliometrix R package tool was used to analyze research trends using the Web of Science database. The results show the significant increase in number of publications on Freezing desalination in recent years. Researchers from various countries have investigated the application of freezing technologies in desalination.These findings indicate freezing desalination is an active innovative area of research and this study sheds light on how scientific priorities have changed over time and provides new insights for the optimization of desalination technology.

title: Chemistry-Aware State Estimation for Distributed Battery Energy-Storage Systems
authors: Yu Zhang, Chen Fang, Haojing Wang, Feng Wang, Xiaodong Tang, Shanshan Shi
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: This paper develops a chemistry-aware state-space library and an Interacting Multiple-Model Adaptive Extended Kalman Filter (IMM-AEKF) for real-time state estimation in distributed lithium-ion energy-storage fleets. Two equivalent-circuit models Lithium Iron Phosphate (LFP) and Nickel Cobalt Manganese 811 (NCM811)—are each subdivided into charge, discharge, standby and thermal-conditioning modes; a block-diagonal Markov chain governs mode transitions. The IMM-AEKF executes a six-stage recursion: mode-probability prediction, state/covariance mixing, parallel Extended Kalman propagation, innovation-driven covariance inflation, mode update and global fusion. Multi-rate voltage, current and surface-temperature data sampled every 5 s are fused with online parameter adaptation via recursive least squares. Simulation on NASA PCoE LFP and Oxford Set 1 NCM datasets yields root-mean-square SOC errors of 0.63 % and 0.69 %, and SOH errors below 2 %, surpassing single-model EKF and Unscented KF baselines by more than 35 %. End-to-end latency on an ARM Cortex-A76 processor is 0.18 s, satisfying embedded deployment constraints. The proposed framework offers an accurate, robust and scalable foundation for cloud-coordinated optimisation and will be extended to degradation-aware charge scheduling in future work

title: A Multi-View SAR Images Fusion Positioning Method Based on Error Propagation Model
authors: Huatao Yu, Anxi Yu, Ao Luo, Wenhao Tong, Zhen Dong
publish: 2024 5th China International SAR Symposium (CISS)
abstract: Under the influence of multiple non-ideal factors of the SAR system, the system-level geometric correction SAR images usually have large geometric positioning errors, and the system positioning errors of multiple SAR images with different viewpoints usually have strong consistency in the two-dimensional space of range-azimuth, while also presenting a certain degree of variation. This paper proposes a multi-view SAR images high-precision fusion positioning method based on the error propagation model. Firstly, the two-dimensional systematic positioning error between two different viewpoint images is estimated based on the equivalent equation of the real geographic location of the homonymous point. Then, different viewpoint SAR images positioning error propagation model is established, and multiple estimates are fused with weights to derive an accurate estimation of the positioning error across multi-view SAR images. Finally, by compensating the two-dimensional system positioning errors in each view angle SAR image, a precise correspondence between pixel coordinates and geographic coordinates can be established to realize high-precision positioning of SAR images. Validation experiments are carried out using multi-view airborne SAR images, and the results show that the method can realize high-precision positioning of multi-view SAR images without ground control points(GCPs).

title: Flammable Gas Leakage Boundary Recognition System in Mountain Environment Based on Raspberry Pi
authors: Haibo Wu, Xiaolong Chen, Shaodong Zhu, Fubin Jiang, Xingmeng En
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: The geomorphological characteristics of our country are diverse and complex. The combustible gas is mainly transported by pipeline in the transportation process, and gas leakage is inevitable. When leakage occurs in complex mountainous environment, it will not only lead to poisoning degree, environmental pollution and other problems, but also the concentration distribution of leakage gas and the difficulty of identifying the gas leakage boundary. For this reason, a combustible gas leakage boundary recognition system in mountainous environment is designed. The system takes Raspberry Pi as the main control unit, uses MQ5 liquefied gas sensor, GPS Beidou dual-mode positioning ATK1218-BD module and other hardware, based on Gaussian plume model, combined with Gaussian plume model. Radial Basis Function (RBF) interpolation method improves the calculation accuracy of leakage gas concentration distribution in complex mountain scenes, and realizes the visualization of leakage gas boundary through Matplotlib.

title: Moroccan Outward FDI in the CFA Zone: Currency and Exchange Rate Risk in the Banking Sector
authors: Layla Jabri, Abdelghani Rahmouni, Kaoutar Benslama, Ghizlane Saad, Malainine Cheklekbire
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: This paper investigates the growth of Moroccan outward foreign direct investment (FDI) from 2014 to 2024, with a specific focus on the investments channeled into the West and Central African CFA franc zone, particularly in the banking sector. The study finds that nearly 66 percent of the general moroccan FDI is directed toward the CFA region, highlighting its strategic importance. Despite the CFA franc’s peg to the euro, the research uncovers that persistent exchange rate volatility, coupled with regulatory divergences and macroeconomic uncertainties, poses significant financial risks for cross border investments. In the banking sector, these challenges manifest in eroded profit margins due to heightened currency risks, increased compliance costs, and intensified market competition. The analysis employs rigorous econometric models to quantify the actual impact of currency fluctuations on profitability, revealing that even marginal increases in volatility can substantially diminish profit margins. The findings underscore the need for proactive risk management strategies, such as effective hedging and coordinated policy measures, to mitigate these risks and sustain the momentum of Morocco’s international expansion.

title: SGMSNet: Spatial-Gated Memory Network for Chest X-ray Image Segmentation
authors: Zhongming Li u, Xin Huang, Xiao Li, Xiang Zou
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Complex Medical Engineering (CME)
abstract: Complex anatomical structures, blurred boundaries, and significant scale variations make automatic segmentation of chest X-ray images a highly challenging task. This paper proposes a novel segmentation network, SGMSNet, to improve segmentation accuracy and robustness. SGMSNet incorporates a Memory Module in the high-level encoder layers to enhance the modeling of global context and long-range dependencies, enabling dynamic integration of semantic information. The decoder adopts a multi-stage upsampling structure and introduces a Gated Attention mechanism at skip connections to adaptively suppress redundant feature information. In addition, a Spatial Attention Module is employed to further strengthen the model’s focus on critical anatomical regions. Experimental results on publicly available chest X-ray segmentation datasets demonstrate that SGMSNet consistently outperforms several state-of-the-art methods in terms of both segmentation accuracy and robustness, validating the effectiveness and superiority of the proposed approach.

title: YOLOv10-CBAM: Lightweight Metal Surface Defect Detection Based on YOLOv10
authors: Yan Song, Danpei Li, Pinglai He, Jiayi Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: To address the challenges of deploying metal surface defect detection algorithms on edge devices, insufficient feature representation, and class imbalance in samples, this study proposes a lightweight defect detection algorithm named YOLOv10-CBAM (You Only Look Once version 10 with Convolutional Block Attention Module). First, the original backbone network of YOLOv10 is replaced with a more lightweight backbone, MobileNetV3, which significantly reduces the model size while maintaining accuracy. Second, the CBAM (Convolutional Block Attention Module) attention mechanism is integrated into the C2f module of the YOLOv10 neck network to capture both spatial and channel information, thereby enhancing the model’s representational capacity. Finally, the Focal-EIOU (Focal and Efficient Intersection over Union) loss function is introduced to replace the original CIOU (Complete Intersection over Union) loss, improving the model’s convergence speed and regression accuracy. Experimental results on the GC10-DET dataset show that the proposed model achieves a Precision (P) of 90.4%, Recall (R) of 81.2%, and an inference speed of 263 frames per second (FPS), which are improvements of 2.9%, 3.6%, and 18.6%, respectively, compared to the original model. These results demonstrate the great potential of the proposed YOLOv10-CBAM model for deployment on industrial edge devices.

title: Study on Power-Frequency Distributed Residual Current Protection Based on Time-Varying Closed Surfaces
authors: Xiangbo Liu, Fang Gao, Sen Wang, Wenxuan Zhang, Yuning Zhang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: To address the issue of difficulty in activating main and branch protection in low-voltage distribution networks due to inherent residual currents and repeated neutral grounding, this paper proposes a distributed residual current protection method based on closed-surface power frequency measurements, leveraging the full-domain monitoring capability of the power IoT. By defining a protection closed surface and calculating the phasor sum of currents at its external connection points as the residual current, the method significantly reduces residual current during normal operation and enhances protection sensitivity.

title: Multi-UAV Cooperative Target Consensus Detection and Trajectory Optimization in Urban Environments
authors: Kunzhong Miao, Chang Wang, Yifeng Niu, Huangzhi Yu, Tianqing Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: As the demand for autonomous reconnaissance in urban environments grows, target loss occurs when multiple unmanned aerial vehicles (multi-UAVs) encounter regions that are difficult to access since obstacles. To address this challenge, this paper proposes a multi-UAV cooperative target consensus detection strategy. A model related to the UAV's visual region and sensor coverage area is established, considering the line-of-sight (LoS) obstruction caused by obstacles in urban environments. Bayesian theory is applied to update the global probability map, by employing dynamic occupancy grids to represent the probability of target presence and integrating sensor data from UAVs. To enhance detection speed, a consensus-based information fusion algorithm with state predictor is incorporated. Furthermore, an objective function for trajectory optimization is constructed by integrating cumulative probability and detection cost. Different typical target scenarios are designed, and UAV positions are dynamically adjusted using an improved sparrow search algorithm (ISSA) within a model predictive control framework. Then, an obstacle configuration mechanism is proposed: when at least one UAV avoids obstacles, a strict constraint mechanism is applied; otherwise, a fuzzy constraint mechanism is utilized. Finally, simulation results validate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm.

title: Simulating Extinct Species
authors: Sandrine Ceurstemont
publish: Communications of the ACM
abstract: Determining how long-gone animals moved, using the only existing evidence and the latest scientific techniques.

title: PowerCause: Leveraging Causality for Self-Recovery in Unbalanced Distribution Networks
authors: Yihong Li, Yicheng Pan, Meng Ma, Ping Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Reliability
abstract: This article proposes PowerCause, a method for phase unbalance positioning and active regulation in smart distribution networks. PowerCause can automatically detect anomaly intervals, locate the source of phase unbalance using Granger causality test, back-search, and generate a list of potential root cause buses. It takes regulation measures for specific buses to alleviate the impact of the unbalance. This implements a closed-loop solution that handles the entire process from the occurrence of phase unbalance to its positioning, and finally, to active regulation. This study builds a closed-loop simulation environment based on the open distribution system simulator (OpenDSS) to enable autonomous and controllable unbalance injection, collect multidimensional bus metrics, including voltage and phase angle. The environment also includes causal analysis and active regulation modules for method verification. The proposed method demonstrates high accuracy in root cause location, efficient performance, and robustness against environmental influences such as measurement noise and data loss errors.

title: Unveiling the Visual Rhetoric of Persuasive Cartography: a Case Study of the Design of Octopus Maps
authors: Daocheng Lin, Yifan Wang, Yutong Yang, Xingyu Lan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: When designed deliberately, data visualizations can become powerful persuasive tools, influencing viewers' opinions, values, and actions. While researchers have begun studying this issue (e.g., to evaluate the effects of persuasive visualization), we argue that a fundamental mechanism of persuasion resides in rhetorical construction, a perspective inadequately addressed in current visualization research. To fill this gap, we present a focused analysis of octopus maps, a visual genre that has maintained persuasive power across centuries and achieved significant social impact. Employing rhetorical schema theory, we collected and analyzed 90 octopus maps spanning from the 19th century to contemporary times. We closely examined how octopus maps implement their persuasive intents and constructed a design space that reveals how visual metaphors are strategically constructed and what common rhetorical strategies are applied to components such as maps, octopus imagery, and text. Through the above analysis, we also uncover a set of interesting findings. For instance, contrary to the common perception that octopus maps are primarily a historical phenomenon, our research shows that they remain a lively design convention in today's digital age. Additionally, while most octopus maps stem from Western discourse that views the octopus as an evil symbol, some designs offer alternative interpretations, highlighting the dynamic nature of rhetoric across different sociocultural settings. Lastly, drawing from the lessons provided by octopus maps, we discuss the associated ethical concerns of persuasive visualization.

title: Reliability-Aware Placement of Virtual Network Functions via Multi-Agent Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: Haojun Huang, Jialin Tian, Hao Yin, Bo Li, Geyong Min, Haozhe Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Networking
abstract: Network Function Virtualization (NFV) often suffers from unexpected failures in some mission-critical applications due to the reliability-agnostic deployment of Virtual Network Functions (VNFs), thus achieving suboptimal service performance. To cope with this issue, we propose a Reliability-aware VNF service Provisioning (RVFP) approach for NFV-based networks via Multi-Agent Deep Reinforcement Learning (MADRL), where each VNF is hosted and backed up in appropriate hardware with reliability guarantees. Specifically, a novel MADRL-based framework for VNF placement is designed with two alternating optimization objectives, namely maximizing reliability and minimizing VNF instance failure probability, to incorporate diverse objective landscapes and encourage broader exploration within the solution space. Furthermore, two agent allocation strategies are developed to alternately arrange the tasks of collaborative agents for reliability-aware placement of VNFs in a parallel and cooperative manner. Besides, the newly-designed prioritized experience sampling, built on reward and sampling frequency, is used to better exploit valuable experiences for faster model training. Extensive simulation results obtained from various scenarios show that RVFP can significantly improve placement reliability and service acceptance ratios for VNF deployment compared with the state-of-the-art approaches.

title: Fuzzy Logic-Enhanced Neuroadaptive Fault-Tolerant Control for Vehicular Platoons With Stochastic Disturbances and Asymmetric Spacing Constraints
authors: Yao Wen, Xiaohong Chen, Xuesong Xu, Anguo Zhang, Yongfu Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Neural Networks and Learning Systems
abstract: This article introduces a novel fuzzy logic-enhanced neuroadaptive sliding mode control (FLENNSMC) framework, developed for vehicular platoon systems subject to a confluence of challenges. Leveraging the synergistic integration of fuzzy logic’s interpretive strengths and neural networks’ adaptive learning capabilities, FLENNSMC effectively addresses nonlinear dynamics, stochastic disturbances, actuator faults, and stringent asymmetric spacing constraints. We propose a Takagi–Sugeno (T-S) fuzzy model to structure the learning process and a fuzzy logic-enhanced RBFNN (FLERBFNN) for robust approximation of unknown functions, including unmodeled dynamics and fault signals. The controller design incorporates a fault-tolerant control mechanism for enhanced robustness, an asymmetric barrier Lyapunov function (BLF) to strictly enforce spacing constraints, and a Nussbaum function to compensate for actuator faults with unknown directions. The fuzzy logic-enhanced structure allows for localized and efficient learning, which reduces computational burden and improves adaptation speed. Through a rigorous stochastic Lyapunov–Krasovskii stability analysis, we derive sufficient LMI-based conditions for the uniform ultimate boundedness (UUB) of tracking errors in the mean square sense and guarantee a mixed H-infinity/passivity performance. Extensive simulations on a 2-D multilane vehicular platoon demonstrate the superior performance of the proposed FLENNSFC compared to conventional neuroadaptive control approaches, particularly highlighting the benefits of fuzzy logic in structuring the learning process and handling complex uncertainties. Simulation code is available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/zhanganguo/FLENNSMC-Platoon-Control-Simulation</uri>

title: A Dynamically Weighted ADMM Framework for Byzantine Resilience
authors: Vishnu Vijay, Kartik A. Pant, Minhyun Cho, Inseok Hwang
publish: IEEE Control Systems Letters
abstract: The alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM) is a popular method to solve distributed consensus optimization utilizing efficient communication among various nodes in the network. However, in the presence of faulty or attacked nodes, even a small perturbation (or sharing false data) during the communication can lead to divergence of the solution. To address this issue, in this work we consider ADMM under the effect of Byzantine threat, where an unknown subset of nodes is subject to Byzantine attacks or faults. We propose Dynamically Weighted ADMM (DW-ADMM), a novel variant of ADMM that uses dynamic weights on the edges of the network, thus promoting resilient distributed optimization in settings without central coordination. We establish that the proposed method (i) produces a nearly identical solution to conventional ADMM in the error-free case, and (ii) guarantees a bounded solution with respect to the global minimizer, even under Byzantine threat. Finally, we demonstrate the effectiveness of our proposed algorithm using illustrative numerical simulations.

title: The Gradual Interval Mapping Method Integration Framework for Multiple Metasurfaces Fast Design
authors: Peng Wang, Chao Luo, Zhenning Li, Wen Jiang, Tao Hong, Gert Frølund Pedersen, Ming Shen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: This work presents a gradual interval mapping method (IMM) integration framework for the rapid design of multiple metasurfaces. By leveraging the deep neural networks, the gradual design framework efficiently predicts both S-parameters and geometric structures using interval folding lines as input. Unlike traditional and current approaches, the proposed method integrates IMM with a filling strategy, simplifying data processing and enhancing prediction accuracy. To validate its effectiveness, three types of frequency selective surface (FSS) are designed, one of which is fabricated and experimentally measured in a microwave chamber. Simulation and measurement results confirm the superior performance of the framework, highlighting its potential for intelligent electromagnetic device design. Finally, we conclude with a short discussion of the work, including its limitations and developability.

title: Reconfigurable Scattering Cross Section Control for Aircraft-Like Objects at Meter-Wave Bands Based on Characteristic Mode Cancellation
authors: Di Zhang, Haotian Li, Yikai Chen, Shiwen Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: Aircraft-like objects exhibit significant electromagnetic scattering in the meter-wave frequency range due to their inherent resonance effects. Traditional scattering cross-section (SCS) reduction techniques, such as shape optimization and radar-absorbing materials, often require large structural modifications to control meter-wave scattering, which inevitably affect the aerodynamic performance. This article proposes a novel reconfigurable capacitive loading technique based on characteristic mode cancellation. By strategically placing a small number of capacitive loadings on the surface of aircraft-like objects, dominant scattering modes are induced to cancel each other. The alternating direction method of multipliers is introduced to transform the non-convex scattering optimization problem into a two-step iterative process, which is incorporated with the characteristic mode analysis to efficiently determine the near-optimal capacitive loadings. An electronically reconfigurable loading network is then implemented to dynamically control the states of the capacitive loadings for wideband SCS reduction. Numerical results for a simplified aircraft-like object show a maximum monostatic SCS reduction of 44.0 dB and a maximum 10-dB SCS reduction fractional bandwidth of 9.5% over 84.0–120.0 MHz. A scaled prototype is designed, fabricated, and measured, which demonstrates the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

title: Enhancing Position Estimation Accuracy in IPMSMs Sensorless Control via Virtual Shaft Amplitude Demodulation
authors: Haoyuan Li, Guanjun Li, Shaojie Zhu, Lingfeng Wei, Guowei Chen
publish: IEEE Journal of Emerging and Selected Topics in Power Electronics
abstract: Conventional high-frequency (HF) rotating injection for IPMSM sensorless control suffers from degraded position estimation accuracy due to stator resistance variations, fundamental interference, digital delays, and filter phase shifts. This paper proposes an enhanced method via virtual shaft amplitude demodulation. This method transforms HF currents into a virtual shaft frame defined as the estimated magnetic pole position angle plus π/4, inherently eliminating delay/filter-induced phase compensation needs. This configuration inherently eliminates the need for phase deviation compensation caused by digital system and filter delays. Experimental validation is conducted on a 20 kW IPMSM test platform under representative operating conditions. Results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves better position estimation accuracy and dynamic response than conventional HF injection method. Additionally, detailed design guidelines for phase-locked loop (PLL) parameters and magnetic polarity detection algorithms are provided to ensure system robustness.

title: Muscle Fatigue-Aware Controller for a Semi-Rigid Knee Exoskeleton
authors: Yifang Zhang, Jingcheng Jiang, Arash Ajoudani, Nikos G. Tsagarakis
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: Wearable assistive devices that monitor muscle fatigue reduce the risk of work-related musculoskeletal disorders, enhance rehabilitation outcomes, and extend operational time by optimizing the power consumption of the device. This work proposes a muscle fatigue-aware controller (MFAC) for a semi-rigid knee exoskeleton. During an offline calibration phase, we use Gaussian Process Regression (GPR) to model the relationship between muscle activation (measured via EMG) and the corresponding joint moment and angle, enabling fatigue state estimation for the controller. The trained model then approximates muscle activation online using only joint states and moment derived from user’s kinematic data and ground reaction forces provided by the wearable device. The estimated muscle activation is used to assess the muscle fatigue state through a model-based fatigue evaluation module. Notably, EMG measurement is only required during the offline training in our approach, enabling EMG-free online estimation, which significantly enhances the feasibility for long-term mobile applications. Building on muscle fatigue and human-exoskeleton interaction models, we then developed an adaptive controller within a predictive control framework. The resulting optimization problem generates control signals that adjust assistance to reduce the fatigue progression. Two experiments validate the EMG-free fatigue estimation method and the integrated MFAC, demonstrating accurate muscle activation estimation and effective adaptive assistance based on the estimated fatigue state. Analysis of actuator power output reveals adaptivity in which the controller conserves energy during low muscle fatigue and progressively improves power output with increasing fatigue, suggesting a longer duration of the device with a fixed battery capacity.

title: Two-Stage Semi-Supervised Co-Training for Enhanced Multi-Class Intrusion Detection
authors: Reynaldi Ichsanul Selamat Sembiring, Favian Dewanta, Danu Dwi Sanjoyo
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Information Technology, Computer, and Electrical Engineering (ICITACEE)
abstract: Due to the growing amount and variety of network traffic, traditional intrusion detection systems (IDS) have become insufficient due to inadequate labeled data, severe class imbalances, and the rigidity of confidence thresholds in semi-supervised learning. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a two-stage, cascaded co-training framework that utilizes Naive Bayes and Random Forest algorithms with graph-based label propagation. In recognition of the fact that static confidence cutoffs either introduce noisy labels or restrict learning excessively, adaptive thresholds derived from Flexible Confidence (FlexCon) variants are applied to govern pseudo-label inclusion. Additionally, three feature representations-original, IPCA, and random projection-are compared to ensure equal trade-offs between detection accuracy and computational overhead. By utilizing both labeled and unlabeled data, this design balances class imbalance while dynamically adjusting labeling criteria to enhance the performance of multi-class anomaly detection in large-scale IDS.

title: Tri-perspective Multi-view Classification
authors: Xiaojian Ding, Xiaoying Zhu, Fumin Ma
publish: ACM Transactions on Knowledge Discovery from Data
abstract: Multi-view classification aims to improve prediction performance by integrating heterogeneous data sources, leveraging the complementary and consistent information across different views. However, existing approaches predominantly focus on consistency and complementarity, often overlooking the role of diversity, which is crucial for enhancing generalization and mitigating redundancy. To address these issues, we propose a Tri-perspective Multi-view Fusion and Classification (TMFC) framework that systematically unifies consistency, complementarity, and diversity principles. TMFC consolidates multi-view data into a meta-view through feature concatenation and generates diverse latent views via random mapping, preserving structural information while reducing redundancy. These latent views are optimized through a unified formulation that balances alignment, information enrichment, and feature distinctiveness, reformulated as a semi-definite programming problem and efficiently solved using the reformulation-linearization technique with a cutting plane algorithm. Extensive experiments on real-world datasets demonstrate TMFC’s superiority over state-of-the-art methods, achieving significant improvements in accuracy, normalized mutual information, and adjusted rand index.

title: Transitional Patterns for Tick-Shape Backbones
authors: Chi-Hieu Le, Thanh Tuan Nguyen, Hoang Anh Pham, Hoai Nam Vu, Thi-Minh-Chau Le, Thanh Phuong Nguyen
publish: 2025 24th International Symposium on Communications and Information Technologies (ISCIT)
abstract: A lightweight Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) is one of the potential solutions for real applications on edge devices. Recently, TickNets have been formed by allocating FullResidual Point-Depth-Point (FR-PDP) blocks in a multiple of tick-shape backbones. However, there can be a lack of diverse information since only the FR-PDP-based features have been exploited in those backbones. This shortcoming can be the cause of their modest performance in several circumstances, while still taking a high computational cost. To mitigate this issue, a transition layer is proposed to exploit the transitional patterns for learning diverse information in TickNets. Simply, a pointwise convolution is embedded as a hooking connection for pointwise-based features instead of the FR-PDP-based features that have been transferred between two basic tick-shape backbones. It can be seen that addressing such a transition layer would lead to two practical benefits: i) extracting diverse patterns for the learning process; and ii) a significant reduction of model complexity thanks to the lightweight pointwise operation. Experiments for image classification on benchmark datasets have validated the efficiency of our proposal. Particularly, with less computational complexity, the proposed transitional patterns have boosted about 1.2% rate on Stanford Dogs versus the original TickNets, while it is the same on CIFAR-10/100. It could be an alternative solution for TickNets in real applications. The implementation code is available at https://github.com/DevHieuLC/TickNetSLM.

title: Adaptive Decomposition Level Determination Method for Fractional High-Density Discrete Wavelet Based on Multi-Scale Symbolic Dynamic Entropy
authors: Zhinong Li, Susu Zheng, Shanshan Huang, Xin Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: Local characteristics at any time and frequency are expected to be manifested well done when the non-stationary signal is analyzed. Therefore, based on high-density discrete wavelet transform (HD-DWT) and fractional time-frequency analysis, the fractional high-density discrete wavelet transform (FH-DWT) is constructed in this paper. However, when using the FH-DWT for fault diagnosis, the diagnosis effectiveness is greatly influenced by the decomposition level. Therefore, how to adaptively determine the decomposition levels in FH-DWT has become an urgent problem. Based on the principle that multi-scale symbolic dynamic entropy (MSDE) can measure the similarity between components at different scales, a method for adaptively determining the optimal decomposition level is proposed in this paper. In the proposed method, the MSDE value in each layer can be used to measure the similarity between low-frequency and mid-frequency components, and the decomposition level can be adaptively determined. The results of simulation show that the FH-DWT based on MSDE is superior to traditional HD-DWT, and can adaptively determine the optimal decomposition level in FH-DWT. Finally, the effectiveness of proposed method is verified by two experimental cases further.

title: Antenna-Independent Deep Learning for Self-Interference Cancellation in In-Band Full-Duplex MIMO Systems
authors: Anh Tuyen Le, Xiaojing Huang, Le Chung Tran, J. Andrew Zhang, Peiyuan Qin, Y. Jay Guo
publish: 2025 24th International Symposium on Communications and Information Technologies (ISCIT)
