abstract: In-band full-duplex (IBFD) operation in multipleinput multiple-output (MIMO) systems faces significant challenges due to self-interference (SI). The cancellation complexity of SI grows quadratically with the number of antennas, posing a critical scalability challenge for 6 G and integrated sensing and communications (ISAC) applications. Existing self-interference cancellation (SIC) techniques, including both model-based and recent deep learning approaches, typically operate on a perantenna basis and thus inherit this prohibitive complexity growth. This paper proposes a novel beam-based deep learning framework that fundamentally overcomes this limitation. By operating in the beam domain, our method models the interference at each receiver as a linear combination of the transmit beam signals, allowing the neural network to learn the end-to-end system effects without explicit channel estimation. The key advantage of this approach is that the network's complexity only scales with the number of beams, making it independent of the number of transmit antennas and highly suitable for massive MIMO systems. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed framework achieves over 33 dB of SIC, with performance robust to increasing number of transmit antennas. This beam-domain approach offers a scalable and effective solution for practical IBFD implementation in future wireless networks.

title: A Tool Wear Condition Recognition Model Based on GBDT-BiGRU
authors: Long Xie, Hongjun Wang, Henglin Ge
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: Tool wear condition monitoring is essential for enhancing machining efficiency and ensuring product quality. Conventional approaches are limited in predictive accuracy and generalization when coping with complex nonlinearities and temporal dependencies. To address these deficiencies, a novel monitoring model that integrates Gradient Boosting Decision Tree (GBDT) with Bidirectional Gated Recurrent Unit (BiGRU) is proposed. The architecture encompasses three sequential modules: data preprocessing, GBDT-based feature selection, and BiGRU-based training. After signal acquisition and preprocessing, GBDT is employed to quantify feature importance, through which key wear-relevant features are retained and dimensionality is reduced, thereby improving computational efficiency. Subsequently, the BiGRU network is utilized to capture temporal evolutions of the selected features and to classify wear states accurately, leading to markedly improved monitoring precision and generalization capability. Validation on both the public PHM 2010 dataset and the in-house EX dataset demonstrates training accuracies of 98.9 % and 97.8 %, respectively, confirming the validity and robustness of the proposed framework.

title: Application of Large Language Models in Software Development: Review of the Current State and Development Perspectives
authors: Bozidar Radenkovic, Sergei Prokhorov, Milos Radenkovic, Aleksandra Labus
publish: 2025 6th International Workshop on Engineering Technologies and Computer Science (EnT)
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) are rapidly transforming software engineering by automating tasks such as code generation, test creation, debugging, and documentation. Their integration across the software development lifecycle, from requirements analysis to deployment, introduces both unprecedented opportunities and serious challenges. This paper offers a comprehensive review of LLM applications in software engineering, contextualized within the frameworks of LLMOps and DevOps. It examines how specialized models and autonomous agents are reshaping workflows and proposes a framework for assessing organizational readiness for LLM adoption. In addition to technical capabilities, we discuss limitations such as hallucinations, context constraints, and the lack of explainability, as well as broader concerns around licensing, security, and developer deskilling. Drawing from recent research and tooling ecosystems, we synthesize the emerging best practices for safely deploying LLMs in production environments. This article aims to equip practitioners and researchers with a structured understanding of the current state and future direction of LLM-assisted software development.

title: Current transformer phase error correction method based on SVM algorithm
authors: Qinglan Ji, Aiming Zhao
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: Electromagnetic current transformers are widely used in current measurement and protection signal transmission in power systems. Their measurement accuracy is related to the normal operation of high and low voltage electrical equipment. However, due to the influence of magnetizing current and nonlinear characteristics of the iron core, current transformers have ratio errors and phase errors in practical applications, resulting in deviations between the measurement results and the true values. Although traditional error compensation methods can effectively reduce errors, they have problems such as high cost, complex system, and high power consumption. To this end, this paper proposes an error correction method based on SVM algorithm to predict and correct the phase error caused by excitation current. In this paper, a large amount of excitation characteristic data are collected through experiments for model training. Experimental results show that the SVM algorithm can effectively predict and correct current phase errors, and has high accuracy and stability.

title: Fault Diagnosis via Deep Transfer Learning with Multi-Scale Feature Extraction and Multi-Layer Domain Adaptation
authors: Jiankang Wang, Yibin Liu, Konghua Yang, Fangchuan Rong, Chunbao Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: Fault diagnosis technology plays a pivotal role in ensuring production safety and enhancing the operational efficiency of industrial equipment. However, traditional fault diagnosis methods often exhibit limited feature extraction capabilities and poor generalization when applied to real-world scenarios characterized by scarce labeled data and complex, variable working conditions. These constraints result in unsatisfactory diagnostic accuracy and reliability. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a deep transfer learning-based fault diagnosis framework that integrates Multi-Scale feature extraction and Multi-Layer domain adaptation (MS-ML). Initially, vibration signals are processed using a Multi-Scale convolutional neural network (MSCNN) to extract hierarchical features that capture both localized details and global patterns across multiple scales. This architecture significantly enhances the model's capacity to identify complex fault signatures. Subsequently, a Multi-Layer domain adaptation strategy is introduced to minimize distribution discrepancies between source and target domain data, thereby improving the model's generalization performance under diverse operating conditions. The proposed method is rigorously validated on two benchmark datasets: the Jiangnan University dataset and the Paderborn University dataset. Comparative experiments with existing approaches demonstrate that the proposed method not only achieves superior diagnostic accuracy but also exhibits strong cross-domain adaptability, maintaining stable performance in transfer scenarios. These findings provide both theoretical support and technical advancement for the development of intelligent diagnostic systems in industrial applications.

title: Psych-R1: A New LLM for Psychiatric Diseases Based on Group Relative Policy Optimization
authors: Zhi Luo, Zhenbo Xu, Qinghong Yang
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Complex Medical Engineering (CME)
abstract: The diagnosis of psychiatric diseases poses a significant challenge for clinicians due to its high complexity, symptom subjectivity, and the prevalence of comorbidities. Although Large Language Models (LLMs) have demonstrated considerable potential in the general medical field, a unified framework specifically for the complex reasoning tasks in psychiatry remains a gap. This paper introduces Psych-R1, an LLM designed to unify psychiatric disease reasoning, motivated by Reinforcement Learning (RL). Psych-R1 employs a pure RL paradigm, combining a rule-based hybrid task reward function with multi-objective reward optimization. This allows Psych-R1 to generate concise and verifiable reasoning chains, effectively handling a variety of psychiatric question-answering (QA) tasks, from multiple-choice questions (MCQ) to complex open-ended text generation. Experimental results show that Psych-R1 significantly outperforms open-source general and medical models of similar scale on several challenging psychiatric benchmarks. Furthermore, Psych-R1 demonstrates strong generalization capabilities on out-of-distribution (OOD) tasks.

title: Construction of Physical Information Guided Bearing Degradation Indicators and Remaining Useful Life Prediction
authors: Yuntian Ta, Jinsong Xie, Tiantian Wang, Siyu Jiang, Zhibin Guo, Ran Bi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: As a critical component of rotating machinery, the degradation indicator (DI) and remaining useful life (RUL) prediction of bearings are crucial for the safe operation of equipment. This paper proposes a physics-informed method for constructing bearing degradation indicators and predicting RUL. By embedding the physical laws governing the bearing's service process, the method enhances the physical interpretability of the degradation indicator and the robustness of the prediction model. In the construction of the degradation indicator, an exponential physical equation describing the evolution of bearing crack length over time is established based on Paris' law. A loss function incorporating physical constraints is designed to compel the deep learning network to extract features that conform to the material damage accumulation law. In the RUL prediction stage, a time-series constraint loss function is introduced to ensure that the prediction results align with the physical law of "remaining life monotonically decreasing with time," mitigating the black-box characteristics of data-driven models. Experiments utilize the PHM2012 dataset, constructing a physics-informed degradation indicator network and a physics-informed remaining useful life prediction network. The results demonstrate that the degradation indicator constructed by the proposed method outperforms traditional statistical features in terms of trend and monotonicity, and the accuracy of the prediction results is significantly improved.

title: Research on Fault Diagnosis Method for Antenna Drive Reducer Bearings Based on SVMD-CNN-LSTM Fusion
authors: Shike Mo, Binbin Xiang, Wei Wang, Xuetong Yang, Longfei Niu, Yuming Fan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: This paper constructs a fault diagnosis model for antenna drive reducer bearings based on the fusion of Successive Variational Mode Decomposition (SVMD) and Convolutional Long Short-Term Memory Neural Network (CNN-LSTM). SVMD is utilized to decompose bearing vibration signals, obtaining multiple Intrinsic Mode Functions (IMFs) which are used to construct the dataset. The CNN extracts local spatial features from the signals, while the LSTM captures temporal characteristics, enabling deep analysis of fault features. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed model achieves a classification accuracy of 97.63%. Compared to CNN, CNN-LSTM, Transformer, and AlexNet models, the classification accuracy is improved by 5.94%, 2.42%, 1.12%, and 2.45%, respectively. This model provides a novel solution approach for fault diagnosis in antenna drive reducer bearings.

title: Double-layer optimal scheduling of industrial parks based on equipment behavior correlation graphs
authors: Weidong Bao, Yang Zhou, Jingbo He, Kaihua Lou, Xiuhua Ding, Ning Bao
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: This paper establishes a two-layer optimization scheduling model for industrial parks based on the equipment behavior correlation graph. The model fully explores the flexible regulation ability of equipment behavior among high energy-consuming loads, acquires the optimal scheduling plan of the park, and realizes the coordinated operation of industrial parks and high energy-consuming enterprises. First of all, the goal of the level regulation plan of the power grid regulation center, as the upper-level manager, is to ensure the safe and stable operation of the system, minimize the operating cost of the system, and maximize the consumption of clean energy power generation. As a lower-level industrial park, the primary purpose of its operation is to achieve sustainable economic development in the park, reduce production costs and improve efficiency. Finally, the feasibility and validity of the model proposed in the paper were verified through numerical examples. The results show that the proposed method reduces the operating cost of the power grid regulation center on the basis of ensuring the safe and reliable operation of the system.

title: Compressive Sensing for Inter-Frame Video Compression Using OMP and TVAL3 Algorithms
authors: Hien Thu Nguyen, An Thanh Nguyen, Hung Duy Nguyen, Quang Duc Pham
publish: 2025 24th International Symposium on Communications and Information Technologies (ISCIT)
abstract: This paper presents a compressive sensing-based inter-frame video compression approach using Orthogonal Matching Pursuit (OMP) and the Total Variation algorithm (TVAL3). The goal is to evaluate their trade-offs in reconstruction quality, processing time, and compression efficiency, with root mean square error (RMSE) as the metric for reconstruction quality. Video frames are divided into smaller segments and selectively reconstructed based on sparsity thresholds. Experimental results on multiple scenarios show that OMP outperforms TVAL3 in terms of faster recovery times, higher compression ratios, and lower reconstruction errors, making it particularly effective for applications such as security cameras and landscape surveillance. These findings provide guidance for selecting appropriate methods for various real-world video compression applications.

title: Voltage Stabilization of Slim DC-Link Systems Using Modulated MPC and Voltage Injection
authors: Mostafa Bedir, Omar Nasser, Mohamed Rabah, Abdelmomen Mahgoub
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Power Electronics and Renewable Energy (CPERE)
abstract: The trend toward minimizing DC-link capacitance in electric drive systems promotes higher reliability and facilitates the adoption of durable film capacitors. Nonetheless, this reduction in capacitance can induce instability, primarily due to the negative incremental impedance effect associated with constant power loads. To address this, a voltage regulation strategy based on Modulated Model Predictive Control (M2PC) and active damping via voltage injection is introduced. The proposed controller predicts future DC-link voltage behavior using a discrete-time model and counteracts deviations by adjusting the applied inverter voltage accordingly. Compared to conventional PI-based voltage injection damping methods, the proposed M2PC-based strategy provides enhanced damping effectiveness, reduced voltage ripple, and lower harmonic content. Simulation results validate the proposed scheme’s ability to enhance both stability and transient response in systems with reduced DC-link capacitance.

title: Simulation Study on Electric Field Distribution of Maintenance Personnel in Live Substation Operations
authors: Hongwu Wang, Rundong Yang, Weiyan Zhao, Ruidong Zheng, Feng Pang, Zhengwen Li, Lichao Jiang, Yang Shen
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: This paper primarily investigates the electric field distribution encountered by maintenance personnel during equipotential operations on conductors in a 500 kV substation. With the rapid development of power systems, the scale and voltage levels of substations have continuously increased, and the safety and efficiency of maintenance operations have become increasingly prominent issues. Given that maintenance personnel working in high-voltage substations are susceptible to strong electric fields, which can cause electric field distortion and safety hazards, this study employs electric field simulation analysis to systematically examine the electric field distribution when maintenance personnel are engaged in equipotential operations. The results indicate that the neck, hands, and feet of the workers are the areas with the most significant electric field distortion, and noticeable distortion also occurs on both sides of the chest. This research provides a solid theoretical basis and practical guidance for optimizing substation maintenance procedures and enhancing the safety of maintenance personnel.

title: A Novel Phase-preserving Motion Compensation Method for Spaceborne Dual-antenna InSAR
authors: Caihua Liu, Taoli Yang
publish: 2024 5th China International SAR Symposium (CISS)
abstract: Spaceborne dual-antenna interferometric synthetic aperture radar (InSAR) systems often experience baseline oscillations during operation, leading to phase errors in SAR imaging and reduce accuracy in interferometric measurements. This paper presents a novel phase-preserving motion compensation method, which derives the actual trajectory of the radar platform using measured baseline oscillation data. Precise compensation is then applied to correct both envelope and phase errors caused by these oscillations by quantifying the slant-range errors between the actual and ideal trajectories. The effectiveness of the proposed method is validated through comparative analysis and simulations. Simulation results demonstrate that the phase deviation of compensated point targets is less than 1° from the absolute phase, indicating that the method effectively mitigates the impact of baseline oscillations.

title: Performance Comparison of YOLOv8 and Detectron2 for Obstacle Inference Tasks in Autonomous Driving Systems
authors: Mardiyono, Afif Ihza Darmawan, Nurul Hasanah, Bambang Wahono, Taufik Ibnu Salim, Suherman, Munawar Agus Riyadi, Yanuandri Putrasari, Prayitno
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Information Technology, Computer, and Electrical Engineering (ICITACEE)
abstract: Obstacle/Object inference tasks in autonomous driving systems are crucial for ensuring vehicle safety and operational efficiency. Traditional object detection models, while effective, often exhibit limitations in handling complex and dynamic driving scenarios, particularly inaccurate obstacle detection and estimating the distance to obstacles to provide timely warnings. To address these challenges, state-of-the-art deep learning frameworks such as YOLOv8 and Detectron2, have shown promising advancements in object detection accuracy and distance estimation. However, the comparative performance of these frameworks in terms of key evaluation metrics such as Precision, Recall, and F1 Score remains underexplored. Here, we present a comprehensive analysis of YOLOv8 and Detectron2, for obstacle inference and distance estimation tasks in autonomous driving systems. Our results indicate that YOLOv8 achieves a Precision of 88%, Recall of 88%, and F1 Score of 88%, demonstrating robust and balanced detection performance. In contrast, Detectron2 achieves a slightly higher Precision of 89% but lower Recall and F1 Score at 84% and 86%, respectively, indicating a trade-off between detection accuracy and sensitivity. The proposed distance estimation algorithm has MAE of about 80 cm. These findings underscore the nuanced performance characteristics of YOLOv8 and Detectron2 when deployed in autonomous driving environments, providing valuable insights for selecting appropriate frameworks based on specific detection and distance estimation priorities.

title: Decision Making and Admission Process in Home Health Care
authors: Doha Saalaoui, Lina Aboueljinane, Maria Lebbar
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: Home Health Care (HHC) services consist in attending patients in their own homes, provided by a multidisciplinary team. This healthcare service offers several advantages, such as improving patients’ quality of life and reducing both hospital congestion and the increasing costs of the healthcare system. However, not all patients can access HHC due to various medical, logistical, and organizational constraints and decisions. HHC services require multiple decision-making processes at different levels of care—before, during, and after patient admission. The admission process itself is complex and depends on several factors, including the patient’s medical condition, the suitability of the home environment for care delivery, the availability of healthcare professionals, etc. Additionally, uncertainty plays a critical role in decision-making, affecting medical staff, patients, and their families. In this paper, we propose a structured framework for HHC services, detailing the system’s organization and decision-making processes at different planning levels and periods of care. We also provide an overview of the patient admission process and review existing approaches in the literature that address HHC service challenges and decisions. Finally, we conclude with a discussion on current limitations and potential future research directions.

title: Four-Diode Photovoltaic Model with Enhanced Parameter Extraction Using Fractional-Order Particle Swarm Optimization
authors: Ahmed G. Mahmoud, Mohamed A. El-Beltagy, Ahmed M. Zobaa
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Power Electronics and Renewable Energy (CPERE)
abstract: This study presents the application of the Fractional Order Particle Swarm Optimization (FO-PSO) algorithm for the accurate parameter estimation of photovoltaic (PV) modules, formulated as a complex, nonlinear, multi-modal, and implicit optimization problem. Two mathematical models—the Double Diode Model (DDM) and the Four-Diode Model (FDM)—are employed under the constraint of relying solely on datasheet information provided by manufacturers. A custom fitness function, based on the minimization of the error between computed and datasheet I–V characteristics, guides the optimization process. The proposed FO-PSO approach is benchmarked against conventional optimization techniques using Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) as the evaluation metric. Results indicate that FO-PSO achieves a notably lower RMSE, particularly when applied to the FDM, reaching values below 0.08. This demonstrates its superior capability in capturing the true behavior of PV modules compared to traditional methods. The methodology offers a significant advancement in PV modelling, enabling more accurate representations of commercial PV panels without requiring extensive empirical data. FO-PSO applied to the FDM proves to be a competitive and robust tool for PV parameter extraction, with strong potential for future applications in advanced PV modelling, including multi-junction modules and smart grid integration.

title: Bayesian-Optimized CNN-LSTM for Forecasting Short-Term Photovoltaic Power in Microgrids
authors: Hany S. E. Mansour, Shafeek Ghareeb Shafeek, M. Abdel-Aziz, Mohamed Nabil Mohamed, Eyad S. Oda
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Power Electronics and Renewable Energy (CPERE)
abstract: The development of deep learning algorithms has also made it possible to use artificial neural network algorithms to forecast time series with excellent results because solar energy is intermittent. In this research, a CNN-LSTM structure optimized using Bayesian optimization is suggested for photovoltaic power forecasts of the Rye microgrid employing real data coming from an area in Trondheim, Norway. The proposed hybrid model extracts local characteristics from the data by using the convolutional structure as a filter, as well as the construction of short- and long-term memories, and then extracts temporal features. In a hybrid prediction technique, the method updates hyperparameter weights using Bayesian inference. According to the performance evaluation, the suggested model performed better than the others, obtaining an MAE of 1.38 and an RMSE of 3.93. Ultimately, the hybrid model’s performance was evaluated against that of ANN, MLP, CNN, LSTM, and GRU. Additionally, Results show that, concerning the prediction effect, the proposed hypothesis performs better than the other models.

title: Leverage Sub-Band and Cross-Band Information in Real-Time Speech Signal Improvement
authors: Nhat Linh Nguyen Thi, Quoc Cuong Nguyen
publish: 2025 24th International Symposium on Communications and Information Technologies (ISCIT)
abstract: Sub-band and cross-band information have proven beneficial in improving high-resolution characteristics for speech separation and enhancement tasks. Nevertheless, the extraction of high-resolution features frequently results in significant computing complexity, which contradicts the low-complexity demands of real-time systems. To address this difficulty, conventional methodologies often employ an autoencoder design that compresses frequency data to diminish computing demands and encapsulates global information within the bottleneck. Nonetheless, these models frequently neglect the significance of sub-band and cross-band parameters in speech signal processing. To overcome this issue, we offer a real-time model that efficiently utilizes both sub-band and cross-band information at high resolution, while adhering to the autoencoder architecture to meet real-time requirements. The suggested model demonstrates exceptional performance across multiple speech quality metrics, attaining a SIG score of 3.49 and an OVRL score of 3.01 on the blind test set of the ICASSP 2024 Speech Signal Improvement Challenge, with a real-time factor (RTF) of 0.30.

title: An Optimized Ultrasonic Guided Wave Defect Location Approach Based on the Wavelet Energy Entropy
authors: Jialiang Gu, Shaoping Zhou, Zhi Luo, Qinfei Li, Yusong Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: Ultrasonic guided waves are widely employed for defect detection in plate structures due to their long-range propagation and subsurface sensitivity. However, Lamb wave generation and detection exhibits inherent dependence on environmental temperature, adhesive layer thickness, and measurement uncertainties, which often introduce spurious artifacts in defect localization maps. To address this critical limitation, this study proposes a hybrid-domain imaging framework that synergistically integrates time-domain wave propagation analysis with frequency-spectral entropy quantification. A path-weighted elliptical algorithm is developed to mitigate environmental-induced noise while preserving spatial resolution. Finally, an experiment was conducted to verify the location accuracy of the proposed method, and the experimental results show that artifacts can be significantly suppressed.

title: Proposal of Noncontact Fish-Pulse Estimation Camera for Flatfish
authors: Kento Ohno, Daishi Kobayashi, Keiya Kumaki, Takeshi Kumaki, Kyosuke Kageyama
publish: 2025 24th International Symposium on Communications and Information Technologies (ISCIT)
abstract: The Fisheries industry is increasing in demand across various fields. Fish have a risk of disease spreading in the same area. Therefore, it is crucial to identify fish in poor health conditions. A noncontact fish-pulse estimation camera has been proposed and is based on remote photoplethysmography (rPPG) technology. It is known that hemoglobin in blood has the characteristic of absorbing light. Green to yellow light with wavelengths of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 4 0} \sim \mathbf{5 7 7} \text{nm}$</tex> is particularly absorbed by blood. A fish-pulse and stress level are estimated using this characteristic. In experiment 1, fish-pulse was estimated in a tank with stable water temperature. As a result, fish-pulse is estimated at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4 2. 5} \pm 9.6 \text{bpm}$</tex>. In experiment 2, fish-pulse was estimated while the flatfish was subjected to three types of stress: a temperature change stress, a tank acclimation stress, and a physical contact stress. As a result, the temperature change stress caused a minor change in fish-pulse within the range of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$42.5 \pm 9.6 \text{bpm}$</tex>. Additionally, the tank acclimation stress and the physical contact stress caused an increase of about 20 bpm.

title: Security Challenges in Civilian and Military IoT - Common Attacks and Vulnerabilities
authors: Željana Lončarević, Zoran Čiča, Stefan Stanković
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Technologies, Systems and Services in Telecommunications (TELSIKS)
abstract: IoT (Internet of Things) as a technology with its associated advantages and limitations has become indispensable part of day-to-day life. The last two decades have experienced a steady rise in the production and deployment of IoT devices reinforcing the importance of security and reliability aspect. Moreover, this technology has become an integral component of contemporary military systems. Thus, security in IoT has emerged as a critical concern, attracting considerable attention from researchers in recent years. This paper proposes a comprehensive survey of prevalent attacks on IoT devices, along with taxonomy structured around various relevant criteria. The aim of the survey is to highlight the security challenges in civilian and military IoT, considering the diversity of vulnerabilities and demands.

title: Adaptive Multi-Stage Sparse Gaussian Process Regression for Bearing Remaining Useful Life Prediction
authors: Wei Fan, Xiaoxu Gao, Liling Han, Zhenying Xu, Chao Chen, Long Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: The remaining useful life (RUL) of bearings directly affects their operational efficiency and safety, rendering accurate RUL prediction essential for ensuring reliable performance. However, existing RUL prediction methods often rely on a single-stage degenerate model, which limits their accuracy. In addition, conventional data-driven approaches require extensive computational costs due to the extensive quantification of monitoring data. To solve these problems, an adaptive multi-stage degradation framework based on sparse Gaussian process regression (GPR) is proposed in this paper. The degradation process is divided into multiple stages based on change points, whose number is determined by the Elbow Method and the change points are adaptively selected from Binary Segmentation (BS), the Degradation Angle (DA) index, and the Exponentially Weighted Moving Average (EWMA) through error assessments at each stage. A degradation indicator and sparse GPR model with matched kernel function selected based on trend variations is constructed for each stage. The proposed method is validated on both a simulated signal and a PHM challenge bearing dataset. Comparative experimental results demonstrate its effectiveness and superiority over alternative models.

title: FusedBoostNet: A Lightweight Hybrid Model for Consumer-Grade Intrusion Detection
authors: Ankita Sharma, Shalli Rani
publish: IEEE Transactions on Consumer Electronics
abstract: The rapid accumulation of AI-enabled cyberattacks poses a significant threat to the security of consumer applications and smart devices. Traditional intrusion detection and prevention systems (IDPS) often struggle to balance accuracy, efficiency, and deployability in resource-constrained environments. FusedBoostNet, a novel hybrid framework that fuses Gradient Boosting Machines (GBM) with an attention-augmented one-dimensional Convolutional Neural Network (1D-CNN) has been proposed to deliver accurate, robust, and lightweight threat detection. The system leverages the interpretability and decision strength of GBM on tabular network features while capturing temporal patterns from sequential traffic using the 1D-CNN, enhanced by a channel-level attention mechanism. A score-level fusion strategy ensures optimal synergy between the models for final classification. Extensive experiments on the CIC-IDS2018 dataset demonstrate that FusedBoostNet outperforms classical machine learning, deep learning, and ensemble-based techniques, achieving a detection accuracy of 96.8%, an F1-score of 96.0%, and a false positive rate below 3%. The model is further validated for edge deployment with a compact footprint (less than 5 MB) and inference latency under 10 ms. In addition, robustness testing against adversarial perturbations highlights the system’s resilience to AI-enabled evasion attacks. FusedBoostNet offers a practical and scalable solution for securing next-generation consumer applications in an increasingly adversarial digital landscape.

title: Output Feedback Quantized Tracking Control for a Class of Nonlinear Systems With Sensor Failures
authors: Hanfeng Li, Min Li
publish: IEEE Control Systems Letters
abstract: The primary objective of this paper is to develop an adaptive output feedback quantized control scheme for strict-feedback nonlinear systems. Three technical challenges must be overcome in addressing this problem. First, it is necessary to compensate for the unknown parameter associated with sensor failures, but the existing compensating method is applicable only within the backstepping framework, which complicates the overall design process. Second, sensor failures lead to only corrupted output being available and prevent the observer and controller from utilizing the true system output. Third, the nature of input quantization renders the actual controller discontinuous, which unavoidably introduces an undesirable quantization error and thus poses a challenge in mitigating its effect. To circumvent these difficulties, this paper establishes a new compensation scheme and a transformation of the control signal to address the effects of sensor failures and input quantization. A concise dynamic gain approach is proposed to construct a novel adaptive observer by using only the corrupted output signal. It is shown that, with the derived output feedback quantized controller, all closed-loop signals are bounded and the tracking error converges to an adjustable region. Two simulation examples are presented to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed scheme.

title: A High-Sensitivity Microwave Sensor Based on Unequal-Width Three-Coupled Lines for Characterizing the Permittivity of Liquids
authors: Yu-He Li, Yi Le, Guo-Dong Su, Jun Liu, Ling-Ling Sun
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: In this paper, we present a planar microstrip sensor based on unequal-width three-coupled lines (UWTCLs) for characterizing the relative permittivity of liquid materials. The sensor consists of three parallel coupled lines, featuring a wider central line and narrower side lines. The interaction of these unequal-width coupled lines enhances the fringe field effect and electric field concentration, thereby improving sensitivity and resolution. The sensor's performance was evaluated by measuring its response in ethanol-water mixtures with varying volume fractions. The permittivity of ethanol-water mixtures ranges from 6 to 75 at 25°C, and the corresponding resonance frequency varies from 3.7 GHz to 5.65 GHz. For this range of permittivity, the proposed sensor achieves an average normalized sensitivity of 2.064%. Compared to previously reported sensors, the proposed sensor demonstrates superior sensitivity across a wide range of permittivity.

title: Fast-Calibration-Based Control for an Upper-Limb Prosthesis
authors: Darkhan Zholtayev, Amna Khawaja, Kassymbek Ozhikenov, Aiman Ozhikenova, Ussen Shylmyrza, Beibit Abdikenov
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Dexterous prosthetic control demands intent decoders that calibrate quickly and remain robust to arm-pose variation. We present a transfer-learning framework that advances the calibration-based family of algorithms via a dual-branch Transformer fusing surface electromyography (sEMG) and inertial measurement unit (IMU) signals. Training proceeds in three stages:(i) SourceNet learns pose-robust, subject-agnostic features from a multi-subject cohort; (ii) TargetNet adapts these features to a new user with only two repetitions per class; and (iii) PFCNet (Parallel Feature Concatenation) combines SourceNet and TargetNet embeddings for final classification. To our knowledge, prior calibration-based methods have focused predominantly on sEMG-only pipelines and do not explicitly optimize the models using additional sensing modalities during calibration; our modality-aware design addresses this gap. On a held-out subject (9 subjects; held-out subject evaluation; two-repetition calibration), the Transformer decoder achieves 99.35% accuracy, surpassing a strong CNN baseline while using approximately five times fewer learnable parameters. This supports embedded, real-time deployment. This model comprises 3.71M parameters (≈ 14.84 MB in 32-bit float; ≈ 3.71 MB when 8-bit quantized). Accordingly, its embedded inference footprint and latency are small: we expect single-digit to low double-digit millisecond inference times depending on hardware (e.g., sub-10 ms with 8-bit quantization on an NPU, or tens of ms on a CPU-only platform), making the system compatible with real-time prosthetic control. Ablations confirm that (a) sEMG–IMU fusion is essential for accuracy under pose changes and (b) minimal, two-repetition calibration suffices for reliable personalization. To enable reproducibility, we release a systematically curated dataset of nine subjects with synchronized sEMG and IMU recordings. Collectively, the proposed framework delivers a more accurate, parameter-efficient, and rapidly calibratable solution for prosthetic hand control, extending the calibration-based algorithm family with a principled, multimodal optimization strategy.

title: A Review of Interline Series Power Flow Controllers in HVDC Grids
authors: Shubhangi Bhadoria, Frans Dijkhuizen, Hans-Peter Nee
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Power Electronics
abstract: Power flow controllers (PFCs) can give added benefits in meshed High-Voltage Direct Current (HVDC) grids to increase renewables integration. Interline PFCs have been gaining attention for the last decade due to their easy structure and no need for an external power supply. This paper discusses various interline PFC topologies along with their advantages and disadvantages. The existing topologies are compared with respect to several aspects. These aspects include, for instance, modularity, the number of capacitors, the control range of the PFC, the shape of voltage waveforms inserted by the PFC on the lines, number of devices, the directionality of the current, simplicity of the topology, total power semiconductor rating and losses, and protection of the topologies for external faults. It is concluded that the topology of a PFC for a particular application can be chosen depending on the main goal since the topologies come with their advantages and disadvantages when classified based on various aspects.

title: Block-wise Contrastive Few-shot Learning with Multi-view Mixing for Hyperspectral Image Cross-scene Classification
authors: Yan Du, Yingze Xie, Zhengyi Lv, Xuebin Wang, Chuang Liu, Yuxiang Zhang, Mengmeng Zhang
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: The cross-scene classification of hyperspectral images (HSI) faces challenges posed by different sensors and various land cover categories, and methods based on the cross-domain Few-shot Learning (FSL) framework are commonly used to address the challenge. However, current few-shot learning (FSL) methods struggle with the issue of intra-domain inductive bias, where models tend to learn simplistic and potentially erroneous correlations within samples (classes with similar backgrounds are always confused due to simple correlations with the background), leading to poor generalization ability to target domains. Furthermore, most approaches employ a patch-wise representation learning mechanism, which provides the model with all information within a sample, but inherently limits its representation capacity when dealing with the limited prior information in FSL tasks. To address these issues, we propose a Block-wise Contrastive Few-shot Learning (BCFSL) framework. First, a multi-view cross-domain mixing strategy enhances spatial diversity and constructs harder samples to mitigate inductive bias. Second, a novel block-wise representation mechanism performs fine-grained feature extraction from local regions, improving generalization. Finally, a multi-view spectral reconstruction module preserves essential high-dimensional spectral information during training and assists the block-wise representation in fully leveraging prior knowledge. Extensive experiments on three benchmark HSI datasets validate the effectiveness and superiority of the proposed method.

title: Resonance Transition Radiation in One-dimensional Moiré Lattices
authors: Xiaoke Gao, Xiaoyu Zhao, Xikui Ma, Tianyu Dong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Magnetics
abstract: When free electrons travel photonic crystals (PCs), multiple transition radiations occur, yielding highly directional resonance radiation if the emitted electromagnetic (EM) waves are coherent. In this work, we have investigated the resonance transition radiation regulated by the moiré lattices, which can offer greater flexibility in manipulating EM waves compared to conventional PCs, facilitating more intricate free-electron radiation phenomena. In particular, an exponential scattering matrix cascading approach is proposed, which can significantly decrease the necessary cascading steps, signifying a substantial reduction in computational resources. The angular energy density distribution is obtained and the velocity forbidden zone is observed. The radiation modes are categorized into s- and p-polarized types, determined by the inherent dispersion relation and iso-frequency contours. It is also found that the lattice band gap leads to a significant suppression of the radiation. Our work could provide a foundation for exploring the promising wave behavior within the moiré lattices.

title: LoGCC: Local-to-Global Correlation Clustering for Scalar Field Ensembles
authors: Nicolas F. Chaves-de-Plaza, Renata G. Raidou, Prerak Mody, Marius Staring, René van Egmond, Anna Vilanova, Klaus Hildebrandt
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: Correlation clustering (CC) offers an effective approach to analyze scalar field ensembles by detecting correlated regions and consistent structures, enabling the extraction of meaningful patterns. However, existing CC methods are computationally expensive, making them impractical for both interactive analysis and large-scale scalar fields. We introduce the Local-to-Global Correlation Clustering (LoGCC) framework, which accelerates pivot-based CC by leveraging the spatial structure of scalar fields and the weak transitivity of correlation. LoGCC operates in two stages: a local step that uses the neighborhood graph of the scalar field's spatial domain to build highly correlated local clusters, and a global step that merges them into global clusters. We implement the LoGCC framework for two well-known pivot-based CC methods, Pivot and CN-Pivot, demonstrating its generality. Our evaluation using synthetic and real-world meteorological and medical image segmentation datasets shows that LoGCC achieves speedups-up to 15× for Pivot and 200× for CN-Pivot-and improved scalability to larger scalar fields, while maintaining cluster quality. These contributions broaden the applicability of correlation clustering in large-scale and interactive analysis settings.

title: Explainable Machine Learning for Predicting Computational Thinking Proficiency in K-12 Students Using National-Level Data
authors: Hyuna Noh, Hansung Kim, Hyeoncheol Kim
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: This study aimed to identify the key factors predicting computational thinking (CT) attainment among Korean elementary- and middle-school students and to provide educational implications for promoting CT education. Using national-level digital literacy assessment data collected by the Korean government (14,468 elementary- and 16,622 middle-school students), we developed machine-learning-based predictive models and applied Shapley Additive Explanations (SHAP), an explainable AI (XAI) technique, to evaluate feature importance and interaction effects. The SHAP analysis revealed that information and communications technology (ICT) literacy levels, coding skills, and perceptions of the future occupational usefulness of digital devices were common positive predictors of CT attainment for both groups. For elementary students, Internet search proficiency and grade level exerted additional positive effects, whereas the time spent on digital devices for out-of-home learning purposes, leisure-centered use, and high autonomy negatively affected CT attainment. Among middle-school students, the ability to create presentation materials emerged as a key positive factor, whereas the effects of grade level and information-search ability were relatively limited. SHAP dependence analysis demonstrated that combinations of ICT literacy levels, grades, coding skills, and perceptions of occupational usefulness consistently enhanced CT attainment, whereas the combination of high digital autonomy with occupational usefulness perceptions hindered CT attainment. These findings highlight the need to systematically strengthen ICT and coding education, establish stage-specific strategies, and provide guidance for goal-oriented and structured digital use. Ultimately, this study contributes to academic significance by applying XAI methods to national-level CT data, enabling interpretable analysis of feature importance and interaction effects, and uncovering complex relationships among variables that traditional statistical approaches could not fully reveal.

title: Two-round Certificateless Multi-signatures with Key Aggregation in Smart Contracts
authors: Jianhong Zhang, Qing Ji, Chuming Shi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: Multi-signatures have recently garnered considerable attention, particularly within the domain of smart contracts in blockchain ecosystems, as they enhance account security and mitigate single points of failure by requiring the approval of multiple key holders for transaction execution. However, most existing multi-signature schemes heavily rely on traditional Public Key Infrastructure (PKI), which requires a trusted authority and conflicts with the decentralized nature of blockchain technology. Certificateless multi-signature (CLMS) schemes, which eliminate the requirement for a trusted authority, represent promising solutions to address this issue. Nevertheless, existing CLMS schemes encounter challenges that limit their suitability for smart contract applications, including high communication overhead, expensive verification costs, and “loose" security reductions. To address these challenges, we propose two novel two-round certificateless multi-signature schemes. These schemes not only support key aggregation but also optimize the signing process with two-round communication, maintaining fixed computational overhead during verification. Furthermore, the security proofs for the proposed schemes are independent of the Forking lemma, resulting in tighter security reductions and strengthened security assurance. Finally, experimental results demonstrate that the proposed schemes significantly reduce both communication and computational overhead compared to existing CLMS schemes, making them more efficient and practical for blockchain-based smart contract applications.

title: More Granular, Less Trust: Enforcing Intra-Process Isolation with Arm CCA in an Untrusted Management Environment
authors: Shiqi Liu, Zhouqi Jiang, Jie Wang, Wei Zhou, Kun Sun, Zhaohui Chen, Yulai Xie
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: With the increasing adoption of confidential computing, security-sensitive applications are often deployed in confidential virtual machines (CVMs), which reduce reliance on third-party cloud providers. However, privilege attacks originating from the OS remain a significant threat in these environments. Existing finer-grained isolation schemes, such as SHELTER (USENIX SEC’23), provide process-level protection but are still vulnerable to intra-process attacks and potential collusion between the OS and intra-process adversaries. Many current intra-process isolation techniques continue to depend on the OS to manage and enforce isolation domains, leading to a large Trusted Computing Base (TCB). This gap highlights the need for more granular, less trust-dependent confidential computing solutions. In this paper, we present CCAegis, a system that extends the Arm Confidential Compute Architecture (CCA) to enforce intra-process isolation of sensitive data and operations, safeguarding them from both intra-process adversaries and the OS. We employ static analysis to track the flow of sensitive data and identify functions that handle such data. Permission-switching instructions are inserted at the function call and return points, adjusting permissions via the Granule Protection Table (GPT) to ensure that only designated functions can access the isolated data. Notably, CCAegis places trust solely in the Secure Monitor, which configures the GPTs and manages domain switching, thereby minimizing the TCB. We implemented CCAegis on both an official emulator and a real development board to assess its performance. Our experimental results show that CCAegis effectively isolates sensitive data and operations, with performance overheads ranging from 1.01× to 1.43× compared to the original version across real-world cryptographic workloads.

title: Deep Learning for Bird Identification Using Sound: Enhancing Avian Monitoring and Conservation in Indonesia and Malaysia
authors: M. Rifqi Dzaky Azhad, Rafiq Labib, Athila R. Saputra, Fathan A. Maulana, Ema Rachmawati, Mohamad Fizl S. Ramji, Rohana Sapawi, Edward Ferdian
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Information Technology, Computer, and Electrical Engineering (ICITACEE)
abstract: Bird populations worldwide are declining, with Indonesia and Malaysia among the countries facing significant species threats. Traditional bird monitoring methods are invasive and rely heavily on the availability of experts, highlighting the need for automated, real-time, and region-specific acoustic classification systems to effectively address these issues. This study presents a bird classification framework using Mel-spectrogram and a CNN-based model for bird songs from Indonesia and Malaysia. Evaluations were performed on an open-source regional dataset with 200 species and multiple manually collected datasets, demonstrating that our fine-tuned model outperforms existing models in terms of overall accuracy and weighted metric scores. Our model achieved an accuracy of 76.28 %, precision of 89.48 %, recall of 76.28 %, and F 1-score of 80.29 %. These findings demonstrate that region-specific data improves the accuracy of bird classification models based on acoustic signals, contributing to improved avian biodiversity monitoring.

title: Edge-Oriented Federated YOLOv8 Detection Framework for Photovoltaic Fault Identification
authors: Zhefan Jin, Jiaojie Li, Renjie Zhang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: With the continuous expansion of photovoltaic (PV) systems, accurate and efficient fault detection has become increasingly vital to ensure operational stability and safety. Federated learning (FL) offers an effective solution for distributed model training in PV applications while preserving data privacy. However, conventional FL methods face significant challenges in the presence of data heterogeneity, class imbalance, and inconsistent model convergence. To address these issues, this paper proposes a novel aggregation approach, termed Class-Aware Federated Proximal Aggregation (CAFPA), which integrates the local regularization mechanism of FedProx and the label-aware aggregation strategy of FedLA, and incorporates the YOLOv8 object detection model for PV cell fault identification. Moreover, CAFPA introduces an adaptive learning rate strategy, combining accuracy plateau detection and cosine annealing, to further enhance convergence speed and stability of the global model. Experiments conducted on multiple non-independent and identically distributed (non-IID) clients demonstrate that CAFPA outperforms mainstream methods such as FedAvg, FedProx, and FedLA in terms of mAP50, accuracy, and convergence speed, highlighting its strong potential for deployment in edge computing scenarios.

title: Effect of Storage Time on Oxidative Pyrolysis Characteristics of Coal
authors: Qinggang Lu, Jinling Li, Honghu Huang, Liang Chen
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: This study uses TG-DSC to analyze mass and heat changes of Xinjiang long-flame coal before/after natural oxidation at three heating rates, exploring the effects of storage time and heating rate on oxidative pyrolysis. Kinetic parameters are derived via ln[g(α)/T<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>]~1/T curve fitting. Key results: (1) TG-DSC curves show five stages in oxidative spontaneous combustion. (2) Higher heating rates shift TG/DTG to higher temps, reduce oxygen-absorption weight gain, and increase max weight loss rate and heat release. (3) Long-flame coal follows the 3D Z-L-T model during low-temperature oxidation at all heating rates. (4) Prolonged storage reduces dehydration/oxygen-absorption weight loss and total combustion weight loss, while increasing weight loss rate and decreasing max/total heat release.

title: “Made by people, described by people”: The Changing Work Practices of Audio Description Professionals
authors: Cynthia L. Bennett, Amy Pavel, Aidan Bryant, Laura J. McCarthy Eberly, Renee Shelby, Shaun K. Kane
publish: ACM Transactions on Accessible Computing
abstract: Audio description (AD) narrates important visual details which are played during dialogue gaps in video soundtracks, making them accessible to blind and low vision (BLV) audiences. AD professionals (producers, writers, narrators, mixers, and quality control specialists) possess expert knowledge of AD development and the constraints that affect their work. However, their perspectives remain largely absent in AD research. We present interviews with 17 AD professionals (8 BLV), detailing their workflows to produce AD for recorded media and live theater. We additionally explore their perspectives on recent changes impacting their work, revealing tensions between advocacy for culturally-competent AD and the rise of automations—some beneficial, others with concerning implications for AD quality. Highlighting these tensions, we offer research directions to support AD professionals, and we pose guiding questions for AD and AI innovators on preserving the high-quality human touch professionals consider fundamental to the accessibility provision.

title: QoE Evaluation for VR with Vibrotactile Feedback Based on Inter-user Brain Spatial Information
authors: Yan Zhang, Rui Song, Riting Xia, Zhenwei Shi
publish: ACM Transactions on Multimedia Computing, Communications, and Applications
abstract: Subjective measurement remains one of the most widely used approaches for evaluating quality of experience (QoE) in tactile virtual environments. However, its reliability is often compromised by factors such as conscious bias, variations in user expressiveness, and contextual influences, which may distort the accuracy of evaluation outcomes. In light of the fact that electroencephalography (EEG) provides a direct window into neurophysiological correlates of emotion and cognitive states, this paper proposes an objective QoE evaluation method for virtual reality (VR) with vibrotactile feedback based on inter-user brain spatial information (IBSI). The proposed IBSI feature extraction method enhances the conventional common spatial pattern (CSP) algorithm through the introduction of a regularization constraint term designed to mitigate overfitting. Moreover, the covariance matrix of each non-target user is weighted according to its Kullback–Leibler divergence from the target user, enhancing cross-user alignment and supporting effective transfer of neural information. To validate the performance of the proposed method, we design a VR shooting interaction experiment involving 64 participants. The study comprises three main phases: preparation, interaction, and subjective feedback. During the preparation phase, participants receive task explanations and familiarize themselves with the VR environment. In the interaction phase, participants complete a standardized shooting task while EEG data are recorded synchronously. Finally, subjective feedback is collected through questionnaires. QoE assessment is accomplished by classifying IBSI features using classical classifiers, with subjective QoE ratings serving as ground truth. Experimental results show that our method outperforms existing methods in classification accuracy, and the dominant activation pattern in the alpha rhythm is consistent with neural mechanisms associated with motor perception. Meanwhile, the mutual interpretability between subjective and objective data characterizing QoE further validates the rationality of the experimental paradigm.

title: Multi-Objective Optimization Design of Sar Constellation for Balancing Efficiency and Cost
authors: TANG Peihua, MAO Liheng, WU Qiushi, YOU Chaolan, DENG Qing, SUN Daotian
publish: 2024 5th China International SAR Symposium (CISS)
abstract: Aiming at the high timeliness remote sensing application requirements of SAR satellites, and addressing the challenging balance between construction costs and constellation efficiency, a multi-objective optimization design for the SAR constellations is conducted. The main innovations lie in: combining constellation efficiency indicators with cost indicators as joint optimization objectives in the design; proposing various efficiency evaluation metrics to construct a comprehensive assessment model for constellation efficiency, reducing the extreme requirements for the number of satellites by a single indicator, and enhancing the optimization space; based on the concept of multi-satellites launches, using the number of launch vehicles and the total number of satellites as cost indicators to build a cost model. Employing multi-objective optimization algorithms can reduce the total number of satellites by 22.86%, decrease the number of launch vehicles by 35.71 %, significantly lower the overall deployment cost of the constellation, and provide a reference for the overall design and low-cost construction of large-scale constellation.

title: Research on Comprehensive Evaluation Weights of Metering Asset Operation Benefits Based on AHP-Entropy Weight Method
authors: Lin Liu, Jinfeng Yang, Ziang He, Yingnan Zhang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: This paper proposes a combined weighting model integrating the Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) and the entropy method to address the issue of comprehensive evaluation of the operational efficiency of electric energy metering equipment. By constructing a three-level evaluation index system covering economic benefits, business support, and equipment reliability, the organic integration of subjective judgments and objective data is achieved. Taking 4 different transformer districts of a provincial electric power company as evaluation cases, the calculation processes of the two methods are elaborated in detail, And calculate the comprehensive score of the transformer district through combined weight calculation. The research shows that this model quantifies each index system, providing a decision-making basis for electric power enterprises to optimize equipment operation and maintenance strategies and resource allocation.

title: Can Oriented Bounding Box Enhance Small Object Detection?
authors: Lam Thai Nguyen, Tran Hiep Dinh
publish: 2025 24th International Symposium on Communications and Information Technologies (ISCIT)
abstract: Small object detection (SOD) presents several challenges, such as limited context and background noise. While advanced deep learning mechanisms have significantly improved detection performance, the role of bounding box orientation remains underexplored. Although oriented bounding boxes (OBBs) are typically used for rotated objects, we propose that they can also reduce background pixel inclusion, thereby improving SOD. This study investigates whether OBB can enhance SOD. Specifically, we evaluate the effectiveness of OBBs by comparing them with horizontal bounding boxes (HBBs) within a YOLO-based detection framework. The target object is the tiny “NoteHead” from the DeepScoresV2 public dataset. Given DeepScoresV2's clean background, we further extend our evaluation to noisy images. Results show that OBBs consistently outperform HBBs across multiple experimental settings. On clean images, OBBs achieve gains of up to 9% in <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$F_{1}$</tex>-score and 10% in recall. On noisy images, OBBs maintain their advantage across all noise levels, with performance gains reaching up to 17% in <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$F_{1}$</tex>-score, 30% in precision, and 19% in recall. These findings highlight the potential of bounding box orientation in SOD and motivate further research into its application.

title: Swarm Intelligence for Enhancing Cyber Security in Vehicular Ad-Hoc Networks
authors: Moujal Fouad, Elouadi Abdelmajid
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: Vehicular Ad-Hoc Networks (VANETs) are an important aspect of Intelligent Transportation Systems (ITS) because they allow vehicles and roads to communicate with each other in real time. which makes roads safer and traffic flow better. As a result of being dynamic and decentralized, VANETs are vulnerable to major cybersecurity concerns such Sybil attacks, denial-of-service (DoS) attacks, and routing manipulation. In these cases, typical security processes usually stay the same. This paper looks at how to employ bio-inspired algorithms like Ant Colony Optimization (ACO), Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO), and Bee Algorithms to make VANET safer by using secure routing, intrusion detection, and anomaly monitoring. We also proposed a hybrid security system that combines blockchain-based decentralized trust management with swarm intelligence. Swarm algorithms enable you identify and update things in real time, while blockchain technology makes sure that trust and behavior data are always shared and can be checked across the network. The document talks about what has been written about the subject so far, points out issues with putting the ideas into practice, and underlines key gaps in the study. Our suggested plan is a solid and flexible technique to keep VANETs safe in big, high-mobility areas.

title: Advancing Lunar Communication Through Inter-Domain Space Networks and Dynamic Orchestration
authors: Selen Geçgel Çetin, Barş Dönmez, Güneş Karabulut Kurt
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: The resurgent era of lunar exploration is defined by a strategic shift from temporary visits to a sustained international and commercial presence, resulting in an unprecedented demand for a robust and continuously available communication infrastructure. The conventional direct-to-Earth communication architecture relies on limited and oversubscribed deep space networks, which are further challenged by the radiative environment and insufficient visibility in certain areas of the cislunar domain. We address these issues by proposing a foundational move toward inter-domain space network cooperation by introducing architectures based on near space networks. They can directly service lunar surface users or, via cislunar relays, by forming a resilient and multi-layered communication backbone. First, we establish a unified link analysis framework incorporating frequently disregarded environmental factors, such as the Moon's variable illumination, to provide a high-fidelity performance evaluation. Second, we assess architectures' reliability based on the outage risk, essential for quantifying the operational robustness of communication links. Finally, to manage the inherent dynamism of architectures, we propose an inter-domain space digital twin: a dynamic decision-making engine that performs real-time analysis to autonomously select the best communication path, ensuring high and stable reliability while simultaneously optimizing power consumption. Overall, our paper provides a holistic architectural and conceptual management framework, emphasizing the necessity of lunar communications to support a permanent human and economic foothold on the Moon.

title: A Short Overview of Recent Advances in Sitting Posture Monitoring Systems
authors: Miloš D. Jevtić, Nenad Nedović, Djordje Urukalo
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Technologies, Systems and Services in Telecommunications (TELSIKS)
abstract: Bad sitting posture can cause the early development of musculoskeletal disorders. Consequently, a lot of research is done on sitting posture monitoring systems (SPMSs). We provide an overview of SPMS research, focusing on what is missing in the prior work. We synthesize a coherent 2 D taxonomy of sensors used in SPMSs, review recent SPMS papers and radar based SPMS papers, and provide a clear overview of sensor type combinations used in multi-sensor SPMSs. Motion and pressure sensors are prevalent in the recent SPMSs, while radar was rarely used. There are many sensor combinations which have not been used in multi-sensor SPMSs. Based on our findings, we point out the possible paths of future research.

title: SPICE-Based Automatic Parasitic Extraction in Double Pulse Test Circuits for SiC MOSFETs
authors: Ahmed Abdelkareem, Anouar Belahcen, Ahmed Hemeida, Mohamed Taha
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Power Electronics and Renewable Energy (CPERE)
abstract: This paper presents an automated method for extracting parasitic elements of SiC MOSFET double pulse test (DPT) circuits. The approach uses the open-source PYLTspice package to simulate the DPT under varying parasitic elements. A differential evolution (DE) optimizer adjusts these parasitic values so that the simulated switching energies ($E_{\text {on }}$ and $E_{\text {off }}$) match the device data sheet’s specified loss curves. The tuned model achieves up to a $92.7 \%$ reduction in error between simulated and data sheet switching loss values, compared to the untuned baseline.This workflow avoids the need for commercial 3D field solvers (e.g., Ansys Q3D or Altium Designer) since the circuit layout is not available and relies entirely on free SPICE tools. The results emphasize that stray, connection, and component placement parasitic inductances have a non-negligible impact on switching performance. Even slight variations in these inductances can cause switching losses to deviate significantly from data sheet values. Incorporating these parasitic elements yields simulated waveforms that closely follow the data sheet curves especially for high current devices, highlighting the importance of modeling parasitic elements in switching device simulations. and in SPICE-based converter and inverter designs to ensure result accuracy.

title: Cable Fault Diagnosis Method Based On Dynamic Integral Function Construction
authors: Jun Hou, Zhijie Wang, Zhuyu Shao, Qijun Guo
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: In order to solve the problems of cable terminal detection blind area and large positioning error existing in the existing cable defect detection methods, a cable defect diagnosis method based on dynamic integral function is proposed.First, establish a mathematical model of the reflection coefficient spectrum of online cable lines, and further study the principle of online cable defect location based on the integral transform; Afterwards, a dynamic integration transformation function based on the upper limit of dynamic integration and the reflection coefficient spectrum is constructed; Next, use simulation to diagnose and analyze cables under different defect conditions; Finally, aging defects and insulation layer defects were designed on power cables for diagnostic analysis. Simulation and experimental results showed that this method effectively eliminates the "ripple effect" at the cable terminal location, achieving high-precision positioning of cable defects.

title: Remaining Life Prediction of Rolling Bearing Based on Multi-Scale Feature Fusion and Deep Learning
authors: Hongwei Fan, Xinggang Zhang, Xiangang Cao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: Aiming at the problem that the current Remaining Useful Life (RUL) prediction approaches of rolling bearing have a single feature extraction capability and cannot fully utilize the spatio-temporal information embedded in data, an innovative RUL prediction technique leveraging CEEMDAN combined with TCN-BiLSTM-Multi-head Self-attention is proposed. Simultaneous extraction of spatial features hidden in time-series data is achieved through a dual-network architecture consisting of a Temporal Convolutional Network (TCN) and a Bi-directional Long Short-Term Memory (BiLSTM) network. The degradation feature information is enhanced through multi-head self-attention weighting, followed by the RUL prediction of rolling bearing through fully connected layers. The designed model fully utilizes bearing characteristics extracted from both the frequency domain and 1D time series data. Combined with signal processing techniques, these features enable a multi-dimensional characterization of the degradation evolution in bearing. By employing the proposed methods, the RUL prediction intervals can be efficiently quantified without relying on physical or statistical prior information about the bearing system. A case study on rolling bearing is conducted to validate the advantages of the suggested approach. Experimental findings prove that the developed model improves prediction accuracy and tends to anticipate the RUL slightly in advance, which helps to carry out the predictive maintenance.

title: A Joint Parameter Estimation and Subspace Segmentation Inversion Method for Motion Error Compensation in MIMO-SAR
authors: Yang Zhang, Min Zhu, Yuchen Lin, Lei Cui, Shuangxi Zhang, Yuanjie Zhi
publish: 2024 5th China International SAR Symposium (CISS)
abstract: Multiple input multiple output synthetic aperture radar (MIMO-SAR) leverages the characteristic of multichannel spatial parallel sampling to achieve high-resolution wide-swath (HRWS) imaging. However, existing MIMO-SAR motion compensation methods ignore the differences in motion errors between channels and the range spatial variation of the phase errors of the scene, which degrades the Doppler ambiguity suppression performance and ultimately affects imaging results. In order to solve these two existing problems, this article proposes a joint parameter estimation and subspace segmentation inversion method for motion error compensation. The method Firstly establishes a geometric model of motion errors for MIMO-SAR. With this model, subspace segmentation estimation and parameter estimation are applied to invert the platform motion errors. Finally, the motion error is accomplished by using the motion parameters obtained from the inversion. The proposed method compensates for spatially variant motion errors in the range direction through segmentation processing and compensates for each channel motion errors before the Doppler ambiguity suppression, thereby improving imaging quality. The simulation results verify the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Unsupervised Machine Learning for Credit Card Fraud Detection: Comparative Study of Individual and Ensemble Models
authors: Walid Soufiani, Abdessamad Dine, Abdeljalil Sakat
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: Fraud detection is a critical challenge for large economic entities, as the advancement of new technologies in commerce and online banking has increased the use of credit card payments, leading to a rise in fraudulent transactions. Researchers employ various methods to detect and analyze these fraudulent activities, which can cause significant damage to financial institutions and individuals. Current credit card fraud detection methods mostly rely on supervised approaches requiring labeled and balanced datasets. However, in practice, datasets are often highly imbalanced, with few labels or sometimes none at all, which suggests the need to use other techniques and approaches. In this paper, we present an approach that relies on unsupervised techniques by comparing several methods on a highly imbalanced dataset, including Local Outlier Factor (LOF), Isolation Forest (IF), One-Class SVM (OC-SVM), and Autoencoder (AE), along with two ensemble methods based on majority voting and score aggregation. After evaluating these methods using various metrics, we found that the Isolation Forest algorithm generally delivers the best performance compared to the other methods, including the proposed ensemble methods.

title: A Clustering-Based Damage Identification and Localization Method for Composite Structures Using Multi-Physical Features of Ultrasonic Guided Waves
authors: Danyang Han, Jing Lin, Jiadong Hua
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: Structural Health Monitoring (SHM) has become a vital technique for ensuring the safe operation of critical engineering structures. Among various SHM approaches, guided wave–based damage detection has attracted widespread attention due to its ability to capture early structural anomalies over long distances by extracting signal-based features from wave propagation paths. However, existing methods often rely on single damage-sensitive features, which are susceptible to noise and insufficient for describing complex signal variations. Meanwhile, deep learning–based approaches,although effective in feature learning, typically require large labeled datasets and suffer from limited interpretability in practical engineering applications.To address these limitations, this study proposes a two-stage clustering-based unsupervised damage identification method using multiple physically interpretable features.Three types of damage-sensitive indicators are extracted from each guided wave propagation path: correlation coefficient, envelope energy ratio, and time of maximum difference. In the first stage, K-means clustering is employed on a path level to distinguish damaged from undamaged paths based on the correlation-energy feature space. In the second stage, a 36-dimensional time-of-flight vector is constructed using the identified damaged paths for each damage case. A hierarchical clustering algorithm is then applied to classify 28 damage cases into seven structural zones.The proposed method achieves an identification accuracy of 85.7%, demonstrating strong performance in both localization and interpretability. Compared to traditional single-feature-based or deep learning approaches, the proposed technique offers advantages in requiring no labeled data, being computationally efficient, and providing robust physical interpretability, thus showing great potential for real-world SHM scenarios with limited data and high reliability requirements.

title: Research on Bearing Fault Diagnosis Based on Digital Twin Technology
authors: Haibo Wu, Yuheng Yang, Chengpiao Zheng, Mengqi Yang, Xuan Wang, Rongzhen Luo
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: In response to the challenges inherent in bearing fault diagnosis, this paper proposes a digital twin-based fault diagnosis architecture. Within the physical layer, a bearing test bench equipped with sensors facilitates data acquisition, with data fusion achieved through transformation and encapsulation processes. The data layer utilizes the OPC UA communication protocol to enable data interaction and synchronous mapping, thereby generating twin data. In the virtual layer, 3D modeling and rendering are performed, followed by model integration into Unity 3D to realize the virtual mapping of the physical entity. Building upon this foundation, the fault diagnosis module employs order analysis and result encoding to derive image data, which is subsequently processed by a deep learning model for fault diagnosis. This architecture achieves synergistic coordination among the physical, data, and virtual layers. It is anticipated to enhance the accuracy and real-time performance of bearing fault diagnosis and provide effective support for the predictive maintenance of industrial equipment.

title: Adaptive method of biometric authentication, AC-CNN based on convolutional neural networks under conditions of partially available biometric data
authors: Nenad Badovinac, Dejan Simic
publish: 2025 6th International Workshop on Engineering Technologies and Computer Science (EnT)
abstract: Digital transformation and the rise of electronic payments in the post-COVID19 period require more accurate methods of biometric authentication. Standard biometric authentication methods show limitations when users wear masks and gloves. In this paper, the method of biometric authentication AC-CNN (Adaptive Clustered Convolutional Neural Network) is proposed. AC-CNN is based on the classification of facial images into clusters and their vectorization using previously trained CNN facial recognition models (e.g.VGGFace, ArcFace, DeepFace). After classification, the facial image is vectorized by the CNN algorithm, which shows the best facial recognition accuracy for facial images from that cluster. The registration and verification processes use different types of CNN algorithms.
