In the process of user identification, after successful user identification, the type of CNN algorithm that was used for that user in the registration process is loaded from the database and the same CNN algorithm will be used in the verification process. In the verification process, the biometric template of the identified user is compared with the reference biometric template contained in the database and based on their Euclidean distance, a verification decision is calculated. Since the biometric templates of the users in the database are divided into clusters, an allowable decision threshold is calculated separately for each cluster. The results of experimental research show that the presented method allows for increased verification accuracy even in conditions where the face is masked and when only partial biometric data is available.

title: MPU Circuit Generation From Programs With Meta-Instructions
authors: Tomoyuki Morimoto, Hiroto Iwata, Kiyoto Goto, Toshiyuki Tsutsumi
publish: 2025 24th International Symposium on Communications and Information Technologies (ISCIT)
abstract: Simultaneous consideration of the microprocessor's (MPU's) architecture and its corresponding circuit is essential in MPU design. Nonetheless, generating a comprehensive circuit diagram during the early stages of architectural design is a significant challenge for designers. At present, there are no established computer-aided design tools capable of automatically generating MPU circuit diagrams during the early stages of design. This research addresses this gap by enabling the automatic generation of MPU circuit diagrams at the architecture design level. Our MPU architecture design toolset, MEIMAT, has been enhanced to visualize the MPU circuit diagram required to execute a given assembly program. We present a novel method for generating the MPU circuit diagram by synthesizing instruction circuit diagrams derived from assembly programs written with MEIMAT's metainstructions. The MPU circuit diagram is visualized based on a corresponding MPU functional expression, which is synthesized from the functional expressions of the meta-instructions within the assembly program. Since the meta-instructions are capable of representing any instruction set, MEIMAT can generate MPU circuit diagrams for arbitrary assembly programs. This innovative toolset empowers MPU designers to achieve a comprehensive and precise understanding of architectural configurations during development.

title: Bird detection method for transmission line based on improved YOLOv8 algorithm
authors: Sishi Fu, Shuang Liu, Bo An, Hu Chen, Zhiang Zhang, Yubin She, Anqi Wang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: Transmission lines often face the infestation of bird damage, which brings hidden danger to the stable operation of transmission lines, in order to solve the impact of birds on transmission lines and facilitate real-time detection. This paper proposes the CTE-YOLO algorithm: based on YOLOv8, firstly, the DLKA deformable large kernel attention module is added to substantially improve the accuracy of the algorithm, especially for the identification of feature information in complex environments. Then the CCFM cross-scale feature fusion module is used, which greatly reduces the number of parameters of the algorithm due to its lightweight structure design. After experimental verification, the CTE-YOLO algorithm proposed in this paper realizes 88.4% detection accuracy while the GFLOPs are reduced to 7.4, which meets the demand of bird detection on transmission lines, and the effectiveness and superiority of the algorithm proposed in this paper are proved by ablation and comparison experiments.

title: Prediction of system strength margin for multi-infeed systems based on federated learning
authors: Zhihao Chen, Haiqing Cai, Wei Chen, Yun Liu, Zixiang Lin
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: The increasing penetration of renewable energy in power systems has led to a significant decline in system strength, thereby elevating the risk of small-signal instability. Consequently, it becomes imperative to proactively assess the system strength margin (SSM) of the system to implement timely measures for ensuring secure and stable grid operation. To this end, this paper proposes a federated learning-based SSM prediction method for multi-infeed systems. Firstly, based on the generalized short-circuit ratio (gSCR) theory, the quantification of the SSM under non-rated condition in multi-infeed systems is established. Subsequently, a SSM prediction architecture is constructed via Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) neural networks, leveraging their proven efficacy in capturing nonlinear time-series dependencies. Furthermore, on the premise of data privacy, the collaborative training of the SSM prediction model for multiple wind farms has been achieved based on federated learning. Finally, the effectiveness and accuracy of the proposed SSM prediction model are verified by some simulations in a multi-infeed system with 9 wind farms.

title: A 107 DB-SNDR and 165 DB-FOM Second-Order Noise-Shaping SAR ADC
authors: Viet Nguyen-Thien, Thao Cao-Chau, Minh Tran-Quang, Huy Thai-Quang, Loan Pham-Nguyen
publish: 2025 24th International Symposium on Communications and Information Technologies (ISCIT)
abstract: This paper presents a noise-shaping (NS) SAR ADC that integrates data-weighted averaging (DWA) and mismatch error shaping (MES) techniques to improve linearity without calibration. The prototype ADC is designed in a 65 nm CMOS process. It consumes 1.62 mW at 5 V while operating at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$128 \text{kS} / \mathrm{s}$</tex>. The ADC achieves an SNDR of 107 dB, corresponding to an SNDR-based Schreier figure of merit (FoM) of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 6 5 ~ d B}$</tex>.

title: A two-Layer Authentication Scheme Against Node Replication Attacks in Mobile Heterogeneous Sensor Networks
authors: Boqing Zhou, Sujun Li, Decheng Miao
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Communications Society
abstract: Replication nodes can compromise a network by not only stealing confidential data but also by selectively forwarding packets and injecting false data to the base station. This undermines the base station’s decision-making, ultimately allowing attackers to control the network. Scholars have proposed various solutions to deal with this attack. However, network performance is still susceptible to its impact because of their inherent limitations. In this paper, we introduce a novel authentication scheme. In this scheme, the network contains high-energy nodes, mobile sensor nodes (MSNs), and a base station. High energy nodes act as cluster heads. MSNs must be authenticated by a cluster head before they can obtain or provide data to the cluster head. Authentication between intra-cluster nodes relies on key information pre-distributed by the cluster head, leveraging a Bloom filter for efficient verification. Within a cluster, node a will only forward node b’s data after node b is authenticated by node a. The analysis and simulation validate that the proposed scheme significantly enhances the network’s resilience against replication attacks. The communication probability between high-energy nodes is about 90%, and the probability that high-energy nodes can complete MSNs authentication within 1 hop is about 1; after introducing the bloom filter scheme within the cluster, the storage overhead of MSNs can be reduced by 90%, and the impact on the transmission of information from MSNs within the cluster to the cluster head can be ignored.

title: A Scalable Data Model for Signalized Intersection Performance Measures
authors: Christopher M. Gartner, Rahul Suryakant Sakhare, Jairaj Chetas Desai, James Sturdevant, Darcy M. Bullock
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Traditionally, traffic signal management has been largely tactical and operated from the “bottom-up,” focusing on individual intersection performances influenced by public suggestions, field observation, and in some cases high-resolution controller data. Connected vehicle trajectory data now enables a scalable, complementary “top-down” approach for system-wide performance analysis, even for locations with no detection or communication. This paper proposes a data architecture for derived performance measures that can be used for both strategic (top-down) and tactical (bottom-up) management of traffic signals. To leverage a “top-down” approach, large amounts of data must be processed into smaller datasets. For efficiency and interoperability between performance measures and the tools used to derive the same, a scalable data management architecture is essential. This paper discusses and demonstrates a framework developed for the Indiana Department of Transportation, which contains the derived information from over 177 billion records per year for the state, covering more than 2,500 signalized intersections in just 80,000 or so rows of derived performance measures. This framework collects data using a combination of a fixed time period, date, movement, approach, and intersection identifier. The structured model of derived performance measures supports both tactical applications, such as green-time allocation, and top-down, strategic management applications such as identifying capacity-constrained signals that are candidates for capital improvements. This framework is applicable to other tools used to derive performance measures, such as high-resolution or LiDAR datasets.

title: RCANet Based User Partitioning Channel Estimation for RIS Assisted mmWave MIMO Systems
authors: Jinhao Wang, Xiao Zhou, Chengyou Wang, Zhiquan Bai
publish: IEEE Transactions on Green Communications and Networking
abstract: Reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS) can effectively overcome the limited coverage of millimeter wave (mmWave). The effective operation of RIS relies on accurate channel state information (CSI) obtained from channel estimation. However, accurate channel estimation is challenging due to the passive nature and the presence of high pilot overhead. Recently, deep learning (DL) based channel estimation methods have shown potential. However, high model complexity and low estimation accuracy are still key issues. This paper proposes a user partitioning channel estimation method based on reparameterization and coordinate attention network (RCANet). The proposed method uses user partitioning to achieve angle segmentation for accurate estimation and obtains the estimated channel by the trained RCANet. Initially, partial CSI is obtained by RIS elements grouping and least square (LS) algorithms. Subsequently, the data of users in the partition is utilized to train RCANet in the offline training part. Finally, using well-trained network allows estimating the channel with low complexity in the online test part. Our comprehensive simulation results show that the proposed method has lower normalized mean square error (NMSE) as well as lower complexity compared to other channel estimation algorithms.

title: Fusing SIFT Keypoint Density and Multi-Resolution Wavelet Features for Enhanced CVD Classification via a Residual Attention Network
authors: Imane El Boujnouni
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: According to the World Health Organization, cardiovascular diseases (CVDs) have been listed as the principal contributor to human fatalities. Thus, with a view to slackening the current rate of mortality and to mitigate the negative impacts of CVDs, early diagnosis and timely treatment are of paramount importance. In our study, we propose a novel computer-aided diagnosis system to automatically classify nine distinct CVD classes from electrocardiogram signals. Our method introduces a hybrid feature representation that combines Multi-Resolution Wavelet Features with Scale-Invariant Feature Transform keypoint density maps. Next, an advanced deep Convolutional Neural Network architecture, named the Residual Attention Network, is trained to utilize these enriched features in order to capture the most discriminative spectral features, and therefore enhance the diagnostic performance. To overcome the inherent issue of imbalanced classes, Focal Loss is employed alongside data augmentation techniques. We assessed the robustness and reliability of the proposed approach through the five-fold cross-validation method.

title: Electric Energy Substitution Potential Prediction Based on CEEMDAN-LSTM-GM Model
authors: Zhukui Tan, Yong Xiao, Dunhui Chen, Ziwen Cai, Qihui Feng, Yun Zhao
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: To address the problems of insufficient feature extraction of non-stationary sequences and the complexity of multi-factor coupling modeling in electric energy substitution potential (EES) prediction, this paper proposes a hybrid prediction model based on the improved CEEMDAN-LSTM-GM. First, we conduct multi-scale decomposition of the EES sequence using the improved CEEMDAN algorithm with dynamic noise injection and energy entropy control to suppress modal aliasing and extract high/low-frequency components and residual terms. Second, we construct a frequency-segmented prediction architecture: The architecture adopts the particle swarm optimization (PSO) algorithm to adaptively adjust long short-term memory (LSTM) hyperparameters for capturing short-term fluctuations in high-frequency components, while employing the grey model (GM) to predict long-term trends in low-frequency components. Finally, we introduce an attention mechanism to dynamically fuse multi-band prediction results. An empirical study taking a certain province in southern China as an example shows that the model performs well in indicators such as root mean square error (RMSE=0.85) and mean absolute percentage error (MAPE=3.5%), and the mutation detection rate (STR=11.8%) indicates its sensitive capture ability for unexpected events such as policy adjustments. This model provides methodological innovation for the multi-scale prediction of the potential of electric energy substitution.

title: Vibration Sensor Placement Optimization in Electrical Transmission for Prognostics and Health Management System
authors: Shufeng Lin, Changdong Zheng, Cenbo Xiong, Liang Yu, Qizhi Xu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: This study optimizes accelerometer placement for vibration signal acquisition in Electro Transmission (ET) units to support Prognostics and Health Management (PHM) dataset construction. HyperMesh finite element models of ET housing sub-components are developed and validated through impact hammer modal testing, correcting material properties and boundary conditions. These validated sub-models are assembled into an integrated ET model. Romax multi-body dynamics simulations provide bearing support reaction forces from the internal planetary gear system; these forces are converted into the frequency domain and applied as excitation inputs. Vibration response under typical operating conditions is analyzed using the modal superposition method. The Modal Assurance Criterion (MAC) calculates characteristic vibration modes, forming an objective function for Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) to determine optimal accelerometer locations. Hardware-In-the-loop (HIL) testing validates the optimized layout, with acquired signals demonstrating strong auto-correlation and cross-correlation, confirming the method's effectiveness. This work provides a theoretical basis for ET vibration monitoring and PHM dataset development.

title: Modeling the Academic Impact of Early ICT Exposure: A Cross-National Study Using Pooled Variance Optimization
authors: Ilyas Tammouch, Abdelamine Elouafi, Soumaya Nouna, Assiya Nouna
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: As digital technologies permeate childhood at progressively younger ages, global disparities in access and outcomes have intensified. While early digital device usage among children is often met with concern, especially regarding its potential impact on learning, this study offers a more nuanced understanding of its academic implications. Leveraging data from 156,277 15-year-old students across 18 OECD countries collected through the Programme for International Student Assessment (PISA), we used a pooled variance analysis to examine how early digital exposure can influence learning outcomes. Contrary to common concerns, early digital exposure does not hinder academic performance and is often associated with comparable or even superior outcomes. These outcomes, however, depend significantly on environmental factors. Countries with strong educational systems and effective digital integration such as Finland tend to gain more from early exposure. In contrast, nations facing socioeconomic crises, like the Dominican Republic, often show uneven ICT development. The study highlights the importance of educational equity, infrastructure investment, and policy design in shaping the effects of initial digital access, underlining the need for data driven, context sensitive strategies to support technology enhanced learning.

title: Multiple Point-Source Tracking with Lensless Single Random Phase Encoding Optical Systems
authors: Saurabh Goswami, Jiheon Lee, Gokul Krishnan, Bahram Javidi
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: In this paper, we demonstrate the capability of a lensless single random phase encoding (SRPE) system to track the lateral motion of multiple moving point-sources using a Probability Hypothesis Density (PHD) filter. Our system consists of an image sensor and a diffuser that captures the motion of point-sources by projecting a pseudorandom pattern on the image sensor. Using the theory of diffraction, we deduce the mapping between the locations of point-sources in the free-space and the pseudorandom pattern obtained from SRPE systems, obtain an initial maximum-likelihood estimate of the point-source locations, use a Markovian motion prior to predict the locations at subsequent time-instants and, use captured video frames to refine the predicted location estimates. Our results show that lensless SRPE systems, coupled with PHD filtering algorithm, can estimate lateral motion of point-sources accurately and in a computationally efficient manner. Moreover, lateral motion tracking with SRPE is robust to motion-blur and increase in image-sensor pixel size. Tracking with lensless SRPE systems also show robustness to dimensionality reduction of the captured pseudorandom patterns which have computational benefits. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first work to demonstrate lensless SRPE systems as an object tracking modality.

title: A Multi-Agent DRL-Based Framework for Optimal Resource Allocation and Twin Migration in the Multi-Tier Vehicular Metaverse
authors: Hayla Nahom Abishu, A. Mohammed Seid, Aiman Erbad, Tilahun M. Getu, Ala Al-Fuqaha, Mohsen Guizani
publish: IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology
abstract: Although multi-tier vehicular Metaverse promises to transform vehicles into essential nodes – within an interconnected digital ecosystem – using efficient resource allocation and seamless vehicular twin (VT) migration, this can hardly be achieved by the existing techniques operating in a highly dynamic vehicular environment, since they can hardly balance multi-objective optimization problems such as latency reduction, resource utilization, and user experience (UX). To address these challenges, we introduce a novel multi-tier resource allocation and VT migration framework that integrates Graph Convolutional Networks (GCNs), a hierarchical Stackelberg game-based incentive mechanism, and Multi-Agent Deep Reinforcement Learning (MADRL). The GCN-based model captures both spatial and temporal dependencies within the vehicular network; the Stackelberg game-based incentive mechanism fosters cooperation between vehicles and infrastructure; and the MADRL algorithm jointly optimizes resource allocation and VT migration in real time. By modeling this dynamic and multi-tier vehicular Metaverse as a Markov Decision Process (MDP), we develop a MADRL-based algorithm dubbed the Multi-Objective Multi-Agent Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient (MO-MADDPG), which can effectively balances the various conflicting objectives. Extensive simulations validate the effectiveness of this algorithm that is demonstrated to enhance scalability, reliability, and efficiency while considerably improving latency, resource utilization, migration cost, and overall UX by 12.8%, 9.7%, 14.2%, and 16.1%, respectively.

title: 2025 IEEE Conference on Power Electronics and Renewable Energy (CPERE)
authors: N/A
publish: N/A

title: Challenges and Opportunities in Electric Propulsion Systems for Low-Altitude eVTOL Aircraft
authors: Litao Dai, Shuangxia Niu, Zekai Lyu, Xiaohui Huang, K. T. Chau
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Electronics
abstract: Low-altitude aviation is rapidly emerging as a transformative solution for next-generation transportation, driving significant advancements in electric propulsion systems. As a core subsystem in electric aircraft, electric propulsion systems require comprehensive evaluation of their technological progress, ongoing challenges, and future opportunities to support the development of low-altitude aviation. Unlike land vehicle applications, aircraft propulsion systems demand safety-critical designs governed by stringent operational constraints. This review identifies three critical metrics for such systems: power density, operational reliability and fault tolerance, and thermal management efficiency. While existing studies often address these metrics individually, their interdependencies are not well explored. To bridge this gap, this review systematically investigates state-of-the-art solutions, benchmarks their limitations under flight-critical conditions, and establishes correlations between technological advancements and operational requirements. Furthermore, it highlights future research directions by identifying emerging methodologies. As low-altitude aviation approaches scalable deployment, this paper aims to serve as a technical reference to support the safe and effective development of aerial propulsion technologies.

title: Self-Wearing Adaptive Garments via Soft Robotic Unfurling
authors: Nam Gyun Kim, William E. Heap, Yimeng Qin, Elvy B. Yao, Jee-Hwan Ryu, Allison M. Okamura
publish: IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters
abstract: Robotic dressing assistance has the potential to improve the quality of life for individuals with limited mobility. Existing solutions predominantly rely on rigid robotic manipulators, which have challenges in handling deformable garments and ensuring safe physical interaction with the human body. Prior robotic dressing methods require excessive operation times, complex control strategies, and constrained user postures, limiting their practicality and adaptability. This paper proposes a novel soft robotic dressing system, the Self-Wearing Adaptive Garment (SWAG), which uses an unfurling and growth mechanism to facilitate autonomous dressing. Unlike traditional approaches, the SWAG conforms to the human body through an unfurling-based deployment method, eliminating skin-garment friction and enabling a safer and more efficient dressing process. We present the working principles of the SWAG, introduce its design and fabrication, and demonstrate its performance in dressing assistance. The proposed system demonstrates effective garment application across various garment configurations, presenting a promising alternative to conventional robotic dressing assistance.

title: Sizing Antenna Arrays for Near-field Communication and Sensing
authors: Marcin Wachowiak, André Bourdoux, Sofie Pollin
publish: IEEE Wireless Communications Letters
abstract: This paper presents key performance metrics for near-field communication and sensing systems and their scaling behavior as a function of the antenna array aperture. Analytical expressions are derived for several standard array geometries to ease the design of the large antenna arrays under given system requirements. First, the near-field beam focusing is analyzed and the minimum beamdepth is observed to rapidly saturate to a low asymptotic limit as the array aperture increases. In contrast, the near-field region span is shown to scale quadratically with the array aperture. Based on these two metrics, the maximum number of resolvable beamspots at 3 dB separation is derived analytically, exhibiting a linear dependence on the array aperture. Moreover, when considering a region where the beamfocusing resolution does not exceed a specified threshold, the extent of the region is also shown to scale linearly with the array size. Finally, the number of significant singular values of a channel observed at the array’s broadside is estimated, showing a power-law dependence on the aperture. The resulting expressions provide practical design guidelines for evaluating aperture requirements in near-field communication and sensing applications.

title: Multi-Agent PPO-Based Resource Optimization for Full-Duplex RIS-Aided NOMA-ISAC Systems
authors: Nonis Wara, Anal Paul, Keshav Singh, Aryan Kaushik, Wonjae Shin
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Communications Society
abstract: This paper proposes a multi-agent deep reinforcement learning (DRL) framework based on proximal policy optimization (PPO) for joint resource optimization in full-duplex (FD) reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS)-aided non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) systems. The goal is to maximize the minimum beampattern gain under quality-of-service (QoS) constraints for both uplink (UL) and downlink (DL) users. The optimization jointly controls transmit beamforming, RIS phase shift, DL power allocation, and UL transmit power. A centralized training with decentralized execution approach is adopted, where two agents are defined: a DL agent responsible for DL beamforming, RIS configuration, and power allocation, and a UL agent responsible for uplink power control. Each agent interacts with the shared environment, which comprises the base station (BS), RIS, and users, and learns its optimal policy under time-varying channels and mutual interference. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed multi-agent PPO (MA-PPO) significantly outperforms baseline methods, including single-agent PPO and heuristic schemes, in terms of convergence speed, sum-rate, and beampattern gain. Moreover, the MA-PPO method exhibits superior scalability and performance in FD mode over half-duplex (HD) counterparts under various user densities and RIS configurations, showcasing its effectiveness for real-time joint communication and sensing in next-generation wireless networks.

title: TELSIKS 2025 Breaker Page
authors: N/A
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Technologies, Systems and Services in Telecommunications (TELSIKS)

title: ICEEPS 2025 Preface
authors: N/A
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)

title: Large Multimodal Model-Empowered Task-Oriented Autonomous Communications: Design Methodology and Implementation Challenges
authors: Hyun Jong Yang, Hyunsoo Kim, Hyeonho Noh, Seungnyun Kim, Byonghyo Shim
publish: IEEE Vehicular Technology Magazine
abstract: Large language models (LLMs) and large multimodal models (LMMs) have achieved unprecedented breakthroughs, showcasing remarkable capabilities in natural language understanding, generation, and complex reasoning. This transformative potential has positioned them as key enablers for 6G autonomous communications among machines, vehicles, and humanoids. In this article, we provide an overview of task-oriented autonomous communications with LLMs/LMMs, focusing on multimodal sensing integration, adaptive reconfiguration, and prompt/fine-tuning strategies for wireless tasks. We demonstrate the framework through three case studies: LMM-based traffic control, LLM-based robot scheduling, and LMM-based environment-aware channel estimation. From experimental results, we show that the proposed LLM/LMM-aided autonomous systems significantly outperform conventional and discriminative deep learning model-based techniques, maintaining robustness under dynamic objectives, varying input parameters, and heterogeneous multimodal conditions where conventional static optimization degrades.

title: Data-Driven Stabilisation of Unstable Periodic Orbits of the Three-Body Problem
authors: Owen M. Brook, Jason J. Bramburger, Davide Amato, Urban Fasel
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Many different models of the physical world exhibit chaotic dynamics, from fluid flows and chemical reactions to celestial mechanics. The study of the three-body problem (3BP) and its many different families of unstable periodic orbits (UPOs) has provided fundamental insight into chaotic dynamics as far back as the 19th century. The 3BP, a conservative system, is inherently challenging to sample due to its volume-preservation property. In this paper we present an interpretable data-driven approach for the state-dependent control of UPOs in the 3BP, through leveraging the inherent sensitivity of chaos and the local manifold structure. We overcome the sampling challenge by utilising prior knowledge of UPOs and a novel augmentation strategy. This enables sample-efficient discovery of a verifiable and accurate local Poincaré map in as few as 55 data points. We suggest that the Poincaré map is best discovered at a surface of section where the norm of the monodromy matrix, i.e. the local sensitivity to small perturbations, is the smallest. To stabilise the UPOs, we apply small velocity impulses once each period, determined by solving a convex system of linear matrix inequalities based on the linearised map. We constrain the norm of the decision variables used to solve this system, resulting in locally-optimal velocity impulses directed along the local stable manifold. Critically, this behaviour is achieved in a computationally efficient manner. We demonstrate this sample-efficient and low-energy method across several orbit families in the 3BP, with potential applications ranging from robotics and spacecraft control to fluid dynamics.

title: Dynamic Task Scheduling and Adaptive GPU Resource Allocation in the Cloud
authors: Hoda Sedighi, Fetahi Wuhib, Roch H. Glitho
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network and Service Management
abstract: The growing demand for computational power in cloud computing has made Graphics Processing Units (GPUs) essential for providing substantial computational capacity. Efficiently allocating GPU resources is crucial due to their high cost. Additionally, it’s necessary to considercloud environment characteristics, such as dynamic workloads, multi-tenancy, and requirements like isolation. One key challenge is efficiently allocating GPU resources while maintaining isolation and adapting to dynamic workload fluctuations. Another challenge is ensuring scheduling maintains fairness between tenants while meeting task requirements (e.g., completion deadlines). While existing approaches have addressed each challenge individually, none have tackled both challenges simultaneously. This is especially important in dynamic environments where applications continuously request and release GPU resources. This paper introduces a new dynamic GPU resource allocation method, incorporating fair and requirement-aware task scheduling. We present a novel algorithm that leverages the multitasking capabilities of GPUs supported by both hardware and software. The algorithm schedules tasks and continuously reassesses resource allocation as new tasks arrive to ensure fairness. Simultaneously, it adjusts allocations to maintain isolation and satisfy task requirements. Experimental results indicate that our proposed algorithm offers several advantages over existing state-of-the-art solutions. It reduces GPU resource usage by 88% and significantly decreases task completion times.

title: A Multiport Bidirectional LLC Resonant DC-DC Converter for Vehicle-to-Grid Applications
authors: Alielden A. Abouelseoud, Rahim Mohamed, ELsayed A. Ibrahim, Abdelrahman M. Mahmoud, Mohamed E. Dessouki, Ahmed A. Ibrahim, Abdelrahman Farghly
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Power Electronics and Renewable Energy (CPERE)
abstract: LLC dc-dc converters are renowned for their high power density and their ability to achieve zero-voltage switching (ZVS) over a wide operating range. However, traditional LLC converters lack support for bidirectional power flow and simultaneous power transfer to multiple ports. This paper proposes a high-performance, multiport bidirectional LLC resonant converter designed for emerging vehicle-to-grid (V2G) applications. The proposed converter extends conventional LLC architectures into a multiport topology, enabling concurrent bidirectional power exchange between multiple sources and loads. The design is validated through comprehensive PLECS-based simulations.

title: Travel time estimation using Eikonal equation with finite element method in ultrasound imaging: an in-silico study
authors: Feixiao Long, Weiguang Zhang
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Complex Medical Engineering (CME)
abstract: Estimating the travel time of ultrasound in an inhomogeneous medium is crucial for high-quality imaging, as with an accurate estimate of the distribution of speed of sound, phase aberration, which is normally viewed as one of the main reasons for image degradation, can be corrected by multiple methods. To estimate the ultrasound travel time, the approach using solutions to the eikonal equation is attractive, since it can be easily integrated into a conventional delay-and-sum beamformer. In our manuscript, we first propose employing the finite element method to solve the eikonal equation in ultrasound imaging, which is easy to extend to a high-order numerical scheme and potentially runs faster on GPU. We prove that the experimental order of convergence of our proposed method is approximately 2, which is advanced than fast marching methods with order of convergence around 1. The mean relative error of our results is less than $4 \%$ in the imaging plane, compared to the results acquired with the fast marching method with one public dataset. These results preliminarily demonstrate the potential of applying finite element method as an alternative approach in calculating the travel time of ultrasound within inhomogeneous medium.

title: Toward Secure and High-Performance Blockchain Integration in the Internet of Vehicles: A Layered Architecture Based on Hyperledger Fabric
authors: Soukayna Kerkaa, Kawtar Jellid, Tomader Mazri
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: Connected and Autonomous Vehicles (CAVs) have become more and more widespread over the past few years, with a significant advance to transportation systems through intelligent decision-making and real-time connectivity. Operating within the Internet of Vehicles (IoV), AVs continuously exchange sensitive data with other vehicles, infrastructure, and cloud services. These vehicles come packed with advanced IoT technologies that enable them to sense their surroundings, interact with their environment, and even operate autonomously. This high level of autonomy and connectivity offers significant benefits like safer roads and more efficient traffic, nevertheless it also creates new opportunities for cyberattacks. As the technology improves, so do the tactics used by attackers, who are constantly developing smarter ways to exploit vulnerabilities in connected systems or execute harmful actions that may compromise safety and public trust. Centralized security solutions, which are becoming outdated, are insufficient specially in a dynamic and distributed environment particularly in terms of security and system performance. This survey paper proposes a multi-layered security architecture for blockchain-enabled AV networks, built upon Hyperledger Fabric. By combining fog computing and middleware with blockchain’s inherent strengths, our approach delivers strong authentication and data integrity, low-latency communication, scalable transparent transactions, and decentralized trust management while mitigating emerging cyber threats.

title: Airport Adjustment Strategy Based on Air Traffic Flow Prediction Using EMD-BiLSTM Hybrid Mode
authors: Yuekai Wu, Jian-An Zhang, Qingyuan Zhang, Kexin Li, Mengting Lin, Jiahao Sun, Wenxi Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: In airport operations, the common experience-based flight scheduling often leads to low runway utilization and air traffic congestion. Accurate flight flow prediction has become critically important to support informed and efficient scheduling decisions. To address this issue, this paper proposes an air traffic flow prediction method based on EMD-BiLSTM (Empirical Mode Decomposition-bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory network) hybrid model and a dynamic margin driving strategy. Firstly, the EMD is used to adaptively decompose the non-stationary traffic data into multi-scale intrinsic mode functions to eliminate noise interference. By further capturing the bidirectional dependence of time series using BiLSTM, the fusion prediction model is constructed. Then, the throughput margin equation is defined based on the prediction results and the maximum runway capacity. A three-level response mechanism is also established to quantitatively support the flight scheduling strategy. Finally, the proposed methods are implemented to the Hangzhou Xiaoshan Airport. According to the historical departure flow data, the mean absolute percentage error of prediction is reduced to 7.18% compared with other models. Combined with the margin strategy, the runway overload risk probability in peak hours is also effectively reduced. The simultaneous construction of GIS airspace simulation and decision platform realizes the visualization of flow and strategy, improving the efficiency of airport operation and resource utilization.

title: Study on Insulator Flashover Induced by Lightning on the Midpoint of Lightning Protection Lines Based on the High-Frequency Electromagnetic Pulse Coupling Principle
authors: Ke Li, Bo Lu, Jian Zhang, Jianggao Hong
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: During lightning events and rainfall, transmission lines frequently experience tripping incidents due to breakdown discharges across insulator strings and air gaps, which significantly threaten the reliable operation of power systems. To investigate the mechanism by which direct lightning strikes on lightning protection lines lead to insulator flashover, this paper proposes a line insulation failure theory, based on the high-frequency electromagnetic pulse coupling principle and the characteristic behavior of lightning currents. The study examines the probability of insulator flashover induced by lightning strikes on lightning protection lines. The results indicate that lightning surges can be regarded as high-frequency electromagnetic pulses. When a lightning strike hits a lightning protection line, the capacitance between the ground wire and the phase wire induces a high-frequency coupling effect, accumulating high-frequency components of lightning voltage on the phase wire. This voltage is then transferred via the equivalent capacitance of insulator strings toward ground. Theoretical calculations show that the high-frequency components of lightning surges can penetrate the capacitive distance (approximately 10 to 15 meters) formed between the ground wire and the phase wire. This implies that when the high-frequency component of the lightning current reaches a certain threshold, it can pass through the equivalent phase-to-ground capacitance, and if the high-frequency current exceeds 2 to 5 A, a high-frequency flashover of the insulator is likely to occur. In addition to established mechanisms such as back flashover and shielding failures, the research identifies a previously underexplored phenomenon: high-frequency electromagnetic pulse coupling that induces small-current flashover. This phenomenon is substantiated by experimental evidence. Our findings contribute to a more comprehensive theoretical framework for lightning-induced tripping and pro-vide a theoretical basis for designing and selecting external insulation for transmission lines.

title: Pattern Recognition of Partial Discharge Signals in DC Gas-Insulated Switchgear Based on Multi-Domain Feature Extraction
authors: Yuanchun Song, Songhang Du, Jiawei Yuan, Jiaoyang Xin, Zhichao Liu, Li Chen
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: High voltage direct current gas insulated switchgear is frequently affected by partial discharges arising from internal defects, which can lead to equipment failure and significant economic losses. Accurate identification of defect types responsible for partial discharge phenomena is therefore critical. Existing research on direct current ultra-high frequency signals primarily remains confined to single-characterization domains, with limited studies addressing the extraction of time-frequency domain features from direct current partial discharge signals. To address this gap, this paper investigates four typical defect models—protrusions, metal particles, air gaps, and insulator surface fouling—in direct current gas insulated switchgear. Time-domain and frequency-domain features are extracted, and time-frequency domain features are additionally derived using empirical wavelet transform and multiscale permutation entropy. A comparative analysis evaluates the characterization capabilities of three single domains for partial discharge signals. Finally, a three-branch convolutional neural network is developed to integrate features from all three domains, enabling joint detection and accurate classification of the four defect types.

title: IoT Security Risks and Mitigation Strategies for Smart Grids: A Literature Review
authors: Bara’ Fteiha, Saif Alsamahi, Mohamed Alameri, Alyssa Palmer, Huma Zia
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: Rapid population expansion and growing energy consumption have marked the 21st century and have prompted the crucial call for attempts to make the electrical grid more intelligent and responsive to meet consumer requirements while boosting the dependability and efficiency of contemporary power systems. IoT serves as a main technology in accomplishing a smart grid transformation and provides state-of-the-art solutions across various domains, including critical infrastructures. Considering that IoT nodes are interconnected through the network, this leaves the grid susceptible to a wide range of cyber threats. A smart grid cyberattack would have a catastrophic effect on all of the facilities connected to the grid due to the potential cascade effects of turning off an electrical supply. IoT-enabled smart grids’ infrastructure and architecture are reviewed in this research, with emphasis on the main challenges and security issues related to their implementation. Finally, the primary finding of this literature work is to emphasize the approaches and tools which could make IoT-enabled smart grids more secure and robust to current physical and cyber threats. To protect the whole electrical grid from cyber-physical attackers, adaptive security and blockchain-based data transfer network technology will be required in the near future.

title: Optimal Coordinated Control for Distributed SAR Formation Reconfiguration Application
authors: Li Cheng, Wei Ju Zheng, Deng Qing, You Chao Lan, Li QingYu, Hu Xian da
publish: 2024 5th China International SAR Symposium (CISS)
abstract: The distributed SAR satellite system can construct ultra-long variable baselines by means of multiple baselines, multiple perspectives, and other methods, has greatly improved radar performance. To meet the trends of multifunctional, software defined, and intelligent reconstruction in future distributed SAR satellite system, which will lead to a massive demand for formation configuration. In the paper we focus on the theme of distributed SAR formation reconfiguration study. Firstly, a formation relative motion model was constructed based on the C-W equations; Secondly, the optimal controller was designed to solve the problem of configuration reconstruction; and then considering the formation coordination control needs, a consensus coordination control algorithm was developed; Finally, taking the configuration reconstruction of three satellites formation as an example, the algorithm was simulated and verified, the results showed that the algorithm exhibits high control accuracy and good consistency.

title: Research on corrosion fault diagnosis method of grounding network based on the joint method of electrical network and electrical impedance imaging technology
authors: Liuqing Yang, Jiayi Yu, Haiqing Dong, Zhefei Wang, Bin Xu, Runping He
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: Electrical impedance imaging technology as a high-precision grounding network corrosion fault diagnosis method, when faced with the need to detect the grounding network area is large, the number of accessible nodes is relatively small, there will be a substantial increase in the amount of measurement work, the measurement accuracy of the problem of a substantial reduction. In view of the above problems of the electrical impedance imaging technology, this paper proposes the joint application of the electrical network theory method and the electrical impedance imaging technology in fault detection. Detection strategy is: first, based on the principle of electrical network theory, build a preliminary diagnostic model of grounding network corrosion faults, choose EVO-MNR with good convergence performance to solve the model, determine the corrosion branch or corrosion area; and then apply electrical impedance imaging to the corrosion area to further determine the degree of corrosion of the branch as well as the exact location of the branch corrosion. In this paper, a substation grounding network in Shanghai Jiading is subjected to fault diagnosis simulation experiments, and the results show that: the method proposed in this paper can significantly reduce the amount of engineering at the same time, to ensure the high precision of the conductivity distribution image, and the method can be widely used in grounding network corrosion fault detection, which has a broad application prospect.

title: A Novel Predictive Model for Hypertension Comorbidity in COPD Patients Based on the Feature-Adaptive Stacking Framework (FASF)
authors: Zeyuan Hao, Yifan Duan, Haolin Wang
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Complex Medical Engineering (CME)
abstract: Objective: This study aimed to develop and validate a novel comorbidity prediction model for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) patients with concurrent hypertension, thereby enhancing early risk stratification and facilitating precise clinical intervention. Methods: We retrospectively analyzed clinical records from seven hospitals in Chongqing, covering the period 2014-2023. A two-stage feature selection process combining Maximum Relevance Minimum Redundancy (mRMR) and the knockoff method was employed to identify 19 critical clinical indicators. Based on a SuperLearner model, we introduced a Feature-Adaptive Stacking Framework (FASF) that integrates logistic regression, decision trees, support vector machines, naive Bayes, and k-nearest neighbors. The dataset was split into training and testing cohorts in a $70: 30$ ratio. Model performance was assessed using receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curves, confusion matrix metrics (accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score), and decision curve analysis (DCA). An online prediction tool was also developed to facilitate clinical application. Results: A total of $\mathbf{2, 1 8 5}$ patient records were evaluated, with 1,088 (49.79%) exhibiting COPD with comorbid hypertension. The implementation of the FASF framework significantly enhanced the predictive performance of the SuperLearner model, achieving an AUC of 0.91, an accuracy of 0.85, and precision, recall, and F1-scores of $\mathbf{0. 8 3}$. All performance metrics were notably improved compared to the baseline model without FASF, and DCA confirmed the model’s high clinical utility. Conclusion: The SuperLearner-based prediction model employing the FASF framework demonstrates excellent discriminative capability and clinical decision-making benefit in assessing hypertension risk among COPD patients. By integrating a two-stage feature selection process with an adaptive weighting strategy, the model significantly enhances prediction accuracy, providing a robust tool for early identification of high-risk patients, personalized intervention planning, and the advancement of precision medicine.

title: A brief review on AI-driven approaches for predictive maintenance of pipelines
authors: Jouary Oumaima, El Kiri Yassine, Mighouar Zakaria, Zahiri Laidi
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: Pipeline maintenance guarantees the integrity and safety of essential infrastructures. This article maps how artificial intelligence is revolutionizing predictive maintenance of pipelines. Utilizing a systematic bibliometric scan of the best databases (2020-2025), authors filter 86 preliminary papers down to 17 open-access papers that correspond to machine-learning models, digital twins and IoT sensors with maintenance operations. Four outstanding 2024-2025 papers are taken in depth to demonstrate AI-driven solutions for failure prediction, integrity optimization, flow forecasting and real-time defect detection. The performance of each classifier is normalized on a 1–5 scale by efficacy, real-time capability, implementation complexity and interpretability and presented in a comparative table and heat-map. The merger recognizes Random Forest as the top all-around classifier and positions its outputs as state signals for a future reinforcement-learning framework capable of scheduling inspections and repairs dynamically. Finally, the paper establishes research gaps edge deployment, physics-guided models and rare event learning and sets a roadmap for data-centric, life cycle optimized pipeline integrity management.

title: Fault Identification of Voltage Source Converter Valve Discharge Based on Mel-Spectrum and CNN
authors: Dawei Chen, Biao Li, Lixuan Zhu, Lijian Jiang, Tianshu Sun, Lin Zheng, Jin Liu, Xiaolong Zhang, Shaoyan Gong
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: Voltage source converter valves are subjected to multiple internal and external stresses under long-term complex operating environments. There is a hidden danger of partial discharge caused by reduced insulation performance. Currently, there is a lack of effective means of discharge monitoring inside the converter valve hall. Usually, the occurrence of local discharge can only be investigated after the fault causes the converter valve to stop. Therefore, there is an urgent need to study the online monitoring technology to realize the active diagnosis of discharge faults. In this paper, a set of discharge fault identification methods based on key time-frequency feature extraction of mixed voiceprint signals is proposed. Firstly, the discharge signal is extracted from the mixed voiceprint pattern based on the fast independent component analysis method. Then the time-frequency spectral feature extraction is realized using Mel spectral analysis. Finally, a deep convolutional neural network is constructed to recognize the discharge fault type. In this paper, a voltage source converter valve discharge simulation test platform is built. The test results show that, compared with other algorithms, the method in this paper has superior accuracy while the computational speed is fast.

title: Short-Term Cascade Operation Modeling for the Three Gorges-Gezhouba: Integrating Dynamic Storage and Backwater Effects
authors: Xian Lin, Yuan Liu, Xiaodong Cheng, Hongwei Cao, Youwu Wang, Meng Duan, Xiang Hu, Mingzhao Guo, Feilin Zhu
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: This study investigates the impacts of dynamic storage capacity and backwater effects on the short-term operation of the Three Gorges-Gezhouba cascade hydropower system. A coordinated dispatch model was developed using Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) to minimize residual load fluctuations, incorporating dynamic penalty functions to address complex constraints. By coupling hydrological-hydrodynamic modules, the research quantitatively analyzes the nonlinear effects of dynamic storage on power output. Validation with 2022-2025 historical and forecast operational data demonstrates that when accounting for dynamic storage and backwater effects: Three Gorges water level deviations average within 10 cm, Gezhouba deviations are predominantly within 20 cm. The findings provide theoretical support for precision scheduling in cascade hydropower systems.

title: Multicast Broadcast Services in Railway Communication Applications
authors: Ivaylo Atanasov, Dragomira Dimitrova, Evelina Pencheva
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Technologies, Systems and Services in Telecommunications (TELSIKS)
abstract: Multicast broadcast solution can improve communication efficiency and provide the required reliability, coverage, latency, mobility, and scalability in the railway transport. The paper presents a method for the design of information recording and broadcasting as services for railway applications. The method feasibility is proved by modeling the state of a multicast broadcast session.

title: Dynamic Response Characteristics of Photovoltaic Power Station Inverters in Industrial Scenarios
authors: Li Ding, Libin Liang, Pengfei Zhang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: Photovoltaic (PV) power generation is expanding rapidly but faces challenges due to intermittency, requiring grid-connected inverters to ensure stability. This study analyzes inverter dynamics under grid faults, load fluctuations, and irradiance changes. A mathematical model of LCL-filtered inverters was developed, revealing that grid impedance amplifies coupling effects in parallel systems. Key findings show phase-locked loop (PLL) harmonics during voltage jumps, transient oscillations from load shifts, and MPPT-driven power adjustments under irradiance variations. Simulations highlight sensitivity to control parameters, underscoring the need for adaptive strategies. The results offer insights for enhancing grid stability in large-scale PV integration, with future work focusing on intelligent control algorithms.

title: Multidimensional Data Analysis and Diagnosis Model of Blood Diseases Based on Deep Learning
authors: Xingnan Li, Min Gu
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Complex Medical Engineering (CME)
abstract: This paper discusses the multidimensional data analysis and diagnosis model for leukemia based on deep learning, aiming to solve the subjectivity and inefficiency issues of traditional leukemia diagnosis methods. The research focuses on the automatic identification of four subtypes of acute myeloid leukemia (AML), acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), and chronic lymphoblastic leukemia (CLL). By integrating heterogeneous data from multiple sources, including morphologic images of peripheral blood smears and bone marrow smears, time series data of continuously monitored blood parameters, and flow cytometry data, a diagnostic framework integrating convolutional neural networks (CNN) and long-short term memory networks (LSTM) was constructed. The model uses CNN to extract image spatial features, LSTM to capture temporal dynamics, and achieves end-to-end classification through deep fusion of multi-dimensional information via a crossmodal attention mechanism. Empirical analysis shows that the model is significantly better than the mainstream multimodal algorithm in the diagnosis of four types of leukemia. The key advantage lies in strengthening the weight allocation of key biomarkers, improving the recall rate and AUC value, providing efficient and objective auxiliary diagnostic tools for clinical practice and promoting the development of accurate hematology.

title: Optimization of Electrode Combinations for High-Performance Bilateral TIBS Stimulation
authors: Anshun Kang, Yan Zhao, Jian Ouyang, Qiwen Luo, Jiayuan Zhao, Zilong Yan, Guangying Pei, Tianyi Yan, Wenhao Chen, Li Wang
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Complex Medical Engineering (CME)
abstract: Temporal Interference brain stimulation is a noninvasive neuromodulation technique enabling direct electrical stimulation of deep brain regions. This study aimed to identify the optimal electrode pair combination for targeting the thalamus. Using MRI data from 26 healthy adults, individualized head models were developed and envelope fields computed to simulate electrical stimulation under various electrode configurations. Forward simulations and assessments of 998 electrode combinations within these head models revealed the F7-P7/F8-P8 combination demonstrated superior overall performance. These findings provide a foundation for establishing a targeted optimization framework for thalamic stimulation, including the selection and evaluation of reference metrics.

title: An Intelligent Information System for Semantic Analysis of Social Network Discussions
authors: Aleksa Dzunic, Nenad Petrovic, Milorad Tosic
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Technologies, Systems and Services in Telecommunications (TELSIKS)
abstract: This paper addresses the challenge of extracting meaningful insights from decentralized social media, where discussions are typically noisy and fragmented. Focusing on Mastodon posts containing the #AI hashtag, we propose a multilayered methodology that integrates sentiment analysis, Named Entity Recognition (NER), semantic enrichment with DBpedia, Resource Description Framework (RDF) modeling, and SPARQL querying. The system transforms unstructured text into machine-interpretable knowledge graphs, enabling structured exploration of emotional tone - sentiment, thematic clusters, and conceptual relationships. The main contribution is a comparative evaluation of rule-based and spaCy-based NER approaches on noisy social media text, combined with semantic enrichment that links entities to external knowledge bases. Experimental results on $\mathbf{1, 0 0 0}$ posts show that semantic enrichment improves interpretability and supports knowledge extraction. Compared to existing studies focused mainly on sentiment or frequency analysis, our approach provides deeper semantic insights into online AI discourse.

title: Rüppell’s Fox Optimization Algorithm for Solving the Optimal Power Flow Problem with Renewable Energy Integration
authors: Ahmed H. A. Adam, Mahmoud A. Ali, Salah Kamel, Francisco Jurado
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Power Electronics and Renewable Energy (CPERE)
abstract: Optimal power flow (OPF) is essential for the secure and economical operation of power systems. The integration of renewable energy sources (RESs) adds complexity to this task due to their inherent variability and uncertainty. This study addresses the OPF problem through a hybrid generation system that incorporates thermal units, wind power generators (WPGs), and solar photovoltaic generators (SPGs). The recent nature-inspired optimization technique, Rüppell’s Fox Optimization (RFO), is applied to determine the optimal operating conditions. The developed approach is evaluated using a modified IEEE-30 bus system to measure its performance. Simulation results indicate that RFO achieves lower overall generation costs and faster convergence compared to several established optimization methods. These findings underscore RFO’s potential as an effective and computationally efficient solution for OPF challenges involving renewable energy integration.

title: SAGECN: A Spectral-and-GraphSAGE Enhanced Convolutional Network for Robotic Arm Fault Diagnosis
authors: Weixia Hao, Haowei Wang, Danyang Han, Shuohai Sang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: Modern industrial robotic systems often operate under dynamic working conditions, which can cause faults of motors in robotic arms and further lead to system reliability. However, existing fault diagnosis approaches typically rely on static signal features in combination with fixed thresholds, which limits their ability to capture temporal dynamics and structural dependencies. These methods treat sensor channels independently and lack mechanisms to model the spatiotemporal correlations within sensorial time series, which are critical for detecting subtle and localized fault patterns. To address these challenges mentioned above, this paper proposes a Spectral-and-GraphSAGE Enhanced Convolutional Network (SAGECN). This paper introduces a hybrid graph neural architecture that embeds GraphSAGE-based neighborhood aggregation into a Graph Convolutional Networks (GCN) backbone, enabling joint modeling of global topological structures and localized temporal perturbations. Sensor time-series data are first transformed into structured path graphs using a sliding window mechanism, preserving temporal continuity and directional progression. Then, a multi-stage Graph Neural Network encoder is constructed by stacking GCN and Graph Sample and Aggregate (GraphSAGE) layers, enabling the extraction of both global and local structural features. Finally, top-k pooling is applied for hierarchical node selection and graph-level representation learning. Experimental results on a public dataset from fault-injected motors in robotic arms demonstrate that the proposed model achieves superior performance in fault detection accuracy and generalization compared with existing graph-based models.

title: Design of a Speed Control Algorithm for Switched Reluctance Wind Turbine Generators Based on a Tracking Differentiator
authors: Jiaheng Li, Honghua Wang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: To address the issues of overshoot oscillation and dynamic lag in the speed control of switched reluctance wind turbine generators, a speed closed-loop control method based on a tracking differentiator (TD) is proposed. A TD collaborative optimization framework is constructed, which enables high-precision tracking and differential extraction of noisy speed signals by dynamically adjusting the speed factor and filtering factor—specifically, increasing the filtering factor at low speeds to suppress noise and enhancing the speed factor at high speeds to accelerate tracking. Considering the characteristics of the self-excited asymmetric half-bridge power converter in switched reluctance generator (SRG), an adaptive parameter adjustment function is designed to overcome the lag and jitter issues of fixed-parameter TD under variable-speed operating conditions. Simulation results show that the collaboratively optimized TD controller achieves smoother chopper current transitions during wind speed fluctuations and effectively reduces DC bus voltage ripple compared to conventional TDs, demonstrating advantages in enhancing the dynamic performance and anti-interference capability of SRG.

title: Fully Soft Switched High Step Up Three Level DC-DC Converter with Continuous Input Current for LED Drivers Applications
authors: Hamed Moradmand Jazi, J. Marcos Alonso, Ehsan Adib, Guirguis Z. Abdelmessih, Pablo Quintana-Barcia, Javier Ribas
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Power Electronics and Renewable Energy (CPERE)
abstract: This paper introduces a quasi-three-level high step-up boost converter that integrates multiple performance-enhancing features. Primarily, the inclusion of a Zero-Voltage Transition (ZVT) cell enables all switching devices to operate under soft-switching conditions, thereby minimizing switching losses and enhancing overall efficiency. The proposed configuration leverages coupled inductors along with voltage multiplier cells to achieve a significantly elevated voltage gain. Furthermore, adopting a three-level arrangement effectively lowers the voltage stress imposed on the main switches. To demonstrate the viability of the proposed approach, a hardware prototype is developed. Experimental evaluations, conducted on a 200-W laboratory prototype, confirm superior efficiency compared to conventional three-level converter counterparts.

title: Fault Pattern Recognition for Bearings via Convolutional Sparse Representation of Multi-source Heterogeneous Information
authors: Ruiyao Wan, Ziwei Wang, Haoxuan Zhou, Dingxia Li, Tao Liu, Guangrui Wen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: Bearing fault diagnosis is crucial for ensuring the operational reliability and safety of rotating machinery. However, traditional diagnostic methods face significant challenges: strong background noise often obscures weak fault signals, and reliance on single-sensor information provides an incomplete picture of complex fault states. These limitations can lead to decreased diagnostic accuracy and reliability. To address these issues, this study proposes a novel convolutional sparse bearing fault pattern recognition method based on multi-source heterogeneous information from vibration and sound signals. Firstly, embedding a convolutional sparse representation layer within the deep learning framework, which adaptively extracts key quasi-periodic fault impulses from raw multi-source signals and suppresses noise and irrelevant background features through an end-to-end learned convolutional dictionary and sparse constraints; secondly, designing a novel fusion convolutional layer that integrates standard convolution and dilated convolution to capture local fine structures and broader contextual and multi-scale information in parallel, thereby achieving deep and effective fusion of purified feature streams from different sensors. Finally, a classification stage utilizes these comprehensively fused features to perform the bearing fault diagnosis. Experimental results on multi-source heterogeneous datasets from two bearings types demonstrate that the proposed Multi-source Deep Sparse Representation Network(M-DSRN) method achieves outstanding fault recognition performance, compared with traditional rivals including deep neural networks and Sparse Representation Classification. This fully validates its effectiveness and advancement in achieving high-precision fault diagnosis under conditions involving strong background noise and multiple fault types through enhanced feature extraction and multi-source information fusion.

title: Application of Convolutional Neural Network in Fault Diagnosis of Electric Power Communication Network
authors: Li Liu, Qianglong Meng, Dongqing Zhou, Xiangjun Liu, Hong Tang, Dan Yan, Rongshu Zhang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: In order to understand the application of fault diagnosis in power communication networks, the application of convolutional neural networks in power communication network fault diagnosis is proposed. Firstly, this paper introduces the common fault diagnosis methods of power communication networks, including traditional fault diagnosis technologies and machine learning-based fault diagnosis technologies, and compares their respective advantages and disadvantages. Secondly, the related knowledge of convolutional neural networks is summarized. Convolutional neural networks are mainly composed of convolutional layers, pooling layers, and fully connected layers. Finally, through simulation experiments, convolutional neural networks are compared with long short-term memory networks, recurrent neural networks, residual networks, and Bayesian classification algorithms. The results show that convolutional neural networks have the highest accuracy and stability, with a fault diagnosis accuracy rate of 99.2% and an accuracy standard deviation of 0.916%, providing a certain reference for future intelligent fault diagnosis research in power communication networks.

title: Task-irrelevant Visual Stimuli with Semantic Content Interfere with Auditory Working Memory Retrieval
authors: Yijia Ming, Shilong Yu, Wanlong Liu, Hongtao Yu, Xiaoyu Tang
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Complex Medical Engineering (CME)
abstract: This study investigated the effect of task-irrelevant modality stimuli with or without semantic content on working memory retrieval by adopting delayed matching to sample paradigm. The results showed that under semantic conditions, the speed of responses to cross-modality congruent was slower than unrelated, indicating task-irrelevant modality information entered into working memory retrieval, leading to interference with auditory retrieval but absent under non-semantic conditions. During retrieval phase, the presence of task-irrelevant semantically congruent visual stimulus rapidly triggered memory reactivation, thereby causing interference. However, non-semantic stimuli lacked long-term associative strength, less triggering automatic encoding.

title: Stochastic Wireless Signal Generation Using a VAE With Statistical Latent Sampling
authors: Muhammad Taqiyuddin, Yuhei Nagao, Masayuki Kurosaki, Hiroshi Ochi
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Information Technology, Computer, and Electrical Engineering (ICITACEE)
abstract: In wireless signal classification, collecting large-scale labeled datasets is often impractical due to hardware limitations, privacy concerns, and environmental variability. To address this, we propose a stochastic signal generation framework based on a pretrained Variational Autoencoder (VAE). Our approach utilizes global latent statistics-mean and variance-derived from real signal encodings to generate synthetic signals through decoder sampling. Specifically, we implement this framework using a Nouveau VAE (NVAE), which offers a hierarchical latent structure well-suited for complex time-series data. Latent vectors are sampled from a Gaussian distribution formed from the learned latent statistics and decoded into synthetic I/Q signals. This method allows lightweight and controlled signal generation without retraining. Experimental results demonstrate that the generated signals exhibit realistic time-domain and spectral properties and achieve high classification accuracy when evaluated using a CNN-based UAV signal classifier. This confirms the utility of VAE-based generation for data augmentation in signal classification scenarios.

title: Hybrid Integration of MAVlink Telemetry and Sensor Data Via REST API for Real-Time UAV-Based Fire Detection Monitoring
authors: Finodya Yahdun, Dania Eridani, Rinta Kridalukmana, Ike Pertiwi Windasari
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Information Technology, Computer, and Electrical Engineering (ICITACEE)
abstract: Forest and land fires pose significant global challenges, necessitating prompt and efficient detection to mitigate their devastating impacts. Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) equipped with advanced sensors offer a promising solution for real-time fire monitoring in inaccessible terrains. However, existing UAV communication systems often suffer from fragmented data streams due to the independent operation of telemetry protocols like MAVLink and web-based data transmission via REST API. This paper proposes a hybrid integration system for real-time UAV-based fire detection monitoring, addressing the crucial need for unified and comprehensive data. Our approach centralises onboard data fusion on a Raspberry Pi companion computer, where MAVLink telemetry is intelligently merged with environmental sensor data and fire detection results. This fused data is transmitted to a remote web server using a structured REST API with a timestamp-based JSON payload. The proposed system design enhances data completeness and cohesion, minimises latency, and improves real-time situational awareness by providing a unified data source for monitoring personnel. This integrated solution is expected to significantly improve the responsiveness and effectiveness of UAV-based fire detection systems, despite facing challenges related to onboard computational resources, network reliability, and security, which are addressed with specific mitigation strategies and outlined as directions for future work.

title: Integrating Multi-center Blood Samples for Disease Marker Screening Using Heterogeneous Federated Meta-learning
authors: Lv Kanchen
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Complex Medical Engineering (CME)
abstract: In order to solve the problem of insufficient model generalization ability due to heterogeneity of multi-center blood data and low efficiency of cross-center knowledge transfer under privacy constraints, an adaptive federated meta-learning framework is introduced. Dynamic feature alignment is used to eliminate distribution differences between centers and retain biological pathway features related to disease markers; meta-knowledge distillation is combined to extract low-dimensional meta-features shared across centers to enhance the generalization ability of the model; at the same time, adaptive federated aggregation under the attention mechanism is introduced. Experiments show that the model has an accuracy of 84.8% for LC (Lung Cancer) marker screening, and the enrichment P values of various diseases are all below 0.05, providing a feasible solution for robust screening of disease markers under multi-center collaboration.

title: FUSTT: Forecasting Using Spatio-Temporal Transformers for Predicting Marine Stressors of Blue-Carbon Ecosystems
authors: Chinmay Kapoor, Bhan Singh, Navneet Popli, Mohammad Mamun
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Marine stressors such as temperature, salinity, turbidity, and chlorophyll strongly influence the health of Blue Carbon Ecosystems (BCEs) and play a critical role in global climate regulation. Accurate long-term forecasting of these stressors enables baseline construction, anomaly detection, and restoration planning. In this study, we present FUSTT (Forecasting Using Spatio-Temporal Transformer), a deep learning model- derived from making efficient additions to the original Transformer architecture, specifically for multivariate long-term forecasting of marine parameters. FUSTT integrates a dual-encoder design, Dimensional Flipping Layer (DFL), and Flagged Dual Stage Attention (FDSA), enabling the model to capture complex temporal and cross-variable dependencies. Using real-world datasets collected by Ocean Networks Canada (ONC) at four representative Salish Sea locations (Discovery Passage, Burrard Inlet, Baynes Sound, and Boundary Pass), FUSTT consistently outperformed baseline models. It achieved 15–33% lower error than traditional transformer architectures and 30–40% higher accuracy compared to domain-specific models such as LSTM and CNN-LSTM, while also delivering faster training with minimal trade-offs. These results demonstrate FUSTT's capability to provide highly accurate and computationally efficient predictions of marine stressors at operational ecological monitoring sites, offering a practical foundation for advancing BCE management and climate resilience.

title: Detection of Multi-stage Attacks through Attack Pattern Segmentation
authors: Seonghyeon Gong, Jake Cho, Kyuwon Ken Choi
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Advanced cyberattack patterns threatening network assets employ various attack vectors, multi-stage attack processes, and diverse penetration strategies. Among these multi-stage attack patterns, many exhibit behaviors similar to normal activities on the network or patterns commonly observed across multiple attack patterns. This tendency of advanced attacks makes it difficult for artificial intelligence (AI) models to learn the data distribution, allowing intrusion detection systems (IDS) to be bypassed and complicating the construction of effective IDS training datasets. To address these issues, this paper proposes an IDS system that segments and identifies multi-stage attack patterns into detailed sub-patterns, enabling effective classification and detection of multi-stage attacks. The proposed approach consists of attack pattern segmentation using a clustering algorithm and a detection model utilizing a stacking ensemble. The attack pattern segmentation method uses the inter-class silhouette metric to segment network flows related to attacks and subdivide the attack patterns. Using a stacking ensemble, the detection technique determines the final attack pattern by leveraging machine learning models that ensure explainability using the segmented attack patterns. The proposed approach was validated by comparing the detection accuracy of multi-stage attack patterns against recent baselines using the public benchmark dataset CIC-IDS-2018. Experimental results showed that the proposed approach achieved an average F1 score of 0.9732 for multi-stage attack patterns, demonstrating higher performance than recent baseline methods and effectively detecting sophisticated multi-stage attacks.

title: Heterogeneity-Aware Federated Learning for Medical Image Classification with Dynamic Parameter Optimization
authors: Pranab Sahoo, Ashutosh Tripathi, Sriparna Saha, Samrat Mondal
publish: IEEE Transactions on Artificial Intelligence
abstract: The development of robust artificial intelligence based models for medical applications necessitates extensive datasets from multiple institutions. However, privacy concerns often hinder data sharing across these institutions. Federated learning (FL) emerges as a promising paradigm, facilitating collaborative model training while safeguarding data privacy. Nevertheless, the efficacy of FL is constrained by two fundamental challenges: system heterogeneity and statistical heterogeneity. To address these challenges, recent studies have incorporated regularization terms into the objective function, aiming to improve the stability of the method. While these approaches have shown promising results, our study reveals that the fixed and manual calculation of the regularization term constrains its effectiveness.
