In this paper, we introduce FedDPO, a heterogeneity-aware federated learning approach that employs a reinforcement learning-driven strategy to dynamically determine an adaptive regularization term for each client’s objective function. This regularization term is tailored to individual client states, including data distribution, system specifications, and performance feedback, enabling regularized local model updates that account for heterogeneity across the federated network. Additionally, FedDPO incorporates local batch normalization to mitigate the impact of heterogeneous data. Extensive experiments on two medical and one non-medical image classification tasks demonstrate FedDPO’s consistent superiority over several baselines across diverse heterogeneity settings. Furthermore, the theoretical analysis provides formal guarantees of FedDPO’s efficacy compared to manual and heuristic proximal term selection methods.

title: Guest Editorial Special Issue on Intelligent IoT for Sustainable Agriculture and Food Industries
authors: Yuemin Ding, Zhibo Pang, Yu Liu, Kan Yu, Fei Pan
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal

title: Orthogonal Doppler Frequency Modulation over Doubly Selective Channels
authors: Chong Zhang, Jinhong Yuan, Yiqing Zhou, Jinglin Shi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications
abstract: In this paper, we present a novel orthogonal Doppler frequency modulation (ODFM) to meet the challenging requirements of high-mobility communications. Firstly, we revisit the basic concepts of multicarrier modulations (MCMs) and discuss the capability to explore both time and frequency diversity in doubly selective channels for the most popular MCMs. We then illustrate how ODFM maps information symbols into Doppler-frequency domain and converts them into time-delay domain for transmission, where we show ODFM has the potential to exploit both delay space (frequency) and Doppler space (time) diversity. Specifically, we propose two types of ODFM schemes using the conventional time-frequency domain orthogonal pulses (TFOP-ODFM) and the novel delay-Doppler domain orthogonal pulses (DDOP-ODFM). We give exact channel input-output relations (IORs) in the Doppler-frequency domain of these two ODFM schemes and show their properties in efficient channels, implementation complexity, and others. Subsequently, we simulate the performance of these ODFM schemes with other MCMs, such as orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (OFDM), and orthogonal time frequency space (OTFS) modulation. In particular, we investigate the performance of the TFOP-ODFM in the physical downlink shared channel of the Five-Generation New Radio (5G NR) link, where TFOP-ODFM show better performance than OFDM and OTFS.

title: SceneCluster: Interactive Scene Synthesis by Clustering Groups of Furniture Objects
authors: Shao-Kui Zhang, Liang Yue, Haoran Zhang, Han-Xi Zhu, Yong-Liang Yang, Song-Hai Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: Scene synthesis is crucial to computer graphics. However, the current interactive scene synthesis methods usually cost the user too much time and interactions to edit objects. This paper presents a new interactive scene synthesis method that alleviates the designer from interacting with the 3D scene and its objects. Designers only need to select an object group in an independent panel through coarse clustering and fine clustering. Then, the furniture objects will be automatically added to the scene. This paper proposes a two-level clustering that applies the Affinity Propagation Algorithm (APA) to groups of furniture objects such that the object groups can even be clustered without linear representations, latent encoding, etc. To fully apply the APA, we also propose quantitatively measuring how different the two layouts are, i.e., how quantitatively the arrangements of two object groups differ. Experiments first show that our method is more user-friendly and interactively efficient than other interactive synthesis methods. By comparing our method with recent automatic scene synthesis methods, we demonstrate that our methods still have competitive plausibility. We also verify that our method does not harm the diversity and generalization of 3D scenes.

title: Enhanced Slow-Light Phenomenon in Dot-Bragg Gratings through Offset Engineering
authors: Qingtao Chen, Jean-Sébastien Boisvert, Foroogh Jafari, Mohammad S. Sharawi, Sébastien Loranger, Raman Kashyap
publish: Journal of Lightwave Technology
abstract: We demonstrate enhanced slow-light phenomenon in dot-Bragg grating (DBGs) inscribed by femtosecond laser (FSL) in bulk glass through offset engineering. Two types of first-order DBGs, Model-I and Model-II, are inscribed based on single-laser-pass waveguide (SLPWG) and double-laser-pass waveguides (DLPWG), respectively. In Model-I DBG, the effective light-guiding occurs in the shell region with a refractive index (RI) change of ∼2×10⁻<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>, while the core region exhibits a smaller RI change less than 0.4×10⁻<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>. The enhanced slow-light phenomena are achieved at a 5 μm offset, yielding a transmission dip of 6.7 dB, a slow-down factor (SDF) of 1.21, and a maximum group delay (GD) of 33 ps. In Model-II DBG, the two-pass inscription combined with center distance adjustment in DLPWG enhances the core RI change by a factor of 2 over SLPWG, with a value of 0.8×10⁻<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>, while the shell RI change decreases to ∼1×10⁻<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup> due to the lower repetition rate. With offset optimization, the transmission dip in Model-II DBG nearly doubles, up to 12.5 dB at a 5 μm offset with a 5 μm center distance, leading to slow-light effect with an SDF of 1.45 and a maximum GD of 43 ps—representing an 87% improvement in transmission, and 20% and 30% improvements in SDF and GD, respectively, compared to Model-I DBG. In addition, a time delay of ∼7 ps is obtained by comparing the detected signal pulse at the Bragg wavelength of Model-II DBG with the signal pulses at wavelengths tuned near the reflection edges, which represents an overestimated value for the slow-light effect. These results demonstrate that the two DBG models hold significant potential for optical filtering in communication and sensing, as well as in optical networks for data traffic management and dynamic reconfiguration of optical channels.

title: Accelerating Adaptive Diffusion and Uncertainty Modeling for Underwater Image Enhancement
authors: Xiuna Zeng, Jiaao Peng, Zhenqi Fu, Linyu Fan, Xiaotong Tu, Yue Huang, Xinghao Ding
publish: IEEE Transactions on Multimedia
abstract: Underwater image enhancement (UIE) aims to mitigate wavelength-dependent absorption and multi-path scattering effects, enabling the recovery of natural colors and rich details. Despite notable progress, consistently achieving high-quality enhancement in both fidelity and perceptual clarity remains a fundamental challenge. To address this, we propose the Laplacian domain Dual-Focus Enhancer (DFE), an innovative framework consisting of two stages: adaptive diffusion-accelerated low frequency enhancement (ADALE) and progressive uncertainty driven high-frequency enhancement (PUHE). Specifically, DFE applies a Laplacian transform to decouple the frequency-specific degradations in underwater images, supporting fidelity- and clarity-oriented enhancement along separate pathways. To facilitate high-fidelity restoration, ADALE incorporates an HSV guided optimization mechanism (HSV-OM) to establish a robust color and brightness calibration baseline for the low-frequency diffusion model, adaptively managing basic degradations with minimal sampling steps. Furthermore, to enhance contour and detail perception, PUHE models the uncertainty of reference textures and integrates it with feature modulation to progressively reconstruct multi-scale high-frequency structures. The multi reference underwater texture enhancement (MUTE) dataset fur ther improves image clarity. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our DFE outperforms state-of-the-art (SOTA) methods in both quantitative metrics and visual quality.

title: Partition Map-Based Fast Block Partitioning for VVC Inter Coding_supp1-3632639.pdf
authors: Dong Liu
publish: N/A
abstract: Among the new techniques of Versatile Video Coding (VVC), the quadtree with nested multi-type tree (MTT) block structure yields significant coding gains by providing more flexible block partitioning patterns. However, the recursive partition search in the VVC encoder increases the encoder complexity substantially. To address this issue, we propose a partition map-based algorithm to pursue fast block partitioning in inter coding. Based on our previous work on partition map-based methods for intra coding, we analyze the characteristics of VVC inter coding and improve the partition map by incorporating an MTT mask for early termination. Next, we develop a neural network that uses both spatial and temporal features to predict the partition map. It consists of several special designs, including stacked top-down and bottom-up processing, quantization parameter modulation layers, and partitioning-adaptive warping. Furthermore, we present a dual-threshold decision scheme to achieve a fine-grained trade-off between complexity reduction and rate-distortion performance loss. The experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves an average 51.30% encoding time saving with a 2.12% Bjøntegaard-delta-bit-rate under the random access configuration. The source code is publicly available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/ustc-ivclab/IPM</uri>.

title: TBNet: A Chest X-ray Classifier Supporting Image Segmentation with Self-attention Mechanism for Secondary Tuberculosis Detection
authors: Muhammad Irhamsyah, Roslidar Roslidar, Mulkan Azhary, Qurrata A’yuni, Nasaruddin Nasaruddin, Fitri Arnia, Khairul Munadi
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Several studies have been conducted to develop tuberculosis detection using artificial intelligence-based chest radiographs (CXR). However, CXR images also contain atypical information on pulmonary tuberculosis that could affect the accuracy of the learning. This work aims to identify the regions of interest (RoI) in CXR images that support information on secondary pulmonary tuberculosis in the upper lung area and train a vision transformer network to build a robust CXR classifier. The dataset used in this study consists of 1,304 annotated CXR images. The ground-truth masks of the upper one-third lung region were manually created using ImageJ. The methods include enhancing the CXR image using Contrast-limited Adaptive Histogram Equalization before extracting RoI using the Attention U-Net segmentation algorithm. The informative CXR images were then fed into the self-attention network of the vision transformer (ViT-L/16). The results show that the segmentation model achieves 100% accuracy in identifying important areas on images that have undergone image contrast pre-processing. The classifier model exhibits stable performance during training, achieving an accuracy of 97.75%. The test results on 260 images, 130 normal and 130 TB, showthat TBNet achieves 97.04% accuracy, 97.96% sensitivity, 96.92% specificity, and 96.94% precision. TBNet achieves a high accuracy rate and has a size of 127 MB for segmentation and 1.12 GB for classification; thus, practically, the proposed TBNet can be deployed to support tuberculosis detection system. These findings contribute to research on medical image analysis by highlighting the importance of region-specific annotation and transformer-based architectures for secondary tuberculosis detection.

title: Tactile-Sensitive Artificial Skin for Multiaxial Force Detection and Texture Recognition
authors: Chern Yang Leong, Jingxian Cui, Xin Cheng, Lin Htein, Hwa-Yaw Tam
publish: Journal of Lightwave Technology
abstract: Tactile perception, particularly at the fingertips, is fundamental to human dexterity, enabling fine motor control and reliable manipulation of objects through the precise real-time modulation of normal and shear forces based on encountered frictional conditions. To bridge this capability gap in robotics, a novel tactile-sensitive artificial skin is designed to significantly enhance robot-object interaction and environmental recognition. The artificial skin, fabricated from a 2-mm thick silicone elastomer membrane embedded with polymer optical fiber Bragg grating (FBG) sensor array, achieves large measurement range (detecting forces up to 10 N normal and ±4 N shear) and high sensitivity for multiaxial forces. The skin's performance was evaluated through tests involving normal force loading of up to 10 N and shear force loading around ±4 N using a three-axis translation gantry. Additionally, the study examines slip-induced vibrations on various textured surfaces. A multi-input multi-output convolutional neural network (MIMO-CNN) was developed to simultaneously estimate force and recognize textures based on multichannel FBG inputs. The MIMO-CNN achieved an R-squared value of 0.96 for force estimation and classification accuracy of 94% for texture recognition across 20 fabric samples. These findings highlight the potential of tactile-sensitive artificial skin to enhance robotic perception and manipulation, paving the way for more advanced humanoid robotic systems.

title: A Fly-Crawl-Fly UAV for Full-Circumference Inspection of Non-Magnetic Pipes via Thrust Adhesion
authors: Robert Watson, Taiyi Zhao, Dayi Zhang, Gordon Dobie, Charles MacLeod, S. Gareth Pierce
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: Unmanned Aerial Vehicles have become common tools for remote visual screening of in situ structures. To further improve structural insight, cut downtime, and reduce human hazard exposure, airborne inspection offers a means to deploy established Non-Destructive Evaluation methods in physical surface contact. This may significantly benefit elevated pipework inspection, where aging-related degradation causes critical failures but asset scale and inaccessibility render frequent manual assessment cost-prohibitive. To this end, a novel multirotor-crawler hybrid vehicle is developed from rigid-body modeling, through an offline energy-optimization interaction control scheme, to an experimental prototype. In a unique fly-crawl-fly inspection mode, this platform may crawl around the full circumference of pipes and other cylindrical assets following initial flight access. A multidirectional array of reversible thrust, fixed-pitch, propellers yield generic surface adhesion without magnetism or specific grasping features. This stable, short-reach, interaction relaxes control requirements and aids re-positioning during target contact. Laboratory testing demonstrates mean absolute deviation below 1.03 mm during arbitrary circumferential position holding and successful scanning around the target at 0.075±0.011 m/s. Multiple landings show repeatable successful transitions from flight to interaction at a mean distance of 12.68 mm from a target point. Performance and operational confidence bounds are thereby quantified.

title: Trust-Driven Resource Trading for DAG Blockchain-Aided Mobile Edge Computing Networks: A Game Theoretic Approach
authors: Weiwei Yang, Lixin Luo, Long Shi, Jinkai Zheng, Yanfeng Zhang
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: Mobile edge computing (MEC), integrated with directed acyclic graph (DAG) blockchain technology, has emerged as a promising paradigm for ensuring secure and efficient resource trading between IoT user equipment (UEs) and edge service providers (ESPs). However, due to the open and heterogeneous nature of MEC networks, ESPs are susceptible to malicious attacks, rendering resource trading information potentially unreliable. While DAG blockchains ensure the reliability of on-chain data, they fail to guarantee the trustworthiness of ESPs and cannot effectively incentivize their participation in resource trading and blockchain consensus. To address these challenges, we develop a trust-driven resource trading framework for DAG blockchain-aided MEC networks. In this framework, we first design an off-chain trust-driven resource pricing mechanism, in which the resource price set by each ESP is positively correlated with its trust value. In addition, we design an on-chain trust-driven consensus mechanism, wherein the on-chain security of transactions published by each ESP is positively associated with its trust level. To enable UEs to better evaluate the on-chain transaction security, we design a novel metric termed transaction security satisfaction and incorporate it into the utility function of UEs. Furthermore, we model the resource trading between UEs and ESPs as a multi-leader multi-follower Stackelberg game, and verify the existence and uniqueness of its equilibrium. To maximize the utilities of both ESPs and UEs, we propose a backward induction-based iterative algorithm to jointly optimize resource pricing, resource demand, and offloading strategy. Numerical simulations validate the effectiveness of our proposed scheme, demonstrating its superior performance compared with baseline schemes.

title: A Differential Cluster-Analysis-Based Multibaseline Phase Unwrapping Algorithm
authors: Zhen Wang, Xuemao Li, Chao Xing, Zhenfang Li
publish: 2024 5th China International SAR Symposium (CISS)
abstract: The utilisation of multibaseline phase unwrapping can facilitate the processing of data in regions with discontinuous terrain, which is a challenge encountered when employing single-baseline phase unwrapping techniques. This paper introduces differential processing of multiple interferograms into the cluster-analysis(CA)-based multibaseline phase unwrapping algorithm. By modifying the method of calculating the number of clustered groups and examining the factors influencing the number of pixels within each cluster group, it can be demonstrated that the differential CA(diff-CA)-based algorithm exhibits enhanced robustness. Furthermore, the baseline relationship of the proposed algorithm is also constrained. Ultimately, the superiority of diff-CA method over the conventional CA method is substantiated through the simulated experiment.

title: Hybrid Feature Fused Few-Shot Learning for CSI-Based Adaptive Beam Prediction
authors: Chaiyawut Thiangkate, Shimpei Nishiyama, Dipanita Chakraborty, Minoru Okada, Kundjanasith Thonglek, Pattara Leelaprute, Arnon Rungsawang, Bundit Manaskasemsak, Kosin Chamnongthai
publish: 2025 24th International Symposium on Communications and Information Technologies (ISCIT)
abstract: Accurate beam prediction is essential for efficient and adaptive beamforming in next-generation wireless networks, particularly in dynamic user environments. However, conventional deep learning methods often rely on large labeled datasets and require costly retraining when deployed across varying scenarios. In this work, we propose a hybrid attention-based feature learning approach within a Prototypical Network framework for adaptive beam selection from the Channel State Information (CSI) of user equipment (UE). The model integrates attentionenhanced convolutional layers and multi-head Transformer encoders to capture both spatial and sequential features from CSI. A variational autoencoder (VAE) is used to regularize the latent feature space, improving generalization to unseen environments. By leveraging few-shot learning, the model constructs class prototypes that represent beam directions, enabling rapid adaptation to new scenarios with minimal supervision. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed approach achieves competitive beam prediction accuracy while significantly reducing training overhead, making it a practical solution for real-time, low-latency beamforming in diverse and previously unseen deployment environments.

title: Artificial Neural Networks for Solving Partial Differential Equations: A Deep Learning Approach
authors: Soumaya Nouna, Assia Nouna, Ilyas Tammouch, Abdelamine Elouafi
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: This study explores the use of artificial neural networks (ANNs) to solve nonlinear partial differential equations (PDEs) arising in reaction-diffusion systems. Two variants of the Newell-Whitehead-Segel equation are examined, each involving distinct nonlinearitiesone cubic and the other quadraticalong with different boundary conditions. The NeuroDiffEq framework is employed, which encodes initial and boundary conditions directly into the neural network architecture. Learning is driven by minimizing the residuals of the PDE, eliminating the need for labeled data. Numerical experiments, supported by comparisons with analytical solutions and 3D surface plots, demonstrate the methods accuracy. The results highlight the capability of neural networks to approximate complex PDE solutions effectively, offering a mesh-free alternative to conventional numerical approaches. This study underscores the potential of physics-informed neural networks to address a broad class of nonlinear PDEs with both precision and efficiency.

title: Intelligent Typing of Gangrenous Cholecystitis Based on LSTM-XGBoost Integrated Model
authors: Dingqi Zhang
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Complex Medical Engineering (CME)
abstract: Aiming at the difficulties in clinical typing of Gangrenous Cholecystitis (GC) and the insufficient capture of dynamic progression features by traditional diagnostic methods, this study proposes an innovative LSTM-XGBoost integrated learning model. By integrating temporal dynamic features and static clinical indicators, this model achieves intelligent and precise typing of GC. The study collected clinical data of GC patients from multiple centers, including laboratory temporal indicators (dynamic monitoring data such as WBC, CRP, and bilirubin) and static features (CT radiomics and clinical baseline data). The LSTM network was used to model temporal data to capture the evolution patterns of inflammatory indicators, while the XGBoost[] algorithm was employed to analyze static features and select key predictive factors. Finally, a joint model was constructed through a feature-level fusion strategy. The results showed that the LSTM-XGBoost model performed the best on the test set (accuracy of $90 \%$, AUC $=0.96$), significantly outperforming traditional methods ($\mathbf{P}\lt 0.05$). Specific findings include: among temporal features, the 48-hour change rate of CRP has the highest contribution to predicting gangrene progression; among static features, the proportion of low enhancement areas in the gallbladder wall on CT is a core imaging biomarker for typing. The model can effectively identify high-risk subtypes (e.g., ischemic vs. infectious types).By integrating multimodal data, the LSTM-XGBoost integrated model successfully achieved dynamic risk stratification and precise typing of GC, providing a reliable intelligent decision-making tool for early clinical intervention.

title: Research on Collaborative Operation Methodologies and Strategies for New-Energy Engineering Vehicle Fleets in Plateau Railway Tunnel Muck Removal
authors: Chen Jin, Xi Cao, Pu Guo, Qiuchen Yun, Linjuan Zhang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: In high-altitude railway construction zones characterized by extreme elevations and ecologically sensitive environments, the operational limitations of conventional diesel-powered construction machinery become pronounced. Conversely, electric-powered equipment demonstrates superior adaptability under such conditions. Focusing on the mucking operations, a critical phase involving multi-vehicle coordination and intricate logistical processes that dictate overall project efficiency and cost-effectiveness, this study investigates collaborative scheduling strategies for battery-electric engineering vehicles in plateau railway tunnel construction. By establishing a multi-objective optimization framework integrating energy consumption, equipment utilization, and ventilation coordination, the proposed methodology demonstrates a 23.36% reduction in construction costs through empirical case studies, thereby empirically validating the model's efficacy. This research contributes both theoretical insights and actionable guidelines for implementing energy-efficient equipment synergies in extreme-altitude infrastructure projects.

title: Research and Application of Electric Installation Technology "I" Type Insulated Sheath
authors: Feng Zhao, Ningbo Cai, Bin Liu
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: Tripping due to insulation failure in power systems is a critical challenge to the safety of energy infrastructure. As a key insulation component, the integrity of substation "I" insulation sheaths is critical to prevent equipment flashover failures. Statistical analysis shows that about 16% of substation tripping accidents are directly related to insulation sheath defects, of which aging off is the main failure mode. In this study, a mechanical locking principle-based insulating sheath installation technology is proposed, which systematically solves the problems of precise positioning, fixation and safe operation in an electrified environment by establishing a three-dimensional mechanical transfer model. The system integrates the elastic pre-tensioned "telescopic column + positioning hole" locking mechanism, "4 horizontal and 4 vertical" orthogonal grid adaptive adjustment system and high-precision closed-loop control module to realize sub-millimeter positioning accuracy. Experimental results show that the system maintains 100% structural stability under 4N radial tension and 8N axial pressure, and the maximum deformation is 0.21mm; the process capability index of force control accuracy is Cp=1.59 (n=100, σ=0.17), which reaches the level of industrial-grade precise control. In the field verification of 19 substations, the technology reduced the single-phase insulation sheathing installation time from the traditional 306 minutes to 5.3±0.3 minutes, while eliminating the need for power outages, significantly improving the efficiency of grid operation and maintenance and system reliability.

title: Context-Aware Advisor System for Crowded Environments
authors: Aisha Alkandari, Sa'ed Abed, Amnah Alrashed, Afnan Alrumaidhi, Nawal Almutairi, Reem Alenezi
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Information Technology, Computer, and Electrical Engineering (ICITACEE)
abstract: In recent years, the number of smart devices connected to the internet has significantly increased and has strongly influenced daily living. This study utilizes Internet of Things (IoTs) and big data applications to promote smart and comfortable living. In this study, we integrated two technologies, namely, IoT and a context-aware system, to develop a smart system that tracks user trajectories in a crowded environment. We developed a smart context-aware advisor system for airports where congestion is a major issue. This smart system provides individuals pertinent scheduling information that reduced walking distances by up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 4. 3}$</tex> meters and improved task sequencing, especially for passengers requiring multiple adjustments.

title: Cybersecurity in Smart Cities: A Review of Theoretical Models, Emerging Threats, and Defense Strategies
authors: Genadiy Gospodinov, Lyubomir Gotsev, Tamara Ristovska, Svetlana Syarova, Viktoriya Angelova, Tito Titov
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Technologies, Systems and Services in Telecommunications (TELSIKS)
abstract: This paper reviews theoretical cybersecurity approaches in smart cities, categorizing classical, systemoriented, and innovative models. It highlights current gaps, such as limited Al integration and regulatory fragmentation, and proposes a novel framework combining Game Theory, Complex Systems Theory, and Blockchain to enhance resilience and adaptive security in smart city infrastructures.

title: A Barrage Jamming Suppression Method for High-Resolution Wide-Swath SAR Systems on Correlation Filtering
authors: Hongtao Zhan, Qiang Zhao, Yan Feng, Shuangxi Zhang, Shaohui Mei, Yuanjie Zhi
publish: 2024 5th China International SAR Symposium (CISS)
abstract: The azimuth multichannel synthetic aperture radar (SAR) increases swath width by reducing the pulse repetition frequency (PRF), thus enabling the simultaneous achievement of high-resolution and wide-swath (HRWS) imaging. However, the quality of multichannel SAR images will suffer from electromagnetic jamming in the electronic antagonism environment, resulting in the loss of scene information. In this paper, we present a novel interference suppression method rooted in correlation filtering. First, multi -channel data undergoes multi -beam formation, and then one of the beam echoes is used as the interference matching signal; the other beam echo is correlation filtered to obtain the suppressed beam echo. Finally, inverse processing is applied to the multi-beam data, yielding interference-suppressed multi -channel data. Simulation confirms that this method effectively mitigates interference and obtains the HRWS SAR images.

title: Multiband Clustering Weighted Envelope Spectrum for Axle-Box Bearing Fault Diagnosis
authors: Junsheng Xin, Zaigang Chen, Xin Chen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: The service state of axle-box bearings in rail vehicles directly affects the safety of train operation. Current fault diagnosis methods based on spectral coherence (SCoh) often ignore the key information in the discrete fault bands excited by bearing faults, which reduces the diagnostic performance for weak faults. To solve this problem, this paper proposes a fault diagnosis method based on multiband clustering weighted envelope spectrum (MCWES). First, the original SCoh is reconstructed, and the proposed autocorrelation cycle ratio (ACR) calibration algorithm is utilized to achieve automatic identification of potential fault frequencies within each spectral frequency slice (SFS). Subsequently, a weighting metric is constructed to evaluate the richness of fault information in each SFS to determine the initial central frequency band for the optimization process. Next, an equal-proportional extended optimization structure is designed to generate EPEOgram for detecting the optimal demodulation bands in each initial center band. Finally, optimal demodulation bands (ODBs) with similar potential cyclic frequencies (PCFs) are clustered to construct MCWES for efficient detection of bearing faults. The results of axle-box bearing bench tests on rail vehicles show that the proposed method can fully integrate bearing fault information in different narrow frequency bands without relying on nominal fault cycle information. Compared with the three advanced methods recently proposed, the method identifies the axle-box bearing fault characteristics and their harmonics more effectively, which significantly improves the diagnostic performance of weak faults.

title: A Suitable Range Selection Method for MED Filter Length and Its Application
authors: Jiajiu Sheng, Guo Chen, Zhiyuan He, Yuxiang Kang, Hao Wang, Xunkai Wei
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: Minimal Entropy Deconvolution (MED) can mitigate the influence of complex transmission paths, but its effectiveness depends on the choice of the filter length. In this study, we investigate the relationship between the signal characteristics and MED performance as the filter length increases, aiming to determine a suitable range of the filter length. First, we construct various indices based on four different characteristics: periodicity, kurtosis, cyclostationarity, and entropy. Then, two indices that can reflect the filter effect are designed to discuss the correlations between the characteristic indices and the filter performance. Analysis of both simulation data and measured signals from an aircraft accessory gearbox reveals that as the filter length increases, the filter performance can be categorized into four distinct zones: the initial barren zone, the abundant zone, the fluctuation zone, and the final barren zone. By combining the jump points of characteristic indexes, we can accurately delineate the boundary of each zone. Selecting the filter length within the abundant zone will result in feature-rich results, making the MED effective for fault diagnosis.

title: Broken Wire Damage Identification Method for Elevator Steel Belts Based on a 2D Wave Model
authors: Yimin Wei, Xiaoli Leng, Qikang Lai
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: With the rapid development of high-rise buildings, elevator steel belts have been widely adopted due to their advantages of low weight, high strength, small bending radius, and low operating noise. However, during long-term service, internal steel wires are prone to fracture, forming broken wire defects that compromise structural integrity and threaten operational safety. Existing detection methods such as magnetic flux leakage (MFL), ultrasonic guided waves, and eddy currents often rely heavily on external sensors, which suffer from complex deployment and limited sensitivity, making it difficult to reveal the internal damage mechanism through structural response. This study proposes a damage identification method based on two-dimensional wave modeling combined with finite difference simulation. The anisotropic composite nature of the steel belt is first homogenized using the rule of mixtures, and a 2D in-plane wave equation is derived. The control equation is discretized using an explicit central difference scheme, and time-domain responses, frequency spectra, envelope curves, and energy distributions are obtained for both healthy and damaged cases. Simulation results demonstrate that broken wire damage leads to reduced wave speed, decreased response amplitude, frequency downshifts, and energy dispersion, all indicating strong damage sensitivity. The proposed method relies on the intrinsic wave response of the structure itself without requiring external sensors, offering a promising theoretical and technical approach for early damage identification in elevator steel belts.

title: Change Detection in SAR Images Using HDBSCAN Clustering
authors: Ahidjo Abdoulaye, Shaohui Mei, Alejandro C. Frery, Mingyang Ma
publish: 2024 5th China International SAR Symposium (CISS)
abstract: This paper proposes an approach for change detection in Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) images, based on the Hierarchical Density-Based Spatial Clustering of Applications with Noise (HDBSCAN) algorithm. We first normalize multi-temporal SAR images, and then apply HDBSCAN to identify significant clusters and generate a difference image to highlight changes. We cluster the results and categorize them into high probability, low probability, and noise clusters, producing a refined change map. Evaluation metrics, including precision, recall, F1 score, accuracy, and kappa coefficient, demonstrate that this approach enhances detection accuracy, with practical applications in environmental monitoring and urban planning.

title: Transformer Intelligent Fault Diagnosis Based on Knowledge-Enhanced Data Generation and Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks
authors: Ying Liu, Xiao Liang, Pengfei Tang, Sai Zhang, Zhihao Wang, Shaohe Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: Transformer fault diagnosis is vital for ensuring the reliability and safety of power systems. Dissolved Gas Analysis (DGA) serves as a key technique in this field. However, the scarcity and imbalance of DGA data significantly hinder the performance of conventional diagnostic models. To address this challenge, we propose a novel diagnostic framework that integrates Knowledge-Enhanced Data Generation with Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks (KAN). By incorporating domain-specific knowledge into the Generative Adversarial Networks (GAN), the generator is guided to produce high-quality synthetic DGA samples, effectively mitigating data scarcity and imbalance. Simultaneously, KAN is employed for its superior nonlinear modeling capabilities to achieve high-precision fault type identification. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method significantly improves diagnostic performance on real-world DGA datasets, offering an efficient and reliable solution for intelligent transformer fault detection.

title: On the Robust Stability of Battery-Supercapacitor Hybrid Power Sources in Electric Vehicles
authors: Adnan Rafi Al Tahtawi, Arief Syaichu Rohman, Pranoto Hidaya Rusmin, Arwindra Rizqiawan
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Information Technology, Computer, and Electrical Engineering (ICITACEE)
abstract: This paper introduces a polytopic modeling approach for the battery-supercapacitor hybrid power sources (Batt-SC HPS) in electric vehicles, along with its Lyapunov-based stability analysis. The proposed model captures the nonlinear behavior of the Batt-SC HPS by leveraging a Linear Parameter Varying (LPV) framework within a convex set. In this paper, the converter duty cycles are treated as time-varying parameters, enabling the model to represent the system dynamics across all possible input conditions. This is facilitated by the intrinsic dependency between the system's state variables and the duty cycles. This approach enables the system to be modeled in the form of a polytopic-LPV. The robustness of the system is then analyzed using a common Lyapunov function and Linear Matrix Inequality (LMI) techniques applied to the polytopic model under two load current scenarios. The analytical results are then validated through open-loop simulations under all possible duty cycle conditions.

title: Study on Adaptive Overcurrent Protection for Distribution Network With Distributed Generations
authors: Guoliang Lv, Guomin Luo, Junheng Chen, Ziliang Gao, Miao Chen, Ling Wan, Xiudan Yao, Jingyi Huo
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: High-penetration integration of distributed energy resources introduces significant randomness and uncertainty, posing formidable challenges to conventional power system protection paradigms. To enhance the operational robustness of overcurrent protection in distribution networks and mitigate the adverse impacts of distributed generation, this paper proposes an adaptive current protection method based on a VMD-LSTM photovoltaic output prediction model with a dual-optimized SSA network. The research first conducts a systematic analysis of the influence mechanisms of representative inverter-interfaced distributed generators (IIDGs) on traditional three-stage overcurrent protection schemes in distribution systems. Then, a VMD-LSTM neural network is constructed, and its parameters are double-optimized using the sparrow search algorithm (SSA). Finally, based on the optimization results, the protection device settings are automatically adjusted to achieve a comprehensive adaptive overcurrent protection scheme. Simulation experiments under diverse operating scenarios validate the efficacy of the proposed scheme. Results demonstrate that the methodology not only significantly improves the selectivity and sensitivity of distribution network protection but also effectively accommodates the stochastic characteristics of IIDG outputs.. This work provides a valuable technical reference for optimizing protection strategies in modern power systems with high renewable energy penetration, contributing to the development of smart grid resilience against distributed generation uncertainties.

title: Brain Tumors Classification Using Vision Transformer and Convnext Models
authors: Muhammad Haikal Afinas Sidiq, R. Rizal Isnanto, Bellia Dwi Cahya Putri
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Information Technology, Computer, and Electrical Engineering (ICITACEE)
abstract: Brain tumor classification is a critical challenge in the medical field due to the complexity of its various shape and locations. Imaging technologies such as MRI have helped medical personnel in diagnosing this disease. The application of deep learning is a favorite in helping interpret complex MRI images. The types of tumors that will be classified in this study are glioma, meningioma, pituitary. Several image processing methods and architectures have shown convincing results in recognizing tumor diseases. Vision Transformer (ViT) and ConvNeXt which were the latest deep learning architectures had proved excellent performances in managing complex images, showing their potential capability in arranging tumor classification. The pretrained ViT (Base and Large) and ConvNeXt (Tiny, Small, and Base) models were programmed using a uniform configuration. The dataset used came from kaggle, a combination of figshare, SARTAJ, and Br35H datasets with a total of 7024 images. The results were compared based on the metrics of accuracy, precision, recall, F 1 -score, and specificity. The results show that ViT Large performs best with a test accuracy of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 9. 6 9 \%}$</tex>, followed by ConvNeXt Small with an accuracy of 99.39 %. Comparisons with same and different datasets are made to see the margin between previously used models and the currently used model. Thus, the ViT Large model outperforms other models. This study confirms that transformer architectures, especially ViT Large, have an excellent generalization capability, but ConvNeXt Small offers an attractive balance between high accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Systematic Mapping Study on AI Integration in CI/CD Pipelines
authors: Othmane Berrouyne, Manal El Bajta, Imade Benelallam
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: This Systematic Mapping Study (SMS) investigates the integration of Artificial Intelligence (AI) within Continuous Integration and Continuous Deployment (CI/CD) pipelines an essential component of modern DevOps practices. Although AI is increasingly adopted in software engineering, its application in CI/CD remains fragmented and underexplored. This study systematically analyzes 30 primary research papers published between 2018 and 2024, classifying AI-enhanced CI/CD efforts by publication trends, methodologies, applied techniques, challenges, and future directions. Results show that AI is primarily employed for test case prioritization, build failure prediction, and CI workflow optimization, leveraging machine learning, deep learning, reinforcement learning, and hybrid models. However, notable challenges remain, including limited explainability, data scarcity, integration complexity, and a lack of real-world validation. The study highlights key research gaps particularly in DevSecOps, explainable AI, and cross-project generalization and advocates for benchmark dataset creation and improved AI-human collaboration. This SMS offers a structured foundation to advance research and guide the practical adoption of AI in CI/CD environments.

title: Detection of COVID-19 epidemic outbreak using Attention Mechanism Capsule Network
authors: Yuan Xue, Qiwei Xing, Zhihua Li, Xiaolin Chen, Heping Gou
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Complex Medical Engineering (CME)
abstract: Since the emergence of the novel coronavirus epidemic in 2019, it has significantly affected human health and the economy. In the face of the sudden epidemic, both medical staff and the healthcare system have been overwhelmed by the high pressure and workload. The challenge lies in how to diagnose COVID-19 patients more rapidly and accurately, leveraging computer-aided automatic diagnosis. To address these challenges, we introduce the Attention Mechanism Capsule Network (AMCapsNet) framework, which efficiently capitalizes on the traits of attention mechanisms and capsule networks. Specifically, we propose the Attention Mechanism Feature Extraction Module (AMFEM). This module employs a grouping and merging strategy, utilizing small convolutions and identity mappings to extract multi-scale deep features, thereby enabling the network to capture both detailed and contextual information from images. Furthermore, the features are refined sequentially from both channel and spatial dimensions, which strengthen the network feature extractor’s attention to key features in the image and minimize redundant information, thereby improving the network’s fine-grained detection capabilities. Experimental results demonstrate that AMCapsNet achieves state-of-the-art performance on two publicly available datasets, with accuracy rates of $\mathbf{9 9. 2 \%}$ and $\mathbf{9 5. 3 \%}$, respectively, showing its capacity to accurately identify COVID-19.

title: Novel Triple Band Bandpass Filter Designed for WiMAX Communication Systems
authors: Quoc-Cuong Vuong, Duy Khuong, Quang-Huy Tran, Duy-Long Tran, Anh-Tuan Mai, Binh-Duong Nguyen, Linh Mai
publish: 2025 24th International Symposium on Communications and Information Technologies (ISCIT)
abstract: This paper presents a triple band bandpass filter (BPF) tailored for WiMAX communications. The proposed triple band BPF employs two Folded Open-loop Stepped-Impedance Resonators (FOLSIRs), which are themselves variants of conventional Stepped-Impedance Resonators (SIRs). In addition, a further structural modification is introduced to the FOLSIRs to generate the desired additional passband and improve filter performance. Full-wave electromagnetic simulations reveal that the filter effectively operates across three passbands: 1.75-1.97 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{GHz}, 3.83-4.36 \text{GHz}$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5.62-5.86 \text{GHz}$</tex>. The corresponding insertion losses at the center frequencies are <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.45 ~\text{dB}, 0.51 ~\text{dB}$</tex>, and 1 dB, while the return losses are better than 18 dB across all three bands. These results indicate excellent impedance matching, low transmission loss, and sharp out-of-band rejection.

title: Deadbeat Control of Synchronous Reluctance Motor Adopting Nonlinear Flux Linkage Model
authors: Ahmed Mahmoud Abo-Shady, Mohamed Mamdouh Elshormbably, Essam Eddin M. Rashad
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Power Electronics and Renewable Energy (CPERE)
abstract: Synchronous reluctance motors (SynRM) are attracting more attention in both industry and research communities. Compared to induction motors (IM) and permanent magnet synchronous motors (PMSM), SynRMs are characterized by simple construction, low copper losses, low cost since no rare earth materials are needed. However, achieving high-performance operation for SynRM is challenging due to magnetic saturation and cross-coupling, which complicates controller design. In this paper, an accurate maximum torque per ampere (MTPA) trajectory is used considering the saturation effect. Moreover, a nonlinear flux linkage function is adopted for the stator voltage calculation. The deadbeat (DB) control concept is then applied to generate the command stator voltage vector. The proposed controller is characterized by its simple structure and its ability to handle system nonlinearities. The performance of the proposed controller is compared to conventional cascaded PI controller and predictive current control (PCC) methods. Simulation results prove that the proposed controller has superior performance for both steadystate and transient operations.

title: Automated machine learning for maritime accident analysis: A case study
authors: Meryem Beljadid, Halima Ait Boukous, Aafaf Beljadid, Adil Tannouche
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: The maritime fishery sector continues to be one of the highest-risk sectors due to the vulnerability and hostility of the marine environment, but there are always ways of reducing these risks. Accidents are often caused by more than one factor contributing to a complex interaction. Identifying the root causes and their interactions is essential to preventing and understanding these accidents. This study presents an analysis of maritime events in Morocco between 2014 and 2023 using automated machine learning (AutoML) techniques. These techniques offer a multitude of options for examining voluminous amounts of historical data concerning marine events through advanced algorithms that facilitate the incorporation of predictive analysis into decision-making, operational and policy processes with the aim of increasing safety at sea. Multiple classification ML algorithms were trained such as Decision Tree, Xgboost and Random Forest with the aim of increasing the accuracy and robustness of detection. The ensemble model, which merges six separate models to generate a final prediction, proved to be the best performer in terms of optimal predictive accuracy.

title: PV Hosting Capacity Analysis in Distribution Systems with Uncertain Demand and Weather Conditions
authors: Salem S Alhaisoni, Ahmad Eid
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Power Electronics and Renewable Energy (CPERE)
abstract: The rapid growth of distributed photovoltaic (PV) integration has raised significant concerns regarding the hosting capacity of distribution networks, particularly in the context of planning and operation. Traditional assessment methods often struggle with adapting to varying weather conditions and load fluctuations, leading to challenges in accurately managing uncertainty. This study presents an enhanced PV hosting capacity assessment model that incorporates source-load uncertainty to improve both the practicality and precision of hosting capacity evaluations. The proposed approach optimally allocates PV sources while respecting system limitations such as voltage levels, cable capacities, and transmission system. To analyze the effects of PV integration, the forward/backward load flow method is employed. The study also includes a series of case studies using the IEEE 28-bus radial distribution system to demonstrate the model’s effectiveness in real distribution systems.

title: Simulation Study of Electric Drive Vibration Working Condition of Flexible Tracked Vehicle Based on RecurDyn
authors: Gang Li, Wei Wang, Chengzhang Zhao, Zhengxing Zuo
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: In this study, a flexible tracked vehicle model is developed to investigate vibration characteristics under different driving speeds and surface roughness conditions. The aim is to provide vibration boundary references for the layout and control strategy of electric drive systems. The flexible body is first modeled in HyperMesh software and then imported into RecurDyn software, where the complete tracked travel system is constructed. Root-mean-square (RMS) acceleration values are extracted from multiple monitoring points to analyze the distribution of structural vibrations. The results indicate that both driving speed and road roughness significantly affect the vibration response. Notably, the bottom and rear regions of the vehicle body experience lower acceleration levels, suggesting these areas are better suited for installing key electric components.

title: Numerical simulation of turbulent flow through a wastewater bar screen
authors: Loubna En-Nabety, El Mostapha Boudi
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: Bar screens are frequently used in the screening stage as the first step of the wastewater treatment process. These devices are crucial in catching debris from the wastewater flow and protecting downstream facilities. Despite their significance in this preliminary treatment phase, there are relatively few studies in the literature that focus on bar screens. However, examining various configurations and parameters that influence the performance of wastewater screening can lead to more improvements and optimization in the design and operation of bar screens. Thus, this work aims to analyze the hydrodynamic behavior of a turbulent fluid flow across a wastewater bar screen for different inlet velocities. The current numerical study was carried out using Ansys Fluent CFD code for a three-dimensional, steady, and turbulent flow. The results show that the fluid inlet velocity affects bar screen function by influencing the pressure drop and velocity distribution; higher inlet velocities or insufficient ones could damage the screening operation.

title: Towards Sustainable Oil Extraction: GAMS Based Battery Sizing Optimization in PV Hybrid Sucker Rod Pump System
authors: Amr Makhlouf, Mohammed Alhasheem, Ibrahim Abdel Salaam
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Power Electronics and Renewable Energy (CPERE)
abstract: This paper presents a hybrid energy solution tailored to meet the operational demands of sucker rod pumps (SRPs), a vital technology in oil extraction. The proposed system integrates photovoltaic (PV) generation, diesel generators, and battery energy storage systems (BESS) to ensure a reliable and cost-effective power supply. Central to this study is a multi-layer optimization framework developed in GAMS® for determining the optimal BESS capacity, explicitly accounting for the SRP’s highly variable load profile. The model incorporates Battery technical constraints while also considering battery degradation and aging effects to enhance the system’s lifecycle performance. The framework has been validated through a case study implemented in an Egyptian oil field, demonstrating both technical feasibility and economic viability. Furthermore, the study benchmarks the GAMS-based approach against conventional optimization platforms, highlighting its superior flexibility in modeling nonlinear constraints and real-world operational parameters. This work offers practical insights into scalable renewable integration for off-grid industrial loads in remote energy-intensive applications.

title: A Lightweight Hybrid Prediction Framework for Remaining Useful Life Based on CS-TCN-SAPINN
authors: Cunjin Zheng, Liyong Wang, Shuyuan Chang, Wei Du, Yifan Yu, Ximing Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: Accurate remaining useful life (RUL) prediction is essential for prognosis and health management. However, existing methods for RUL prediction generally suffer from the issues of ignoring variable operating modes, requiring numerous training parameters and producing significant prediction errors. To address these challenges, a novel lightweight hybrid network model, CS-TCN-SAPINN is proposed. Specifically, firstly, raw data are clustered and standardized (CS) based on operating modes. Secondly, for mapping high-dimensional hidden features to the low-dimensional space and capturing long-term dependencies, a temporal convolutional network (TCN) is utilized. Subsequently, a self-attention mechanism assisted physics-informed neural network (SAPINN) is employed for regularizing the prediction network and mapping features to the RUL. Finally, the C-MAPSS dataset is used for validation and results show that, compared to the existing state-of-the-art methods, the proposed approach achieves advanced performance with the least number of trainable parameters.

title: Deep Learning for Schizophrenia Diagnosis from EEG Signals: A Comparative Study of Time-Domain vs. Frequency-Domain Models
authors: Yuhe Tang
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Complex Medical Engineering (CME)
abstract: Schizophrenia is a severe mental disorder characterized by a complex and often subjective diagnostic process. To explore more objective and reliable auxiliary diagnostic methods, this study investigates the application of deep learning techniques in the analysis of electroencephalogram (EEG) signals. We systematically compare the performance of two core deep learning models: a one-dimensional convolutional neural network (1D-CNN) for time-domain analysis and a two-dimensional convolutional neural network (2D-CNN) for frequency-domain analysis. The $1 \mathrm{D}-\mathrm{CNN}$ processes raw EEG time-series data directly, while the 2D-CNN analyzes time-frequency spectrograms generated via Short-Time Fourier Transform. By replicating, training, and validating these models on two independent datasets, this research aims to thoroughly evaluate their effectiveness and, crucially, their generalization capabilities. Experimental results reveal a critical dichotomy: while the 1 D -CNN achieves nearperfect accuracy in training and validation on a single dataset, its performance collapses dramatically when tested on unseen data, indicating poor generalization. In contrast, the 2D-CNN, by capturing more stable and physiologically relevant time-frequency features, demonstrates significantly superior robustness and reliability in cross-dataset testing. These findings underscore the pivotal value of frequency-domain features in building generalizable EEG-based diagnostic models and provide vital empirical evidence and methodological guidance for developing trustworthy, automated diagnostic tools for schizophrenia.

title: Discrete Orthogonal Moments-Based Deep Clustering: A Racah Polynomials and Cauchy Distribution Approach
authors: Bouali Aymane, El Madmoune Yassir, El Ouariachi Ilham, Zenkouar Khalid, Zahi Azeddine
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: Deep embedded clustering (DEC) has emerged as a powerful paradigm for unsupervised representation learning in high-dimensional data. This paper introduces a novel DEC framework that integrates a fully connected autoencoder with separable discrete orthogonal moments (SDOMs) derived from Racah polynomials. Specifically, the x-axis leverages Racah moments, while the y-axis employs a choice between Racah, Tchebichef, Krawtchouck, or Hahn moments, enabling rich spatial feature extraction. To enhance computational efficiency, we propose using only half of the moment orders, which have been empirically shown to retain discriminative power while reducing dimensionality. Furthermore, we replace the traditional Student t-distribution with a Cauchy distribution in the clustering layer, offering improved robustness to outliers. Experiments on MNIST, Fashion-MNIST, and USPS demonstrate superior performance over state-of-the-art methods in clustering accuracy, normalized mutual information (NMI), and adjusted Rand index (ARI). Theoretical insights, ablation studies, and limitations are thoroughly discussed, indicating that hybrid moment configurations and a Cauchy-based clustering objective hold considerable promise for robust deep clustering.

title: Research On The Diagnosis Of Reasons For Misoperation And Refusal Of Protection Based On Online Data And The Warning Technology For Hidden Dangers
authors: Chengjun Cai, Minchou Han, Jialin Zhen, Quanke Ba
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: After a power system failure, there is often a phenomenon of protection misoperation or refusal to operate due to abnormalities in protective devices, secondary circuits, or switch mechanisms. At present, there is no comprehensive diagnostic and analysis method that relies on technical experience and manual inspection for investigation. The automation level is low and does not have the effect of early warning. This article is based on a secondary equipment online monitoring system, which collects relevant information and analyzes hidden dangers and problems in hardware protection devices, protection logic, protection settings, secondary circuits, switch mechanisms, and other aspects. The analysis of the causes of misoperation or refusal to move after a fault plays a strong supporting role, and based on real-time monitoring, hidden dangers can be detected in advance for early warning, avoiding the occurrence of misoperation or refusal to move in advance. After pilot verification in a 220kV intelligent substation, the expected results have been achieved, improving the efficiency of accident analysis and ensuring the stable operation of the power system.

title: Distributed Non-Coherent Spiral Sar Imaging With Random Rf Illumination
authors: Cao Hong Phuc Nguyen, Xiaojing Huang, J. Andrew Zhang
publish: 2025 24th International Symposium on Communications and Information Technologies (ISCIT)
abstract: This paper presents a non-coherent synthetic aperture radar (NC-SSAR) imaging framework based on an Archimedean spiral trajectory by a single or dual active receiving antenna(s) operating under random ambient radio frequency (RF) illumination signals. Theoretical formulations for image reconstruction are developed, including system geometry, signal modeling, and analytical derivations of the point spread function (PSF), point blur function (PBF), and signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) under non-coherent assumptions. Simulations using signals in the P-band and L-band with full and sparse spatial sampling demonstrate that NC-SSAR can achieve effective image reconstruction under diverse illumination conditions. These findings highlight the system's potential for compact, spatially distributed and cooperative microwave imaging systems in practical RF noisy environments.

title: Predicting Groundwater Levels with Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) Networks and Seasonal Pattern Classification
authors: Syahriza Malika Yahya, Muhammad Suryanegara, Sito Dewi Damayanti, Supriyanto, Sukarno
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Information Technology, Computer, and Electrical Engineering (ICITACEE)
abstract: Sustainable groundwater management is essential to mitigate the adverse impacts of climate change and ensure freshwater availability. This study introduces a predictive and recommendation system that forecasts groundwater levels using Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks and classifies seasonal patterns using K-Means clustering. The data-driven approach uses information collected from the “Pantir” monitoring initiative at Universitas Indonesia. The LSTM model, optimized with Grid Search and early stopping, achieved an R2 of 0.9211, MAE of 6.1028, and RMSE of 9.3159. The clustering component identifies Indonesia's wet and dry seasons, enhancing the contextual accuracy of the prediction results. This study offers a novel integration of LSTM forecasting and K-Means classification within a user-friendly dashboard. The system is intended to support both policymakers and the general public by providing accessible insights that encourage sustainable groundwater usage and informed water resource planning.

title: Inferring Input Grammars from Code with Symbolic Parsing
authors: Leon Bettscheider, Andreas Zeller
publish: ACM Transactions on Software Engineering and Methodology
abstract: None

title: Addressing Human-Robot Symbiosis via Bilevel Optimization of Robotic Knee Prosthesis Control_supp1-3634368.pdf
authors: Varun Nalam
publish: N/A
abstract: This study presents an innovative solution for integrating a human and a robotic knee prosthesis symbiotically for walking. Achieving this requires human-robot cross-joint coordination to provide personalized walking assistance. Our approach uses inverse reinforcement learning (IRL) to identify control objectives for reinforcement learning (RL) controller. Unlike existing methods that optimize performance of human or robot alone, our approach considers both human (thigh segmental angle) and robot (knee joint kinematics) aspects. This bilevel optimization method was evaluated on 3 non-disabled participants and 2 people with amputation. Results showed that the approach personalized the objective function and resulted in a robust policy, completing optimization within a duration of 3.5 minutes. Compared to previous approaches focusing only on robot states, this symbiotic approach increased stance time and step length on the prosthesis side for most participants. Our results highlight the potential of integrating human state into prosthesis control personalization, enhancing the functionality and health of people with amputation.

title: Frequency-Domain Nonlinear Self-Interference Cancellation in Full-Duplex Zero-IF Transceivers: From Algorithm to Prototype
authors: HyeonHwi Lee, Yonghwi Kim, Hanju Yoo, Byoungnam Kim, Chan-Byoung Chae
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: Full-duplex (FD) zero-intermediate-frequency (zero-IF) transceivers are attractive for the Internet of Things (IoT) because they reduce cost, power consumption, and hardware complexity. However, their practicality is limited by severe self-interference (SI) dominated by DC offset, frequency-selective in-phase/quadrature (IQ) imbalance, and power-amplifier (PA) nonlinearities that vary over time with thermal effects and protection logic. Conventional cancellers that rely on uniform, time-domain models perform poorly under these frequency-selective and state-dependent distortions. This paper proposes a hardware-aware, frequency-domain self-interference cancellation (SIC) framework that (i) analytically characterizes zero-IF distortion spectra to enable selective per-subcarrier basis allocation, and (ii) introduces lightweight state-adaptive processing using DC-magnitude detection to switch coefficient sets in real time. A USRP X310 prototype demonstrates mean SIC of 35.5 dB across both stable and dynamic PA states at 15 and 21 dBm transmit power, achieved with only 2.57 basis functions per subcarrier on average. Compared with polynomial, parallel Hammerstein, and neural-network baselines, the proposed design achieves superior cancellation with orders-of-magnitude lower complexity. These results establish frequency-domain, hardware-aware SIC as a practical and scalable solution for resource-constrained IoT devices operating in dynamic wireless environments.

title: Suppressing the Back-Gating Effect of Normally-Off p-GaN Monolithic Bidirectional Switch on 6-Inch Sapphire for Compact Power Conversion Systems
authors: Junbo Wang, Xiangdong Li, Jian Ji, Xi Jiang, Song Yuan, Shuzhen You, Tao Zhang, Long Chen, Yue Hao, Jincheng Zhang
publish: IEEE Journal of the Electron Devices Society
abstract: In this work, normally-off p-GaN monolithic bidirectional switch (MBDS) with common-drain configuration on 6-inch sapphire has been successfully fabricated using CMOScompatible process in our pilot line. Comparative analysis reveals that devices on Si exhibit severe current collapse, with dynamic RON rising by tens of times to 207 Ω and 58 Ω depending on substrate termination under AC chopping tests, attributed to high substrate potential during ON-state. In contrast, MBDS on sapphire maintain stable performance with only 1.3 dynamic RON during double-pulse test and current collapse below 20% under high-voltage substrate bias test. The insulating sapphire substrate effectively suppresses the back-gating effect and paves the way for the use of MBDS on sapphire to significantly simplify the power conversion systems in the future.

title: Design of An Intelligent Pixel Readout ASIC with ADC-less In-sensor Computing based on Binary-Weight Analog Neural Network for Hybrid X-Ray Imaging Detectors
authors: Jingsi Cheng, Chunyang Yu, Shuao Yang, Xiaoyu Wu, Yaoxing Dou, Hanting Wu, Wu Gao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Nuclear Science
abstract: More advanced hybrid pixel detectors are required in the next-generation instrumentation for high-energy physics, nuclear physics, and photon science experiments. Conventional front-end readout electronics based on a pixel readout integrated circuits (ROIC) which rely on analog-to-digital conversion will encounter bottlenecks of data conversion and transmission. Deploying neural network hardware at the source end of the detector to achieve analog-to-information conversion has become an important solution to overcome these bottlenecks. In this paper, we propose a novel intelligent pixel readout circuit with an all-analog in-sensor computing architecture to enable analog-to-information conversion for photon-count X-ray imaging. In this novel architecture, an analog multiplier-accumulator (MAC) unit and a ReLU circuit are integrated into a super pixel circuit to realize first-layer convolution. Then, the generated analog voltage signals are transferred to an analog in-memory computing (IMC) accelerator to complete the fully-connected layer computing. A prototype with a 28 × 28 pixel matrix and an IMC macro has been designed in 180-nm CMOS technology. A binary-weight convolutional neural network featuring 784 inputs and 10 outputs is constructed. It accomplishes MNIST dataset classification task with the accuracy of 73% with an energy efficiency of 558 GOPS/W and the power consumption of 58 μW/pixel. The area overhead and the power over head of the proposed computing circuit are only 8.3% and 8.5% of the whole ASIC, respectively. The achieved results show that the integration of the pixel front-ends with in-situ analog computing is highly feasible.

title: Enhancing Mathematical Reasoning Through Autonomously Learning Knowledge
authors: Jiayu Liu, Zhenya Huang, Enhong Chen, Qi Liu, Hongke Zhao, Xin Lin, Jing Sha, Shijin Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: Enabling machines to solve mathematical problems is a vital endeavor in developing intelligence that emulates human- like thinking and reasoning. However, most existing approaches focus on reconstructing human comprehension of problems, which are still far from enough since they neglect the fundamental human ability to learn knowledge from experiences. In this article, we focus on empowering models with the cognitive capacity to autonomously learn knowledge from mathematical problem-solving. We first propose a Cognitive Solver (CogSolver) that contains an intelligent BRAIN-ARM framework as the cognitive structure and operates the knowledge learning process in Store-Apply-Update steps inspired by two cognitive science theories. The BRAIN system stores three basic types of mathematical knowledge, and the ARM system applies them organically in answer reasoning process. After solving problems, the BRAIN updates its stored knowledge based on the ARM's feedback, with knowledge filters to eliminate redundancies and foster a more rational knowledge base. Our CogSolver carries out the above three steps iteratively, emulating a more human- like behavior. Furthermore, in order to overcome knowledge forgetting during the learning process, we extend CogSolver to CogSolver+ by incorporating an essential knowledge Recall mechanism, which is inspired by another prominent cognitive theory. We first discuss and fuse three crucial factors in simulating human memory replay. Then, we propose a influenced-based method with a theoretical guarantee of efficiency to consolidate the updated knowledge. Experiments on three math word problem benchmarks demonstrate the improvements of our CogSolver and CogSolver+ in answer reasoning and clearly illustrate how they acquire knowledge, leading to superior interpretability.

title: Combining airborne LiDAR data and optical Imagery for improved national-scale beach topography estimation: a case study in New Zealand
authors: Yuhao Wang, Conghong Huang, Yue Ma, Xin Ma, Yifu Ou, Chunpeng Chen, Binbin Li, Shaoguang Zhou, Dongzhen Jia, Zhen Wang, Qingquan Li, Nan Xu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Accurate beach topography mapping is crucial for understanding coastal dynamics and mitigating climate change impacts. However, traditional methods such as airborne LiDAR have limitations, leading to substantial gaps in national-scale elevation data. This study presents an innovative framework to reconstruct missing elevation data along New Zealand’s coastline by integrating airborne LiDAR, Sentinel-2 optical imagery, and geometric features (distance) using machine learning methods. Our results show that Artificial Neural Network (ANN) emerged as the best model (test set: R²=0.79, RMSE=0.91 m; validation set: 0.79, RMSE=0.93 m), outperforming other models in accuracy. The produced 10-m DEM for national-scale sandy beaches expands area coverage by 286.6% (114.15 km²), filling gaps in 1249 beaches, including remote areas such as Stewart Island. This novel framework offers a scalable solution for improving the comprehensiveness and accuracy of beach topography. It provides essential support for inundation prediction, habitat management, and the development of climate adaptation strategies, thereby facilitating more informed decision-making in coastal zone management and climate change mitigation efforts.

title: ICOA 2025 Cover Page
authors: N/A
