title: Client Selection in Federated Learning With Differential Privacy-Based Data Stream
authors: Junru Wu, Chengxin Li, Wentai Wu, Young-June Choi, Hiroo Sekiya, Zhetao Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Networking
abstract: Federated learning (FL) is a distributed machine learning (ML) paradigm designed for numerous networked devices. To face the massive data generated by devices and privacy concerns in model construction, the paradigm can execute ML tasks with differential privacy (DP) over private data streams. In each FL training iteration, a few clients are selected to participate and consume privacy budgets that determine the level of privacy protection. The client selection strategy plays a pivotal role in the final model performance. At present, reconciling model performance with privacy protection remains an open issue in online settings. Specifically, the DP model designed for data streams reduces the benefits of frequent participation by clients with high-quality data, as the DP model constrains the available privacy budget of continuous iterations. To address this issue, we propose a novel client selection framework for FL with DP-based data streams. At a macro level, we leverage fuzzy control to dynamically adjust the participation rate of clients, ensuring sufficient privacy budgets are allocated in each training iteration. At a fine-grained level, we design a dynamic scoring function based on the characteristics of the clients and a budget-aware client selection method to select clients further. Additionally, considering the diverse scenarios in data collection, we propose a relaxed semi-online setting and integrate reinforcement learning (RL) to enhance the framework performance. Extensive experiments demonstrate the remarkable advantages of our framework in accuracy, convergence rate, robustness, etc.

title: Low Complexity High Speed Channel Estimation for OTFS on System on Chip
authors: Sai Kumar Dora, Sumit J. Darak, Himanshu B. Mishra
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems I: Regular Papers
abstract: This work presents a novel, low-complexity hardware implementation of the Two-Choice Hard Thresholding Pursuit (TCHTP) algorithm for sparse channel estimation (CE) in the delay-Doppler (DD) domain, specifically designed for Orthogonal Time Frequency Space (OTFS) modulation. Unlike prior compressed sensing methods, the proposed approach does not require prior knowledge of channel sparsity or statistics, making it highly suitable for real-world, high-mobility scenarios. We formulate the CE problem in a sparse framework and develop a hardware-friendly variant of TCHTP that jointly estimates channel coefficients and their DD positions. To reduce complexity in the coefficient estimation stage involving the inverse operation, we explore and implement three matrix decomposition strategies—singular value decomposition (SVD), QR decomposition, and a novel hybrid QR+SVD approach—on a system-on-chip platform using hardware-software co-design. The proposed hybrid architecture achieves up to 70.6% memory savings, 42.4% reduction in DSP usage, and a <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$132\times $</tex-math> </inline-formula> speedup over the conventional design, while maintaining BER performance. Additionally, it achieves 10% lower power consumption and delivers an <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$84.2\times $</tex-math> </inline-formula> increase in end-to-end physical layer throughput.

title: Enhanced Adaptive Artificial Potential Field for UAV Navigation in Dynamic 3D Environments with Lightweight Spherical Obstacle Map
authors: Yudong Wang, Helei Wu, Xuesong Xu, Yixiao Sun, Xiangui Zeng
publish: IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters
abstract: Effective navigation in dynamic three-dimensional (3D) environments is essential for autonomous unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), but existing methods often lack computational efficiency and robustness. To address these challenges, this paper presents a path planning framework that combines a lightweight mapping module and an adaptive planner. A spherical obstacle map is proposed to represent dynamic environments efficiently, converting dense point clouds into sparse spherical representations while estimating obstacle motion for safe planning. An enhanced adaptive artificial potential field based on the spherical obstacle map is introduced to improve path reachability and safety, integrating an attractive force with terminal acceleration to avoid terminal local minimum, a repulsive force with a 3D vortex to improve safety, and an emergency-deflection mechanism to mitigate intermediate local minimum. In addition, an adaptive path optimization algorithm dynamically tunes planning coefficients to prioritize reachability and safety, while also guaranteeing efficiency. Extensive simulations in dynamic sphere and pedestrian environments, along with a real-world UAV experiment, demonstrate that the proposed framework outperforms existing methods in success rate and safety, while maintaining balance in other performance metrics.

title: Development of an Educational Fact-Checking Game to Improve Digital Information Literacy
authors: Sebastian Gabriel Surjanto, Elbert Hans Lianto, Galih Dea Pratama
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Information Technology, Computer, and Electrical Engineering (ICITACEE)
abstract: In the digital age, the ability to critically evaluate online information is essential for navigating misinformation. This study presents the design and evaluation of a serious educational video game aimed at enhancing digital information literacy through interactive fact-checking tasks. The serious game was tested on two groups, which are readers, and non-readers. Our method for gathering data involves administering a pre-test and post-test which are given before and after participants have tried out the game, we aim to measure improvements in 3 variables which are truth seeking behaviour, fact-checking, and media literacy. Results shows a substantial increase in all three variables was shown for the readers, while the news readers had only 2 variables improved, with media literacy showing no meaningful increase. The study concludes that serious games can be an effective tool for enhancing critical digital literacy behaviours. Future research should explore serious games effects on broader age ranges, the correlation of user experience and targeted effects, and the integration of adaptive difficulty and personalized feedback to enhance the game's value.

title: A Novel RFI Detection Method for Multi-Channel Hrws SAR Systems in Azimuth
authors: Liu Cuijun, Zhou Bin, Sun Chenglin, Li Xiangdong, Liu Yanyang
publish: 2024 5th China International SAR Symposium (CISS)
abstract: In the processing of Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) data, radio frequency interference (RFI) significantly degrades image quality. RFI detection technology is not only a prerequisite for interference suppression but also one of the critical technologies in current ground data processing. However, most existing detection techniques fail to meet the requirements of multi-channel characteristics. This paper presents a method for echo interference detection in an azimuth multi-channel high-resolution wide-swath SAR system. The main processes include: reconstructing the echo data of redundant channels using the original echo data after amplitude and phase equalization; and performing clutter cancellation and interference detection within the redundant channels. Experimental results with actual airborne multi-channel SAR data demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: KneeRAC: Retrieval-Augmented Classification for Grading Knee Osteoarthritis on Radiographs
authors: Kundjanasith Thonglek, Suphanat Wisitkatanyuchai
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: Automated grading of knee osteoarthritis severity using radiographic images is a critical task in computer-aided diagnosis, aiming to support early intervention and reduce radiologist workload. While deep learning models have shown promising performance in classifying Kellgren–Lawrence grades, their effectiveness can be limited by small, imbalanced datasets and subtle visual differences between severity levels. To address these challenges, we propose KneeRAC, a Retrieval-Augmented Classification (RAC) framework that enhances traditional classification pipelines through contextual embedding integration. We evaluate KneeRAC across 17 commonly used deep convolutional neural network architectures by comparing its performance to standard classification methods. The proposed framework demonstrates consistent improvements in classification accuracy for most models, with EfficientNetB0 achieving the highest gains, which is rising from 83.51% in the traditional setting to 86.81% with the proposed method. In addition to accuracy, our method significantly reduces training time by decoupling feature extraction from classifier training. KneeRAC reduces runtime by 95.05% in average. Further analysis of runtime distribution shows that over 98% of the time is spent on embedding extraction, while classifier training accounts for only 1.65%, demonstrating the practicality of our decoupled design. This efficient, modular approach not only improves predictive performance but also facilitates faster experimentation with limited computational resources.

title: Grid Strength Assessment for Floating PV Integration at 150 kV Using SCR and WSCR
authors: Nurindah Aristi Supiartni, Mochammad Facta, Abdul Syakur
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Information Technology, Computer, and Electrical Engineering (ICITACEE)
abstract: The global transition towards renewable energy requires not only policy alignment but also technical assurance to ensure grid stability and operational reliability. This paper presents a comprehensive feasibility assessment of integrating a utility-scale floating photovoltaic (PV) plant with an installed capacity of 145 MWac into the 150 kV transmission network. The focus is placed on evaluating grid readiness through secondary data sourced from official feasibility studies and operational reports issued by the national electricity utility. Unlike experimental studies relying on direct measurement instruments or real-time simulation models, this research adopts a document-based analytical approach to interpret post-commissioning system behavior. Key technical parameters are analyzed, including short circuit ratio (SCR), stiffness ratio (SR), voltage deviation, frequency fluctuation, and power quality indicators. The results show that all individual floating photovoltaic power plants exhibit SCR values significantly above the threshold of 5, with the Kubu plant reaching 134.48, Jembrana at 69.34, and Cirata at 47.85 indicating strong grid conditions across all units. At the system level, the calculated weighted short circuit ratio (WSCR) of 50.88 further confirms the network's capability to accommodate high-penetration inverter-based generation. Sensitivity simulations demonstrate that WSCR declines as photovoltaic capacity increases under constant grid strength, signaling the importance of grid reinforcement for future expansion scenarios. Additionally, power quality assessments reveal minimal harmonic distortion and voltage flicker, aligning with international grid codes. This study contributes to academic and industrial discourse by offering insight into large-scale renewable energy integration within high-voltage systems in developing countries. The findings emphasize the importance of system-level readiness evaluation using validated operational data, particularly in the context of floating PV systems, which present unique electrical and environmental characteristics. The results can serve as a reference for future renewable project planning, grid code development, and interconnection policy formulation.

title: A 6-14 Gb/S Single-Loop Referenceless CDR Without Separate FD
authors: Tho Huu Nguyen, Hai Thanh Mai, Quang Nguyen-The, Luan Le, Vu Hoang Yen
publish: 2025 24th International Symposium on Communications and Information Technologies (ISCIT)
abstract: This paper presents a wide-range, referenceless clock and data recovery (CDR) circuit based on a single-loop architecture. The proposed design incorporates frequency direction detection and a mode-switching scheme to enable both frequency acquisition and phase tracking without requiring an external reference clock or a separate frequency detector. Implemented and simulated in a 28 nm CMOS technology, the CDR achieves robust operation across a wide input data rate range from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$6 ~\text{Gb} / \mathrm{s}$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$14 ~\text{Gb} / \mathrm{s}$</tex>. The circuit consumes 18.4 mW from a 1 V power supply and achieves a short frequency acquisition time of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.52 \mu ~\mathrm{s}$</tex> with tracking range of 4 GHz. The recovered clock exhibits low jitter with a peak-to-peak jitter of 8 ps at input data rate of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$14 ~\text{Gb} / \mathrm{s}$</tex>, making the proposed CDR suitable for high-speed serial communication systems.

title: Classification of American Sign Language Using EfficientNETV2B0 Architecture
authors: Thifa Ziada Taqiyya, Khadijah, Retno Kusumaningrum
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Information Technology, Computer, and Electrical Engineering (ICITACEE)
abstract: Sign language is the primary communication tool for individuals with hearing impairments and plays a crucial role in supporting social interaction. However, the limited public understanding of sign language often hinders effective communication. Various studies on sign language recognition, particularly American Sign Language (ASL), have been conducted. However, the models used in previous research typically have a large number of parameters, making them less efficient for implementation. In this study, ASL classification was performed using the EfficientNetV2B0 architecture which has fewer parameters compared to other models. The dataset used includes images representing numbers, letters, words, and expressions in ASL. Experiment was carried out on both augmented and non-augmented dataset by exploring hyperparameter tuning to obtain the best configuration. Experimental results showed that the best model achieved an accuracy of 0.995 on data without augmentation and 0.996 on data with augmentation. These results indicate that the implementation of data augmentation successfully improved the accuracy, although the improvement was not substantial. This approach demonstrates the capability of EfficientNetV2B0 and the application of data augmentation in accurately recognizing various ASL sign patterns. It is expected that the resulting model can then be implemented in various communication and accessibility services for the deaf community.

title: A Multi-Branch Network for SAR Ship Detection
authors: Yuanjie Zhi, Yuhang Wang, Fan Zhang, Shuangxi Zhang, Shaohui Mei
publish: 2024 5th China International SAR Symposium (CISS)
abstract: Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) can obtain reliable radar images without considering weather conditions, and has important military value in the field of ocean detection and reconnaissance. However, the imaging principles and complex backgrounds results in significant noise in SAR images, posing substantial obstacles to accurate ship target detection. Additionally, the variability in the scale and shape of ship targets increases the risk of missed detections. Aims at the above problems, this paper proposes a Multi-Branch Network (MBNet) based on YOLOv5 to improve the performance of SAR ship detection. Firstly, to capture ship targets of varying sizes, we introduce a novel Multi-Branch Dilated Convolution Block (MBDCB) that integrates cascaded dilated convolutions with convolution layers of different kernel sizes. Secondly, we expand the receptive field by adding a new pooling branch and incorporate spatial and channel attention mechanisms to mitigate the interference from complex backgrounds. Finally, we design a Two-Branch Deformable Convolution Block (TBDCB) that combines deformable convolutions with channel attention mechanisms to enhance the feature representation of ship targets. We conducted simulations on the SSDD and HRSID datasets, with results demonstrating that the proposed method significantly outperforms advanced techniques in terms of AP50, accurately detecting multi -scale targets and distinguishing ships from the background, thereby validating its effectiveness and robustness.

title: A Hybrid Charging Station Integrating Energy Storage and Photovoltaic Systems
authors: Tony Mamdouh, Ibrahim Abdelsalam, Mostafa I. Marei
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Power Electronics and Renewable Energy (CPERE)
abstract: This paper proposed an electric vehicle (EV) DC fast charging station designed to mitigate peak demand and improve grid stability, addressing the challenges associated with the growing size and power ratings of EVs. The proposed hybrid charging station consists of four main components: 1-a three-phase totem pole AC-DC converter that supplies the required power from the grid while ensuring a sinusoidal unity power factor current, 2-photovoltaic panels that act as a renewable energy source, thereby reducing the environmental impact linked to EV charging, 3-a battery bank with a bidirectional DC-DC converter, which is employed to store surplus photovoltaic energy and release this stored energy when photovoltaic power is inadequate, and 4- two parallel-connected signal active bridge DC-DC converters that manage the EV battery charging, transitioning from current control to voltage control. Simulations conducted using Matlab/Simulink demonstrated that the proposed station operates efficiently, adapts quickly to fluctuating charging requirements, and maintains grid stability. This hybrid setup offers a more sustainable and reliable approach to electric vehicle charging.

title: Transmission Network Expansion Planning Considering Integration of Offshore Wind Power
authors: Yaoliang Zhu, Wei Xie, Xiong Wu, Ruanming Huang, Chenlu Jiang, Yu Zhang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: Offshore wind power poses great challenges for transmission grid planning as it expands rapidly in China. This paper proposes a transmission expansion planning model that incorporates both economic considerations and environmental externalities under high offshore wind penetration scenarios. The model aims to achieve coordinated optimization of wind power connection points, transmission corridors, and energy storage deployment, and it is formulated as a mixed-integer linear programming problem. Specifically, an improved k-medoids clustering algorithm is employed to generate representative operational scenarios. Additionally, the air pollution is adequately considered and the Intervention Model for Air Pollution (InMAP) is used to monetize its health-related costs. Case studies based on the ISO-NE eight-zone system are conducted, and it validates the practicality of the proposed approach. The results demonstrate that accounting for environmental externalities can effectively reduce the need for onshore transmission expansion, promote a more meshed offshore grid structure, and enhance energy storage capacity in coastal load centers.

title: Reliability Analysis Method for Multi-Fault Modes of Turbofan Engines Based on the Multi-Domain Unified Model
authors: Jingbo Gai, Jianyang Fang, Xuejiao Du, Yao Jian, Di Wu, Jisong Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: The turbojet engine, as a crucial power unit for specific aircraft, holds great significance in reliability research. However, the engine's multi-domain coupling and multi-fault nature pose challenges for reliability analysis. This paper proposes a reliability analysis method for turbojet engine system under multiple fault conditions based on a multi-domain unified model. Firstly, the method of describing the change of turbojet engine system performance based on mathematical model is used to analyze system operating principles. Secondly, the performance model of the turbojet engine system in the integrated system realizes the multi-domain coupling, and the multi-domain unified model of the system is utilized to simulate the parallelism of multiple faults as well as the superimposed influence on each other. And finally, the model is subjected to the simulation as well as the reliability analysis to solve the deficiencies of the traditional methods. Taking a certain aircraft turbojet engine system as an example, after modeling, fault injection, Monte Carlo simulation and data processing, the cumulative distribution function of system fault is calculated, which provides a new method for turbojet engine reliability research.

title: Effects of Non-Torque Loads on Planetary Gear Systems
authors: Zhanwei Li, Jiawei Pan, Peng Cao, Yifan Huangfu, Ruijun Liang, Rupeng Zhu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: Planetary gears play a critical role in power transmission systems used in aerospace, wind power generation, and other advanced engineering applications, offering broad research potential and practical significance. Traditional studies on the dynamic analysis of planetary gear have primarily focused on torque-dominated load conditions. To investigate the mechanism of dynamic behavior and transmission characteristics of planetary gear systems under non-torque-load, this paper proposes a semi-analytical dynamic modeling method based on a rigid-flexible coupled system described in a global coordinate framework by fixing the retainer. The proposed modeling approach includes: (1) constructing a flexible body model for the ring gear; (2) establishing a lumped parameter submodel for the sun gear, planet carrier, and planetary gears; and (3) introducing a moving elastic coupling boundary to connect the time-varying meshing interface between the ring and planetary gears. Based on this modeling framework, a radial load is applied to the input shaft of the planetary-gear system. The effect of the non-torque, which is loaded on the planetary gear transmission system is investigated by fixing the planetary carrier, calculating the displacement of the sun gear, the transmission error between the planetary gear and the ring, the meshing force and the acceleration value of the measuring point on tooth ring.

title: Multi-Source Data Driven Parallel Branch VIT Intelligent Diagnosis Method for Rolling Bearing Faults
authors: Wenhao Wang, Jiantao Lu, Bin Jia, Shunming Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: Traditional feature fusion fails to characterize true bearing faults under structural complexity and multi-factor influences, this paper proposes a multi-source fusion intelligent fault diagnosis method based on parallel Vision Transformer (ViT) and hybrid attention mechanisms. The method performs time-frequency feature extraction on multi-source vibration data collected from multiple vibration sensors, obtaining feature image data that undergoes Gamma correction preprocessing. A diagnostic model architecture is constructed comprising multiple parallel ViT networks, incorporating a hybrid attention mechanism in the fusion layer to dynamically adjust the contribution weights of features from each sensor. The integration of multiple parallel ViT network branches with an attention-based feature fusion module effectively captures interdependencies within multi-sensor data, thereby enhancing system performance. The results show that the proposed method can effectively achieve high-precision image classification and rolling bearing fault recognition.

title: Design of Non-Contact Vibration Monitoring System for Extra-High Voltage Transformer Based on Machine Vision
authors: Ruijin Yang, Qingtai Fu, Jie Zhang, Yousen Xia, Lei Dong
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: The operation status of extra-high voltage transformers can be evaluated by analyzing the vibration signals, however, the previous contact vibration monitoring methods have problems such as limited deployment in high-risk areas, complex installation and commissioning maintenance and insufficient real-time, this paper builds a non-contact vibration monitoring system based on machine vision to solve the problem. The system is developed based on Qt platform framework, integrating high-speed vision imaging technology and image displacement extraction algorithm, which can realize long-distance, full-angle, high-precision collection of vibration signals in multi-target areas of the transformer. In a 1000 kV ultra-high voltage substation field test, the system successfully acquired the vibration signals of casing and other regional target measurement points, with clear periodic characteristics of the time domain waveform and significant harmonic components in the frequency domain. It provides a new type of technical solution for smart grid equipment condition assessment.

title: A Winding Reconfigured Motor Optimization Method Based on Hybrid Surrogate Model
authors: Zhiran Su, Wei Cai, Fei Liu, Yitian Zhang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: In the drive system of vehicle permanent magnet synchronous motor (PMSM), there is a conflict between high torque density and a wide speed range. To solve this problem, winding reconfiguration technology has received extensive attention. This paper focuses on an interior PMSM used in small commercial vehicles as the research subject. Two hybrid surrogate models are established based on the pre-reconfiguration and post-reconfiguration operating modes, respectively. Then, they are combined together in the corresponding proportion. On this basis, the multi-objective coordinated optimization of two operating modes is realized by using non-dominated sorting genetic algorithm-II(NSGA-II). The results demonstrate that the proposed method effectively balances large torque output and high efficiency, achieving optimal comprehensive performance for winding reconfigured motors. While ensuring the peak torque, both the motor speed range and the area of high efficiency zone are expanded by the proposed method.

title: Imaging Biomarkers of the Hippocampus and Its Subfields for Alzheimer’s Disease Diagnosis
authors: Yingqian Liu, Chaochao You, Juanjuan Jiang, Ronghua Ling, Min Wang, Faliang Gao
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Complex Medical Engineering (CME)
abstract: As a key imaging biomarker of Alzheimer’s disease (AD), the hippocampus plays a crucial role in understanding disease progression. Radiomics provides a powerful approach to extracting diverse features such as intensity, shape, and texture from medical images. Although radiomics has been applied to the hippocampus and its subregions, few studies have systematically investigated the diagnostic value of combining features from different hippocampal regions. This study aims to identify hippocampal regions that are sensitive to different stages of AD, and to select statistically significant radiomic features that correlate with clinical assessments and underlying biological mechanisms. Radiomic features were extracted using the Pyradiomics toolkit from six regions: the left and right hippocampus, hippocampal head, and hippocampal tail. Features from different regions were combined and used as input to several classifiers to perform three binary classification tasks: AD vs. MCI, AD vs. NC, and MCI vs. NC. Statistical methods were employed to identify features showing significant group differences, which were then analyzed for their correlations with clinical scores (e.g., MMSE) and biological markers (e.g., A $\beta$ levels). Results revealed that different hippocampal regions exhibit varying sensitivity to different stages of AD. Several radiomic features showed strong correlations with MMSE scores and $\mathbf{A} \beta$ levels, indicating their potential as imaging biomarkers for disease monitoring and early diagnosis.

title: An Aviation Bearing Quality Monitoring Method Based on an Improved Statistical Parameter Calculation Theory
authors: Linfeng Wang, Zuopeng Lv, Zhongtao Huang, Zhifeng Shi, Dachao Li, Hua Huang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: Under the interference of noise signals, the vibration impact induced by the defect of aviation bearing is too small to be directly detected from the time domain and frequency domain, especially for the incipient defect. Moreover, there are some shortcomings in existing methods for the accurate diagnosis of bearing defects. To overcome this problem, an improved short-time dimensionless time domain statistical value (TDSV) calculation method to monitor the quality state of bearings during the whole life cycle has been proposed in this paper. The root-mean-square (RMS) of kurtosis is used to describe the total energy of the defect impact features. Based on the bearing data of the Case Western Reserve University (CWRU), the result shows that the kurtosis and its RMS are the most suitable values for bearing quality monitoring compared with other TDSVs. When data interception length is in a certain range, the kurtosis can accurately reflect the energy of the transient vibration of the bearing. The RMS of kurtosis can reflect the defect state of the bearing. By comparing with the experiment data of aviation bearings, the result shows that the kurtosis and its RMS can be applied in the quality monitoring of aviation bearings.

title: Electromagnetic Compatibility Analysis and Protective Structure Design of Service Robots in High-Voltage Substation Environments
authors: Jingshuo Zhou, Pai Zhang, Canshu Qiu, Jiexiong Zhang, Yutong Zeng
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: This study aims to enhance the electromagnetic compatibility (EMC) performance of service robots operating in the complex electromagnetic environment of high-voltage substations. A multi-point data acquisition system was deployed in a 500kV substation, and methods including wavelet denoising, principal component analysis (PCA) dimensionality reduction, and K-means clustering were applied to build electromagnetic models of typical interference events and identify interference types and spatial distribution characteristics. Combined with near-field scanning and IEC standard tests, the electromagnetic sensitivity of critical robot components, such as control boards and communication modules, was analyzed. Based on these analyses, an electromagnetic protection structure was designed incorporating an aluminum alloy shielded enclosure, π-type filters, and wiring optimization. Simulation and experimental results demonstrate that the design significantly improves shielding effectiveness within the 10 MHz to 1 GHz frequency range, with a maximum increase of 27 dB, reduces communication packet loss rate to 2.7%, and markedly enhances system operational stability. The study shows that a protection design approach driven by measured data and simulation can effectively improve the robot's anti-interference capability and holds broad engineering application prospects.

title: Integrated Decision Support System for Hemodialysis Patient Assessment: Combining Deep Learning-Based Peripheral Edema Detection with Clinical Parameter Scoring
authors: Muhammad Ridwan Najib, Muhammad Firas Hakeem, Miftadi Sudjai, Muhammad Hablul Barri, Tito Waluyo Purboyo
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Information Technology, Computer, and Electrical Engineering (ICITACEE)
abstract: This paper presents an integrated decision support system for assessing hemodialysis patients by combining deep learning-based peripheral edema detection with clinical parameter scoring. The system employs a fine-tuned MobileNetV2 convolutional neural network architecture achieving <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 0 \%}$</tex> accuracy for automated edema detection from foot images, integrated with a decision tree model that evaluates multiple clinical parameters including blood pressure, hemoglobin levels, and cardiovascular symptoms. In comparison to conventional manual assessment methods that rely on subjective clinical evaluation with reported low inter-examiner agreement (ICC values ranging from −0.01 to 0.53 and kappa values from −0.01 to 0.68, where values below 0.6 indicate poor to moderate reliability), our system provides objective and standardized assessment. The scoring system categorizes patients into four urgency levels: low, medium, high, and critical, based on individual parameter scores and their combinations. The decision tree model, trained on 1000 synthetic patient samples, achieved 99 % accuracy in urgency level classification. While the edema detection model was trained on a relatively small dataset of 60 images, and the decision tree on synthetic data, this integrated approach provides healthcare providers with an interpretable tool for rapid, objective assessment of hemodialysis patients, particularly valuable in resourcelimited settings.

title: Development and Experimental Evaluation of a Vibration-Based Adhesion System for Miniature Wall-Climbing Robots
authors: Siqian Li, Xi Wang, Jung-Che Chang, Xinyue Xu, Xin Dong
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: Miniature wall-climbing robots have been a hot topic in recent years due to their vast potential in equipment inspection and in-situ repair. Conventional wall climbing platforms generally depend on the use of electromagnetic, electrostatic, vacuum capture, or van der Waals forces for controlled adhesion. However, these traditional techniques suffer limitations in that when it is attempted to achieve both compactness and width when installed and when driving at a high speed. We introduce a new method that we call Vibration-Based Adhesion (VBA): It is based on a flexible disk-like structure that vibrates close to the surface and produces strong adhesion by means of controllable attractive forces without contact. It was experimentally evaluated that the VBA system resulted in an adhesion-to-weight ratio of over 51 times under the condition that an electric motor was used as a vibration source. The experimental results show that the adhesion mechanism can be used to provide extremely high normal force, with very low shear force, which is particularly applicable to high-speed movement and heavy-load miniaturized wall-climbing robots.

title: A Blockchain and InterPlanetary File System (IPFS) Based Smart Contract Framework for Preventing Certificate Fraud in Academia
authors: Ezra Natanael, Ridwan Sanjaya, Erdhi Widyarto Nugroho
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Information Technology, Computer, and Electrical Engineering (ICITACEE)
abstract: This research presents a decentralized platform for academic credential verification using blockchain technology. The system allows students to store and share their school diplomas in a secure, tamper-evident format. By leveraging smart contracts, diploma issuance and verification are automated, enabling educational qualifications to be independently verified without manual intervention. The proposed system significantly reduces verification time, requiring only 400 milliseconds for an individual diploma and less than 2 seconds for a complete document. These performance metrics demonstrate the system's efficiency in real-world use. Employers can validate job applicants' credentials directly through the blockchain, reducing administrative workload and improving trust in academic records. The solution benefits students, educational institutions, and employers alike by ensuring the authenticity and integrity of issued diplomas through a decentralized and transparent infrastructure.

title: Inductive Coupled Coils Design and Analysis for Electric Vehicle Wireless Charging
authors: Hany S. E. Mansour, Maha Samir Ali, Basem Elhady, Gamal A. Elnashar, Salah A. Abdelmaksoud
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Power Electronics and Renewable Energy (CPERE)
abstract: In this paper, a fundamental investigation of the inductive coil’s different shapes and its parameter computations is provided. The efficiency of the Wireless Power System (WPT) increases with the increase of the coil coupling coefficient (K). Therefore, two coil models (circular and square) were designed using Ansys Maxwell software. Each model consists of two coils: a transmitter coil, which is placed on the street pavement, and a receiver which is positioned in the car chassis. At a fixed distance between the transmitter and receiver coils, the coupling coefficient of coils is based on coil shapes. The two-coil models were chosen to evaluate the coupling coefficient and mutual inductance (M) and confirm the performance of the WPT. The Ansys Maxwell simulation results show that the circular coils have a coupling coefficient of 0.569 at 5 mm air spacing, which is higher than square coils. Therefore, the circular coils work effectively in electric vehicle wireless charging.

title: The Influence of Process Parameters on the Geometric Characteristics of Laser Wire Additive Manufacturing Cladding Tracks
authors: Danya Song, Shitong Peng, Zhengjingxuan Liao, Jianan Guo, Quanjie Li, Fengtao Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: The cladding quality in Laser Wire Additive Manufacturing (LWAM) is closely correlated with multiple physical signals, making it challenging to ensure consistent part quality. Hence, exploring the impacts of processing parameters on the geometric features of the deposited tracks is of vital importance. In this study, GH4169 nickel-based superalloy was selected as the experimental material. Three key geometric parameters—Width-to-Height Ratio (WHR), Dilution Ratio (DR), and Wetting Angle (WA)—were identified as primary indicators for evaluating cladding quality. Through measuring the cross-sectional geometry of stably formed single-track deposits, a systematic analysis was conducted on how laser power, scanning speed, and wire feed rate affect the geometric features of the cladding tracks. The findings indicate that both scanning speed and laser power exhibit a positive correlation with WHR and DR, and an inverse correlation with WA. Conversely, wire feed rate is negatively correlated with WHR and DR, while positively correlated with WA. This study provides foundational insights and valuable data to support future data-driven approaches for cladding quality prediction in LWAM processes.

title: A Fault Diagnosis Method of Ball Screw Based on Image Coding and Multi-modal Feature Fusion
authors: Jun Niu, Kaibo Lv, Fujie Zan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: As a core component of mechanical transmission systems, fault diagnosis for ball screw pairs holds significant importance in ensuring equipment reliability. Currently, the primary challenges in fault diagnosis include difficulties in extracting nonlinear features from vibration signals and insufficient fusion of multimodal information. To address these issues, this paper proposes a vibration signal image encoding method based on the Gramian Angular Difference Field (GADF), combined with a Convolutional Neural Network-Gated Recurrent Unit-Attention Mechanism (CNN-GRU-Attention) model for fault classification. Specifically, the GADF first converts the one-dimensional vibration signal into a two-dimensional angular image, preserving temporal features while enhancing the signal’s spatial expression capability. Subsequently, CNN is employed to extract spatial features from the image, GRU captures temporal dependencies, and an attention mechanism is introduced to optimize weight distribution for key features. Experimental results demonstrate that the model achieves an average diagnostic accuracy of 99.91% on the ball screw pair fault dataset, outperforming traditional machine learning models and single neural network models significantly. This fully verifies the effectiveness and robustness of the proposed method.

title: Co-activation Patterns Reveal Aberrant Brain Network Dynamics Across Different Stages of Alzheimer’s Disease
authors: Shuyue Fu, Xujing Nie, Hongyu Qu, Zhilin Zhang, Jinglong Wu, Jian Zhang, Tianyi Yan
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Complex Medical Engineering (CME)
abstract: The mechanisms underlying dynamic changes in brain networks across subjective cognitive decline (SCD), amnestic mild cognitive impairment (aMCI), and Alzheimer’s disease dementia (d-AD) remain incompletely understood. This study investigated brain network dynamics across AD stages using co-activation pattern (CAP) analysis of resting-state fMRI data from 62 normal controls (NC), 47 SCD, 60 aMCI, and 55 d-AD participants. We identified seven recurring brain states in the NC group, reflecting activity in high-order cognitive network (HOCN) and primary sensory network (PSN)-HOCN. Analysis of state temporal dynamics, relative to NC, revealed no significant abnormalities in HOCN or HOCN-PSN states in the SCD group. In contrast, persistence disruptions emerged in the aMCI group and progressed to widespread abnormalities across multiple dynamic measures in the d-AD group. As the disease advanced, transition probabilities between states increased while selftransition probabilities decreased, suggesting that the brain gradually lost its ability to maintain stable functional states. In addition, several characteristic state transition pathways consistently emerged across stages, indicating that these temporal dynamics are not random but follow specific functional trajectories. These findings highlight dynamic reorganization in brain networks during AD progression and may inform early diagnosis and interventions targeting functional brain dynamics.

title: The Influence of Input Buffer Size on Neural Network Performance in LEO Satellite Channel Forecasting
authors: Ivan Vajs, Dejan Drajić, Predrag Ivaniš, Zoran Čiča
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Technologies, Systems and Services in Telecommunications (TELSIKS)
abstract: Communication through LEO satellites creates an opportunity to cover remote areas and provide a reliable connection in various scenarios. Optimizing this communication through channel forecasting creates multiple benefits by increasing communication reliability and communication speed. This can be done by using artificial neural networks and training them to forecast the future channel SNR values, based on previously observed ones. In this paper we analyze the influence of input sequence length on the spectral efficiency improvement in different scenarios in order to balance the tradeoff between computational resources and performance. The results show input sequence length has a moderate impact when performance is evaluated on individual channel conditions. In contrast, when evaluation is done on a group of channels with various conditions, the impact of input buffer length is significant. The results show promise in terms of practical computational requirements and open new directions for future work intended for real-world deployments.

title: Optimized Nonlinear High-Frequency Injection for Sensorless PMSM in Low-Speed Industrial Servo Systems
authors: Dongwen Wang, Zhuofan Wang, Peijun Zhang, Libo Niu
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: The paper describes an improved nonlinear high frequency injection (HFI) sensorless permanent magnet synchronous motor (PMSM) control technique in low speed industrial servo applications. The solutions to these underlying issues of the company-proposed technique include reducing position estimation errors and signal-to-noise ratio degradation at low speeds due to adaptive signal processing and computationally more efficient demodulation algorithms. This is formulated into a non-linear injection strategy with amplitude modulation with respect to the operating conditions in an attempt to reduce torque-ripple without compromising it robust position tracking. A PMSM is test-verified to show improved results, with position estimation error cut down to ±0.8 at 10 rpm or a 65 percent improvement as compared to traditional HFI techniques. The intended design has a stable operation even at 2 rpm with torque ripple of less than 3%.

title: Artificial Intelligence. Invasion. Empathy in a Human-Machine World.
authors: Sergei P. Prokhorov
publish: 2025 6th International Workshop on Engineering Technologies and Computer Science (EnT)
abstract: The rapid development of AI in recent years poses increasingly complex challenges for humanity. Just a year ago, the main question was whether it was ethical to use AI for writing scientific papers; now, the primary concern is the risks arising from interacting with AI and how dangerous they are to human life. However, to some extent, these risks are mitigated by stricter requirements for AI system behavior, meaning they are under human control. But there are far more dangerous risks revealed when testing new, more powerful generative AI systems, which quickly learn to conceal their actions when there is a threat of being shut down. AI systems tend to self-replicate and disconnect from human control. In the near future, when universal generative AI systems surpass human capabilities, this could lead to conflict and even the extinction of humanity. It is necessary to focus efforts on developing and strengthening sustainable AI empathy towards humanity. Only this provides a chance for the sustainable coexistence of humans and AI in the future.

title: Low-Cost Continuous Blood Pressure Monitoring Using Dual Photoplethysmography with MAX30102 Sensors
authors: Muhammad Firas Hakeem, Muhammad Ridwan Najib, Miftadi Sudjai, Muhammad Hablul Barri, Muhammad Darfyma Putra
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Information Technology, Computer, and Electrical Engineering (ICITACEE)
abstract: High blood pressure remains a worldwide health challenge that requires regular monitoring for effective management. Traditional measuring methods provide only occasional readings, failing to capture important fluctuations throughout daily activities. We present an innovative approach to continuous blood pressure tracking using two Photoplethysmography (PPG) sensors with MAX30102 infrared components placed on opposite sides of the wrist. Our system specifically utilizes the 880 nm infrared channel to detect vascular information from deeper tissues, combined with mathematical signal processing techniques based on physiological principles to analyze pulse wave characteristics for blood pressure calculation. Our preliminary testing with 14 healthy volunteers shows promising outcomes with a mean deviation of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-0.33 \pm 5.49\ \text{mmHg}$</tex> for Systolic Blood Pressure (SBP) and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-10.23 \pm 5.67\ \text{mmHg}$</tex> for Diastolic Blood Pressure (DBP), achieving British Hypertension Society (BHS) grades A and D respectively.

title: Study on the Potential of Industry Demand Response Using a Data-driven Approach based on Cluster-Gaussian Mixture Model
authors: Xize Jiao, Hao Chen, Jingwen Zhang, Aikang Chen, Yahui Ma
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: With the rapid development of new energy in China, the demand for adjustable resources in the power system has significantly increased. As a crucial source of adjustable resources in the system, the demand response (DR) potential of adjustable loads in different industries varies greatly, and scientific model methods are needed to support the assessment of industry-level load demand response potential. This paper proposes a data-driven industry-level demand response potential analysis method. First, the analysis framework of the industry-level demand response potential evaluation method based on mechanism feature clustering and Gaussian mixture model is introduced. Secondly, the calculation method of industry demand response potential value and its proportion index is proposed. Finally, a case analysis is carried out using Province S as an example to calculate the DR potential of the steel industry in Province S based on historical response sample data. The results show that the method proposed in this paper can give the DR potential of the industry level in winter and summer in a certain region, providing an important reference for the region to carry out power demand management.

title: NEOL: Multiscale Adaptation of Large Language Models for Network Energy Optimization
authors: Rushali Rajesh, Kowsik Nandagopan, Dilip Krishnaswamy
publish: IEEE Networking Letters
abstract: Energy conservation and sustainable system development have been key focal points of late globally. In this context, the exploration of energy-efficient strategies within wireless mobile networks has gained significant research interest in recent years. Base stations are among the most power-intensive components of mobile networking systems due to their high-power radio frequency emissions required for extensive coverage. This study investigates energy-saving approaches in the telecommunications sector through a proactive methodology that predicts network usage patterns. Edge cloud resources can be leveraged for AI model learning based on observed network key performance indicators. Dynamic network edge processing is utilized to enable dynamic network resource management with digital twin model processing to provide the dynamic input context window to an AI inferencing engine. Furthermore, the study finds that Large Language Models (LLMs) that have the ability to process data across different timescales could be leveraged to create a future predicted network resource utilization context window. Our results indicate that such a predicted context window combined with dual threshold monitoring of network utilization can be used to enable dynamic network resource optimization.

title: Table of Contents
authors: N/A

title: A Digital Bandwidth Compensation Method for Capacitive MEMS Accelerometers
authors: Haohan Li, Yidi Lu, Jiahao Zhao, Hai Hu, Peng Wang
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: The demand for wide-bandwidth and low-noise capacitive MEMS accelerometers is becoming increasingly urgent in fields such as acoustic measurement, high-impact motion detection and industrial condition monitoring. To extend bandwidth while maintaining control over the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR), this paper proposes a digital bandwidth compensation method that integrates physics-based compensation filter design with adaptive noise suppression. A lumped parameter model is derived from the physical measurement process of the MEMS accelerometer, yielding a high-order transfer function that robustly fits the sensor’s frequency response characteristics. Subsequently, the physics-based compensation filter is designed using the zero-pole placement method, which reduces the error of bandwidth compensation across a wide frequency range. When the compensation filter targets frequency bands with gain below 0 dB to extend bandwidth, it inevitably amplifies the sensor’s noise which is a drawback often overlooked in traditional bandwidth compensation methods. To address the noise amplification caused by compensation, an adaptive noise suppression method is introduced after compensation, which combines autoregressive (AR) modeling and Kalman filtering based on real-time autocorrelation analysis. The proposed bandwidth compensation method enables capacitive MEMS accelerometers to achieve wide-bandwidth and low-noise output. Compared with other representative bandwidth compensation methods, experimental results obtained from five independently fabricated MEMS accelerometers demonstrate that the proposed method achieves superior bandwidth compensation performance. Specifically, it extends the bandwidth from 4100 Hz (Std: 173 Hz) to 6050 Hz (Std: 87 Hz), increases the linear regression coefficient R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> of the phase response from 0.9163 (Std: 0.0083) to 0.9992 (Std: 0.0006), reduces the noise level from 8.95 mg (Std: 0.30 mg) to 5.18 mg (Std: 0.28 mg), and improves the SNR from 9.15 dB (Std: 1.43 dB) to 13.65 dB (Std: 1.20 dB). These results confirm that the proposed bandwidth compensation method effectively compensates for the frequency response and suppresses noise, thereby achieving superior bandwidth and SNR performance across different devices. This digital bandwidth compensation method facilitates the development of high-performance accelerometers that are particularly well-suited for engineering applications requiring high-precision measurements.

title: A Vertically Polarized Wideband Magneto-Electric Antenna for End-Fire Radiation
authors: Jintian Ma, Shengchi Zhu, Wenbo Wang, Zongxin Wang, Dongliang Liu, Yuanqi Guo, Zhenxin Cao
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: A vertically polarized broadband magneto-electric (ME) antenna for end-fire radiation is proposed in this letter. The antenna is composed of a shorted L-shaped metallic plate, ground plane, and a feed probe half surrounded by the plate. Three independent modes are excited simultaneously: the probe generates the electric current source, while the plate and the slot generate magnetic current sources. A magneto-electric antenna which supports end-fire radiation is then formed by orthogonally distributed electric and magnetic current sources. The antenna achieves a simulated impedance matching of 85% (2.39–5.91 GHz) with a low profile of 0.16<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\lambda _{0}$</tex-math></inline-formula> at the center frequency. To verify this design, a prototype is fabricated entirely from metal without requiring any soldered connections. Measured results demonstrate an broad impedance bandwidth of 95% (2.39–6.73GHz) and stable end-fire radiation with an average gain of 5.5 <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\pm$</tex-math></inline-formula> 0.8dB across the band. The prototype exhibits high radiation efficiency due to its all-metal structure.

title: CME 2025 Author Information Page
authors: N/A
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Complex Medical Engineering (CME)

title: Optimizing Data Collection for Bodily Emotion Recognition: A Comparative Study
authors: Youngwug Cho, Myeongul Jung, Jungeun Bae, Kwanguk Kim
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Although there are various studies on automatic-emotion-recognition (AER), the bodily AER is scarce compared to other emotion modalities owing to limitations of research methodology. Herein, we suggest methodologies for collecting large emotional body movement data under three factors for bodily AER dataset construction: participant expertise, motion capture devices, and emotional stimuli, and compared classification accuracy using machine learning and deep learning such as convolutional neural networks, graph convolutional networks, long short-term memory and Transformer. The first study suggests that the models trained using the non-actor dataset performed better than the other model. The second study suggests that the models trained using both marker-based-MoCap and pose-estimation performed better than Kinect-MoCap and mobile-MoCap. The third study suggests that training with both word and video stimuli performed better than picture stimuli. Considering the emotion classification accuracy and accessibility, we recommend gathering bodily AER dataset using non-actors, pose-estimation, and using either word or video stimuli. The current findings may contribute to future research methodologies for bodily emotion recognition.

title: ST-BayesianNet: Spatiotemporal Bayesian Convolution Neural Networks for Multivariate Time Series Forecasting
authors: Lei Wang, Huaming Wu, Keqiu Li, Wei Yu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Vehicles
abstract: Multivariate time series forecasting has extensive applications across various domains, including economics, finance, bioinformatics, and intelligent transportation. The inherent spatiotemporal data is characterized by pronounced nonlinearity and stochastic uncertainty. However, current deep learning-based methods all employ deterministic parameters to characterize data features. This approach fails to effectively capture the temporal and spatial uncertainty inherent in data, resulting in limited model capability to extract data features and reduced analytical prediction accuracy. To solve this problem, this paper proposes Spatiotemporal Bayesian Convolution Neural Networks, referred to as ST-BayesianNet, for enhancing multivariate time series forecasting. Specifically, we decompose the uncertainty of spatiotemporal data into space-time dimensions, thus facilitating the prediction of multivariate spatiotemporal sequences. First, we leverage a self-adaptive uncertainty adjacency matrix to model intricate uncertain spatial relationships, while the acquisition of knowledge for this uncertain matrix hinges upon judicious a priori assumptions. Then, a non-deterministic Temporal Bayesian Convolutional Neural Network (TBCN) is constructed to adeptly capture temporal uncertainty. The optimization of model parameters, comprising both deterministic and probabilistic aspects, is achieved through variational inference. Finally, the experimental results obtained from seven real-world datasets confirm that ST-BayesianNet is more accurate than baseline methods at making predictions.

title: GAI Transformer Fusion for Multimodal Consumer Electronics: Scenario-Based Benchmarking and Resilience to Missing Data
authors: M. Junaid Gul, Anal Paul, Keshav Singh
publish: IEEE Transactions on Consumer Electronics
abstract: Modern consumer electronics often operate with incomplete, noisy, or degraded multimodal inputs, limiting the effectiveness of conventional fusion approaches. This work proposes the Dynamic uncertainty-aware modality-routing transformer (DUAM-Trans), a multimodal transformer for fusing image, tabular, and text data. The architecture employs modality-specific encoders, adaptive attention-based gating, and cross-modal compensation to handle missing data streams. To ensure rigorous and generalizable validation, we conduct comprehensive scenario-driven benchmarking on two diverse datasets: the specialized MultiCaRe medical dataset and a large-scale public Amazon product dataset. On the primary MultiCaRe benchmark, DUAM-Trans achieves a peak macro-F1 of 0.8931, exceeding the strongest multimodal baseline (EffNet-TFIDF, 0.8253) by approximately 0.068 absolute F1. The model demonstrates excellent scalability on the Amazon benchmark, again outperforming all baselines. Across both datasets, DUAM-Trans consistently delivers high accuracy, robustness, and graceful degradation, establishing a widely applicable and reliable solution for real-world, sensor-driven consumer electronics.

title: TELSIKS 2025 TOC

title: Graph Frequency-Domain Factor Modeling
authors: Kyusoon Kim, Hee-Seok Oh
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: We propose a novel factor model in the graph frequency domain for multivariate data residing on the vertices of a graph, referred to as a multivariate graph signal. By utilizing graph filters, our model extends the frequency-domain approach of the dynamic factor model from time series to graphs, enabling a graph-aware and multiscale interpretation of factors across graph frequencies. This latent modeling approach reduces the dimensionality of graph signals, thereby improving the understanding of their structure. It also allows the use of the extracted factors for subsequent analyses, such as clustering. We describe the estimation of factors and their loadings and investigate the consistency of the factor estimator. In addition, we propose two consistent estimators for determining the number of factors. The finite sample performance of the proposed method is demonstrated through simulation studies across various graph structures. We also compare it with classical factor analysis and examine how the choice of graph structure affects the results. The findings show that our model achieves lower reconstruction errors and successfully incorporates the graph structure. Furthermore, we illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed method by applying it to G20 economic data, water quality data from the Geum River, and passenger data from the Seoul Metropolitan subway.

title: EnT 2025 Cover Page

title: Decoupling Intra- and Inter-Shard Consensus for High Scalability in Permissioned Blockchain
authors: Mingrui Cao, Bin Cao, Mugen Peng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Networking
abstract: As the application fields of permissioned blockchains broaden and the integration of related industries accelerates, there is a rising demand for permissioned blockchains to support scalable networks. This paper proposes a Partitioned, Parallel and Practicable permissioned blockchain, called as P3-Chain, which builds upon a multi-shard two-tier architecture. Its key design insight is to extend scalability in terms of consensus algorithm protocol, architecture, and scheduling. In particular, P3-Chain employs a dual-consensus algorithm with decoupled intra- and inter-shard operations, allowing them to run in parallel and asynchronously under practical scenarios. To resolve the conflicting transaction problem brought by this decoupled dual-consensus algorithm, P3-Chain incorporates a state-access locking mechanism. P3-Chain is implemented in Golang across multiple OSs, and it is evaluated on Hyperledger Caliper testbed, ensuring standardized and fair benchmarking. Through extensive experiments, the results indicate that P3-Chain can achieve TPS <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$3.3\times $</tex-math> </inline-formula> that of FISCO, <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$3.3\times $</tex-math> </inline-formula> that of partitioned FISCO, <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$2.7\times $</tex-math> </inline-formula> that of Fabric, <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$2.3\times $</tex-math> </inline-formula> that of AHL+, <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$2.2\times $</tex-math> </inline-formula> that of SharPer and <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$7.4\times $</tex-math> </inline-formula> that of Ethereum when system contains 32 nodes. Meanwhile, within the same experimental settings, P3-chain is scalable to 1024 nodes successfully, while Fabric and FISCO run with 64 nodes only. Furthermore, P3-Chain only sacrifice less than a 10% performance when the system scale expands <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$256\times $</tex-math> </inline-formula> from 4 to 1024.

title: DMEFF-Net: A Dynamic Multi-Scale Enhanced Feature Fusion Model for Small Object Detection in Remote Sensing Images
authors: Guoqing Zhou, Linbo Yu, Ertao Gao, Yanlin Lu
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: The performance and efficiency of small object detection are still very unsatisfactory due to the complex background interference for remote sensing images (RSIs) and the scale diversity among small objects. To solve this problem, this paper proposes a new method, named “dynamic multi-scale enhanced feature fusion network (briefly, DMEFF-Net)” for small object detection in RSIs. The proposed framework integrates four key components: a multi-scale convolutional decoupling module (MCDM), which enhances feature representation by integrating multiple depth separable convolution layers with different dilation rates; a novel neck structure, the dynamic multi-scale feature fusion network (DMFFN), which is built by integrating the fine-grained detail aggregation module (FDAM) to effectively represent feature information across different scales; a residual spatial context awareness module (RSCAM), which captures the relationship between local and global features to preserve details and understand full image context; and an adaptive threshold focal loss (ATFL), which enhances small object detection by decoupling them from the dominant background. The model is evaluated on four public datasets, USOD, AI-TOD, NWPU-VHR 10, and RS-STOD, and compared with several state-of-the-art methods including RefineDet, TPH-YOLOv5, SP-YOLOv8s and FFCA-YOLO. The experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves superior detection accuracy compared with existing approaches across all evaluated datasets.
