abstract: With the aging of the population, the probability of the elderly suffering from anxiety and depression continues to rise, which seriously affects their physical and mental health. The current subjective self-assessment methods cannot accurately identify patients with anxiety and depression. There is a significant association between physical activity patterns and mental health, and the elderly people with lower levels of physical activity are more likely to experience depressive symptoms. In this study, data from the 13th wave of the National Health and Aging Trends Study (NHATS) were used, with 16 physical activity indicators as features. The XGBoost algorithm was adopted, combined with the SHapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP) analysis method to interpret the features. Finally, a predictive model was constructed to effectively identify anxiety and depressive symptoms in older adults.

title: Research on UAV Path Planning Based on Improved A-star Algorithm for Power Inspection Times
authors: Zhenqi Ma, Jun Zhao, Haodong Ren, Xueyin Li, Xuedong Ren, Bin Sun
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: UAV path planning is the core technology to achieve autonomous navigation and obstacle avoidance, which usually includes global path planning at the front end and local path optimization at the back end. Traditional algorithms rely on building ESDF maps, which have high computational overhead and poor real-time performance. This paper proposes a UAV path planning method based on the improved A-star algorithm. In the global planning stage, a three-dimensional grid map based on Bayesian filtering is constructed, combined with the pre-calculated shortest path matrix, which effectively improves the search efficiency and can quickly replan the path when encountering dynamic obstacles; in the local planning stage, the third-order B-spline curve is introduced to model and optimize the trajectory, comprehensively considering the smoothness, safety and dynamic feasibility of the trajectory, and completing nonlinear optimization through the Ceres solver and LM algorithm. Experimental results show that this method is superior to the traditional Ego-Planner and Fast-Planner algorithms in terms of computational efficiency, trajectory quality and obstacle avoidance performance. It is suitable for complex power inspection scenarios with less dynamic interference and has good engineering application prospects.

title: Strategy for Distribution Networks Considering Dual Uncertainties of Faulted Lines and Photovoltaic Generation
authors: Qian Liu, Qian Chen, Kehan Wu, Jiahua Wang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: As distribution networks evolve from decentralized operation toward a flexibly interconnected paradigm, their power flow regulation capability and post-fault reliability have been significantly enhanced. Considering the uncertainties before and after faults, as well as the heterogeneity among regulation resources in terms of capacity, cost, and response speed, this paper proposes a two-stage fault recovery strategy for distribution networks. In the first stage, prior to line outages caused by faults, key resources are pre-deployed, including network reconfiguration, target output scheduling of micro gas turbines, and connection planning of mobile emergency generator(MEG). In the second stage, following the occurrence of a fault, soft open points(SOP) are coordinated over multiple dispatch intervals, along with selective shedding of non-critical loads, to progressively restore critical load supply. A box uncertainty set and an entropy-based uncertainty set are used to respectively characterize the uncertainties in photovoltaic (PV) generation and the occurrence of faulted branches. The problem is then formulated as a two-stage robust optimization model and solved via a column-and-constraint generation (C&CG) method. Case studies based on a modified IEEE 69-bus interconnected system verify the applicability and effectiveness of the proposed strategy.

title: Beyond Pairwise Connectivity: High-Order EEG Functional Network Representations Enhance Individualized Prediction of Depression Severity
authors: Dixin Wang, Jingxin Liu, Na Chu, Cancheng Li, Jiayao Liu, Lixian Zhu
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Complex Medical Engineering (CME)
abstract: Shifting from conventional low-order interaction (LOI) metrics to high-order interaction (HOI) analyses offers deeper insights into the neural underpinnings of major depressive disorder (MDD). In this study, we introduce a novel informationtheoretic framework based on O-information to quantify HOI from high-dimensional resting-state EEG data. This approach captures synergistic and redundant patterns among brain regions while remaining computationally tractable. We compare grouplevel LOI and HOI connectivity networks and reveal distinct frequency-specific alterations in MDD, highlighting the complementary dimensions of LOI and HOI brain dynamics. To evaluate their predictive relevance, we propose a dual-network sparse latent space regression model (D-SELSER), which integrates LOI and HOI features through sparsity-regularized projections into shared or independent subspaces. Applied to four clinical symptom scales, HOI-based models consistently outperform LOI-based baselines. Notably, the D-SELSER achieves the lowest overall prediction errors, with learned weight matrices which reveal a stronger contribution from HOI-derived connections in individualized prediction. These findings underscore the importance of modeling high-order dependencies in functional brain networks and provide a novel, interpretable framework for personalized prediction in MDD.

title: Fatigue Damage Monitoring Sensors for Structural Damage Quantification
authors: Shuai Wang, Hao Cai, Zhiping Liu, Haojie Xu, Yannan Yu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: This paper presents fatigue damage monitoring sensors for structural damage quantification. The sensor consists of a microstrip patch antenna with crack recognition and a metal ligament for damage sensing. The sensor is arranged on the surface of the structure, and the fatigue information identified by the sensing ligament is quantified into resonant frequency information through the microstrip antenna, thus completing the continuous quantitative monitoring of fatigue damage. Firstly, the design calculation of the microstrip patch antenna and metal ligament parameters was carried out. Then, the design parameters were optimized by simulation, and the monitoring performance of the sensor was analyzed. Finally, the working principle of the sensor is verified by experiments and the influence of the notch size of the sensor on the monitoring performance is analyzed. The results show that the fatigue damage monitoring sensor proposed in this paper has high monitoring accuracy for fatigue damage monitoring and continuous quantification of metal structures.

title: Enhancing User Engagement in Project Management Systems Through UX Evaluation of Gamification Features
authors: Ricky, Elfindah Princes
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Information Technology, Computer, and Electrical Engineering (ICITACEE)
abstract: This research paper investigates the implementation of gamification within agile IT project management systems to enhance engagement and improve user experience among team members. Addressing common challenges such as declining motivation and user disengagement in IT project environments, the study adopts the Mechanics-Dynamics-Aesthetics (MDA) framework to design and assess gamification features systematically. To tailor these features effectively, user motivations are analyzed through Bartle's taxonomy, classifying participants into four personas: achievers, killers, socializers, and explorers. A prototype incorporating key gamification elements—such as points, badges, levels, and leaderboards—is particularly evaluated involving 119 participants through the System Usability Scale (SUS) for rapid usability assessments, detailed Usability Testing across specific tasks, and the User Experience Questionnaire (UEQ), measuring attractiveness, clarity, efficiency, dependability, stimulation, and novelty. The findings demonstrate that integrating structured gamification strategies significantly increases user engagement and satisfaction in project management systems.

title: Artificial Intelligence in the Energy Sector: Regulatory Compliance, Challenges, and Cybersecurity Implications
authors: Ramy Ahmed Fathy
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Power Electronics and Renewable Energy (CPERE)
abstract: The integration of Artificial Intelligence (AI) into energy systems has accelerated the transition toward smart grid infrastructures, offering unprecedented capabilities in automation, demand forecasting, and grid optimization. However, this convergence of AI and smart grid brings about complex challenges that may compromise the safety and security of this critical infrastructure. This paper presents a critical policy analysis to examine the cybersecurity implications of AI adoption in smart grids, addressing the impact of situational awareness IoT systems and decentralized stochastic energy resources within modern smart grid infrastructure. The paper examines common cybersecurity frameworks used in the industry to identify systemic vulnerabilities across an AIenabled grid ecosystem. Key risk vectors examined include increased attack surfaces, due to distributed intelligent devices, black-box phenomena of AI decision-making processes, and AI hallucinations. The paper contributes to the assessment of key cybersecurity challenges associated with using AI in energy systems. This serves as a basis for supporting the development of proper regulatory frameworks for securing distributed smart grid architectures while supporting innovation, emphasizing the need for transparency, explainability, and continuous monitoring.

title: The Future of YOLO: How Open-Vocabulary Detection Evolves Conventional YOLO Architecture in Addressing Imbalanced Datasets
authors: Grace Birgitta Hadhinata, Rafly Adha Prathama, Alexander Agung Santoso Gunawan, Rilo Chandra Pradana
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Information Technology, Computer, and Electrical Engineering (ICITACEE)
abstract: Food ingredient recognition has gathered significant public interest, as this technology addresses various challenges related to the automatic identification of food ingredients, including calorie detection for dietary applications. An unbalanced label distribution in the dataset will pose present challenges during the modeling process, leading to model biased towards one of the labels. Typically, conventional approaches to address the issue of imbalanced datasets involve either modifying the dataset or training parameters. However, these methods can introduce complexity during modeling process. This study aims to bridge this gap by implementing an appropriate model without transforming datasets or training parameters. Especially, the research evaluates and compares the performance of three variants of the YOLO model: YOLOv8, YOLOv11, and YOLO-World. The YOLO-World model is particularly remarkable as it embraces Open Vocabulary Detection (OVD) within its architecture, allowing the model to apply not only visual information but also language information to enhance object detection capabilities. The evaluation was conducted using a food ingredient image dataset which has an unbalanced class distribution, where certain classes has significantly more data than others. To ensure fair evaluation, each model was trained and tested under equivalent conditions. The models evaluated included YOLOv8m, YOLOv11m, YOLOv8n, YOLOv11m, and YOLOv8mWorldv2. The evaluation focused on measuring model performance in terms of detection accuracy and computational efficiency. The findings indicate that OVD models, such as YOLO-World, provide superior accuracy; however, they may not be suitable for deployment on devices with limited specifications. Conversely, YOLOv8n offers a lightweight computational process during both training and prediction, rendering it appropriate for use on devices with constrained capabilities.

title: Design and Application of Oil Online Monitoring System Based on EIS Sensor and WLAN
authors: Min Wang, Guojun Qin, Zheng Hu, Gang Tan, ZiXi Qin, Mingxi Zhu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: The compressor serves as the essential apparatus for the extraction, aggregation, transportation, and processing of natural gas. In response to the demands of online oil monitoring for natural gas compressor units, a design scheme for a oil online monitoring system based on EIS sensor, metal-particle sensor and WLAN (Lora+5G) has been proposed. This involves the establishment of a low-latency, low-power data transmission network dedicated to monitoring oil in natural gas compressor units, alongside the development of an integrated monitoring system encompassing terminal, edge, and cloud platforms. The optimization and development process focused on sensor selection and arrangement, edge gateway innovation, software architecture design, and the formulation of intelligent oil evaluation algorithms. The system was implemented in the Sulige gas field, where application results demonstrated that the newly designed oil online monitoring system effectively addresses the limitations of the existing architecture concerning signal transmission and data aggregation. It enables real-time monitoring, diagnosis, and prediction of lubrication faults and abnormal wear in compressor units, thereby enhancing fault response efficiency and advancing the levels of informatization, digitization, and intelligence in oil detection and preventive maintenance.

title: LD-Net: A Progressive Fusion Network for Enhanced Target Detection in Synthetic Aperture Radar Images
authors: Hao Guo, Qiang Zhao, Shaohui Mei, Yan Feng, Yuanjie Zhi
publish: 2024 5th China International SAR Symposium (CISS)
abstract: Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) technology plays a crucial r ole in target detection across military and civilian domains d ue to its all-weather capabilities and strong penetration. To a ddress the challenges posed by significant target scale variati ons in SAR image target detection, we propose a novel light weight deep learning framework that integrates multiple mo dules for enhanced detection accuracy and efficiency. The m odel utilizes (1) the LD-net, a feature fusion network designe d to mitigate information loss by effectively combining low-and high-level feature representations. (2) the The content-a ware reassembly operator (CARAFE) operator for content-a ware upsampling, which improves feature retention and utili zation; (3) the Receptive Field Block (RFB) module, simulating the human visual system's receptive field to better captur e detailed target features; and Experimental validation on th e SAR-AIRcraft-1.0 dataset demonstrates that our model sig nificantly outperforms baseline approaches, with an approxi mate 1.6% improvement in accuracy over the benchmark Y OLOv8 model, confirming its effectiveness for multi -scale S AR target detection.

title: An Adaptive Dynamic Multiscale Attention Network for Remote Sensing Object Detection
authors: Tao Gao, Haiaun Zhang, Lulu Xu, Xiyue Wang, Feng Wu, Fang Zheng
publish: 2024 5th China International SAR Symposium (CISS)
abstract: Remote sensing object detection (RSOD) faces challenges from complicated environments and tiny objects, which are interrelated. We propose an adaptive dynamic multiscale attention network (ADMA-Net) to address these issues. Initially, our approach incorporates an adaptive dynamic attention module (AAM) to enhance focus on critical features, mitigate noise, and capture multiscale objects as a part of us recommend dynamic global residual fusion module (DRF). By effectively capturing global information, our DRF module allows network to address challenges in intricate environments. Additionally, a productive context-separated, high-efficiency detector (PCD) is proposed to retain essential features for optimal classification and detection, focusing on boosting efficiency. Extensive experiments show ADMA-Net outper-forms state-of-the-art detectors, achieving mean Average Precision (mAP) scores of 73.6%, 95.88%, and 93.12% on the DIOR, RSOD, and (NWPU VHR-10) datasets, respectively.

title: Study on Quantitative Evaluation Method of Tank Bottom Corrosion Based on On-Line Acoustic Emission
authors: Shenjun Yang, Pengcheng Gan, Weiguo Liu, Xiaodong Xie, Guangran Lin, Shi Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: Aiming at the problem that the corrosion rate of atmospheric tank bottom is unknown and can only be predicted by experience, the acoustic emission data and magnetic flux leakage detection data of tank bottom corrosion are comprehensively analyzed, and a quantitative evaluation method of tank bottom plate corrosion based on on-line acoustic emission is proposed. Through 100% magnetic flux leakage detection of the tank bottom plate, the risk curve of corrosion of the tank bottom plate is obtained, so as to calculate the corrosion risk pace (CRP). Before opening the tank, the acoustic emission detection of the tank bottom plate is carried out, and its acoustic emission activity is analyzed, so as to obtain the relationship between acoustic emission activity and the corrosion risk pace, and infer the relationship between corrosion risk pace and actual maximum corrosion pace, so as to establish a quantitative evaluation model of the tank bottom corrosion based on acoustic emission detection. At the same time, the influence of actual working conditions and site environment is fully considered to infer the management corrosion pace, which provides the basis for the decision-making of storage tank management and maintenance.

title: Deep Network-Driven State Space Modeling for Rolling Bearing Degradation Prediction
authors: Yawei Hu, Xiang Fang, Xiaowei Lin, Jinyu Tong, Fuying Zhang, Peng Huang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: Aiming at the non-stationary and non-linear characteristics of rolling bearing degradation, a deep-network-driven state-space modeling method for rolling bearing degradation prediction is proposed. First, the bearing degradation-sensitive features are merged and downscaled using principal component analysis (PCA) to construct health indicators (HI). Then, a deep network-driven state space model is built and trained to predict the bearing degradation. The proposed model is founded on the state-space modeling framework, which uses ECA-BiLSTM network as the state update equation to catch the long-term dependency information in the data; and the variational self-encoder as the degenerate measuring equation to realize the data compression and feature learning to capture the degradation-sensitive features. The Experimental findings indicated that the proposed model can accurately predict the bearing degradation trend.

title: Complex-Valued End-to-End Space Target Recognition via Integrated Network of Enhanced Imaging and Recognition
authors: Peishuang Ni, Yanyang Liu, Lizhong Jiang, Gang Xu
publish: 2024 5th China International SAR Symposium (CISS)
abstract: Recently, deep learning-based radar imaging and inverse synthetic aperture radar (ISAR) space target recognition have been extensively studied. However, these two processes remain separate, limiting the target information available during recognition and thus hindering further improvements in recognition accuracy. To address this issue, this paper proposes a complex-valued end-to-end integrated network for enhanced imaging and recognition, termed CVEIR-Net. In CVEIR-Net, the complex-valued enhanced imaging module employs a complex-valued encoder to extract the hierarchical scattering features from complex echoes and a complex-valued decoder to reconstruct imaging results with enhanced weak scattering features. The complex-valued enhanced recognition module first adjusts unknown deformations in enhanced ISAR imaging results through spatial transformation and then extracts multiscale complex-valued features using stacked complex convolutional layers, enabling end-to-end high-precision target recognition. Experimental results on the space target dataset demonstrate that the proposed CVEIR-Net achieves higher recognition accuracy, indicating that integrating imaging and recognition into a unified network significantly improves space target recognition performance.

title: Study on Ultrasonic Guided Wave Monitoring Technology for Weld Corrosion in Rocket Propellant Tank Repeated Pressurization Tests
authors: Jun Cheng, ZhongWei Yang, Hong Lu, Chunxiao Wang, Hao Chen, Haibo Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: Reusability has emerged as a prevailing trend in the development of aerospace transportation systems. To evaluate the structural reusability performance, ground testing missions involving multiple operational cycles are increasingly implemented. Consequently, the necessity for structural damage monitoring during such testing processes has become increasingly evident. For the rocket propellant tank welds, an ultrasonic-guided-wave monitoring approach tailored to repeated pressurization conditions is introduced. Using an actual rocket propellant tank as the experimental subject, the dispersion characteristics of guided waves in the tank barrel welds were systematically analyzed. On the basis of aliased modal guided wave signals, damage characterization metrics reflecting energy attenuation were formulated. A repeated pressurization experiment extending over a duration of more than 60 days was performed. A monitoring network employing piezoelectric smart layer sensors was established. Weld damage imaging under varying pressurization cycles was successfully accomplished, and the progressive corrosion behavior of the welds corresponding to the number of pressurization cycles was elucidated. The underlying mechanisms of weld corrosion were examined, critically corroded zones were effectively identified, and the efficacy of the proposed methodology was validated.

title: Integrate digital twin with improved TCN-BiLSTM for multi-load prediction model
authors: Jichao Ye, Tong Xia, Linping Liu, Yonghai Xu, Hui Huang, Xinwei Hu
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: To address the issues of low prediction accuracy and difficulty in feature extraction in current power load forecasting models, a multi-load forecasting model that integrates digital twin technology with an improved TCN-BiLSTM has been proposed. First, a digital twin of the power system was constructed to enable real-time dynamic updates and processing of power system data. Then, an enhanced TCN-BiLSTM model was developed. The TCN effectively captures long-term dependencies in time series data by expanding the receptive field through causal and dilated convolution layers, thereby improving computational efficiency. The BiLSTM excels in extracting temporal features, capable of handling both short-term and long-term dependencies in sequence data. By integrating forward and backward information, it can more comprehensively uncover data characteristics. Experimental results show that this method demonstrates excellent performance and high accuracy in power load forecasting evaluations.

title: Electrical Data Acquisition Method and Implementation for On-Load Tap Changers
authors: Guowei Zhou, Hui Yao, Hui Zou
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: To meet the needs of fault diagnosis in On-Load Tap Changers (OLTCs), this paper presents an electrical data acquisition system triggered by tap-changing signals. By monitoring communication messages between the OLTC controller and the OLTC itself, the system substation captures primary and secondary voltage and current data during tap operations in real time. The substation design integrates both hardware circuitry and a state-machine-based software architecture to ensure precise and timely data collection. Experimental results demonstrate stable system performance and successful data capture during tap-up and tap-down operations, supporting OLTC fault diagnostics and showing promising application potential.

title: Distributed Generation for Loss Minimization: An Optimal Placement and Sizing Strategy in Radial Distribution Networks
authors: Tarek A. Boghdady, Ahmed M. Ibrahim, Huda S. Rizk, Sayed A. Zaki
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Power Electronics and Renewable Energy (CPERE)
abstract: The integration of Distributed Generation (DG) units into Radial Distribution Networks (RDNs) presents a significant opportunity to improve system performance, reduce losses, and enhance voltage stability. However, improper placement and sizing of DGs can lead to adverse effects. This paper investigates the optimal sizing and placement of DG units in the IEEE 33-bus RDN using power loss sensitivity factors (LSFs) to identify potential locations. Genetic Algorithm (GA) and a novel technique which is called Musk Ox (MO) optimizer are both employed to identify the optimal size and location of DGs. Objective function is aiming to minimize power losses and improve voltage profiles. Comparative analyses are conducted to evaluate the performance of both optimization methods.

title: Extraction of Abrasion Scratch Topography from Worn Potentiometer Resistive Film Surface Using Vision-Based 3D Reconstruction Coupled with Optical Microscope
authors: Zhendan Lu, Yunxia Chen, Chen Xie, Yawen Zhang, Yu Zhou
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: The study of wear modes in conductive plastic potentiometers (CPPs) benefits from the extraction of three-dimensional (3D) topographies of abrasion scratches at various wear stages. Specialized surface topography measurement devices, such as laser interferometers, are costly for this task and require relatively clean laboratory environmental conditions, which are unsuitable for the harsh environment of wear testing areas. This limitation hampers the ease and lowers the frequency of topography measurements. To overcome these issues, this paper introduces a cost-effective vision-based 3D reconstruction method using an optical microscope. A standard optical metallographic microscope is used to capture images of the resistive film surface, and then computer vision algorithms based on aero-triangulation are utilized to reconstruct the abrasion scratch topographies. As demonstrated by the experimental results, the proposed method offers a balance between affordability and an engineering-acceptable resolution.

title: Heart Rate Measurement by Tracking Involuntary Head Movement
authors: Ali Sameer Salim, Abdul Sattar Mohammed Khidhir
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Information Technology, Computer, and Electrical Engineering (ICITACEE)
abstract: Recently, there has been an increased interest in methods of measuring vital signs that avoid direct contact with people to provide them with comfort or to take into account some cases where it is difficult to measure these indicators through direct contact, such as people who suffer from burned skin or infectious diseases. In this study, a method was presented that measures the heart rate using a regular camera by tracking the head movement generated as a result of the heart pumping blood. This is done by tracking the facial features and their movement, and then the resulting signal is filtered, after which blind source separation techniques are applied to obtain the final result. Experiments were conducted on 20 participants of different ages. The results obtained were good when compared with those of the pulse oximeter device, which had a total mean absolute error value of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1. 6}$</tex> (BPM).

title: Path Percolation with Link Recycling and Fidelity Based Routing in Quantum Networks
authors: Botond L. Márton, László Bacsárdi
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Technologies, Systems and Services in Telecommunications (TELSIKS)
abstract: Quantum communication brings novel ideas and protocols to the field of infocommunications and networks, which imposes new challenges for various networking tasks such routing and link management. In our work we extend a previous model on the behavior of quantum networks and show that this modification reduces the necessary resources for managing a network of this kind.

title: A CAN Bus Based Monitoring System for Elevator Bottoming and Overrun Faults
authors: Ruize Sun, Yuming Peng, Jinping Hu, Junqin Hong, Jianmin Cao, Ye Gu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: In the context of frequent occurrences of elevator accidents attracting global attention, traditional maintenance approaches have proven inadequate to meet contemporary demands. Despite extensive research conducted by numerous elevator manufacturers and scholars on elevator safety, existing monitoring systems still exhibit notable limitations, including limited versatility, escalated hardware costs arising from the inclusion of additional sensors, and an increase in fault nodes. Among various elevator malfunctions, bottoming and overrun faults are of particular criticality due to their high-risk nature and potential to induce catastrophic equipment damage and passenger injuries.Against this background, this study presents a novel elevator monitoring system. A data collector is developed to extract raw CAN bus data from elevators, which undergoes preprocessing and is transmitted via wireless communication to a private cloud platform. Additionally, fault detection algorithms for bottoming and overrun faults are designed to enable elevator fault alerting and other application requirements. The primary advantages of the system are its universal applicability, elimination of extra sensors, resulting in cost-effectiveness, and low susceptibility to environmental interference.

title: Design of Double-Resistor Damped Double-Tuned AC Filters for Harmonic Management of LCCHVDC Systems using Arctic Puffin Optimizer
authors: Asmaa Elhussiny, Shady H. E. Abdel Aleem, E. E. El-Kholy, Ziad M. Ali, Ahmed M. Zobaa
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Power Electronics and Renewable Energy (CPERE)
abstract: This paper proposes a unique harmonic filtering method to improve the power quality (PQ) of a high voltage direct current (HVDC) system. Conventional filtering methods in HVDC systems primarily focus on reducing Total Harmonic Distortion (THD) in voltage waveforms, frequently employing cascaded or parallel filter units that increase system complexity and costs. This paper addresses this gap by introducing a Double-Resistor Damped Double-Tuned Passive Power Filter (DR-DDTF) Filter at the AC sides of Line Commutated Converter (LCC) HVDC systems, a pioneering design integrated with a novel Arctic Puffin Optimization (APO) technique, uniquely engineered to suppress THD in both voltage and current harmonics simultaneously. Unlike previous techniques, the suggested filter uses a simple configuration with only two filters per converter. The research also examines several filtering techniques and the new DR-DDTF for the AC sides of Line Commutated Converter (LCC) HVDC systems. Simulations were performed using the LCC HVDC system to illustrate the DR-DDTF Filter’s superiority, decreasing voltage and current THD, and outperforming traditional filters. The filter’s adaptive tuning capabilities, enabled by APO, assure reliable performance.

title: Arabic Sign Language Recognition using MediaPipe and Deep Neural Network
authors: Youssef Farhan, Zineb Haimer, Oumaima Lamaamar, Abdessalam Ait Madi
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: Individuals with hearing impairments who use Arabic Sign Language (ArSL) often face communication barriers in daily life due to societal unfamiliarity with sign language, limiting their social and professional integration. This paper introduces a high-accuracy ArSL recognition system leveraging MediaPipe for feature extraction and a Deep Neural Network (DNN) for classification. To improve performance and reduce computational complexity, only the most relevant features were collected. By capturing only 21 hand landmark coordinates via MediaPipe, a personally collected dataset of 7,010 samples covering 31 Arabic signs was created. New geometric features (means, angles and distances) have been created to improve spatial understanding using feature engineering techniques, which produce new, more informative features and capture better geometric relationships between hand landmarks. The proposed DNN model achieved a test accuracy of 99.71%, demonstrating near-perfect recognition capability. These results validate the effectiveness of combining MediaPipe for efficient feature extraction with DNN modeling and strategic engineered feature. Furthermore, the proposed research advances accessible communication tools for Hearing-impaired Arabic individuals and provides a scalable methodology applicable to other sign languages.

title: Predicting Depression Treatment Outcome Using Daily Step Count Sensory Data
authors: Md Zakir Hossain, Soumyashree Sahoo, Chinmaey Shende, Parit Patel, Reynaldo Morillo, Zijie Pan, Xinyu Wang, Jinbo Bi, Jayesh Kamath, Alexander Russell, Dongjin Song, Bing Wang
publish: ACM Transactions on Computing for Healthcare
abstract: Personalized depression treatment, despite decades of research, is still elusive. The current best practice is closely monitoring patients and adjusting the treatment as needed. Close monitoring of patients is, however, challenging in clinical settings due to high cost, limited resources, and patient burden. In this paper, we explore using daily step counts automatically collected by a fitness wristband for depression treatment status monitoring. We focus on deep learning models that can effectively learn feature representation from a sequence of raw daily step count data, without relying on handcrafted features. One significant challenge is that our dataset is small, while deep learning models typically need large amounts of data to achieve strong generalization. To address this challenge, we investigate self-supervised contrastive pretraining to learn feature representation, followed by utilizing these representations for binary classification. Our results show that this contrastive pretraining approach significantly outperforms several state-of-the-art deep learning models. When using step count data together with a one-shot self-reported baseline questionnaire score, it leads to validation F1 score up to 0.74, comparable to the best F1 score (0.72) when using baseline and burdensome periodic self-reported scores. Last, when further including daily sleep data, the best F1 score is improved to 0.77.

title: Design, Construction, and Experiment of Roller Shaped High-temperature Superconducting Coil Joint Apparatus
authors: Hyunsoo Park, Jaemin Kim, JuKyung Cha, Jaheum Koo, Se Lee, Ga¨ el Berthet, Younghoon Kim, Wonju Jung, Geonyoung Kim, Sangwon Yoon, Haigun Lee, Seungyong Hahn, Sangjin Lee
publish: IEEE Transactions on Applied Superconductivity
abstract: The fabrication of high-temperature superconductor (HTS) magnets often involves manual soldering joints, which relies on operator skill and causes performance variations. To address these challenges, this study presents the design, construction, and experimental evaluation of a roller-shaped HTS coil joint apparatus for soldering rare-earth barium copper oxide (REBCO) tapes. The apparatus was developed to facilitate the soldering process across various coil dimensions, ensuring high performance and reliable joints between HTS coils. First, simulations and analyses were conducted to ensure the thermal and mechanical requirements based on prior REBCO tape-to-tape joint researches. The apparatus is equipped with functionalities to control parameters such as solder type, target temperature, heating rate, holding time, cooling time, and pressure. Then, the constructed joint apparatus was primarily utilized to validate the tape-to-tape soldering process, with a focus on maintaining consistent electro-mechanical performance. Finally, experimental evaluations of HTS coil-to-coil joints evaluations demonstrated the ability to achieve high performance and reliability joint, highlighting its potential for applications in advanced HTS REBCO magnet systems.

title: Lyapunov-based Control Barrier Functions for Real-Time Safe Navigation in Three-dimension Complex Environments
authors: Fuwei Zhang, Zhiwei Hou
publish: IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters
abstract: In the field of safe navigation for mobile robots, control barrier functions (CBFs) have garnered significant attention due to their ability to transform complex safety constraints into real-time solvable optimization problems. In this letter, we propose a novel Lyapunov-based CBF framework. It offers the following key advantages: (1) Using a single Control Lyapunov Function (CLF), this method synthesizes spatially shifted CBFs to construct an expansive safe invariant set in obstacle-dense environments. (2) The framework is capable of incorporating existing approaches for constructing quadratic CLF, making it applicable to a wide range of complex nonlinear systems and enhancing its generality and extensibility. (3) It enables real-time synthesis of CBFs, and ensures safety in large-scale 3D environments through efficient CBF-based quadratic programming (CBF-QP). (4) The method ensures safety while inheriting the stability properties of the CLF, allowing the asymptotic convergence of the system state to equilibrium, thus unifying safety and motion stability. To validate efficacy, we rigorously tested the framework in both simulations and hardware experiments.

title: Strip-ViTAE: A Direction-Aware Transformer with Enhanced Feature Modeling for Remote Sensing Image Object Detection
authors: Minqi Lin, Hongzhen Chen, Chenzheng Li, Guangyuan Liu, Chunjiang Bian
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: Recently, ViTAE-RVSA, the first large-scale Vision Transformer (ViT) tailored for remote sensing, has demonstrated the potential of ViTs by integrating window attention with a convolutional branch. However, as this branch still adopts isotropic square kernels and conventional Feature Pyramid Networks neglect directional priors in multi-scale fusion, the resulting representations remain suboptimal for arbitrarily oriented, high-aspect-ratio, and small objects. To overcome these limitations, we propose Strip-ViTAE, a transformer-based detector that embeds a rotation-equivariant convolution (R2Conv) in the backbone to capture orientation-consistent local features. Moreover, we introduce a Parallel Strip Convolution Module (PSCM) employing horizontal and vertical strip kernels to adaptively enlarge the receptive field and strengthen local feature modeling for elongated and small objects. Finally, we design a Strip Feature Pyramid Network (StripFPN) composed of a Bottom-Up Reflow Module (Bottom-Up RM), a Strip-Based Enhancement Module (SBEM), and a Self-Attention Excitation Module (SAEM) to achieve direction-consistent cross-scale fusion. Experiments on the DOTA-v1.5 dataset show that Strip-ViTAE attains 72.82% mAP, surpassing the state-of-the-art (SOTA) by 1.35% and improving the mAP for high-aspect-ratio and small objects by 3.20%, validating the effectiveness of our method.

title: Cover
authors: N/A
publish: 2024 5th China International SAR Symposium (CISS)

title: Impact-Angle-Constrained Guidance via Virtual Targets for Large Initial Heading Errors
authors: Muhua Qian, Donghe Chen
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Precision strike systems struggle to simultaneously achieve terminal impact angle and zero-miss-distance constraints. This is especially challenging with limited resources and uncertain autopilot dynamics. This paper proposes a guidance law utilizing a virtual coordinate system. Its adaptive parameters are stability-guaranteed and derived from Lyapunov analysis. The method introduces two key innovations. First, a virtual target transformation ensures compatibility with conventional guidance architectures by decoupling angular error compensation. Second, a nonlinear parameterization eliminates offline tuning, enhancing computational efficiency for resource-constrained systems. These advancements enable real-time adaptation to autopilot dynamics, ensuring robust performance. Rigorous Lyapunov-based stability analysis confirms the method’s convergence under defined constraints. Comparative simulations validate its superiority over existing approaches, demonstrating an 87% success rate and a 2.13-fold reduction in total acceleration compared to Linear Impact Angle Constrained Guidance.

title: Enhancing Communication Security in TDMA-based Multi-User VLC with Obstructed Links: A Relay-Aided Cooperative Transmission and Jamming Approach
authors: Kun Wu, Yuhan Dong, Xinchun Yu, Yongkang Ding, Jian Song, Xiao-Ping Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications
abstract: In this paper, we propose an innovative relay-aided physical layer security scheme leveraging cooperative transmission and jamming that operates effectively in time-division-multiple-access-based multi-user visible light communication (MuVLC) systems with obstructed communication links. First, to circumvent obstacles between the light source (LS) and legal receivers, we utilize a transmission relay (TR) to forward information signals from the LS to the receiver plane. Subsequently, to ensure communication security, we select a jamming relay to enlarge the channel capacity gap between eavesdroppers and legal receivers through cooperative jamming. Using stochastic geometry, we derive closed-form expressions for key performance metrics, including the cumulative distribution function of secrecy capacity, security outage probability, and their lower and upper bounds, both with and without relay cooperation. To further enhance system security, we introduce a disk-shaped security-protected zone around the TR. All analytical expressions are numerically verified through Monte Carlo simulations, serving as benchmarks to evaluate security performance. Numerical results confirm that our proposed scheme can ensure continuous signal reception and high-level security. Furthermore, while relay cooperation modestly enhances system security, the introduction of a security-protected zone around the TR yields substantial security improvement, which offers practical insights for designing secure time-division-multiple-access-based MuVLC where communication links are obstructed.

title: Forest Tree Species Classification Based on Deep Ensemble Learning by Fusing High-Resolution, Multi-Temporal, and Hyperspectral Multi-Source Remote Sensing Data
authors: Dengli Yu, Lilin Tu, Ziqing Wei, Fuyao Zhu, Chengjun Yu, Denghong Wang, Jiayi Li, Xin Huang
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: Forest tree species classification has great significance for sustainable development of forest resource. Multi-source remote sensing data provides abundant temporal, spatial, and spectral information for tree species classification. However, there lacks tree species classification methods which comprehensively capture and fuse spatio-temporal-spectral information. Therefore, a tree species classification method based on deep ensemble learning of multi-source spatio-temporal-spectral remote sensing data is proposed. Firstly, multi-temporal, high-resolution and hyperspectral data are utilized for training temporal, spatial, and spectral deep networks. Furtherly, deep ensemble learning is developed for fusion of spatio-temporal-spectral network outputs, where weighted fusion is implemented via dynamic weight optimization based on the spatio-temporal-spatial features. Experimental results indicate that the importance of temporal features is higher than that of spatial information, and spectral networks perform best among all network structures. After the spatio-temporal-spectral ensemble learning, the performance of tree species classification is further improved, and the overall accuracy of the proposed method reaches above 90%. The proposed algorithm realizes precise and fine-scale tree species classification, and provides technique support for the monitoring and conservation of forest resource.

title: Interpretable Fair Value Hierarchy Classification via Hybrid Transformer-GNN Architecture
authors: Bingying Jiang, Bi Wu, Jialei Cao, Yutong Tan
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Fair value hierarchy classification under IFRS 13 presents a significant challenge in financial reporting, requiring accurate categorization of financial instruments into Level 1 (directly observable prices), Level 2 (indirectly observable inputs), or Level 3 (unobservable inputs). This classification critically impacts perceived valuation reliability, yet remains inconsistent when performed manually. We propose a novel hybrid architecture combining transformer-based attention with graph neural networks (GNNs) that jointly exploits temporal market patterns and inter-instrument relational dependencies. Our approach leverages transformer encoders to capture time-series dynamics in market data while utilizing graph neural networks to model structural relationships between instruments. To address limited labeled data availability, we implement self-supervised pretraining on unlabeled market data, enhancing model efficiency. The architecture’s attention mechanisms provide interpretable explanations crucial for audit and regulatory compliance. Experiments on open-source datasets of derivatives and structured products demonstrate that our model achieves 88% classification accuracy, significantly outperforming traditional methods including rule-based classifiers (73%) and XGBoost (80%). Notably, our model excels at identifying Level 3 instruments (F1-score 0.90) while maintaining interpretability through attention-based explanations that highlight key temporal periods and influential instrument relationships. Ablation studies confirm the complementary contributions of both transformer and GNN components. This work bridges advanced deep learning with financial compliance requirements, facilitating more consistent, accurate, and transparent valuation procedures that align with regulatory standards.

title: Enhancing Redactable Blockchain With Robust and Efficient Threshold Redaction
authors: Zhaoman Liu, Biming Zhou, Yunlei Zhao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing
abstract: Blockchain technology, known for its decentralized and tamper-resistant nature, offers strong auditing guarantees across a wide range of applications. However, its inherent immutability presents challenges when correcting erroneous transactions or removing sensitive information is necessary. To address this, the concept of redactable blockchain has emerged, aiming to improve adaptability to real-world regulatory and operational needs. Yet, existing designs often suffer from limitations in decentralization, security, or efficiency. This paper introduces an Enhanced Threshold Chameleon Hash (ETCH) scheme as a foundational building block for redactable blockchains. ETCH enables redactions only when a predefined threshold of nodes collaborates to generate trapdoor shares, preserving decentralization. It also enhances collision resistance, overcoming key security flaws in prior schemes, and incorporates a periodic trapdoor refresh mechanism to improve long-term robustness. Experimental results show that ETCH reduces computational overhead by 50% in Hash and Verify phases and by 22.26% in the Adapt phase. The prototype implementation of the ETCH-based redactable blockchain further confirms ETCH's effectiveness in supporting low-latency redactions and mitigating blockchain state growth. Overall, ETCH improves both the security and efficiency of redactable blockchains, broadening their applicability in privacy-sensitive and regulated scenarios.

title: Application of Convolution Neural Network for Unfolding Simulated Neutron Spectra of an Activation Spectrometer
authors: Rodayna Hmede, Thibaut Vinchon, Quentin Ducasse, Mokhtar Z. Alaya, Wilfried Monange, Jeremy Bez, Ronan Lelièvre, Francois Trompier
publish: IEEE Transactions on Nuclear Science
abstract: Neutron studies are of significant interest in fields such as radiation protection, nuclear reactor physics, and criticality safety, where accurate determination of the neutron field is essential. Determining the neutron field typically involves unfolding the detector signals, such as those obtained from the Activation and Counting Neutron Spectrometer (SNAC) detector. Traditional methods, as Bayesian approaches, have been widely integrated for the neutron spectrum unfolding. However, these methods rely on an initial solution estimation, introducing biases or uncertainties. Recent studies in Artificial Intelligence (AI) have demonstrated its potential to address challenges as hysteresis regression. This work is based on our novel convolutional neural network (CNN) architecture to overcome the hysteresis problem in neutron spectrum unfolding. The CNN model predicts the neutron spectrum directly from detector counts, eliminating the need for prior solution predictions. The proposed architecture was trained on a large simulation dataset and validated through a combination of Serpent simulations of various Californium-252 (Cf) spectra and Monte Carlo N-Particles (MCNP) simulations of the Silene reactor. These two complementary simulation approaches are used to evaluate the CNN’s evaluation in realistic neutron environments. The results demonstrate the model’s high efficiency and accuracy, as evidenced by key performance metrics and the quality of the predicted spectrum (SQ). This approach represents a significant step forward in optimizing and validating AI-based methods for neutron field, especially in criticality dosimetry and radiation protection applications. Preliminary comparisons with Bayesian unfolding codes already indicate than CNN based predictions can capture fine spectral features. A benchmark against MAXED, GRAVEL and Nubay remains a key perspective, together with validation campaigns on neutron facilities.

title: Classification and Analysis of Packaging Design Styles Based on Visual Feature Extraction
authors: Tang Xin, Sungpil Kim, Zhang Shangshang
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: This study addresses the critical task of analyzing packaging design styles through advanced visual feature extraction, aligning with the mission of advancing computational sciences and applications in areas such as computer vision, machine learning, and pattern recognition. Traditional methods for style classification often depend on manually designed descriptors or basic segmentation techniques, which are constrained by limited semantic representation, poor generalization across diverse packaging motifs, and low classification accuracy. To address these challenges, this research proposes a method that extracts multi-level visual features—including color, texture, shape, and structural layout—from packaging images using a deep neural network architecture that combines convolutional layers with attention modules and semantic segmentation. The extracted feature vectors are utilized in a classification pipeline to categorize packaging designs into stylistic groups. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves a style classification accuracy improvement of over 4% and exhibits enhanced clustering coherence, indicating clearer separation between stylistic categories. Furthermore, model optimization techniques reduce inference time by approximately 20%, enhancing computational efficiency. These findings underscore the effectiveness of the integrated feature extraction and classification framework, contributing to the fields of computational aesthetics and multimedia vision by advancing methodologies in visual feature extraction, semantic segmentation, and style analysis.

title: VLF Scattering Characteristics of Dielectric Cylinder Receiving Antennas in an Anisotropic Magnetoplasma
authors: Zhu Hong Lin, Guang Chen, Yu Feng Yu
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: The VLF space-borne receiving antenna, operating in the ionosphere, holds significant importance for ionosphere detection, remote sensing, and communication. However, materials covering the receiving antenna influence the accuracy of experimental data. To address this, we utilize a finite-length dielectric cylinder as the antenna model and transform the receiving antenna problem into a target scattering problem. A theoretical method is developed for studying the scattering properties of a finite-length dielectric cylinder in the anisotropic ionosphere. Our analysis outlines the surface current and scattered pattern in terms of the ordinary wave (O-wave) and extra-ordinary wave (E-wave) using the integral equation (IE) approach and the method of moment (MoM). Numerical results demonstrate that the current distribution is sensitive to the structure’s dimensions (radius and length of cylinders), incident angles, and material characteristics. The surface current of a dielectric cylinder is composed of electric and magnetic currents, with electric current playing the main role. Furthermore, the variations in current amplitude and phase as functions of operating frequency are also studied. The current envelope undergoes slight modifications as the frequency varies. For a given geometry, it becomes more pronounced and shifts towards higher frequencies. Moreover, it is noted that an increment in the scattering angles will lead to a rise in the scattered pattern. Compared with the model analyzed using COMSOL based on the finite element method (FEM) and series method, the results show that the scattered fields against the IE method are in good agreement with those obtained from FEM. Meanwhile, the IE method indicates a low relative error of 3% compared to FEM.

title: Graph Retrieval-Augmented Generation: A Survey
authors: Boci Peng, Yun Zhu, Yongchao Liu, Xiaohe Bo, Haizhou Shi, Chuntao Hong, Yan Zhang, Siliang Tang
publish: ACM Transactions on Information Systems
abstract: Recently, Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) has achieved remarkable success in addressing the challenges of Large Language Models (LLMs) without necessitating retraining. By referencing an external knowledge base, RAG refines LLM outputs, effectively mitigating issues such as “hallucination”, lack of domain-specific knowledge, and outdated information. However, the complex structure of relationships among different entities in databases presents challenges for RAG systems. In response, GraphRAG leverages structural information across entities to enable more precise and comprehensive retrieval, capturing relational knowledge and facilitating more accurate, context-aware responses. Given the novelty and potential of GraphRAG, a systematic review of current technologies is imperative. This paper provides the first comprehensive overview of GraphRAG methodologies. We formalize the GraphRAG workflow, encompassing Graph-Based Indexing, Graph-Guided Retrieval, and Graph-Enhanced Generation. We then outline the core technologies and training methods at each stage. Additionally, we examine downstream tasks, application domains, evaluation methodologies, and industrial use cases of GraphRAG. Finally, we explore future research directions to inspire further inquiries and advance progress in the field. In order to track recent progress, we set up a repository at https://github.com/pengboci/GraphRAG-Survey.

title: Decision letter for "Strip-ViTAE: A Direction-Aware Transformer with Enhanced Feature Modeling for Remote Sensing Image Object Detection"
authors: N/A
publish: N/A

title: Multimodal Fusion for Smart Contract Vulnerability Detection: An Experimental Dive
authors: Huynh-Giang Le, Huu-Han Nguyen, Thai Hung Van, Doan Minh Trung, Phan The Duy
publish: 2025 24th International Symposium on Communications and Information Technologies (ISCIT)
abstract: Smart contract vulnerabilities pose serious risks in blockchain ecosystems, yet existing detection methods often rely on either source code or opcode analysis in isolation, missing complementary information across modalities. This paper presents a multimodal learning framework that combines semantic features extracted from source code using CodeBERT with Structure-Based Traversal (SBT) encoding and behavioral patterns derived from opcode sequences using a gMLP(gated Multi-Layer Perceptron) model applied to TF-IDF vectors. The framework systematically evaluates various fusion strategies, including concatenation, self-attention, cross-attention, and a hybrid attention mechanism, all within a unified architecture and dataset. Extensive experiments on the SmartBugs benchmark demonstrate two key findings: (1) the pairing of CodeBERT(SBT) and gMLP(opcode) achieves superior modality synergy (F1-score: 0.84), and (2) our hybrid attention fusion mechanism further improves performance to 0.87 F1, outperforming other fusion strategies by up to 3.6%. Compared to the best unimodal baselines, our approach yields a 12.8% F1 gain. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first study to provide a systematic benchmark of these fusion strategies under a unified framework for smart contract vulnerability detection. These results underscore the importance of informed modality selection and intelligent fusion design in building robust AI-driven vulnerability detection tools.

title: Mitigating Class Imbalance in Chest X-Ray Classification With Memory-Augmented Models
authors: Hoang Khuong Duy, Nguyen Huu Duy, Huynh Cong Viet Ngu
publish: 2025 24th International Symposium on Communications and Information Technologies (ISCIT)
abstract: Chest X-ray analysis using deep learning has shown promise in automated diagnosis, yet performance is hindered by class imbalance and limited data for rare diseases. We propose a memory-augmented deep learning framework for multi-label chest X-ray classification that addresses these challenges by integrating a memory bank module to store and retrieve reliable pathological features. This mechanism enhances representation learning by filtering out uncertain outlier features and retaining stable pathological patterns, leading to improved classification accuracy. Evaluated on the ChestX-ray14 dataset, our model outperforms state-of-the-art baselines, achieving higher AUC scores across multiple disease categories. Feature visualization via PCA and t-SNE reveals more distinct and compact clusters for pathological classes, highlighting the effectiveness of memory-enhanced learning in mitigating long-tailed distribution effects.

title: SAR Image Small Target Detection Algorithm Based on Improved YOLOv8
authors: Qianqian Wang, Yan Feng, Shaohui Mei
publish: 2024 5th China International SAR Symposium (CISS)
abstract: To address the problem that small targets in SAR target detection often appear as scattering points with high brightness and insignificant features, and are easily confused with noise or background, we propose a novel algorithm based on improved YOLOv8. Firstly, considering the small targets in SAR images, adding a small target layer into the neck network to capture details. Secondly, the global feature pyramid network is combined to produce better fused features. And a global attention mechanism is introduced to reduce feature loss and amplify features in the global dimension. Finally, the generalized Focal Loss is used to improve the miss-detection false detection in target aggregation scenarios. The experimental results show that the improved algorithm achieves a detection accuracy of 93.1 % on the MSAR dataset, which is 3.2 percentage points higher than the YOLOv8s algorithm, thereby enhancing the algorithm's ability to detect small targets in complex backgrounds.

title: Enhanced ECG Classification Using Deep Convolutional Neural Networks
authors: Hassoun Zakaria, Aattouchi Issam, Ait Kerroum Mounir
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: Cardiovascular diseases continue to pose a significant global health problem, accounting for approximately 32% of all global deaths according to the World Health Organization. Emphasizing the urgent need for efficient and reliable diagnostic methods, electrocardiogram (ECG) analysis offer critical informations on cardiac state and activity, making it fundamental for identifying a wide range of heart conditions. This paper presents an enhanced approach for ECG signal classification using deep convolutional neural networks (CNNs). We introduce several improvements to conventional CNN architectures, including statistical resampling, targeted data augmentation, residual connections, and attention mechanisms to address the significant class imbalance present in ECG datasets. Using the MIT-BIH Arrhythmia Database, our model classifies five arrhythmia categories: Normal, Supraventricular, Ventricular, Fusion, and Unknown beats, achieving 98% accuracy. Our experimental results, including a comprehensive ablation study, demonstrate that each component of our architecture contributes to the overall performance, with data augmentation and class weighting having the most significant impact. The enhanced model shows particular strength in handling the severe class imbalance (82.8% Normal beats) common in real-world ECG datasets, making it suitable for clinical applications. Comparative analysis with recent state-of-the-art methods reveals that our approach offers a favourable balance between classification accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: FPGA-Based Hardware Acceleration for EEG Signal Classification in Brain-Computer Interfaces
authors: Yizhou Yang, Gang Bu
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Complex Medical Engineering (CME)
abstract: In recent years, with the rapid growth of demand in medical rehabilitation and human-machine interaction, BrainComputer Interface (BCI) technology has become increasingly important. In the field of electroencephalogram (EEG) signal recognition, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) have become a research focus due to their strong feature extraction capabilities. However, current EEG signal processing methods, often constrained by CPU-based computing due to memory access limitations, struggle with high computational complexity and insufficient real-time performance. These limitations hinder the development of portable and low-power BCI systems for future applications. To address these issues, this study focuses on EEGNet, a lightweight CNN model, and proposes a hardware-software collaborative optimization strategy. We designed a configurable hardware acceleration framework to improve efficiency. Experimental results on the BCI Competition IV Dataset using an FPGA platform show that the proposed method achieves millisecond-level real-time inference while maintaining low resource usage. Compared to software implementation solutions, it reduces power consumption by $\mathbf{9 2. 4 \%}$ and delivers an $\mathbf{8. 2}$ times speedup with only a $0.9 \%$ accuracy drop. This work demonstrates notable strengths in three aspects: accuracy preservation, inference efficiency, and power consumption characteristics, thus providing an efficient solution for the hardware deployment of BCI systems.

title: Facial Expression Recognition Using Deep Learning: A Hybrid Approach with ResNet121 and LightGBM
authors: Jialin Li, Liren Pan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: Facial expression recognition (FER) plays a vital role in human-computer interaction, social robotics, and mental health monitoring. This paper proposes a novel deep learning framework for FER that combines ResNet121 for deep feature extraction and LightGBM for efficient classification. Traditional FER methods often suffer from low accuracy and poor generalization due to manual feature engineering and limited learning capabilities. To address these challenges, we introduce a hybrid architecture that leverages the power of deep convolutional networks and gradient boosting. Our method first employs ResNet121 to extract high-level discriminative features from facial images, followed by a LightGBM classifier optimized with weight normalization to enhance classification performance. Experiments conducted on the FER13 dataset demonstrate that our approach achieves superior accuracy (99.19%), recall (98%), F1 score (98%), and precision (98%) compared to existing methods. The results highlight the effectiveness of our framework in capturing complex emotional expressions and its potential for real-time applications. Future work will explore the integration of multimodal data and advanced architectures like Transformers to further improve robustness and generalization.

title: Research on Remote Control Link of Target Vehicle Considering MQTT Communication Delay Interference
authors: Zhenji Meng, Heyan Li, Baolong Wang, Haoyun Yuan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: In order to improve the safety, repeatability, and standardization of the execution of assisted driving vehicle test scenarios, this paper proposes the use of remote driving cooperative control for interference target vehicles to effectively reproduce standard interference test dynamic scenarios and examine the performance of assisted driving vehicles. The jamming target vehicle achieves low-latency remote transmission of inertial guidance information, vehicle information, and control instructions with the help of a Local Area Network (LAN), a Message Queuing Telemetry Transport (MQTT) server, and Controller Area Network (CAN) protocol conversion equipment. The terminal computing center deploys cloud servers to receive vehicle feedback information for lateral and longitudinal control models, planning vehicle trajectories, desired speeds, and accelerations, etc. The lower controller, composed of lateral LQR and longitudinal dual PID, sends control commands and remotely transmits them to the jamming target vehicle, realizing closed-loop data. By designing simulation condition experiments and Real-time Software-in-the-Loop (RT-SIL) experiments to study the communication link delay throughout the entire process and the control effect of the control algorithm under this delay, the results show that the vehicle has a good trajectory tracking control effect in both straight-line acceleration and deceleration conditions and lane change conditions. Its speed tracking effect, longitudinal error, lateral error, and heading angle error achieve ideal results.

title: Inverse Physics-Constrained Learning for Robust Fault Diagnosis in Robotic Joint Transmission Systems
authors: Qiao Han, Jing Liu, Yuan Zheng, Hao Lan, Xu Tan, Weihua Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: Accurate and interpretable fault diagnosis for robotic joint transmission systems remains a key bottleneck in achieving reliable industrial automation. These systems often degrade through complex time-varying dynamics—such as stiffness loss and damping fluctuations—that challenge conventional black-box models, especially when signal noise and structural ambiguity are involved. To overcome this, we propose an inverse Physics-Constrained Learning (iPCL) framework that infers latent mechanical parameters from vibration signals using a simplified dynamic model. A residual physics constraint is introduced to align estimated responses with system dynamics, offering physically consistent supervision without relying on hard-to-measure forces. In parallel, motor current signals are leveraged as auxiliary inputs to enhance class separability, decoupled from the physics pathway to preserve interpretability. The fused representation significantly improves both classification accuracy and physical insight. Experimental results on real-world joint datasets demonstrate that iPCL consistently outperforms traditional signal-driven and deep learning baselines. This work establishes a scalable and physically grounded diagnostic paradigm for intelligent health monitoring in industrial robotic transmissions.

title: Defect Detection in Terahertz Images by the Enhanced YOLOv8 Network
authors: Yijing Liu, Xingyu Wang, Yuqing Cui, Nuoman Tian, Tiancheng Zhou, Liuyang Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: Terahertz defect detection plays a crucial role in various industrial applications, where accurate and efficient identification of small defects is challenging. In this study, we propose an enhanced version of YOLOv8 tailored for terahertz defect detection, incorporating key innovations to address the challenges posed by small and densely packed defects. Our model integrates a P2 layer for improved small object detection, Outlook Attention for contextual awareness, and ODConv for adaptive convolutions. To support model development and evaluation, we constructed a customized dataset using dual-material 3D-printed samples with diverse defect morphologies, captured via a QCL-based THz imaging system. Our enhanced model achieves a mAP@0.75 of 0.724 and a mAP@0.5-0.95 of 0.625, outperforming the YOLOv8 baseline by 11.0% and 3.3%, respectively, and surpassing even robust YOLO versions like YOLOv9 and YOLOv10. Visual comparisons further highlight the enhanced detection accuracy, with high confidence scores and few missed detections, particularly for small defects. These results demonstrate that our approach is highly effective for terahertz defect detection.

title: Spare Parts Demand Forecasting and Reserve Optimization: A Gradient Descent Approach with Real-Data Validation
authors: Chen Zhang, Qiuyan Yao, Hui Yang, Xiaoliang Luo, Xiaojing Wang, Lin Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: Aiming at the problem that aviation spare parts inventory management is difficult to dynamically respond to demand fluctuations and lack of multi-airport reserve layout optimization, this paper proposes a data-driven three-stage framework: Firstly, we establish the consumption rule of spare parts. Secondly, the Deep Q-Network (DQN) was used to construct a multi-warehouse dynamic inventory optimization. Finally, the aviation spare parts demand under the condition of multiple airports was solved, and the spare parts reserve amount of each airport was reasonably allocated. The results show that the proposed framework has high prediction accuracy, supports adaptive spare parts inventory optimization among multiple airports, and lays a foundation for the application of dynamic optimization and predictive maintenance fusion technology for aviation equipment.

title: Optimal Decision-Making Model for Renewable Energy Cost Analysis in Cross-Regional DC Transmission Channels under Medium-to-Long Term and Spot Trading Modes
authors: Honghao Guan, Yunpeng Xiao, Haiqiong Yi, Lang Zhao, Xueying Wang, Zhiyun Hu, Yihan Liu, Zhiyu Wang, Hao Liu
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: Currently, DC power transmission trading modes are primarily divided into two types: medium-to-long-term transmission trading and cross-regional spot trading of surplus renewable energy. To investigate the impacts of these different transmission modes on renewable energy accommodation, this study establishes a renewable energy accommodation model that incorporates both medium-to-long term transmission trading and cross-regional spot trading of renewable energy. Using this model, we analyze the effects of different trading modes on key indicators such as renewable energy curtailment rate, the proportion of renewable energy generation in total electricity output, and DC transmission utilization hours. Based on actual data from a northwestern province in China, the DC transmission scheduling is optimized for this province, effectively reducing the renewable energy curtailment rate while ensuring the required DC transmission utilization hours.

title: High Availability Microclustering Server Using Kubernetes K3s and Haproxy on Raspberry Pi
authors: Zufar Asyraf Al - Hamid, Yudha Purwanto, Tody Ariefianto Wibowo
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Information Technology, Computer, and Electrical Engineering (ICITACEE)
abstract: High Availability (HA) is a key requirement in edge computing systems, particularly when running on resource limited devices such as the Raspberry Pi. In this paper, we propose a microclustering server architecture utilizing Kubernetes K3s and HAProxy for providing a low cost HA solution. The architecture implements a two master, two worker cluster setup with a Virtual IP (VIP) failover mechanism and agent based health checks for adaptive load balancing support. Two HAProxy load balancing algorithms, Round Robin and Least Connection, were compared under three scenarios: constant, incremental, and imbalanced traffic flow. Experiment results demonstrate that under constant and incremental loads, the performance of Round Robin was better by up to 4.3 % in terms of throughput and 7.3 % in response time compared to Least Connection. On the other hand, in the imbalanced load scenario the performance gains were statistically significant (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{p}<\mathbf{0. 0 1}$</tex>) in the favor of the Least Connection algorithm. The performed system has a Mean Time Between Failures (MTBF) of 478.27 seconds and Mean Time To Recovery (MTTR) of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1. 7 3}$</tex> seconds, providing 99.64 % system availability. The results confirm the possibility to deploy high availability microclusters on low power ARM devices by utilizing lightweight orchestration tools. The implemented system provides valuable insights into developing reliable edge computing infrastructures with minimum resource usage.

title: Predictive Analytics for B2B Customer Retention: a Machine Learning Random Forest Based on Net Promoter Score Model
authors: Iwan Rusdarmono, Aghus Sofwan, Kardison Lumban Batu
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Information Technology, Computer, and Electrical Engineering (ICITACEE)
abstract: In the competitive landscape of Business-toBusiness (B2B) markets, customer loyalty plays a strategic role in sustaining revenue growth. The Net Promoter Score (NPS) is a popular loyalty metric, yet it often falls short in reflecting actual customer behavior, particularly when high NPS scores do not translate into repeat purchases or sales growth. This study introduces a machine learning-based approach to enhance NPS evaluation by integrating it with customer behavior metrics using the Recency, Frequency, and Monetary (RFM) framework. A dataset comprising NPS and transaction records was preprocessed and analyzed using the Random Forest algorithm. The integration of NPS and RFM enabled the identification of customer segments that conventional NPS analysis might overlook, such as high-scoring but lowcontributing customers. The findings reveal that combining behavioral insights with loyalty metrics leads to more accurate customer profiling and actionable strategies for retention. This model supports data-driven decision-making and provides B2B firms with a more reliable method to align loyalty indicators with financial outcomes.

title: A Novel Calculation Method of AC Losses in Hairpin Windings Considering Comprehensive Loss Sources
authors: Jiyuan Liu, Fei Liu, Wei Cai, Jiale Zhu
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: With the trend toward high-speed permanent magnet synchronous motors (PMSMs) in electric vehicles, analysis of alternating current (AC) losses in hairpin winding at high frequency conditions has gained significant attentions. The traditional analytical model only accounts for skin and proximity effects, which neglect the influences of the rotor iron core, air gap and permanent magnet flux-linkage. To address this problem, this paper proposes an improved analytical model by introducing an air-gap correction coefficient and an additional loss model for PM flux-linkage. This method achieves full-operating-range prediction of the winding AC losses. The finite element validation confirms that this model maintains low errors in AC loss calculation of all speed ranges. Significantly, at high speeds, the error remains below 2%, which achieves a great improvement over conventional analytical models. This approach provides a reliable tool for calculations of high-frequency AC losses in the hairpin winding motors of new energy vehicles.

title: Achieving High Accuracy and User-Friendliness in BCI Systems: A Novel Relative Chromatic Quinary m-Sequence VEP Approach
authors: Tingting Guo, Yan Bian
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Complex Medical Engineering (CME)
abstract: Code-modulated visual evoked potentials (c-VEP) based on binary maximal-length sequence (m-sequence) encoding deliver high precision and an extensive instruction set, yet may trigger visual fatigue, impairing user experience. Non-binary encode-ng presents a more comfortable alternative, but existing research only validates grayscale variations, with color modulation remaining unexplored. This study introduces Relative Chromatic Quinary Code, namely Modulated Visual Evoked Potentials (RCQ-c-VEP), utilizing red/green and blue/yellow relative chromatic contrast mechanisms, with gray serving as the neutral reference. We investigated color modulation effects on cVEP neural responses and evaluate RCQ-c-VEP against grayscale-modulated c-VEP (Gray-c-VEP) in terms of accuracy and user-friendliness under 60 Hz and 120 Hz refresh rates. RCQ-c-VEP significantly outperformed Gray-c-VEP in accuracy at both refresh rates. In 120 Hz mode, its average accuracy was 96.22% ($\mathbf{4. 6 7 \%}$ higher, $\mathbf{p}=\mathbf{0. 0 2 0}$). User-friendliness was also optimal: 93.3% comfort, median ratings of 4 for flicker intensity and visual comfort. Moreover, the 120 Hz mode halved single-trial duration, substantially accelerating Visual fatigue experimental speed compared to 60 Hz. The findings demonstrate that RCQ-c-VEP significantly surpasses Gray-c-VEP in accuracy and userfriendliness. Under a 120 Hz refresh rate, RCQ-c-VEP provides a solution that effectively balances speed, accuracy, and user experience.
