title: Bird Detection and Tracking Scheme Around Transmission line Based on Target Tracking Algorithm and YOLOv8
authors: Sishi Fu, Bo An, Zhiang Zhang, Anqi Wang, Shuang Liu, Hu Chen, Chen Fu
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: With the increasing prevalence of avian-related faults in power transmission lines, real-time bird detection and tracking near transmission infrastructure has emerged as the core component for developing automated on-site bird deterrence systems. To address these operational requirements, this paper proposes an avian hazard detection and tracking framework that integrates the Deepsort object tracking algorithm with the YOLOv8 object detection algorithm. A specialized avian detection dataset for transmission line environments was constructed using the FBD-SV-2024 open-source bird tracking dataset for algorithm training. Experimental validation demonstrates that the proposed solution achieves a detection speed of 224 frames/s with 89.3% detection accuracy on edge computing devices, effectively fulfilling the critical requirements for rapid avian detection and tracking in edge computing environments.

title: Influence of Inerter on the Dynamic Vibration Absorber Based on ISD System
authors: Jiangtao Hu, Niaoqing Hu, Yuehao Li, Yi Yang, Zhengyang Yin
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: In this paper, the influence of inerter on the vibration characteristics of dynamic vibration absorber (DVA) based on inerter-spring-damping (ISD) system is studied. By establishing a dynamic model of the DVA based on ISD system, the system dynamic equations are obtained. For the system with and without inerter, the theoretical values of the natural frequencies and the damped vibration frequencies are calculated respectively. Meanwhile, the displacement signals of the system under free vibration are obtained through numerical simulation, and the numerical simulation values of the natural frequencies and the damped vibration frequencies of the system are obtained. The deviation between the theoretical values and the numerical simulation values are within 2%. The results show that the inerter can affect the vibration modes of the system, decrease the natural frequencies and the damped vibration frequencies, and suppress the vibration intensity of the system.

title: ArborNet: Featherweight Representation Learning for Real-Time Cashew Nut Quality Classification
authors: Quang-Anh Nguyen Duc, Dinh-Thai Kim, Minh-Anh Nguyen, Thao Pham Phuong, Ha Phuong Vu, Duc Pham Minh, Dinh-Truong Kim
publish: 2025 24th International Symposium on Communications and Information Technologies (ISCIT)
abstract: Automated quality inspection in Vietnam's worldleading cashew industry is hindered by the high cost and technical barriers limiting adoption by small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). To bridge this critical gap, we introduce ArborNet, a lightweight deep learning architecture designed for efficient, real-time cashew kernel classification on edge devices. ArborNet integrates a MobileNetV4 backbone with our novel Lightweight Efficient Attention Fusion (LEAF) module, optimizing performance for resource-constrained environments. We trained and validated our models on a custom dataset of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{8, 6 0 5}$</tex> annotated instances across three quality grades: Good, Peel, and Broken. The results demonstrate exceptional performance, with the compact ArborNet-s model achieving a mAP@50 of 0.979 and a mAP@50:95 of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 8 4 1}$</tex>. Larger variants maintain high accuracy, with ArborNet-x reaching a mAP@50:95 of 0.848. These findings validate ArborNet as an industrial-grade, accessible solution poised to enhance automation and quality control throughout the cashew supply chain.

title: Damage Imaging with Asymmetric Propagation of Lamb Waves in VariableThickness Plates
authors: Congyu Li, Lu Liu, Jiayi Liu, Fei Gao, Juntao Liang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: Lamb wave-based nondestructive testing faces challenges in tapered plates due to their complex wave propagation behavior. To address this limitation, this study introduces a damage localization imaging method utilizing an ultrasonic guided wave delay superposition algorithm. A finite element model of a linearly tapered plate with varying thickness was first developed to analyze guided wave propagation mechanisms and their interaction with defects. Building on this understanding, a novel approach was proposed that integrates thickness-dependent dispersion curves (under single central frequency excitation) with the delay superposition algorithm for detecting defects correlated with plate thickness variations. The efficacy of this combined method was rigorously assessed through finite element simulations. Furthermore, experimental validation encompassing signal excitation, narrowband signal extraction, and damage imaging confirmed the method's feasibility and accuracy in identifying defects within variable thickness plates, yielding precise damage localization images.

title: Design and Application of Intelligent Operation and Maintenance System for Photovoltaic Power Stations Based on Cloud-Edge-End Collaboration
authors: Wentao Zhang, Jialu Wang, Dexiang Li, Shaohua Li, Teli Ling, Jinheng Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: Photovoltaic power generation plays a vital role in China’s clean energy transition; however, operational efficiency and reliability are hindered by challenges including module mismatch losses, inefficient operation and maintenance, and potential safety hazards. To address these issues, this paper proposes an intelligent operation and maintenance system based on a cloud-edge-end collaborative architecture, integrating power optimizers, data forwarders, smart gateways, and a central software platform. Through hierarchical coordination, the solution enhances power generation efficiency, reduces maintenance costs, and ensures compliance with safety standards. Engineering validation demonstrates measurable improvements in system performance, underscoring the potential of this system to advance the digital transformation of PV power stations.

title: Authentication Using “Brain-Computer Interface Based on EEG Signals” Technologies
authors: G. Panayotova, G. P. Dimitrov, M. Ivanov, V. Martsenyuk, M. Lukanov, P. Nikolov, P. Stoyanov, P. Petrov
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Technologies, Systems and Services in Telecommunications (TELSIKS)
abstract: This paper considers the main methods of user authentication based on brain EEG signals. It describes optimal strategies for preprocessing an EEG signal and proposes directions for further development of methods for user authentication and verification based on the user’s response to stimulation using classification methods.

title: Attention-Guided Fusion for Multimodal Aspect-Based Sentiment Analysis
authors: Ismail Ifakir, El Habib Nfaoui, Abderrahim Zannou
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: Multimodal Aspect-Based Sentiment Analysis aims to determine the sentiment polarity associated with specific aspects by jointly analyzing textual content and corresponding visual information. This fine-grained task plays a crucial role in applications such as brand monitoring, customer feedback analysis, and personalized recommendation systems. Despite recent progress in the field, existing models still suffer from two major limitations: suboptimal modality fusion and weak aspect-level alignment, both of which degrade overall performance. In this paper, we propose a novel attention-guided fusion framework designed two-stage attention mechanism. First, an attention-based fusion is performed between the aspect embeddings and the text embeddings to generate aspect-aware textual representations. These enriched textual features are then fused with visual embeddings using a secondary attention layer, enabling cross-modal interactions that are critical for sentiment interpretation. We evaluate our model on the MASAD multimodal benchmark dataset, where it consistently outperforms several state-of-the-art baselines across multiple categories. The results confirm the effectiveness of our approach in capturing aspect-specific sentiment cues by jointly leveraging textual and visual information in a unified and context-aware manner.

title: Research on the Layout of Charging Facilities in the Airport Airfield Based on the Genetic Algorithm
authors: Jian Zhang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: Under the background of the national and civil aviation's "dual carbon" goals, an increasing number of airport airfields are carrying out the "transformation from fuel to electricity" for vehicles and equipment, and there is a need to construct supporting charging facilities. In order to improve the safety and utilization efficiency of the charging facilities in the airfield, this paper studies the layout planning problem of the airport charging facilities. A location model for charging facilities is established, with the objective function of minimizing the management and construction costs of charging facilities, the on-road operation costs of electric special vehicles, and the charging waiting costs. A genetic algorithm is proposed as the solution method for the model. Finally, combined with an actual airport case, a simulation analysis of the model and the algorithm is carried out, which proves the feasibility of the model and the effectiveness of the algorithm.

title: An Intelligent Detection Method for Equipment Based on SVDD
authors: Jia Chen, Kun Zhang, Miaorui Yang, Long Zhang, Chaoyong Ma, Yonggang Xu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: In order to address the spectral deviations in vibration signals associated with rolling bearing faults, an intelligent detection technique leveraging SVDD is proposed. The method utilizes spectrum data from normal operating conditions to train a high-dimensional hypersphere model, determining the radius and center. The anomaly identification process involves computing the distance between the test spectrum and the hypersphere center. For spectra identified as anomalous, an adaptive dimension-wise contribution analysis is conducted in the high-dimensional feature space to generate a weighting vector that accentuates fault-related frequency components while mitigating the effects of normal vibrations and noise. The proposed method requires only healthy state data for both anomaly detection and feature enhancement, and demonstrates effective diagnostic performance and strong application potential in both simulation signals and experimental gearbox bearing signals.

title: YOLO-Pest: A Robust Model for Golden Apple Snail Detection
authors: Quoc-Viet Hoang, Trung-Hieu Le
publish: 2025 24th International Symposium on Communications and Information Technologies (ISCIT)
abstract: The golden apple snail has become a major pest of rice crops following its introduction into many Asian countries, including Vietnam. Prompt detection of this pest, as well as its eggs, allows growers to apply effective control strategies Yet, existing small object detectors often struggle to accurately detect such pests due to their small size, resulting in incomplete detection outcomes. To tackle this limitation, we introduce a robust method for effectively detecting this pest, termed YOLO-Pest. In our method, a feature reinforcement (FR) module is developed to improve feature maps that are used for prediction. Besides, an extra prediction layer is added to boost the detection performance of small pests. Experimental results on a collected dataset demonstrate that our approach achieves superior performance, attaining a detection accuracy of 76.69 % and outperforming existing lightweight object detection models.

title: Designing a Blockchain-Based Model for International Labor Mobility: Technical Architecture and Stakeholder Logic
authors: Aleksandar Ivanovic, Milos Radenkovic, Marko Mudrinic, Ivana Radenkovic, Jelena Popara
publish: 2025 6th International Workshop on Engineering Technologies and Computer Science (EnT)
abstract: This paper focuses on the internal mechanics of a blockchain-based system for managing international labor mobility. Building on prior conceptual work, we offer a detailed examination of the model’s architecture, including smart contract design, stakeholder roles, digital identity frameworks, and the permissioned ledger structure. Special attention is given to the operational logic governing interactions between migrants, employers, recruitment agencies, and regulatory bodies, as well as the modular elements required for legal and institutional interoperability. Rather than exploring blockchain’s general promise in migration, this paper concentrates on the system-level considerations needed to build a functional, rules-driven platform for cross-border recruitment and compliance management. The goal is to provide a technically grounded reference for practitioners and policymakers working on blockchain applications in labor governance.

title: A Smart University Ontology for Educational Data Mining
authors: Ouidad Akhrif, Nour Eddine El Fezazi, Zakariae Saidi, Younès El Bouzekri El Idrissi
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: In this work, we present a briefing on Educational Data Mining (EDM) methodologies and methods in education. We've also talked about how to incorporate semantic educational data into the EDM process for meaningful processing. To complete this job, we developed smart university ontology as a paradigm for managing the diversity of educational data to provide a knowledge database capable of enhancing the EDM results.

title: Modeling Resilience in Emergency Supply Chains: A Systematic Literature Review
authors: Sassaoui Imane, Hlyal Mustapha, El Alami Jamila
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: Rising disaster risks have made emergency supply chain resilience a cornerstone of effective disaster management. The proposed study presents a systematic literature review and content analysis of 38 research articles focusing on mathematical modeling techniques with a focus on resiliency in emergency supply chains. The review addresses the connections between models, emergency operations, and resilience strategies during preparedness, response and recovery phases, which remains underexplored despite the critical role in post (disaster stabilization. By synthetizing modeling approaches, resilience dimensions, and operation focus, the findings highlight notable research gaps in the integration of quantitative resilience metrics and recovery phase modeling, suggesting directions for future research to improve robustness and adaptability of emergency supply chains under uncertainty. In doing so, this study not only consolidates diverse modeling perspectives but also provides practitioners and researchers with a foundation for designing more responsive, flexible, and data-driven emergency logistics solutions specific to real-world disaster scenarios

title: A bibliometric analysis of trends and future directions in the relationship between Industry 4.0 technologies and quality management systems
authors: Hafid. Anass, Sebtaoui. Fatima Ezzahra, Mouchtachi. Ahmed
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: The implementation of Industry 4.0 technologies on quality management systems has become essential in recent years. These technologies offer numerous opportunities in terms of production, maintenance, and quality management. This paper conducts a bibliometric analysis of existing trends, keywords, and relationships between the fields of Industry 4.0 technology integration and QMS. In this analysis, we use the Biblioshiny library of Bibliometrix to analyze data extracted from the Scopus, and the VOSviewer software to create and visualize graphics. These tools allow for the visualization of the results, providing insight into future directions and research in the field. This analysis shows a rapid growth in publications, demonstrating that this topic is a very important at this time. We also conduct a network analysis of keywords conducting research, which will allow readers to enrich their information.

title: Remote Sensing Image Detection Algorithm Based on Contextual Semantic Information Awareness Networks
authors: Ting Chen, Jinyue Yang, Lulu Xu, Tao Gao, Haijun Zhao, Qianjin Zhao
publish: 2024 5th China International SAR Symposium (CISS)
abstract: Remote sensing object detection (RSOD) is a crucial aspect within the field of object detection methodologies. However, the complex nature of backgrounds in remote sensing images (RSIs), combined with significant variability in target sizes, poses considerable challenges to the effectiveness of conventional object detection techniques. To solve these problems, we introduce an innovative approach called the Contextual Semantic Information-Aware Network (CSIANet). This network integrates a Global-Local Information Sensing Module (G-LISM) that skillfully combines an attention mechanism with convolutional operations to manage the complexities of contextual information. Furthermore, the Dynamic Feature Field Adjustment Module (DFFAM) is designed to improve the detection of smaller targets by dynamically adjusting the receptive field to capture diverse background information. Empirical evaluations conducted on publicly available datasets show that our proposed method achieved a detection accuracy of 74.7%.

title: Selection of Typical Operating Scenarios for High-Penetration Renewable Energy Power Systems Based on Clustering and Probabilistic Modeling
authors: Wangchao Dong, Jingjing Wang, Xu Wu, Xun Mao, Wei Peng
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: Aiming at the challenges of system security and economy caused by the high proportion of new energy access, this paper proposes a framework of operation mode selection that integrates probabilistic modeling and cluster analysis. A joint probabilistic model of wind and solar power output and load is established: wind power adopts Weibull distribution, photovoltaic adopts Beta distribution, and load adopts Gaussian mixture model with seasonal decomposition. The power system operation mode index system including voltage deviation, network loss and line load ratio is constructed, and the typical operation mode is extracted from the sample scenarios by K-means clustering after dimensionality reduction through principal component analysis. Examples show that the operation mode screened by this method can cover various operation states, and can provide effective decision support for the safe and economic operation of the new power system.

title: Systematic Evaluation of YOLO in Student Behavior Detection - A New Dataset
authors: Anh-Tu Tran, Thai-Khanh Nguyen, Trung-Thanh Nguyen, Anh-Ha Tuan, Trung-Hieu Le
publish: 2025 24th International Symposium on Communications and Information Technologies (ISCIT)
abstract: Detecting student behavior is critical for assessing engagement and enabling adaptive instruction. Manual observation, while informative, lacks scalability in large university classrooms. This paper presents a YOLO-based, frame-level detection framework tailored to real-world settings. Key contributions include: (1) a new dataset from actual classrooms using a single ceiling-mounted camera, annotated with multiple behavior and object classes; (2) a benchmark of YOLOv7, YOLOv8, YOLOv12, and Faster R-CNN under challenging conditions; and (3) a lightweight browser-based system enabling real-time inference without cloud support. Results confirm the feasibility of automated classroom behavior monitoring for educational AI applications.

title: Intent-Based Automatic Security Enhancement Method Towards Service Function Chain
authors: Deqiang Zhou, Xinsheng Ji, Wei You, Hang Qiu, Yu Zhao, Mingyan Xu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network and Service Management
abstract: The reliance on Network Function Virtualization (NFV) and Software-Defined Network (SDN) introduces a wide variety of security risks in Service Function Chain (SFC), necessitating the implementation of automated security measures to safeguard ongoing service delivery. To address the security risks faced by online SFCs and the shortcomings of traditional manual configuration, we introduce Intent-Based Networking (IBN) for the first time to propose an automatic security enhancement method through embedding Network Security Functions (NSFs). However, the diverse security requirements and performance requirements of SFCs pose significant challenges to the translation from intents to NSF embedding schemes, which manifest in two main aspects. In the logical orchestration stage, NSF composition consisting of NSF sets and their logical embedding locations will significantly impact the security effect. So security intent language model, a formalized method, is proposed to express the security intents. Additionally, NSF Embedding Model Generation Algorithm (EMGA) is designed to determine NSF composition by utilizing NSF capability label model and NSF collaboration model, where NSF composition can be further formulated as NSF embedding model. In the physical embedding stage, the differentiated service requirements among SFCs result in NSF embedded model obtained by EMGA being a multi-objective optimization problem with variable objectives. Therefore, Adaptive Security-aware Embedding Algorithm (ASEA) featuring adaptive link weight mapping mechanism is proposed to solve the optimal NSF embedding schemes. This enables the automatic translation of security intents into NSF embedding schemes, ensuring that both security requirements are met and service performance is guaranteed. We develop the system instance to verify the feasibility of intent translation solution, and massive evaluations demonstrate that ASEA algorithm has better performance compared with the existing works in the diverse requirement scenarios.

title: YOLO-MFG: Multi-Scale and Feature-Preserving YOLO with Gated Attention for Remote Sensing Object Detection
authors: HengYu Li, Bo Huang, JianYong Lv
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: Driven by the increasing demand for intelligent earth observation and large-scale scene understanding, remote sensing object detection has gained significant academic and practical importance. Despite notable progress in feature extraction and computational efficiency, many recent approaches still struggle to effectively handle issues such as detecting objects at multiple scales and preserving small targets. In this paper, an efficient remote sensing object detector called multi-scale and feature-preserving YOLO with gated attention (YOLO-MFG) is proposed to address these challenges. First, a multi-scale group shuffle attention (MGSA) module is introduced to adaptively aggregate multi-scale spatial features, improving the model’s sensitivity to objects of diverse sizes. Second, the employment of feature-preserving downsampling (FPD) enhances the downsampling process by introducing a triple-branch fusion mechanism that mitigates aliasing while jointly preserving semantics, saliency, and geometry. Finally, gated enhanced attention (GEA) is integrated to capture long-range dependencies and contextual cues crucial for remote sensing scenarios. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed YOLO-MFG achieves a 2.9% improvement in mean average precision at an IoU threshold of 0.5 (mAP50) on the optical remote sensing dataset SIMD compared to YOLO11. In addition, the mAP50 of detection results is improved by 1.4% and 4.2% on the DIOR and NWPU VHR-10 datasets, respectively.

title: MVFMNet: A Lightweight Network for Remote Sensing Image Super-Resolution
authors: Wei Xue, Tiancheng Shao, Mingyang Du, Jing Zhou, Xiao Zheng
publish: IEEE Journal on Miniaturization for Air and Space Systems
abstract: Research on remote sensing image super-resolution (RSISR) based on deep neural network has made significant progress. However, complex network architectures and high computational costs conflict with the resource limitations of small edge devices. To alleviate this problem, in this paper we propose a multi-level variance feature modulation network (MVFMNet), which can effectively utilize both local and non-local information for better super-resolution reconstruction of remote sensing images. Specifically, we propose a local variance-aware spatial attention (LVSA) module, which employs adaptive max-pooling to extract non-local features and introduces local variance to represent local structure. Building upon LVSA, we design a multi-level variance feature modulation block (MVFMB) by integrating two LVSA branches with distinct downsampling scales, enabling adaptive selection of multi-scale representative features. To further enhance the features modulated by MVFMB, we introduce a symmetric gated feed-forward network to fuse more local contextual information. Comparison experiments conducted on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that MVFMNet can achieve a better trade-off between reconstruction accuracy and computational efficiency in remote sensing image super-resolution. The code of MVFMNet will be released at https://github.com/AHUT-MILAGroup/MVFMNet.

title: Social and Ethical Challenges in Future 6G Networks
authors: V. Sridhar, Amrita Mishra, Asheef Iqubbal
publish: IEEE Technology and Society Magazine
abstract: While the fifth-generation (5G) technologies and networks are being deployed worldwide, the global telecom sector is already forecasting the ground-breaking potential of sixth-generation (6G) mobile networks and services that are expected to be standardized by 2030. By offering enhanced human–machine and machine–machine connectivities, with superior low latency and faster speeds than 5G, this next-generation technology is expected to reshape consumer experiences, economies, and societal structures. However, 6G introduces unique challenges, including cybersecurity, privacy, ethical, and responsible use. This article highlights the challenges in these areas by conducting an exhaustive literature survey and interaction with experts in the field. It provides technical and regulatory guidelines to be well-prepared to deploy sustainable and socially beneficial 6G networks and services for the next decade.

title: Table of Contents
authors: N/A
publish: IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics: Systems

title: Trade-Off Design of Delay-Phase Beamforming for Wideband THz Enabled XL-MIMO ISAC System
authors: Yilong Liu, Jun Zhang, Yu Han, Jue Wang, Shi Jin, Xiao Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology
abstract: Integrated sensing and communications (ISAC) is one of the key technologies for the sixth-generation wireless communications, in which the extremely large-scale multiple-input multiple-output (XL-MIMO) with higher and wider frequency bands will be incorporated. In this paper, a near field wideband terahertz XL-MIMO ISAC system is investigated, where the dual-functional base station communicates with a user and detects a non-cooperative target simultaneously. Our objective is to maximize the achievable rate within the constraints of sensing coverage and resolution in both angular and distance domains by designing the delays and phase shifts for the three-dimensional (3D) delay-phase beamforming framework. Firstly, the phase shifts are derived based on the controllable 3D beam squint method. Then, the mathematical relationship between the delays introduced by the true-time-delays (TTDs) and the constraints of sensing coverage and resolution in both angular and distance domains is derived based on the analysis for controllable 3D beam squint effect, based on which the optimization problem is reconstructed. Finally, the optimal delays introduced by the TTDs are derived, facilitating the trade-off between the achievable rate and sensing coverage with adequate sensing resolution. The proposed method can degenerate to the far field case. Numerical simulations are conducted to validate the effectiveness of the proposed method and illustrate the performance trade-off between the achievable rate and sensing coverage with sufficient sensing resolution.

title:
ACIMC: A 342.7-TOPS/mm
                    <sup>2</sup>
                    eDRAM-Based Analog Cryogenic In-Memory Computing Macro
authors: Yuhao Shu, Hongtu Zhang, Yifei Li, Jincheng Wang, Hao Sun, Weiqiang Liu, Yajun Ha
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems I: Regular Papers
abstract: Cryogenic in-memory computing (IMC) emerges as a promising approach for achieving high computing density and parallel data processing at extremely low temperatures. However, existing IMC macros usually utilize single-bit storage per cell, impeding further improvements in computing density. This article presents a 128-Kb embedded dynamic random access memory (eDRAM)-based analog cryogenic IMC (ACIMC) macro with three key techniques to achieve high computing density. First, we optimize an area-efficient dual three-transistor-zero-capacitor (3T0C) eDRAM bitcell to support 4-bit signed weight storage. Second, we design an area-efficient nonlinear write circuit that ensures a linear mapping between the digital weight and the resulting computing current. Third, we present a fast 4-bit flash analog-to-digital converter (ADC) featuring the column-generated reference voltage scheme and reference-storage sense amplifiers to achieve high-speed cryogenic convolutions. Measurement results from our test chip show that the proposed ACIMC achieves a computing density of 342.7 TOPS/mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> and an energy efficiency of 391.2 TOPS/W for 4b<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\times 4$</tex-math> </inline-formula>b cryogenic convolutions. Moreover, the retention time of our ACIMC is improved to 82.6 ms at 4.2 K.

title: N $^{2}$ LoS : Single-Tag mmWave Backscatter for Robust Non-Line-of-Sight Localization
authors: Zhenguo Shi, Yihe Yan, Yanxiang Wang, Wen Hu, Chun Tung Chou, Qingqing Cheng, Weijie Yuan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: The accuracy of traditional localization methods significantly degrades when the direct path between the wireless transmitter and the target is blocked or non-penetrable. This paper proposes N LoS, a novel approach for precise non-line-of-sight (NLoS) localization using a single mmWave radar and a backscatter tag. N LoS leverages multipath reflections from both the tag and surrounding reflectors to accurately estimate the target's position. N LoS introduces several key innovations. First, we design HFD (Hybrid Frequency-Hopping and Direct Sequence Spread Spectrum) to detect and differentiate reflectors from the target. Second, we enhance signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) by exploiting the correlation properties of the designed signals, improving detection robustness in complex environments. Third, we propose FS-MUSIC (Frequency-Spatial Multiple Signal Classification), a super-resolution algorithm that extends the traditional MUSIC method by constructing a higher-rank signal matrix, enabling the resolution of additional multipath components. We evaluate N LoS using a 24 GHz mmWave radar with 250 MHz bandwidth in three diverse environments: a laboratory, an office, and an around-the-corner corridor. Experimental results demonstrate that N LoS achieves median localization errors of 10.69 cm (X) and 11.98 cm (Y) at a 5 m range in the laboratory setting, showcasing its effectiveness for real-world NLoS localization.

title: Robust Compressed Double Diffusion Estimation Algorithm for IoT Based on Maximum Correntropy Criterion
authors: Yurong Xu, Yongfeng Qi
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: Distributed estimation in the Internet of Things (IoT) often suffers from unreliable communication links and non-Gaussian environmental noise, which significantly degrade the performance of conventional algorithms. Most existing approaches assume ideal channel conditions and Gaussian noise, making them inadequate for realistic IoT scenarios. This paper proposes a robust and communication-efficient compressed double-diffusion algorithm based on the Maximum Correntropy Criterion (MCC). The proposed method leverages MCC to effectively handle impulsive and non-Gaussian interference. Furthermore, a random projection compression strategy is incorporated to significantly reduce communication overhead while maintaining estimation accuracy, as well as to enhance resilience against wireless link noise. We provide theoretical analysis on convergence and steady-state behavior, and extensive simulations validate the superior robustness and performance of the proposed algorithm over existing MSE-based and uncompressed MCC diffusion methods. The results highlight the practical potential of our approach for resilient and scalable distributed learning in bandwidth-constrained and noise-prone IoT environments.

title: Research on Correction of Current Probe Transfer Impedance Based on Cubic Spline Interpolation
authors: Yanchang Wang, Xiaobing Tian, Pingping Sun
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: In the electromagnetic compatibility test (EMC), the transmission impedance calibration data of the current probe only covers specific discrete frequency points, and the correction coefficient for uncalibrated frequency points needs to be obtained by interpolation. The traditional linear interpolation method has significant errors in the nonlinear region, which is difficult to accurately reflect the characteristics of the probe. In this paper, a transmission impedance correction method based on cubic spline interpolation is proposed, and the advantages of the method are verified by comparing the error distribution of linear interpolation and cubic spline interpolation with the SOLAR 9207-1 current probe. Furthermore, the hardware test platform was built and the program-controlled scanning system was designed based on LabVIEW to realize harmonic interference data acquisition, cubic spline interpolation correction and limit comparison of test results, and the experimental results showed that the method could improve the measurement accuracy of conducted emissions of power lines and provide technical support for the reliability of testing.

title: High-Security 5G Smart Meter Enabling Real-Time Electricity Trading
authors: Lin Zhou, Chunsheng Guo, Peiran Liu, Xin Qiao
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: This paper proposes a framework of high-security 5G smart electricity meter that enabling real-time electricity trading and settlement. The meter features a secure multi-core hardware architecture compliant with OIML (Organisation Internationale de Métrologie Légale) IR46 (International Recommendation 46) standards: a Measurement Core for precision metering, a Management Core for data handling and communication, and a dedicated Trading Core. The Trading Core integrates a hardware-based digital currency wallet and executes smart contracts within a GlobalPlatform trusted execution environment. Utilizing a 3GPP (Third Generation Partnership Project) R16 uRLLC (Ultra-Reliable Low Latency Communications) 5G module, it enables instantaneous smart contract loading and secure communication. This facilitates automatic, secure real-time payment settlement between generation-side and consumption-side meters based on predefined smart contracts transmitted via 5G. This solution establishes critical infrastructure for real-time electricity markets, improving grid efficiency and facilitating decarbonization objectives, although the specific electricity trading mechanisms are beyond the scope of this study. Furthermore, this study solely proposes a 5G-enabled smart meter framework supporting real-time trading and settlement, while transaction latency and performance under network congestion will be the focus of future research.

title: Design and Parameters Simulation Optimization of a Spiral-Shaped Probe Electrostatic Sensor
authors: Lei Song, Zunmin Liu, Junyi Yang, Hongfu Zuo, Junhui Yang, Zhenzhen Liu, Yibing Yin, Zhenhua Wen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: Coal mining machinery operates under high-intensity, complex conditions, making proper lubrication critical to equipment reliability. Traditional monitoring methods often fail to detect early-stage wear in time. To address this issue, a novel electrostatic sensor was developed as an online monitoring device capable of detecting microscopic wear particles in the early stages of equipment operation. In this study, a new spiral-wound probe electrostatic sensor was designed, and a 3D model of the sensor was constructed to clarify its overall structural design. Since conducting single wear particle charge induction experiments in real environments is challenging, finite element simulations of the spiral-shaped probe were performed using COMSOL software to thoroughly investigate its sensing characteristics. The study analyzed the sensor’s response to various structural parameters, wear particle shapes, and lubricating oil quality. Results showed that increasing the number of turns and the width of the spiral sheet, while reducing the thickness and inner diameter of the insulating tube, enhanced the sensor’s sensitivity. In contrast, the thickness of the probe and the shielding layer had minimal impact on sensing performance. Overall, the electrostatic sensor effectively distinguished different wear types and assessed the quality of lubricating oil.

title: Human Activity Classification Using 2D Tensor Representation of 3D Point Cloud Data from FMCW Radar
authors: Ghufron Andriansyah, Fiky Y. Suratman, Istiqomah
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Information Technology, Computer, and Electrical Engineering (ICITACEE)
abstract: Human Activity Recognition (HAR) is a crucial field in safety monitoring technologies, particularly in efforts to minimize the risk of accidents such as fall detection. However, previous studies often underutilize the combination of spatial and temporal information from multi-domain radar data, limiting classification performance in dynamic scenarios. This study aims to classify human activities using 3D point cloud data generated by the FMCW radar IWR6843AOPEVM. The data is transformed into 2D tensors by stacking multiple feature representations, Doppler vs Range, Doppler vs Time, and Range vs Time, to capture rich spatial-temporal characteristics across domains. A key contribution of this work is the integration of multi-domain features through a stacking method and the evaluation of an optimal windowing strategy that balances temporal resolution with computational efficiency for real-time HAR systems. This research also evaluates the optimal windowing strategy by considering both human motion duration and radar configuration. A 2D Convolutional Neural Network (2D CNN) is employed as the classification model, with hyperparameter tuning performed using Keras Tuner. Experimental results indicate that larger window sizes lead to higher classification accuracy. However, increasing the window size also introduces greater computational load, particularly for real-time systems. Based on the findings, a sliding window of 30 frames with stride 1 yields the highest accuracy of 99.8 % and is considered the best compromise between classification performance and computational efficiency for real-time implementation.

title: A Standalone Device for Stress Detection in Individuals With Visual Impairments Using Fuzzy-Based Noninvasive Techniques
authors: Budi Setiadi, Kalamullah Ramli, Tomy Abuzairi
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Information Technology, Computer, and Electrical Engineering (ICITACEE)
abstract: The mobility behavior of individuals with visual impairments differs significantly from that of individuals with non-visual impairments when experiencing emotional stress, particularly in unfamiliar environments. They often struggle to manage stress independently, indicating the need for an early warning system or a supportive companion to ensure their safety. This study introduces a non-invasive stress detection system based on a photoplethysmography (PPG) sensor and a fuzzy logic model to classify non-stress and stress conditions. The system analyzes five physiological parameters: heart rate (HR), heart rate variability (HRV), respiratory rate (RR), peripheral oxygen saturation (SpO2), and body temperature (BT). Each parameter is categorized into three linguistic levels, resulting in 243 fuzzy rules embedded in a stand-alone device. Experiments were conducted with visually impaired students under three scenarios-relaxation, cognitive, and physical-across five phases, with 120 samples collected per phase. The system achieved a classification accuracy of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 9. 5 \%}$</tex>.

title: Topology Optimization of Liquid Cooling Plate Channels for Enhanced Thermal Management in Electronic Devices
authors: Wenlong Liu, Wei Wang, Shuaiyue Shao, Cihang Zhang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: This study addresses the cooling needs of electronic devices by employing topology optimization to design flow channel structures within liquid cooling plates, specifically targeting the thermal management of a 70W thermoelectric cooler hot end. Utilizing the variable density method and a Brinkman porous media model, coupled with fluid dynamics and heat transfer equations, a multi-objective optimization function is established to minimize both the average temperature and pressure drop. The relative importance of these objectives is balanced by a weighting factor w. Simulations using COMSOL software analyzed four inlet/outlet configurations (diagonal, same-side, single-inlet, dual-inlet) under constraints of Reynolds number 100 and fluid volume fraction 0.5, investigating flow channel evolution patterns and temperature distribution characteristics. The research results show:The weighting factor significantly impacts channel structure—low values (w<0.5) reduce flow resistance but create localized "stagnant fluid lakes," causing temperature non-uniformity; high values (w>0.7) enhance heat transfer via dense branched channels but increase pressure drop by up to 130%, recommending an engineering range of w=0.7-0.9; The dual-inlet configuration with w>0.7 forms a symmetric "figure-eight" channel network, reducing the maximum temperature difference by 38% and improving temperature uniformity by over 60% compared to the single-inlet design; The diagonal outlet layout provides superior temperature uniformity over the same-side layout. The optimized dual-inlet solution (w=0.7) achieves an average temperature of 306.69K and a pressure drop of 0.49Pa, offering an efficient design paradigm for cooling high-power-density electronic devices.

title: Towards an Overview of Artificial intelligence in Healthcare
authors: Latifa Khachchabi, Ibtissam Youlyouz, Abdelghafour Marfak, Saad El Madani
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: As the entire sectors, the artificial intelligence (AI) is transforming the healthcare sector which present the most important sector in every country. the implementation of AI in the healthcare transform different areas including disease analyses, prediction and diagnosis, treatment monitoring and recommendations and healthcare administration. Through the development of the AI technologies and the Machine learning, the healthcare research know progress in various aspects such as vaccine development, reduction of the time spent in diagnosis, prediction of disease progression, disease detection and treatment of genetic data…. With all the applications and the benefits of AI in healthcare many barriers and challenges confront the AI implementation classed into Technological, Ethical and Organizational and Economic parts. To confront the barriers and create more progress, the advancements of AI technologies require different collaborations inside these technologies, between the technologies and healthcare professionals and finally between the healthcare organizations, the governments and the regulators.

title: Few-Shot Health State Recognition of Wind Turbine Drivetrain Using Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Model and Self-taught Learning Network
authors: Jun Zhang, Xin Xiong, Beibei Fan, Bing Zhao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: Few-shot samples and variable operating conditions have long been research challenges for intelligent health state recognition in industrial equipment. This paper proposes an intelligent health state recognition method based on a Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Model (DDPM) embedded with an Inception-structured Self-taught Learning Network (ISLN). The proposed method first converts collected vibration signals into time-frequency representations using Synchrosqueezed Wavelet Transform (SWT). These time-frequency representations are then fed into the DDPM for sample augmentation, generating enhanced training data for the ISLN to perform health state recognition. The method is validated using a wind turbine drivetrain fault simulator. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves the highest intelligent diagnosis accuracy in identifying various bearing and gear faults, outperforming other intelligent diagnosis models.

title: Cascaded Wavelet-Driven Global Interpretable Model for Bearing Fault Diagnosis
authors: Lijuan Zhao, Yi Qin
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: Intelligent fault diagnosis has been widely applied to bearing fault diagnosis owing to its outstanding capability in feature extraction. However, the limited interpretability in deep network models significantly limits the trustworthiness of their diagnostic results. To address this issue, a cascaded wavelet-driven global interpretability model for bearing fault diagnosis is proposed. Specifically, a multi-scale cascaded Morlet wavelet filter bank is designed in the frequency domain to effectively extract key frequency features from bearing vibration signals based on physical priors. A channel attention mechanism is further introduced to adaptively weight and fuse multi-channel signals, dynamically emphasizing the relative importance of each channel and enhancing interpretability during signal processing. Moreover, the model employs statistical features with clear physical significance for quantitative analysis, ensuring the physical traceability of the extracted features. Extensive experiments conducted on both public and private datasets demonstrate the superior interpretability, reliability, and diagnostic performance of the proposed method.

title: Robust Sparse Subspace Tracking from Corrupted Data Observations
authors: Ta Giang Thuy Loan, Hoang-Lan Nguyen, Nguyen Thi Ngoc Lan, Do Hai Son, Tran Thi Thuy Quynh, Nguyen Linh Trung, Karim Abed-Meraim, Thanh Trung Le
publish: 2025 24th International Symposium on Communications and Information Technologies (ISCIT)
abstract: Subspace tracking is a fundamental problem in signal processing, where the goal is to estimate and track the underlying subspace that spans a sequence of data streams over time. In high-dimensional settings, data samples are often corrupted by non-Gaussian noises and may exhibit sparsity. This paper explores the alpha divergence for sparse subspace estimation and tracking, offering robustness to data corruption. The proposed method outperforms the state-of-the-art robust subspace tracking methods while achieving a low computational complexity and memory storage. Several experiments are conducted to demonstrate its effectiveness in robust subspace tracking and direction-of-arrival (DOA) estimation.

title: Negative Transfer Suppression and Cross-Domain Fault Diagnosis Based on Contrastive Learning Multi-Source Domain Adaptation Network
authors: Xing Chen, Liang Chen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: The scarcity of fault samples limits cross-domain knowledge transfer, while training dominated by healthy samples leads to biased decision boundaries. In addition, distribution imbalance further aggravates the problem of negative transfer. To address these issues, a Multi-Source Contrastive Learning model with Pseudo-Label Self-Correction and Weight Adaptation (MSCL-PLWA) is proposed. Synthetic data are first generated using a Wasserstein Generative Adversarial Network (WGAN). Contrastive learning is then employed to train the model by evaluating the similarity between augmented instances and minimizing the distance between similar pairs of synthetic and real samples. A prototype-based pseudo-labeling algorithm is subsequently applied for pseudo-label self-correction, and a multi-pseudo-label-guided Local Maximum Mean Discrepancy (LMMD) strategy is incorporated to enhance subdomain alignment. Furthermore, an adaptive weighting mechanism is introduced to assign higher weights to source domains more relevant to the target domain, thereby reducing the adverse impact of less relevant domains and mitigating negative transfer. Experimental results on two bearing platforms demonstrate that MSCL-PLWA effectively suppresses negative transfer and exhibits strong cross-domain fault diagnosis performance.

title: Performance Evaluation of PSO-Optimized PI Controller for Quadratic Boost Converter: A Comparative Study of ITAE, IAE, ITSE, and ISE Objective Functions
authors: Muhammad Hisyamudin Ramadhan, Iwan Setiawan, Susatyo Handoko
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Information Technology, Computer, and Electrical Engineering (ICITACEE)
abstract: The increasing demand for efficient energy conversion in renewable energy systems such as photovoltaic system and fuel cells (FC), being a reason for the necessity of advanced control strategies in power electronics. The Quadratic Boost Converter (QBC), a high-gain DC-DC converter is particularly suited for applications which requiring significant voltage step-up, such as PV systems and FC. This study proposes a novel control strategy that integrates Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) with a Proportional-Integral (PI) controller to optimize the performance of a QBC. The PSO algorithm dynamically optimizes the PI parameters to obtain the best system performance, while the PI controller ensures robust voltage regulation. A proposed system architecture and control implementation are simulated in MATLAB/Simulink with multi objective functions such as IAE, ITAE, ISE, and ITSE. The simulation results confirm that QBC can maintains an average output voltage of 240.22 V from all load resistance, which remains within the safe limit of the steady-state tolerance <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\pm 2 \%$</tex> of 240 V, i.e., 235.2 V and 244.8 V). From the simulation results, ITAE and ISE objective functions satisfied the critical performance parameters such as rise time (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Tr} r$</tex>), settling time (Tss), and percentage overshoot (Mpp%).

title: Losses Minimization for Isolated Bidirectional Quad Active Bridge Converter
authors: Nader Younis, Tarek Younis, Mahmoud A. Gaafar, Mohamed Orabi
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Power Electronics and Renewable Energy (CPERE)
abstract: An isolated multi-port bidirectional dc-dc converter is widely used to integrate multiple power sources, loads and energy storage devices. However, achieving an efficient operation under single phase-shift modulation remains a significant challenge especially under voltage mismatch and at light load. To tackle this issue, this paper proposes a modulation scheme for multi-port converter. The strategy aims to improve the efficiency based on root-mean-square current minimization. The loss optimization technique is implemented in two phases: first, ripple correlation control is presented to perform real-time optimization. Second, a modulation architecture based on time-division multiplexing approach is implemented to maximize the efficiency. Finally, the optimization strategy is validated and reported by PLECS simulation results.

title: Deep Learning-Enhanced Push-Broom Hyperspectral Imaging System for Non-Destructive Subsurface Defect Detection
authors: Keh-Moh Lin, Ming-Hsien Shih, Ya-Xiu Liang, Wen-Tse Hsiao
publish: 2025 24th International Symposium on Communications and Information Technologies (ISCIT)
abstract: This study presents a custom-developed push-broom hyperspectral imaging (HSI) system integrating a hyperspectral camera, halogen illumination, and a motorized linear translation stage with a C\textbackslash ＃－based interface. The system achieves a spatial resolution of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$31.9 \mu ~\mathrm{m} / \text{pixel}$</tex>（vertical）and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$140.4 \mu ~\mathrm{m} / \text{pixel}$</tex>(scan direction)with a spectral range from 367 to 1027 nm and a spectral resolution of 2.87 nm at 435.68 nm ．A 3D hyperspectral data is processed by selecting diagnostically relevant wavelengths to reconstruct 2D perspective images. Deep learning and Gaussian Mixture Models are used for unsupervised feature extraction and defect classification. Experimental results demonstrate the system's ability to detect surface and subsurface structures, including concealed playing card patterns and internal cracks in the laser－annealed silicon carbide substrate, highlighting its potential for automated，non－ destructive internal defect inspection.

title: Research and Application of Reliability-Centered Condition-Based Maintenance Technology on Steam Turbine System in a 1000MW Thermal power unit
authors: Shanyong Cao, Qizhang Xia, Junfeng Qi, Liqiang Shi, Xinbo Geng
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: This article introduces the background, necessity, basic technical methods, and application suggestions of implementing reliability-centered condition-based maintenance for a 1000MW steam turbine system. Adopting reliability-centered condition-based maintenance is an advanced maintenance management model, which can effectively overcome the problems of over-maintenance or under-maintenance brought by traditional maintenance models. It has a positive application effect on the safety and production of steam turbine system in the context of deep peak shaving, and can improve the operational safety and reliability. The implementation experience of this unit shows that condition-based maintenance of steam turbine system will surely become one of the effective ways for modernizing equipment management in power generation enterprises and enhancing the comprehensive strength of thermal power plants.

title: Research on grid-following inverter based on active disturbance rejection controller in weak power grid
authors: Biao Zhang, Xing Zhang, Yu Xiao, Shuhong Li
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: With the introduction of the national dual carbon strategy of "carbon peak" and "carbon neutrality", renewable energy power generation has developed rapidly. Compared with the power grid dominated by traditional synchronous generators, the structure and characteristics of the power grid under the high penetration rate of renewable energy power generation equipment and power electronic equipment have changed, and the power grid has shown weak power grid characteristics. In addition, the harmonic uncertainty disturbance under the typical weak power grid state poses a major threat to the safe and stable operation of the entire power system. Linear active disturbance rejection control has good dynamic performance and robustness. This paper proposes to apply the active disturbance rejection controller to the grid-following inverter. First, the three-phase grid-connected inverter under two types of control is modeled, and its superiority over the PI controller in weak power grid is analyzed. Secondly, by studying the two types of grid-connected current transfer functions, its advantages in suppressing the background harmonics of the power grid are obtained. Finally, the simulation verifies the good operating performance of the active disturbance rejection controller.

title: Flexible and adjustable load remote control terminal
authors: Wenwen Li, Xijuan Mao, Haoqi Shi, Jia Wan, Xin Jin
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: With the development of smart grids and distributed energy, flexible and controllable load terminals play an important role in optimizing distribution and improving energy efficiency. This study addresses the shortcomings of existing load control terminals in terms of communication reliability, overload protection, and temperature monitoring, and designs a flexible and controllable load remote control terminal based on LoRa communication. This terminal supports a maximum current of 16A, integrates high-precision temperature monitoring function, and has overload protection capability. Through MATLAB simulation, the current regulation performance, temperature change characteristics, and communication stability of the terminal were verified within a 24-hour operating cycle. The simulation results show that the terminal can effectively limit overload current, maintain temperature within a safe range, and achieve a communication success rate of over 95%. This study provides a reliable and efficient solution for load management in smart grids, with practical application potential.

title: Fault Diagnosis Using Graph Neural Networks with Dynamically Updated Edge Weights via Metric Function Fusion
authors: Lin Lin, Huaqing Wang, Siyuan Wang, Zesheng Lin, Liuyang Song
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: Rotating machinery equipment exhibits diverse failure modes under prolonged operating conditions, posing significant challenges for fault diagnosis. While Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have demonstrated notable success in addressing complex fault problems, their edge weight calculations often rely on a single metric function, limiting their ability to capture multi-physics coupling characteristics. Consequently, computing appropriate edge weights has garnered increasing attention. Fusing multiple metric functions for edge weight calculation enables the capture of multi-dimensional relationships between nodes and enhances the robustness of the weighting process. Furthermore, incorporating a dynamic computation mechanism based on node features allows for adaptive edge weight updates, thereby improving the model's expressiveness and adaptability. This paper proposes a GNN-based fault diagnosis method for rotating machinery that dynamically updates edge weights through metric function fusion (DMF-GNN). First, datasets are constructed using vibration signals collected from rotating machinery. During the creation of input samples for the GNN, edge weights are dynamically computed and updated by fusing multiple metric functions and introducing a node-feature-based dynamic mechanism. Subsequently, propose the Multi-Layer Perceptron Enhanced Edge Aggregated Graph Attention Networks (ME-EGAT) method. EGAT integrated with (MLP) modules is employed for deep feature extraction, ultimately classifying the operational states of the rotating machinery. Finally, the proposed method is empirically validated on the Paderborn University bearing dataset. Experimental results demonstrate that the method effectively implements dynamic edge weight updates based on metric function fusion within a GNN framework, leading to enhanced diagnostic performance. It provides an efficient solution integrating multi-source information with stronger adaptability for diagnosing complex faults characterized by difficult-to-capture multi-physics coupling effects.

title: A Condition-Based Maintenance Strategy under Dynamic Spare Provision for Three-State System
authors: Jiantai Wang, Runyu Zhang, Zijian Kang, Yu Zhao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: the appropriate spare provision supports the execution of maintenance activities efficiently. This paper investigates the condition-based maintenance for three-state system wherein a dynamic spare provision policy is devised. The stochastic standard, defect-induced standard and failure-induced emergent orderings are dynamically selective regarding diverse conditions to promote the strategy practicality and decision robustness. Specifically, based on the standard ordering at a stochastic time, 1) a defect-induced standard ordering is placed at defect identification without stochastic ordering before, 2) a failure-induced emergent ordering is placed at sudden failure without the extra ordering before, 3) a threshold controls whether another emergent ordering is needed when the spare has been standardly ordered but unreached at failure time. Furthermore, the postponed and immediate replacement activities are integrated referring to the states of spare and system operation. The cost-efficiency captured by long-term operational cost rate is established and optimized. The superiority of the devised collaborative strategy compared with traditional devise is verified upon the railway bearings.

title: A Lesion-focused Foundation Model for Preoperative Assessment of Pathological Features in Hepatocellular Carcinoma
authors: Ji Xia, Shunjie Dong, Zhehan Shen, Yulin Pu, Xueyang Zou, Wei Xia, Ruokun Li
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Complex Medical Engineering (CME)
abstract: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is a major cause of cancer-related mortality with high post-resection recurrence rates, underscoring the critical need for effective preoperative assessment of microvascular invasion (MVI) and pathological grade. However, prevailing predictive models are often hampered by their reliance on manual segmentation, limited robustness, and failure to adequately integrate lesion-specific features. To overcome these challenges, we propose a novel lesion-focused foundation model (LFM) that leverages self-supervised learning with Masked Siamese Networks and a Vision Transformer. Pretrained on a large dataset of $\mathbf{3 2, 1 2 0}$ annotated lesion patches, our model learns powerful representations that are then refined for prediction tasks via an attention-based multiple-instance learning strategy. On a challenging external validation cohort, the LFM achieved an AUC of $\mathbf{0. 8 2 3}$ for MVI prediction and $\mathbf{0. 7 0 6}$ for pathological grade classification. Remarkably, it maintained robust performance (MVI, AUC: 0.793) when trained on only 10% of the data, demonstrating strong data efficiency. These results underscore the LFM’s potential as a robust, non-invasive tool to enhance surgical strategies and improve patient outcomes.

title: Numerical Calculation and Analysis of Wear Morphology and Stress Field Based on Rough Contact Surface
authors: Long Zhou, Le Li, Liyong Wang, Qian Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: As the main way of mechanical key structure failure, micromotion wear constitutes a serious impact on its stability and reliability, to explore how wear morphology develops and interacts with the stress distribution, a rough surface model was generated based on the two-dimensional W-M fractal function, utilizing MATLAB for numerical construction and Geomagic Studio for surface processing, a numerical model of tangential wear is introduced based on the ABAQUS subroutine UMESHMOTION. Achard wear criterion to establish the numerical model of tangential wear, and analyze the wear amount, wear morphology and contact stress in the micro-movement contact region by changing the normal load F and displacement amplitude μ. During the wear process, the surface contact pressure undergoes a characteristic increase-decrease pattern, reflecting the evolving contact conditions. the initial wear is accelerated under the condition of large displacement amplitude, and the wear resistance and load stability of the material are better under the condition of small displacement amplitude. The increase of displacement amplitude aggravates the sliding and friction at the contact point, which leads to the increase of wear and the decrease of workpiece durability, and the contact center area becomes the main wear zone under high loads.

title: Adversarial Discriminative Domain Adaptation for Drive Train of the Wind Turbines Fault Diagnosis Using Acoustic Emission
authors: Jing Li, Yong Yang, Aiidong Deng
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: The Wind Turbines (WTs) experience gradual wear of gears and bearings under variable weather conditions. This paper presents a novel fault diagnosis method for the drive train of WTs based on Adversarial Discriminative Domain Adaptation (ADDA) and Acoustic Emission (AE). AE, serving as a non-destructive testing technology, is used to detect rub-impact faults in rotating machinery. ADDA, as a form of transfer learning (TL), takes knowledge from a source domain and applies it to a target domain, thereby improving the model's generalization capability. Experiments show that the proposed AE-ADDA method achieves excellent fault diagnosis results. It offers a novel approach to tackle the challenges of fault detection in wind turbine drive trains across varying operational conditions.

title: Multi-Objective Optimal Design and Low-Temperature Performance Study of a Hybrid Energy Storage System for Pulse Discharge and Regenerative Energy Recovery
authors: Zhile Zhu, Yajie Liu
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: In response to the application demands of high-power pulse discharge accompanied by regenerative energy recovery in fields such as electromagnetic launch and rail transit regenerative braking, this paper proposes a multi-objective optimization design method for a hybrid energy storage system (HESS) based on a lithium-ion battery-supercapacitor semi-active topology. First, cell-level and system-level models incorporating coupled electro-thermal characteristics are developed, and corresponding DC/DC energy management strategies are designed to accurately capture the system’s dynamic response. Next, aiming to minimize the total system mass and reduce the maximum operating temperature under environmental constraints, a multi-objective configuration optimization model for the HESS is constructed and solved using an improved elitist non-dominated sorting genetic algorithm (NSGA-II). Finally, a case study is conducted on the HESS configuration optimization under pulsed load conditions with regenerative energy recovery. The optimization results show that, compared to a scheme considering only high-power pulse discharge, the proposed configuration achieves a mass reduction of 5.5% at -40°C and 7.3% at -30°C. Simulation results at -30°C further demonstrate that the optimized configuration maintains excellent voltage stability and confirm the effectiveness of the energy management strategy.

title: Multi-Scale Self-Supervised Learning for Efficient Audio Deepfake Detection_supp1-3634032.pdf
authors: Taiba Majid Wani
publish: N/A
abstract: Neural vocoders enable highly realistic synthetic speech that challenges multimedia authentication; however, existing detection approaches suffer from limited robustness to unseen synthesis methods and inadequate deployment readiness. We propose MASD (Multi-scale Artifact-aware Self-supervised Deepfake detector), combining multi-scale SSL with handcrafted features. MASD decomposes spectrograms into three frequency bands, processed through an encoder pretrained using masked reconstruction, contrastive predictive coding, and adversarial vocoder classification. Features fuse with phase coherence, spectral flux, and high-frequency energy through cross-attention, classified by temperature-scaled SVM. Evaluation on ASVspoof 2019 LA demonstrates state-of-the-art performance. Ablation studies confirm adversarial augmentation as the primary driver of robustness, improving EER from 1.52% to 0.39%, while zero-shot cross-dataset evaluation validates generalization effectiveness, establishing MASD as a practical solution.

title: OpenPyRo-A1: An Open Python-based Low-Cost Bimanual Robot for Embodied AI
authors: Helong Huang, Christopher E. Mower, Guowei Huang, Sarthak Das, Magnus Dierking, Guangyuan Luo, Kai Tan, Xi Chen, Yehai Yang, Yingbing Chen, Yiming Zeng, Yinchuan Li, Zhanpeng Zhang, Shuang Wu, Yingxue Zhang, Weichao Qiu, Tongtong Cao, Mian Qin, Sajjad Pakdamansavoji, Yuecheng Liu, Yuzheng Zhuang, Guangjian Tian, Jianye Hao, Jun Wang, Haitham Bou-Ammar, Xingyue Quan
publish: IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters
abstract: Many real-world tasks, such as assembly, cooking, and object handovers, require bi-manual coordination. Learning such skills via imitation remains challenging due to dataset scarcity, mainly caused by the high cost of bi-manual robotic platforms and barriers to entry in robotics software. To address these challenges, we introduce (1) OpenPyRo-A1, a low-cost, bi-manual humanoid robot priced at approximately 14K. OpenPyRo-A1 achieves <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\text{0.2}~\text{mm}$</tex-math></inline-formula> repeatability and supports a <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\text{5}~\text{kg}$</tex-math></inline-formula> payload per arm, and (2) a Python-first distributed control framework for seamless teleoperation, data collection, and policy deployment, designed for ease of use; moreover, the code-base is installable via <monospace xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">pip</monospace>. We conducted imitation learning experiments in both simulation and the real world, integrating the robot with perception models, motion planning, and a large language model. The results demonstrate that OpenPyRo-A1 is a stable, user-friendly, and high-precision dual-arm platform. We expect that the OpenPyRo-A1 hardware, control system, and curated dataset of bi-manual manipulation episodes will advance affordable and scalable dual-arm robotics.

title: A Class-F VCO With Ultra-Low-Power and Low-Phase-Noise by Reactivating the Common-Mode Coupling Factor in a 1:2 Transformer
authors: Linying Song, Yubing Li, Zemeng Huang, Xiuping Li, Quan Xue
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems I: Regular Papers
abstract: In this paper, a Class-F voltage-controlled oscillator (VCO) with low-phase-noise (PN) and ultra-low-power consumption is proposed by reactivating the common-mode (CM) coupling factor in a 1:2 transformer. Unlike conventional designs that exclusively consider the differential-mode (DM) coupling factor in 1:2 transformers, our proposed architecture effectively leverages the combined potential of DM and CM coupling factors in a single transformer. For DM operation, a novel design method is presented to efficiently guide the design of ultra-low-power VCOs. This method provides clear insights into how Class-F<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sub> resonator parameters influence the loop gain characteristics, establishing a quantitative framework for performance optimization. Regarding CM operation, the 1:2 transformer’s coupling mechanism is analyzed in detail for the first time. The analysis reveals that strategic layout optimization of the center tap can reactivate the CM coupling factor, effectively expanding the CM resonance to reduce PN. Furthermore, by incorporating a tightly coupled tertiary coil, a local oscillator signal with high spectral purity is realized. Fabricated in a 110-nm CMOS process, the proposed VCO achieves a 20.2% frequency tuning range (FTR) from 10.45 to 12.80 GHz, consuming 0.38-0.50 mW with 0.2-V power supply. The measured PN exhibits −107 and −130 dBc/Hz at 1 MHz and 10 MHz offset from a 12.80-GHz carrier, respectively, with corresponding excellent figures-of-merit (FoM) of 192 and 195 dBc/Hz, respectively.

title: Resistance Degradation of Unintentionally Doped Single Crystal BaTiO3
authors: Menglin Wang, Tao Zheng, Reza Farsad Asadi, Han Gao, Bruce Gnade
publish: IEEE Transactions on Device and Materials Reliability
abstract: BaTiO3 based capacitors are critical for power converter functionality. However, they are known to have reliability issues under harsh environments. Thus, it is important to understand the resistance degradation mechanism in high dielectric constant inorganic capacitors. In this paper, the resistance degradation of unintentionally doped single crystal BaTiO3 capacitors has been studied as a function of electric field, temperature, and capacitor size. The experimental data show the degradation behavior of single crystal BaTiO3 depends strongly on the electric field strength. The activation energy for degradation in BaTiO3 capacitors shows a sudden change around the Curie temperature which indicates that the conductivity mechanism above the Curie temperature is different than at low temperature. We observed that unintentionally doped single crystal BaTiO3 capacitors exhibit three distinct stages of degradation, suggesting the presence of multiple conduction mechanisms during the degradation process.

title: A Framework for Energy-Efficiency Optimization in MA-Aided MU-MIMO Systems
authors: Hanyu Yang, Chengwen Xing, Shiqi Gong, Xin Ju, Nan Zhao, Dusit Niyato
publish: IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications
abstract: Movable antenna (MA) has emerged as a promising technology for enhancing communication performance over conventional fixed position antenna (FPA) by exploiting spatial channel variations. In this paper, we propose a general energy efficiency (EE) optimization framework for the MA-aided multi-user multiple-input multiple-output (MU-MIMO) downlink communications. We jointly optimize the precoding matrices and the positions of transmit and receive MAs considering two different types of power constraint models, i.e., the sum power constraint (SPC) and multiple weighted power constraints (MWPCs), and various physical constraints on MA positions. In both the SPC case and the MWPCs case, we optimize the MA positions by jointly employing the weighted minimum mean square error (WMMSE) and successive convex approximation (SCA) methodologies. As for the precoding matrices optimization, by exploiting the uplink-downlink duality of MU-MIMO systems, we transform the downlink EE optimization into their virtual uplink EE optimization counterparts. Then, we derive the optimal structures of the precoding matrices, where the involved optimal power allocations take the multi-user water-filling solutions. To compute the parameters of the multi-user water-filling solutions, by taking advantage of the underlying algebraic monotonicity of the problem, we propose three novel design strategies, i.e., the direct Dinkelbach based design, the modified Dinkelbach based design, and the bound-ware penalty based design. In contrast to conventional fractional programming (FP) based EE optimization methods, the proposed algorithms offer significantly lower computational complexities and explicit physical insights. Moreover, the simulation results demonstrate the superior performance and high efficiency of our proposed EE optimization algorithms.

title: Towards Non-linear, Fast, and Multi-Frame 3D Point Cloud Interpolation in Autonomous Driving
authors: Pengfei Yang, Minyang Liu, Kangqi Xu, Ting Zhong, Fan Zhou
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: LiDAR sensors are critical for 3D scene perception in autonomous driving, providing high spatial accuracy but suffering from limited temporal resolution. Point cloud interpolation, which reconstructs intermediate frames from sparsely captured inputs, effectively enhances temporal continuity. However, the challenges posed by non-linear and non-rigid motion in dynamic scenarios remain unresolved by existing methods, which often sacrifice accuracy for efficiency. To solve the above problems, we propose MSTSINet (Multiscale Transformer and SSM Interpolation Network), a novel framework that combines multiscale forward flow prediction with non-linear trajectory compensation for fast and accurate interpolation. Unlike conventional bidirectional flow-based methods, our forward flow-guided approach reduces inference time while improving robustness to complex motion. MSTSINet integrates multiscale motion modeling through a novel hierarchical feature extraction and semantic-aware cross-frame attention, progressively improving forward flow estimation for accurate non-linear trajectory prediction. To further improve motion fidelity and temporal coherence, we introduce a point-wise compensation mechanism during inference and design a novel multiscale loss function that supervises forward flow learning across varying temporal resolutions. Experiments on autonomous driving benchmarks demonstrate that MSTSINet significantly outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods, achieving up to a 26.39% reduction in Chamfer Distance and substantially improving inference speed. These advantages make it well-suited for real-time deployment in autonomous driving scenarios.

title: Microgrid Black Start Challenges: The Role of Grid-Forming Inverters
authors: Gab-Su Seo, Wenzong Wang, Behrooz Mirafzal
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Grid-forming (GFM) inverters are becoming increasingly important for future power systems, particularly in establishing and restarting microgrids after blackouts.
