title: Hierarchical Heterogeneous Aggregation Network for Multi-shape Coronary Stenosis Detection in X-ray Angiography Sequences
authors: Sigeng Chen, Jingfan Fan, Yujie Xie, Danni Ai, Deqiang Xiao, Tianyu Fu, Hong Song, Yuanyuan Wang, Wenyuan Yu, Yang Yu, Jian Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Accurate detection of multi-shape coronary artery stenoses from X-ray angiography (XRA) sequences plays a crucial role in diagnosing and planning interventions for coronary artery disease. However, vessel overlap, background noise, and nonlinear cardiac motion introduce significant challenges. These factors often result in missed detections, intra-frame class conflict, and temporal category drift, particularly for subtle and morphologically complex stenoses such as focal and bifurcation stenoses. To address these challenges, we propose a Hierarchical Heterogeneous Aggregation Network that effectively integrates both spatial and temporal cues across XRA sequences. The proposed framework incorporates a Channel Importance-guided Fusion module, which aims to enhance the representation of small-stenosis features by dynamically selecting high-importance channels across scales. Furthermore, we introduce a Hierarchical Heterogeneous Aggregator designed to reduce spatial redundancy and explicitly generate discriminative features across frames based on heterogeneous relationships, thereby improving temporal consistency and classification robustness. Existing experiments conducted on two clinical datasets indicate that our method outperforms existing detectors and stenosis methods in terms of detection accuracy and generalization.

title: Identification of Patient-Specific EMG Detectors for Robot-Assisted Therapy Using Rest and Move State EMG Data
authors: Monisha Yuvaraj, A T Prabakar, SKM Varadhan, Etienne Burdet, Ander Ramos-Murguialday, Sivakumar Balasubramanian
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: In severely impaired stroke patients without visible movements, implementing robot-assisted therapy based on movement intention decoded from electromyogram (EMG) requires both sufficient residual EMG to drive robotic assistance and a patient-specific detector to ensure accurate, low-latency detection. However, identifying such a detector is challenging, particularly when the presence of residual EMG in a given patient is unknown. This paper proposes a systematic approach to distinguish between EMG data when the patient is relaxed versus attempting a movement.We investigated six different detector types and separation measures using retrospective EMG data from a previous randomized controlled trial. The results indicate that the approximate generalized likelihood ratio (AGLR) detector, along with the modified Hodges and modified Lidierth detectors, achieved the best separation between the data when a subject is relaxed compared to when he/she attempts movements. Using a subset of clinician-annotated data to evaluate detection performance, the modified Hodges detector combined with probability difference-sum ratio measure (MH-PDSR) showed good performance in terms of both accuracy and latency. Based on the EMG data from 30 severe stroke, we propose a PDSR threshold of 0.7 with the modified Hodges detector to identify patients with sufficient residual EMG. These findings suggest that the MH-PDSR approach can be used to learn a maximally separating detector for a given patient which can be used both to screen patients for residual EMG and to provide a detector to drive robotic assistance if residual EMG is present. Further validation using larger datasets and evaluation of the resulting human machine interaction is warranted.

title: Spacecraft-NeRF: High-Fidelity Reconstruction of Spacecraft by Neural Radiance Field Based Implicit Representation
authors: Yang Liu, Zhihao Sun, Lele Zhang, Lele Xi, Wei Dong, Fang Deng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: Access to the appearance and geometry of spacecraft is one of the key points for conducting on-orbit services. However, without prior information, most contemporary methods still collect raw data from active sensors and then carry out a series of complex reconstruction processes. Therefore, simple and tractable methods for high-fidelity spacecraft reconstruction and rendering remain challenging in the current on-orbit services. Recently, neural radiance field-based implicit representation has demonstrated outstanding performance in a variety of reconstruction tasks. In this work, we focus on the basic needs in maintenance and fault diagnosis in on-orbit service: 1) 2-D view synthesis, 2) 3-D model reconstruction, and propose a high-fidelity reconstruction method, Spacecraft-NeRF. It masks out the complex background content in the outdoor scenario with mask images generated by the segment anything model, solves the sampling and rendering problems with the <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$L_{\infty }$</tex-math></inline-formula> norm construction and a small proposal MLP, and improves the reconstruction quality via a hybrid encoding strategy. Based on simulated satellites, we collected and published a dataset, Spacecraft-3D, consisting of four types of spacecraft with different surface textures and geometric structures. In this dataset, Spacecraft-NeRF shows realistic rendering performance, and the extracted 3-D mesh models properly represent the complex mechanical and geometrical structure of the spacecraft body. In comparison experiments with a series of representative NeRF-based models, Spacecraft-NeRF also outperforms most of the comparison methods in PSNR, SSIM, and LPIPS metrics.

title: Following the Journey of Network Slicing in 5G and 5G Advanced: Essential Concepts, Key Operations, Lifecycle Management, and Future Enhancements
authors: Rahul Varma Chintalapati, Nishith Tripathi, Jeffrey Reed
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: 5G networks deliver services with faster speeds, higher capacity, lower latency and higher resilience. Network Slicing is one of the fundamental pillars for offering diverse services. With the emergence of non-terrestrial networks, unmanned aerial vehicles, Open Radio Access Network (O-RAN), and artificial intelligence in 6G communications, the importance of network slicing will only further increase. This work aims to provide a comprehensive tutorial of network slicing and on how network slicing has evolved over the years since its inception in Release 15 of the 3GPP. This work explains the key concepts in network slicing and illustrates the architectures employed to realize network slicing such as the NFV and O-RAN. This work describes Life Cycle Management (LCM) of a network slice and discusses the influence of network slicing on key operations such as registration and Protocol Data Unit (PDU) session establishment. Since its inception in Release 15, network slicing has been continuously evolving with new feature additions in different releases. This work studies the evolution of network slicing through the years. The work finally concludes by summarizing current challenges in network slicing and identifying future research opportunities.

title:
Virtual Dissection of Void in Solder Joints and the Impact of R
                    <sub>DS(on)</sub>
                    on the Reliability Performance of SiC Power MOSFETs
authors: N.S. Noorasid, A.A. Kamarolzaman, M.Z. Zainal Abidin, N. Razali, M. S. Sukiman, S. Krishnan, G. Omar, F. Arith
publish: IEEE Transactions on Components, Packaging and Manufacturing Technology
abstract: In advanced semiconductor packaging technology, the transition to lead-free solder has introduced further considerations regarding the reliability at the solder joints vicinity, whereas void formation continues to be a significant concern for the performance of the device. The issue of voids in solder joints in semiconductor packaging devices significantly affects the performance and reliability of the full package. In this research, a comprehensive study on the void formation in solder joints was conducted using 2D and 3D X-ray imaging techniques, focusing on SnSbAg and SnSbCuAg solder types in Power SiC MOSFETs. These devices were subjected to industry-standard JEDEC High-Temperature Storage Life (HTSL) test set at 175 °C for up to 2000h. A consistent direct proportion of void formation percentage with RDS(on) was revealed, indicating a strong correlation of the hindered charge carrier mechanism resulting from micro-void formation. Herein, we derived a theoretical formula envisaging the correlation of 2D and 3D X-ray void imaging techniques with a highly regarded R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> of 0.959 and 0.937 for SnSbAg and SnSbCuAg, respectively. It can be conjectured from this study that the void formation originated from the uneven stress due to imbalance diffusion and the fabrication process plays a vital role in influencing the performance of SiC Power MOSFETs, yet can be observed convincingly in a cost-effective way.

title: A Multi-modal Lightweight Transformer for Bearing Fault Diagnosis under High-Noise Industrial IoT Environments
authors: Junjie Liu, Jiaxian Zhu, Weihua Bai, Huibing Zhang, Lianghai Wu, Teng Zhou, Keqin Li
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: Industrial IoT (IIoT) sensing nodes for bearing monitoring often operate in high-noise environments, where acoustic and mechanical interference masks weak fault signatures and undermines diagnostic reliability. To address this challenge, we propose a lightweight multi-modal fusion framework for robust fault diagnosis under extreme noise. Our method first applies multi-resolution decomposition with selective reconstruction and adaptive enhancement to preserve fault-related components while suppressing interference. The enhanced signals are transformed from 1D time series into two-dimensional representations to jointly capture temporal dynamics and spectral characteristics. We then design a tri-branch multi-head attention architecture that integrates a multiscale recurrence plot network, a Gramian angular field network, and a lightweight residual network. Learnable attention weights enable adaptive fusion of complementary cross-modal features with low computational overhead. Extensive experiments on the CWRU benchmark show superior robustness from 0 dB to -6 dB SNR, with a mean accuracy above 99.6% and consistent gains over eight state-of-the-art methods. Additional tasks on single-domain diagnosis, cross-condition fault type recognition, and fault degree discrimination (T1–T3) confirm strong generalization and multi-scale adaptability, with average improvements of 2–4% over the second-best baseline and stable variance under noise. The compact architecture and high noise immunity indicate practical suitability for IIoT sensing nodes and edge deployment in complex industrial scenarios.

title: Enhancing Self-Regulated Learning Using Generative AI: Development and Evaluation of SRLMentor_supp1-3634216.docx
authors: Khe Foon Hew
publish: N/A
abstract: Effective self-regulation is crucial for student success; however, many students struggle with it, especially during online activities, leading to disengagement. Existing methods to boost self-regulated learning (SRL) skills, such as writing self-reflective reports and using prompts in video lectures, lack timely, personalized feedback and can be labor-intensive. This study implemented the Self-Regulated Learning AI Mentor (SRLMentor), a system designed to support students' SRL skills, including goal-setting, planning, help seeking, and reflection. SRLMentor comprises three integrated modules to provide timely customized SRL feedback to each student. The first module features an SRL knowledge base that stores user chat records and relevant memory-driven adaptive SRL prompts, addressing a significant limitation of large language models—inability to store new experiences in long-term memory during a dialogue. The second module incorporates a Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) component to reduce content hallucinations, ensuring that students receive accurate information. The third module provides in-context learning examples that instruct the AI-based chatbot system to produce relevant SRL responses. We evaluated SRLMentor in an eight-session course with 25 students. Our assessment focused on RAG's performance in terms of factual consistency, answer correctness, and semantic similarity; accuracy of SRLMentor's detection of students' goals and plans compared to human coders; quality of SRLMentor's feedback; and students' perceptions of the system's usefulness. The results revealed that RAG enhanced factual, correctness, and semantic accuracy of responses. Additionally, SRLMentor's assessments of students' goals and plans closely matched those of human coders. The cluster analysis revealed that students who engaged more with SRLMentor exhibited greater improvement in SRL skills and course knowledge compared to those who engaged less frequently with the system.

title: Hybrid Contact Dynamics and Residual-RL Framework for Multi-Point Object Pushing
authors: Chen Chen, Xu Dai, József Kövecses
publish: IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters
abstract: Robotic contact manipulation involves applying controlled forces at contact points to guide an object along a desired trajectory while respecting the underlying physical interactions. This paper presents a novel framework that integrates dynamic modeling and Reinforcement Learning (RL) to achieve robust object pushing with a redundant robotic arm. First, a comprehensive dynamic contact model is formulated, incorporating unilateral constraints and a box friction model to capture the nonlinearities present in real-world contact dynamics. Second, the model is extended to handle multiple simultaneous point contacts, enabling effective trajectory planning and tracking for a redundant robotic arm in multi-contact pushing tasks. Third, an RL strategy is introduced as a residual module that augments a model-based controller to improve pushing performance. Simulation and real-world experiments with a Kinova Gen2 arm demonstrate that the proposed method achieves accurate trajectory following and stable contact interactions, significantly outperforming traditional PD control strategies in dynamic pushing scenarios.

title: Co-Polarized In-Band Full-Duplex Radiator-Shared SIW Cavity-Backed Patch Antenna Based on Mode Superposition Method
authors: Huayan Jin, Chunyang Yang, Wenlei Wang, Weiliang Yu, Guo Qing Luo
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: In this communication, a co-polarized in-band full-duplex (IBFD) radiator-shared antenna based on the mode superposition method is proposed. The antenna features a single-layer design, consisting of a substrate integrated waveguide (SIW) cavity and a square metal patch, fed by a pair of symmetrically placed coaxial probes. When one port of the antenna is excited, the superposition of the TE110 mode generated by the SIW cavity and the TM01 mode generated by the patch creates an electric field null region around the unexcited port, achieving a measured peak port isolation of 48 dB without the need for additional decoupling structures. To further reduce the antenna size, a quasi-TEM SIW cavity with a lower resonant frequency than TE110 mode is employed. The miniaturized SIW cavity’s TE010 mode is used in combination with a modified patch’s TM01 mode to achieve high port isolation. Measurements demonstrate isolation greater than 22 dB across the entire operating band, with a peak isolation of 53 dB, while reducing the structure size from 0.70λ<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</sub> × 0.70λ<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</sub> × 0.03λ<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</sub> to 0.39λ<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</sub> × 0.39λ<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</sub> × 0.04λ<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</sub>. The simple antenna structure requires no additional decoupling structures, making it highly suitable for applications in IBFD systems and related scenarios.

title: Advancing Data Governance: A Comprehensive Process Capability Model and Case Validation
authors: Selin Gökalp, Altan Koçyiğit
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Effective data governance is critical for organizations striving to leverage data as a strategic asset, yet standardized frameworks for assessing data governance capabilities remain underdeveloped. To address this gap, this study presents a Data Governance Process Capability Model (DG-PCM) grounded in the ISO/IEC 330xx standards. Building on a well-accepted Design Science Research (DSR) approach, the study develops and evaluates the DG-PCM as the designed artifact. The DSR framework guided the integration of complementary methods—including literature review, Modified-Delphi analysis, and case study—to iteratively design, validate, and refine the model. Developed through a systematic, multi-stage research approach, the model synthesizes insights from a comprehensive review of 326 academic studies and the practical perspectives of industry experts obtained via the Delphi method. The DG-PCM structures data governance processes into four primary domains—Data, Organization, Strategy, and Technology—encompassing eighteen distinct processes, each evaluated across six capability levels, from Level 0 (Not Performed) to Level 5 (Innovating). To assess the model’s practical relevance, a case study conducted within a manufacturing organization validated its utility in aligning data governance practices with broader organizational goals. This structured approach not only fills a critical gap in the literature but also provides a standardized, unbiased, and comprehensive framework for assessing data governance maturity. The findings indicate that the DG-PCM offers a robust foundation for continuous improvement, strategic alignment, and data-driven decision-making, positioning it as a vital tool for organizations seeking to enhance their data governance capabilities in an increasingly data-centric environment.

title: Efficient and Low-complex Approach to Improve Quality Factor of Photonic Crystal Terahertz Cavities
authors: Mai Van Ta, Luong Duy Manh
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Terahertz cavities with high quality factors are essential for sensing and oscillation stabilization applications. Planar photonic crystal cavities are promising owing to their compact size, which is convenient for integration purposes. Moreover, being a transmission-type cavity, it is useful for stabilizing terahertz oscillations, which is essential for high quality wireless communications. However, reported quality factors of planar photonic crystal cavities in the terahertz range are still moderate because the total loss was not effectively suppressed. In this paper, we propose an efficient and simple approach to reduce the total loss and, consequently, improve the quality factor of photonic crystal cavities. We propose simultaneously employing short embedded waveguides and properly displacing edged holes to reduce loss, thereby enhancing the quality factor. In more detail, the short embedded waveguides lead to the coupling loss and the in-plane loss reduction, while the latter corresponds to out-plane loss reduction. Moreover, in this work, the out-plane loss was analyzed and validated using the Fourier transform of the electric field. Proposed cavities were fabricated and characterized. High loaded quality factors of up to ~2.1× 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</sup> were obtained. To the best of our knowledge, this is the highest measured quality factor of a planar photonic crystal cavity in the terahertz range. Additionally, the proposed terahertz cavity also has the advantage of compactness. We believe the presented design of the terahertz photonic crystal cavity will promote promising terahertz applications such as sensing and high data rate wireless communications.

title: Recent Advances in Energy-Efficient and Temperature-Resilient Sensor Interfaces
authors: Woojun Choi, Inhee Lee, Youngwoo Ji, Alexander Delke, Sining Pan, Zhong Tang, Youngcheol Chae
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Solid-State Circuits Society
abstract: The rapid growth of power-constrained applications, including the Internet of Things (IoT) and wearables, demands sensor interfaces with high accuracy and reliability. A fundamental design challenge arises as their performance is severely limited by thermal drift within the analog front-end (AFE) and analog-to-digital converter (ADC) circuits. To address this, this article reviews two principal strategies: 1) the development of robust voltage and frequency reference circuits and 2) the implementation of on-chip temperature calibration. The review covers state-of-the-art temperature-compensated voltage references, such as subthreshold and BJT/MOS hybrid architectures, as well as stable frequency references based on LC and RC time constants. Furthermore, it examines advanced sensor interfaces that integrate on-chip temperature sensors for real-time error correction, featuring recent case studies on current sensor designs. These comprehensive advances are crucial for enabling reliable, energy-efficient sensor interfaces intended for precision-critical applications.

title: Dual-Field Microvascular Segmentation: Hemodynamically-Consistent Attention Learning for Retinal Vasculature Mapping
authors: Jingling Zhang, Xiangfei Liu, Shuting Zheng, Wen Zhang, Jia Gu
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Accurate retinal Microvascular segmentation demands a balanced combination of anatomical fidelity and hemodynamic relevance. However, existing methods fall short in preserving critical structures such as capillary junctions and bifurcations, thus limiting clinical applications and causing fragmentation. To address these limitations, we propose DFMS-Net, a novel dual-field segmentation framework that synergistically integrates geometric-field modeling—achieved through the Spatial Pathway Extractor (SPE) and Transformer-based Topology Interaction (TTI) for preserving structural continuity—and functional-field optimization—realized by the Semantic Attention Amplification (SAA) module for enhancing semantic visibility—via a unified Dual-Field Hemodynamic Attention (DFHA) mechanism. This core module enables joint enhancement of vessel continuity, accurate resolution of complex branching patterns, and recovery of low-contrast capillaries, all under physiological guidance. By co-optimizing geometric and functional cues within a unified attention learning paradigm, DFMS-Net produces segmentations that are both morphologically accurate and hemodynamically plausible. Furthermore, we propose two specialized variants using a streamlined Double SPE Attention for vessel continuity refinement. To address the directionality-dependent nature of structural damage in retinal ischemia and glaucoma, we propose Variant-1—a streamlined architecture that emphasizes dual-stage directional refinement to enhance trajectory coherence and improve the detection of topological disruptions, while Variant-2 supports high-resolution analysis of capillary dropout in early diabetic retinopathy through detailed microvascular recovery. Extensive experiments on retinal (DRIVE, STARE) and coronary angiography (DCA1, CHUAC) datasets demonstrate that DFMS-Net achieves state-of-the-art performance. Meanwhile, its strong generalization capability offers a promising foundation for diagnosing both retinal and cardiovascular diseases. The code will be available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/699zjl/DFMS-Net-new</uri>.

title: Personality-Aware Multimodal Driver Emotion Recognition Towards Intelligent Connected Vehicles
authors: Puning Zhang, Mengxue Hu, Hongbin Zhang, Chao Wu, Zhigang Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Affective Computing
abstract: Accurate emotion recognition of Intelligent Connected Vehicles (ICV) drivers plays a crucial role in mitigating driving risks caused by emotional fluctuations, thereby enhancing road safety and improving driving experiences. Current approaches predominantly suffer from two critical limitations, reliance on single-modality emotional data analysis and neglect of individual personality differences that significantly influence emotional manifestations. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a Personality-aware Multimodal Emotion Recognition Network (PMERNet) that synergistically integrates psychological theory with multimodal learning. Specifically, we first design an end-edge collaborative architecture that optimizes resource allocation between vehicle terminals and roadside units (RSUs), enabling efficient multimodal data collection (end-side) and collaborative feature processing (edge-side). Second, we develop a Weighted Temporal Background Attention module (WTBA-VExt) for robust facial expression analysis and implement a cross-modal self-attention Transformer for explicit multimodal feature fusion. Third, incorporating the psychological Big Five personality theory, we propose a Multimodal Big Five Personality Extractor (Multi-BFPExt) to capture latent personality traits and establish a bidirectional cross-modal fusion mechanism for personality-enhanced emotion recognition. Comprehensive experiments demonstrate that PMERNet achieves statistically significant improvements over existing state-of-the-art methods, reaching superior performance in both accuracy and weighted F1-score. Notably, the weighted F1-score is enhanced by 1.16%.

title: Characterization of Stimulated Raman Scattering in Field-Deployed Coupled-Core Multi-Core Fibers
authors: Giammarco Di Sciullo, Lucas A. Zischler, Divya A. Shaji, Qi Wu, Ruben S. Luís, Robert Emmerich, Menno van den Hout, Benjamin J. Puttnam, Georg Rademacher, Chiara Lasagni, Paolo Serena, Alberto Bononi, Tetsuya Hayashi, Colja Schubert, Chigo Okonkwo, Roland Ryf, Luca Palmieri, Mark Shtaif, Andrea Marotta, Antonio Mecozzi, Cristian Antonelli
publish: Journal of Lightwave Technology
abstract: We report the first experimental characterization of stimulated Raman scattering (SRS) in coupled-core multi-core fibers (MCFs). The experiment was performed using field-deployed fibers, with two complementary methodologies. First, the effective Raman gain coefficient was directly measured over a bandwidth of 120 nm – covering the upper S-, C- and lower L-bands – with the Raman pump being injected into different combinations of fiber cores and using either co- or counter-propagating signal. Second, we analyzed the spectral power tilt induced by SRS when transmitting a wavelength-division multiplexed signal spanning the entire C-band from 1529.4 nm to 1564.2 nm, which was found to be in agreement with the Raman gain coefficient measurements. Measurements performed on a co-deployed standard single-mode fiber (SMF) produced similar results. This observation, together with the notion that the Raman gain coefficient should be similar in MCFs and SMFs, validates our earlier derived model of SRS in fibers with strong mode mixing.

title: CPERE 2025 Panel Discussion
authors: N/A
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Power Electronics and Renewable Energy (CPERE)

title: Assessing Access to Health Services in Guelmim-Oued Noun Moroccan Region under the Southern Provinces Development Programme : A PLS-SEM Approach
authors: Said Housni, Ahmed Akdim, Anas Chekrouni, Rachid Hasnaoui
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: In a context of fierce competition between territories, it is imperative to design public programs adapted to the realities of each territory in order to better respond to the growing needs of citizens, and to adopt innovative approaches to solving problems linked to basic social sectors.In all developed and developing countries, the health sector is recognized as an essential pillar of strength. In Morocco, the health sector has always been a cornerstone of the various strategic public programs implemented.Since its recovery, aimed at the social development of its southern provinces, Morocco has chosen to commit itself to strengthening key sectors of human development, in particular widening the local population's access to quality health care.Territorially, to improve health indicators in the Guelmim-Oued Noun region (GONR), territorial development programs have been rolled out, such as the Southern Provinces Development Programme (DPSP) (2015-2021), with the aim of improving living conditions for the regional population, particularly in rural areas.The objective of the present research is to identify the causal relationship between the implementation of the DPSP and the changes observed in access to health services in the GONR using Structural Equation modelling.

title: Leveraging LLMs for Real-Time Customer Value Management in B2B E-Commerce
authors: Irwan Andriyanto Nugroho, Kusworo Adi, Komang Budi Aryasa
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Information Technology, Computer, and Electrical Engineering (ICITACEE)
abstract: In the highly competitive B2B environment, effective Customer Value Management (CVM) is essential for maintaining and strengthening customer relationships. This study aims to enhance service personalization for B2B customers in the SME segment by transforming historical customer service conversations from an e-commerce platform into actionable data. Utilizing real-time classification with Large Language Models (LLMs), the conversation data is processed to identify customer preferences. The classified information is then visualized through an insight dashboard to support corporate strategic decision making. This research applies data cleaning, classification, and visualisation by employing an exploratory methodology within an Information Systems framework. The findings offer a structured model for optimising the use of data to improve service quality and enhance B2B customer satisfaction.

title: Research on Yaw Speed Control Strategy for Wind Turbine Generators
authors: Tieying Zhang, Zongjie Zhou, Jianxing Zhou, Ziping Zhang, Jirong Zheng, Menglei Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: To address the significant dynamic response hysteresis and overshoot in the valve-controlled motor speed control system of wind turbine generators, this study proposes a variable-domain-optimized fuzzy PID control strategy. Using AMESim, we establish a system model, while a variable-domain fuzzy PID controller is developed on the Matlab/Simulink platform. By incorporating a parameter-adaptive fuzzy inference system, a complete mechatronic simulation environment is constructed. Simulation show that, compared to traditional PID control, the proposed strategy cuts the step response time to 0.4 s and eliminates startup overshoot. Under a ±150-Nm step disturbance, speed fluctuation amplitude drops by 25%, resolving the poor adaptability caused by fixed quantization factors in traditional fuzzy control, with dynamic domain adjustment achieved.

title: Enhancing Performance of Radial Distribution Systems by Integrating Renewable Energy Sources using Exhaustive Search Method
authors: Bandar Alrashidi, Ahmad Eid, Abdulrahman Alsafrani
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Power Electronics and Renewable Energy (CPERE)
abstract: Minimizing power losses in radial distribution systems is essential for efficient, reliable, and low-carbon power delivery. This study investigates the impact of optimally sizing and locating Distributed Generation (DG) units in 10- and 33-bus test feeders using an exhaustive search method (ESM) for load flow solution. Different case studies, including the DG integration working in unity, addressing lagging and achieving optimal power factors, are investigated. The ESM guarantees the global optimum for both networks and is a benchmark for heuristic approaches. Results show that adding a single DG can reduce total real-power loss by up to $70 \%$, while adding two DGs minimizes the loss to more than $85 \%$. Loss reduction is maximized when the DG operates at the optimal power factor, while the voltage profiles improve. Although computation time rises sharply with feeder size, the method remains tractable for medium-scale systems and provides an indispensable yardstick for validating faster meta-heuristics. The findings highlight the operational value of coordinated DG placement and power-factor control for utilities planning high-penetration renewable resources.

title: Modification of the Yolov8 Model for Inference of Disease Detection and Nutritional Deficiency in Corn Plants on Edge Computing Devices
authors: Imran Yusuf, Muhammad Niswar
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Information Technology, Computer, and Electrical Engineering (ICITACEE)
abstract: Early detection of diseases and nutritional deficiencies in plants is crucial in supporting precision agriculture, particularly in corn cultivation. This study proposes modifying the YOLOv8 architecture with patch-based image segmentation techniques to improve edge computing devices' detection accuracy and inference efficiency. Four model configurations were evaluated: YOLOv8 baseline, YOLOv8 with patches, modified YOLOv8, and the proposed model, which is modified YOLOv8 with patches. Experimental results show that the proposed model achieves the best detection performance, with a mean mAP@0.5 (mAP@0.5) of 87%, precision of 0.98, recall of 0.77, and the highest F1-Score of 0.89. Additionally, this model demonstrates superior inference efficiency, with an execution time of 1.9 ms/image on an NVIDIA T4 GPU, 21 seconds/image on a Raspberry Pi, and 121.1 ms/image on a Jetson Nano. Memory consumption is also the lowest, at 308.62 MB on Raspberry Pi and 278.82 MB on Jetson Nano. These results indicate that modifying YOLOv8 with patch-based preprocessing improves detection accuracy and enables practical deployment on edge devices with limited computational resources. This makes the model highly suitable for real-time agricultural monitoring applications in resourceconstrained environments.

title: A Dynamic prediction method for carbon emissions from steel enterprises based on an electricity-carbon coupling model
authors: Chengwei Cui, Fei Jiang, Kaicheng Liu, Naiyue Wu
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: As the industry with the highest share of carbon emissions in the industrial sector, the steel industry plays a critical role in achieving China's dual carbon goals. Accurate carbon emission forecasting for the steel sector is therefore of great importance. However, such forecasting faces dual challenges of incomplete and delayed user data. To address these issues, this paper proposes a dynamic carbon emission prediction method for steel enterprises based on electricity consumption data. First, typical process flows in the steel industry are analyzed, and an energy-carbon emission process knowledge graph is constructed to uncover the relationships between key equipment and carbon emissions. Then, an electricity-carbon coupling model is proposed, using energy as a bridge. Based on the process knowledge graph, major carbon sources and critical equipment are identified, and a coupling model is established using a Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU) and multivariate regression. The energy-carbon conversion coefficients of each process are predicted using a rolling Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) network. Grey relational analysis is employed to achieve carbon emission forecasting for steel enterprises. Finally, a case study of a representative steel enterprise in southern China is conducted to validate the proposed method. The results show that the prediction accuracy exceeds 95%.

title: Federated Intelligence in Immersive Technologies: Systematic Review of Privacy, Agents and Metaverse
authors: Zakaria Izouaouen, Nassim Kharmoum, Soumia Ziti
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: The convergence of Multi-Agent Systems (MAS) and immersive technologies represents a rapidly evolving research domain with significant implications for intelligent virtual environments. This systematic review presents a comprehensive comparative analysis of approaches, frameworks, and applications that integrate MAS within Virtual Reality (VR), Augmented Reality (AR), and Mixed Reality (MR) environments. Following PRISMA guidelines, we systematically reviewed 170 peer-reviewed articles published between 2020-2025, ultimately analyzing 25 high-quality studies that met our inclusion criteria. Our analysis reveals diverse architectural approaches including distributed multi-agent reinforcement learning frameworks, federated learning-enabled systems, and adaptive collaborative platforms. Key application domains identified include healthcare informatics, vehicular metaverses, educational training environments, and immersive collaboration systems. The study identifies critical challenges in real-time performance optimization, scalability with large agent populations, and maintaining quality of experience in distributed environments. Our findings contribute a novel classification framework for MAS-immersive technology integration, highlighting the shift towards privacy-preserving federated approaches and the emergence of metaverse applications. We present quantitative analysis of research trends and provide a roadmap for future developments in this intersection of artificial intelligence and immersive computing.

title: Modelling of Textile Patch Antenna Deformations by the Cylindrical TLM Method
authors: Jugoslav J. Joković, Tijana Ž. Dimitrijević, Aleksandar S. Atanasković, Nebojša S. Dončov
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Technologies, Systems and Services in Telecommunications (TELSIKS)
abstract: This paper explores the potential of the cylindrical Transmission Line Matrix (TLM) method for modeling textileintegrated antennas in wearable applications. It emphasizes the method’s capability to independently address geometric and structural variations under bending and stretching conditions. Various scenarios involving conductive patch and textile substrate characterization are analyzed to demonstrate the suitability of the cylindrical TLM approach as a benchmark tool in the design and optimization of wearable antennas subjected to typical deformation.

title: Key Account Managers (KAMS) Journey Management and Performance Prediction Using Machine Learning
authors: Andri Fabriansyah, Aghus Sofwan, Kardison Lumban Batu, Nala Puspita Murti, Sarah Nazly Nuraya, Shafira Ramadhina Adifa
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Information Technology, Computer, and Electrical Engineering (ICITACEE)
abstract: This research addresses the challenge of managing Key Account Managers (KAMs) by introducing and validating the “7 KAMs Journey” framework, a structured lifecycle model spanning from candidate selection to retirement. Moving beyond subjective evaluations, this study employs and compares two machine learning algorithms, XGBoost and Support Vector Regression (SVR), to analyze integrated historical data from HRIS and CRM systems, aiming to predict performance and identify dominant success factors at each career stage. The empirical results demonstrate that a KAM's career trajectory can be accurately modeled, with XGBoost showing a slightly better overall predictive fit (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}} \boldsymbol{=} \mathbf{0. 5 5 8 0}$</tex>) compared to SVR <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\left(R^{2}=0.5387\right)$</tex>. The models achieved particularly high accuracy in early-stage predictions, with XGBoost excelling at forecasting onboarding success (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$</tex> =0.9358) and SVR strongly predicting long-term performance from candidate data (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}} \boldsymbol{=} \mathbf{0. 8 0 3 2}$</tex>). Key findings reveal that quantifiable attributes, specifically standardized assessments (CnQ Test) and formal certifications, are powerful predictors of future success. This study contributes a validated, data-driven framework for KAM management, providing organizations with a strategic roadmap to optimize recruitment and development using robust predictive models, ultimately empowering them to cultivate a high-performing KAM workforce with greater precision and foresight.

title: Mapping influence zones via Thematic modeling and the Theory of Belief Functions
authors: Fatima-Zahrae Sifi, Wafae Sabbar, Amal El Mzabi
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: Social media platforms have introduced both new challenges and exciting opportunities in understanding human behavior and digital communication. Unlike traditional media, social networks provide a dynamic environment where users actively shape conversations and influence spreads quickly in multiple directions. In this context, influencers have a crucial role to spread information and shape opinions. However, the measure of influence of these individuals goes beyond simple engagement metrics. Because people interact in so many different ways and talk about a variety of topics online, this becomes complicated. We use a hybrid analytical technique that combines interaction based network signals with textual data to solve this. In order to model uncertainty and partial evidence from user interactions (likes, mentions, retweets), we suggest a methodological approach that combines belief function theory with Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA) to identify primary subjects in textual data. This approach allows us to identify influencer’s domain authority and provides a robust process to observe influence trajectories by various thematic clusters. It entitles computational social scientists to create complex models of participation and effect on the digital sphere.

title: Research on Cooperative Fusion Processing and Optimization Method for Multiple Spacecraft and Multisource Data
authors: Aicheng Zhang, Yanhe Cheng, Dong Run, Fencai Zhao, Wei Gao, Xinqian Zhao, Zihe Yang, Asu Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: To improve channel utilization, a multi-channel source packet downlink mode is designed for the multi-spacecraft combined configuration in deep space exploration. Concurrently, a multi-channel periodic multiplexing scheme for telemetry is implemented, adapting to different flight stages and telemetry mode switches. Multiple ground tracking stations receive spacecraft downlink data simultaneously. Addressing diverse user requirements, it is essential to investigate collaborative fusion processing methods for multi-channel, multi-source telemetry data with-in multi-spacecraft configurations. This approach is crucial for enhancing data utilization while ensuring reliability and validity. Telemetry data optimization criteria are established, a multi-source data optimization model is developed, and optimal data is selected for user deliver .

title: Research on Motor Fault Diagnosis Based on Improved Convolutional Neural Network of Random Forest under Small Sample Conditions
authors: Wenjie Liu, Jiajie Hao, Yi Yang, Guoji Shen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: In response to the limitations of traditional convolutional neural networks in motor condition monitoring under small sample conditions, this study proposes an improved convolutional neural network model based on random forests （CNN-RF）, which utilizes Random Forests to replace the softmax classification layer of the original CNN, thereby integrating Random Forest methods with Convolutional Neural Networks. Utilizing the bearing dataset from Huazhong University of Science and Technology, the research generated image sets under small-sample conditions using continuous wavelet transform. The proposed model demonstrates robust classification performance in data-scarce scenarios, achieving 97.38% accuracy with only 10% of the data.

title: A comprehensive identification method of single-phase grounding and disconnection faults based on feature fusion of branch currents and neutral point voltage
authors: Jia Zhu, Feng Wang, Zhenning Wang, Tianyu Liang, Niancheng Zhou, Jian Wang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: Aiming at the difficulty in distinguishing between single-phase grounding and disconnection faults in distribution networks, as well as the vulnerability of traditional identification methods to interference from distributed generators due to their reliance on phase voltage, this paper proposes a comprehensive identification method for single-phase fault based on feature fusion of branch currents and neutral point voltage. Firstly, the abrupt times of zero-sequence voltage, and abrupt features of negative sequence current amplitude and fault phase current of four typical single-phase faults, namely single-phase grounding, disconnection without grounding, disconnection with load-side grounding and disconnection with power-side grounding are analyzed. Secondly, by applying a multi-electrical quantity fusion criterion, different fault types are effectively distinguished. Thirdly, the fault section is located by analyzing the similarity of zero-sequence current waveforms and the abrupt changes in negative sequence current. Finally, a 10kV distribution network model is built in MATLAB/Simulink for simulation verification. The results show that the method has good applicability in systems with ungrounded neutral points and can adapt to complex conditions such as grid-forming distributed generator access, noise interference, abrupt and attenuation of grounding resistance. The proposed method overcomes the limitations of traditional methods that rely on phase voltage and are vulnerable to interference from new energy sources, thereby offering a novel solution for fault diagnosis in smart distribution networks.

title: Radar Fast Target Detection Method Based on DSP
authors: Haowen Lang, Hui Nie, Jinyu Chen, Zhaoming Zhang, Yuanjie Dang, Shuailin Chen, Yuguang Zhang
publish: 2024 5th China International SAR Symposium (CISS)
abstract: By transmitting the pulse signal and processing the echo of the target, the radar can realize the effective detection of the target, and then guide the SAR system to perform high-resolution imaging in a specific area, which significantly improves the efficiency of SAR image acquisition. Therefore, it is particularly important to design a fast target detection method suitable for engineering Pulse-Doppler radar. In this paper, the preprocessing operation is designed for the target clustering algorithm, which saves the hardware system resources and improves the operation efficiency. The feasibility and accuracy of the proposed algorithm in engineering implementation are verified by comparing the DSP online processing results with MATLAB simulation results.

title: Humanitarian Supply Chain Resilience during Natural hazard measurement literature from 2014 to 2024
authors: Oumayya Hechlaf, Moulay Ali El Oualidi, Hasna Mharzi
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: This systematic review synthesizes the literature on humanitarian supply chain resilience (HSCR) in the context of natural hazards drawing on research published from 2014 to 2024. Given the significant growth in HSCR research over the past decade, this study examines two critical dimensions: (1) main resilience measurement methods in literature and (2) alignment of these research methods with different disaster resilience phases. Through this analysis, we identify gaps in current research, including the underrepresentation of high-impact hazards (floods, earthquakes, hurricanes), limited integration of mixed-method approaches, and the need for cross-phase resilience frameworks. These findings lead to three recommendations designed to advance the field: prioritizing underrepresented hazards, combining predictive modeling with organizational learning, and developing integrated resilience frameworks. While acknowledging the limitations of literature reviews, this study provides valuable insights for researchers and practitioners, serving as a foundation for understanding current trends and guiding future research to strengthen humanitarian supply chain resilience in natural disaster contexts

title: Application Research on Lightweight Processing and Visualization Technology of BIM Models for Pumped Storage Power Stations
authors: Lingling Ming, Zengtao Zhao, Feng Cao, Guangyong Zeng
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: With the advancement of digital construction in large-scale hydropower projects such as pumped storage power stations, the web-based application of Building Information Modeling (BIM) technology faces challenges due to the large size and complex attributes of the models. The main research gap lies in efficiently visualizing and interacting with these large-scale BIM models on the web while maintaining performance and usability. To address these issues, this paper proposes a BIM model lightweighting method that integrates usage-oriented component filtering, multi-level semantic retention, and view-priority-based model slicing and loading. By analyzing component complexity and semantic redundancy, ineffective components are removed and geometric models are compressed. The proposed method tackles both the reduction of model size and the improvement of user interaction efficiency on web platforms, which have been longstanding challenges in this domain. Efficient encoding is achieved through the use of the gLTF format combined with the Draco compression algorithm. A web visualization platform is developed using Vue and Three.js, incorporating dynamic loading and data-binding mechanisms to enable high-performance rendering and interaction of BIM models on the web. The results demonstrate that this method significantly reduces model size and loading time while maintaining semantic integrity. It also offers good cross-device adaptability and supports operations and maintenance. This research provides a feasible technical approach and platform foundation for the online management and intelligent operation of BIM models for pumped storage power stations.

title: Optimized Fractional Order Modelling for Advanced Characterization of Photovoltaic Module Performance
authors: Ahmed G. Mahmoud, Mohamed A. El-Beltagy, Ahmed M. Zobaa
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Power Electronics and Renewable Energy (CPERE)
abstract: This work presents a thorough comparison study of integer and fractional order models for five different commercial photovoltaic (PV) modules at a fixed temperature of $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and varying irradiation levels. To characterize the I-V characteristics of the PV modules and assess how closely they align with the datasheet values, the study applies both integer-based and fractional models, which are solved using Grünwald-Letnikov (GL) numerical method. A multi-objective optimization technique, utilizing a gradient-based algorithm and the interior-point method, is employed to determine the optimal differentiation order (α) and achieve the best-fit model. This approach ensures high accuracy and adaptability across diverse irradiance conditions, significantly advancing PV performance analysis and optimization. The optimal α is identified by maximizing the Coefficient of Determination ($\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$) and minimizing the Root Mean Square error (RMSE).The results show that, when compared to integer models, the fractional order models greatly enhance accuracy in some circumstances, particularly for irradiance levels of $600 \mathrm{~W} / \mathrm{m}^{2}$ or less, where RMSE values improved by up to $61.42 \%$ and $R^{2}$ values can increase significantly. The fractional model showed improved alignment with the PV module datasheet values when optimized differentiation orders between 0.92 and 1.00 were used, highlighting their potential to improve PV module characterization. The application of these results to a wider range of environmental circumstances and PV technologies will be investigated in future research.

title: Short-Term Power Load Forecasting Based on SVMD and Enhanced Informer Model
authors: Nanwei Ding, Ming Li, Cong Zhou, Ruijun Tie
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: Short-term electricity load forecasting is essential for ensuring the stable operation of power systems and optimizing energy resource management. This paper proposes a novel hybrid forecasting framework, SVMD-ICM-Informer, which combines Successive Variational Mode Decomposition (SVMD) with a newly designed Interactive Convolution Module (ICM) and the Informer architecture. SVMD effectively decomposes complex load sequences into multiple predictable components, facilitating better feature representation at different temporal scales. The ICM further enhances feature extraction by leveraging multi-scale convolutional paths and cross-feature interactions to capture both local and global temporal dependencies. Integrated with the Informer model, the framework achieves superior long-range temporal modeling capabilities. Experiments on a real-world dataset demonstrate that the proposed SVMD-ICM-Informer model outperforms baseline methods in terms of forecasting accuracy and robustness, confirming its effectiveness for short-term load prediction.

title: Semiconductor Organic Solar Cell Using SCAPS
authors: Mostafa Salah, Basel Erabi, Amro Ahmed, Farah Hossam, Mohamed Abouelatta, Ahmed Saeed
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Power Electronics and Renewable Energy (CPERE)
abstract: Creating high-efficiency organic solar cells (OSCs) has been a major focus in the field of renewable energy research. We tackle the challenging field of organic solar cells (OSCs) in this study by assessing in detail how changes in thickness and affinity affect the performance of a multi-material organic solar. Our research into device physics, computer modeling, and material science is motivated by our quest for maximum efficiency. The foundation of our approach is the intentional control of key factors affecting OSC performance. To explore the potential of the organic solar cell design, we made small adjustments to the component materials’ compatibility and thickness. This rigorous method, fueled by state-of-the-art modeling tools and basic principles, signifies a paradigm leap in the optimization arena for OSCs. Our approach comprises a thorough calibration procedure wherein the affinity and thickness of each material are consistently adjusted within a predetermined parameter space. By exploiting the extensive capabilities of the SCAPS program paired with the powerful analytical tools of MATLAB, we conduct a series of simulations that precisely map the complicated relationship between material characteristics and device performance. The principal concentration of our study is on the quantum efficiency spectra, which are key metrics that determine each material’s photovoltaic performance. We give a rich tapestry of insights into the absorption, emission, and charge transport mechanisms impacting OSC performance by carefully studying quantum efficiency spectra vs wavelength for each of the 12 components. Moreover, given with a complete knowledge of material behavior and device physics, we set out to develop the finest feasible organic solar cell via engineering. Through a process of continual refining and careful change of material thicknesses and affinities, we have produced an OSC that is highly stable and efficient. Our results imply large increases in efficiency across all materials. Our finding opens the door to a new age of sustainable energy harvesting and delivers meaningful steps towards the building of next-generation OSCs with the potential to initiate a worldwide revolution in renewable energy.

title: Wear Prediction of Engine Sliding Bearings UsingPhysics-Informed Neural Networks
authors: Zhongning Wang, Liting Li, Kai Jiang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: Wear is one of the critical factors inducing various mechanical failures, and accurately predicting the wear between friction pairs is essential for equipment health management. As diesel engines progressively develop toward higher explosion pressures and power densities, the working environments of key components such as crankshaft bearings become increasingly harsh, making them more prone to wear issues that compromise engine reliability. Most existing data-driven methods primarily focus on wear modeling using sparse data, yet such approaches exhibit limitations in interpretability. To address this challenge, this paper proposes a physics-informed neural network approach by integrating the Archard wear law and typical wear processes as physical constraints into the neural network framework, thereby enhancing model interpretability. Experimental results demonstrate that incorporating prior physical knowledge improves the overall performance of the neural network. Furthermore, parameter sensitivity analysis reveals that the model maintains behavior consistent with typical wear processes even when applied to unseen data.

title: Modulating sensorimotor synchronization through theta burst stimulation of the posterior parietal cortex: a TMS-EEG study
authors: Han Liu, Xiao Yan g, Mengxuan Hu, Tianyi Yan, Shintaro Funahashi, Guangying Pei
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Complex Medical Engineering (CME)
abstract: We investigated the effects of continuous (cTBS) and intermittent (iTBS) theta-burst stimulation over the right posterior parietal cortex (PPC) on sensorimotor-task performance and cortical activity in three healthy volunteers. The results showed significant changes in the continuation and simple reaction tasks. In the simple reaction task, cTBS consistently shortened reaction times, whereas iTBS lengthened them, indicating a role for the PPC in response control. TMSEEG revealed that cTBS reduced TEP amplitudes of the P2 and the motor areas, whereas iTBS increased them; cTBS also shortened latencies of the motor areas, whereas iTBS lengthened them. In conclusion, cTBS improved motor performance by decreasing cortical excitability and increasing information processing efficiency, whereas iTBS impairs motor performance by excessively increasing excitability.

title: Multi-Modal Fusion for Robust Face Liveness Detection: Integrating Ensemble Learning and Contrastive Techniques
authors: Brahim Bah, Omar Zilati, Houssam Benbrahim, Aouatif Amine
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: In the world of biometrics, face liveness detection is well known, also called anti-spoofing or liveness checking. It’s a set of methods used to authenticate a user properly by utilizing their biometric properties— for example, a real eye or human face rather than a recreated image of one. This is a key concept for systems to protect their users’ privacy, particularly for sensitive applications such as finance, where financial transactions must be carried out safely, and printed photos, video replays, or masks are typical techniques used among attackers. We could point out several challenges that make it difficult for these systems to achieve robust security, such as variability in lighting conditions, diversity in camera qualities, and differences in facial appearances across populations. In this paper, we propose a novel face-liveness detection method that combines ensemble learning and contrastive learning techniques. This mixed approach aims to improve the solidity and accuracy of detecting these various spoofing attacks. We use the NUAA dataset combined with AI-generated text descriptions of the images. We tested our model on the NUAA dataset, achieving an accuracy of 94.98%. Our method effectively detects printed photo attacks, highlighting the potential of this mixed approach in face anti-spoofing.

title: Classification of Acne Based on Facial Images Using KNN and Decision Tree
authors: Fayza Putri Zulfikar, Putu Harry Gunawan
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Information Technology, Computer, and Electrical Engineering (ICITACEE)
abstract: Acne is a common dermatological condition affecting adolescents and adults, with severity ranging from mild to very severe. Accurate severity classification is crucial for effective treatment and monitoring, particularly in automated healthcare systems. This study proposes an image-based acne severity classification system that utilizes facial acne density as the main feature. The workflow includes image preprocessing, acne detection using the YOLOv8 object detection model, and density-based feature extraction. These features are then classified using k-Nearest Neighbors (k-NN) and Decision Tree (DT) algorithms. To address class imbalance, the Synthetic Minority Over-sampling Technique (SMOTE) is applied, improving model generalization. Experimental results show that DT achieves higher performance with 99 % accuracy, while k-NN achieves 97%. Precision, recall, and F1-score metrics further validate the model's robustness. This study confirms the effectiveness of acne density as a feature and demonstrates that integrating object detection with machine learning offers promising results for clinical and telemedicine applications in acne diagnosis and personalized treatment planning.

title: Analysis of Differences in Driver Emergency Braking Behavior by Integrating EEG and EMG Signals
authors: Pengjing Liu, Jin Zhao, Guochao Deng
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: This study proposes a multimodal emergency braking intention recognition method to analyze the differences in physiological responses of drivers of different age groups in emergency driving situations by fusing electroencephalography (EEG) and electromyography (EMG) signals. Through a high-fidelity driving simulation experiment, the EEG and EMG data of 16 drivers (20-30 years old and 60-70 years old groups) were collected in the simulated environment, and features were extracted using adaptive power spectral density (APSD) and conventional spatial pattern (CSP). The experimental results show that the power in the theta- and beta-wave bands is significantly higher in the older group than in the younger group, reflecting a larger cognitive load and longer reaction time; EMG analysis further reveals that the older group has a delayed peak activation (250-270ms) and a higher activation intensity, whereas the younger group responds more quickly (100-115ms). This method provides technical support and neurophysiological basis for the design of intelligent driving systems, especially considering the effect of age differences.

title: CSI-Based Human Activity Recognition Using Low-Cost Wi-Fi Modules and Deep Neural Networks
authors: Van Cong Do, Minh Duc Luong, Tien Khanh Luong, Van Hai Phan, Quoc Cuong Nguyen, Minh Thuy Le
publish: 2025 24th International Symposium on Communications and Information Technologies (ISCIT)
abstract: Human Activity Recognition (HAR) using Wi-Fi Channel State Information (CSI) has emerged as a promising contactless and privacy-preserving approach to understanding human behavior in indoor environments. Compared to vision-based or wearable systems, CSI-based HAR offers the advantages of low cost, non-intrusiveness, and the ability to leverage existing wireless infrastructure. In this paper, we propose a practical and cost-effective HAR framework that utilizes commercial ESP32 Wi-Fi modules to capture CSI data and a deep neural network (DNN) for activity classification. Our system demonstrates the feasibility of using low-cost embedded devices to collect meaningful CSI patterns, enabling activity recognition without the need for expensive routers or specialized hardware. We design and implement an end-to-end processing pipeline, starting with a synchronized data acquisition system that collects multilink CSI signals from multiple ESP32 modules, along with video recordings for ground-truth labeling. The collected data is used to train a two-dimensional convolutional neural network (2D-CNN) for real-time human activity recognition in indoor environments. Experimental results show that the proposed system achieves an average accuracy of 94.7% on our self-collected dataset, while maintaining computational efficiency and scalability. This demonstrates the feasibility of deploying accessible, privacy-preserving smart sensing applications using low-cost Wi-Fi hardware.

title: MPPT Method for PV Arrays under Partial Shading Conditions Based on an Improved PSO-FA Algorithm
authors: Yin Wang, Honghua Wang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: To address the issue of conventional maximum power point tracking (MPPT) algorithms easily falling into local optima under partial shading conditions in photovoltaic (PV) systems, an improved hybrid Particle Swarm Optimization– Firefly Algorithm (PSO-FA) is proposed. This algorithm utilizes Logistic chaotic mapping to initialize the particle population, enhancing population diversity to avoid search blind spots. In addition, an adaptive inertia weight mechanism is introduced to dynamically balance the global search capability and convergence speed of the PSO. When power fluctuations tend to stabilize, the algorithm switches to the Firefly Algorithm for refined local search. Simulation results under various irradiance conditions demonstrate that compared with standard PSO and FA algorithms, the improved PSO-FA algorithm can track the maximum power point of PV systems more quickly and accurately under complex shading scenarios.

title: Voice Type Classification in Choirs Using Acoustic Analysis Techniques
authors: Gilbert Christiansen Tahar, William Hartanto, Alexander Agung Santoso Gunawan, Rilo Chandra Pradana
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Information Technology, Computer, and Electrical Engineering (ICITACEE)
abstract: To achieve the best vocal harmony in music, it is important to identify a person's vocal type, especially in a choir. Male (baritone, tenor, bass) and female (soprano, alto, mezzo-soprano) voice types can be used to categorize the distinctive vocal qualities of each choir member. This research proposes an acoustic analysis-based method that uses feature extraction techniques such as Mel-Frequency Cepstral Coefficients (MFCC) and pitch analysis to extract a person's vocal characteristics to achieve accurate classification. A person's vocal type in a choir is then determined by analyzing these characteristics. The system classifies data using machine learning algorithms, specifically convolutional and artificial neural networks. The goal of the research is to create a system that can accurately and automatically recognize different types of voices in a choir. The experimental results show that the system can classify vocal types based on acoustic features with an accuracy of at least <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 0 \%}$</tex>, marking a significant advancement in music sound analysis.

title: Unsupervised Detection of Lifestyle-Linked Anomalies in Continuous Glucose Data
authors: Aleksandra I. Stojnev Ilic, Dragan H. Stojanovic, Natalija M. Stojanovic, Milos N. Ilic
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Technologies, Systems and Services in Telecommunications (TELSIKS)
abstract: Continuous Glucose Monitoring (CGM) provides detailed, minute-level insights into metabolic processes and holds significant promise for supporting overall well-being beyond traditional diabetes management. Despite its potential, CGM remains underused in detecting subtle physiological and lifestylerelated changes, such as variations in diet, physical activity, or hormonal cycles. To address this gap, an unsupervised anomaly detection framework is introduced to identify atypical daily glucose patterns without the need for labeled data. The approach encodes each day’s CGM profile as a high-dimensional vector, applies UMAP for dimensionality reduction, and uses DBSCAN to detect outliers. Applied to a two-month dataset from a single individual, the method revealed anomalies aligned with unlogged lifestyle changes. One event was independently confirmed through clinical records, underscoring the potential of CGM for passive, personalized monitoring and broader health tracking.

title: CMedGuider: A Smart Healthcare Assistant Empowered by the Proposed Chinese Medical Dialogue Dataset CMedConsul
authors: Qianye Lin, Yanzhi Song
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Complex Medical Engineering (CME)
abstract: Intelligent medical systems improve healthcare efficiency and reduce costs by leveraging health data. Recently, large language models (LLMs) have significantly advanced intelligent medical services. However, challenges persist, including insufficient data quality, limited dataset scale, privacy concerns, and uncontrolled generative dialogue. To address these issues, we propose a knowledge-graph-based method for multi-turn dialogue generation using LLMs and construct the CMedConsul dataset, featuring over $\mathbf{2 0, 0 0 0}$ triage dialogues and $\mathbf{1 7, 0 0 0}$ pre-consultation dialogues to mitigate data scarcity. We then fine-tune LLMs on CMedConsul to develop an intelligent medical assistant CMedGuider, which integrates triage, pre-consultation, and EMR generation into a unified workflow. Experimental results show that it achieves $\mathbf{9 3. 2 \%}$ accuracy in the triage task and $\mathbf{9 5. 3 4 \%}$ accuracy in the EMR generation task, demonstrating its effectiveness and deployment potential. We open-source the datasets and model for future research.

title: FedTM: Federated ASIC Technology Mapping
authors: Bhabesh Mali, Akash Lal Dutta, Chigarapally Chandrabhusan Reddy, Chandan Karfa, Sukanta Bhattacharjee
publish: ACM Transactions on Design Automation of Electronic Systems
abstract: Electronic Design Automation (EDA) software needs to solve computationally hard problems to automate and optimize circuit design. Clever heuristics are used in the EDA tools to trade off between the quality of results (QoR) and runtime. The Application Specific Integrated Circuit (ASIC) Technology Mapping (TM) is a fundamental problem in EDA that transforms a technology independent Boolean representation of a circuit into a technology-dependent representation using standard cells. The academic logic synthesis tool ABC represents the input circuit as And Inverter Graph (AIG) and use a cut-based Boolean matching algorithm for TM. However, this process has high computational overhead due to the Boolean matching across an exponentially large number of cuts. Machine Learning (ML) can provide faster, improved solutions through learning. In this regard, we have proposed LEAP: a novel ML-based cut classifier and a delay predictor, exposing a few high-quality cuts to the mapper. LEAP reduces the number of cuts by 51% compared to the ABC, resulting in a 2% improvement in delay without incurring any area penalty.

title: TDNet: A Transition-Driven Network for Semantic Change Detection in Coastal Wetlands
authors: Yan Lu, Jiawei He, Haojie Li, Yiming Wang, Binge Cui
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: Transition zones in coastal wetlands are prone to frequent semantic changes due to dynamic ecological processes such as tidal fluctuations, seasonal changes, and runoff dynamics. However, existing semantic change detection (SCD) methods generally lack explicit modeling and a structured representation of such regions, making it difficult to accurately locate and identify semantic changes within them. To address this issue, TDNet is proposed for SCD in coastal wetlands. First, a transition zone detection branch is added to identify semantically sensitive regions and guide the network to focus on change-prone areas. Then, a transition zone driven module (TZDM) temporally concatenates the initial segmentation features (ISFs) and transition zone features (TZFs) from the bi-temporal inputs into a four-frame sequence, processes it with a 3D convolutional structure to model spatiotemporal evolution in transition zones , and ultimately generates the final segmentation features (FSFs). Additionally, a transition zone indicator (TZI) is employed to generate pixel-level transition labels that provide spatial supervision, further improving the model’s ability to distinguish change-prone regions. Experimental results demonstrate that TDNet outperforms state-of-the-art methods in addressing the challenge of SCD within transition zones.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning based Idle-Aware Task Offloading in Dynamic Vehicular Networks with Partial Information
authors: Jing Zhang, Fei Shen, Feng Yan, Jie Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network Science and Engineering
abstract: Edge computing provides low-latency computational services for task offloading in vehicular networks. However, challenges such as dynamic transmission rates, resource limitations, and information-sharing constraints impede efficient offloading. Few studies address these issues concurrently in designing dynamic offloading strategies, often resulting in sub optimal system utility. This paper aims to achieve efficient vehicular task offloading via an idleness-aware edge server (ES) from a game theory perspective. We propose a Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU) prediction model with an attention mechanism to guide vehicles to the nearest idle ES. The offloading decision process is modeled as a stochastic game, proving the existence of a Nash equilibrium (NE). Additionally, we model it as a multi agent partially observable Markov decision process (POMDP) to account for limited information access among vehicles. To solve the POMDP and achieve near-optimal NE, we introduce a Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning-based Task Offloading (MATO) algorithm, combining a Differentiable Neural Computer (DNC) and an Advantageous Actor-Critic (A2C) framework. The DNC's external memory stores structured representations of past information, enabling deeper exploration of the strategy space. Adjusting the reward representation enhances training efficiency. Experimental results driven by real-world datasets demonstrate that MATO effectively improves the computing offloading utility while increasing the convergence speed compared to existing schemes.

title: Exploring Vehicle Lateral Motion Limit: Neutral Steering Control for Dual-Motor All-Wheel-Drive Electric Vehicles
authors: Lei Zhang, Tongliang Xu, Zhenpo Wang, Fengchun Sun, Xiaolin Ding
publish: IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology
abstract: Maximizing the utilization of lateral motion limits can significantly enhance vehicle safety under extreme driving conditions. This paper presents a neutral steering chassis coordination control scheme to extend the lateral motion limits of Dual-Motor All-Wheel-Drive Electric Vehicles (DMAWD EVs). First, an optimization model is developed using the tire friction ellipse to determine the maximum lateral force. It is demonstrated that a vehicle can fully exploit its lateral motion limits under neutral steering. Then a driving torque allocation method for the front and rear axles and a sliding mode control method for the electro-hydraulic composite anti-lock braking system are designed to fulfill the driver's driving intentions under normal driving conditions. In extreme driving conditions, a torque vectoring control strategy is proposed to coordinate the motors' driving torques and the hydraulic braking forces, while a Smith predictor-based control scheme is introduced to enhance the hydraulic braking responsiveness. Furthermore, a coordinated pitch and roll attitude controller is developed to maintain neutral steering. Finally, the proposed control scheme is verified through comprehensive testing on a Hardware-in-the-Loop platform. Results indicate that the maximum lateral acceleration increases by 18.14% under the open-loop sine steering scenario. The proposed control scheme renders DMAWD EVs to have comparable performance with four-wheel-independent-drive electric vehicles.

title: Triple-Mode CMA-Optimized HMSIW Antenna with Dual Slits for Smart 5G IoT Platforms
authors: Rakesh Kumar Chandan
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: This research proposes a novel low-profile HMSIW slot-fed slit-loaded elliptical patch antenna for 5G Internet of Things (IoT) applications. The antenna operates in three different modes with respective sub-bands of 5G FR2 band. A hybrid feeding structure comprising a half-mode SIW and a slot is employed to excite three effective radiative modes with proper radiation behavior. The proposed triple-mode antenna profile is derived by tuning the modal significance values obtained from the Characteristic Mode Analysis (CMA), using only two resonating radiators of the antenna structure. The frequencydependent scattering parameter, |S11| validates the bandwidths obtained from CMA. Moreover, bandwidth for all three modes obtained from the simulations is compared with the measured results, which demonstrate good agreement.The proposed antenna design is well-suited for diverse Internet of Things (IoT) applications, offering multi-band operation, compact form factor, and integration flexibility for next-generation wireless sensing and communication systems.

title: Prediction of DNA Methylation With Long-Range State-Space Models
authors: Hao Feng, Sakshar Chakravarty, Stefano Lonardi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Biology and Bioinformatics
abstract: The prediction of DNA methylation from the primary DNA sequence allows one to impute the methylation status of cytosines with insufficient sequencing coverage. Various deep learning models have been proposed in the literature, including transformer-based models and convolutional neural networks.
