The experimental results show that the coefficient of determination R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> of the multivariate nonlinear regression model established by this method can reach 91.55%, the mean absolute error (MAE) is 1.9944, and the root mean square error (RMSE) is 2.702. The failure warning is made 12.5h ahead of time, which is better than that of the simple univariate nonlinear regression model in judging the time when the number of abrasive particles rises sharply, and the model can realize the failure warning of large abrasive particles by using the number of medium-small abrasive particles. In addition, the accuracy and versatility of the method were further verified on other devices, and the warning of unexpected failures was made 5.5h in advance, which is of practical value.

title: Intelligent identification of load characteristics and power supply control strategies based on deep learning
authors: Xiaoman Hu, Cheng Zhang, Chaowen Xie, Fei Meng, Leilei Xu, Jianzhao Qu
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: With the continuous increase in power demand during construction site operations, traditional diesel generators and static uninterruptible power supplies (UPS) struggle to meet the requirements of high - reliability and high - dynamic - response power supply. This paper proposes a control strategy for energy storage grid - forming power supplies based on deep - learning - enabled intelligent load characteristic identification. This strategy is based on a multi - source data fusion and deep - learning - based intelligent load characteristic identification algorithm. By integrating multi - source data and an improved Transformer model, the accuracy of load identification is enhanced. Meanwhile, an improved virtual synchronous control algorithm based on adaptive parameter adjustment and multi - source information fusion is proposed to enhance the system's stability and response capabilities under complex loads. Simulation results show that the proposed control strategy can effectively improve the stability and reliability of the construction power network, reduce frequency fluctuations, and optimize load distribution. The research of this paper provides a new solution for the intelligent control of construction site power supply systems.

title: Short Circuit Resistance Calculation During Thermal Abuse Process
authors: Kun Yu, Jiarui Zhang, Qinghua Gui, Lei Mao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: With the increasing demand for electric vehicles and large-scale energy storage systems, lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) face critical safety challenges, particularly thermal runaway. This study proposes a non-invasive method to calculate the equivalent short circuit resistance of lithium iron phosphate (LFP) pouch batteries during thermal abuse using signal easy to access, such as open circuit voltage (OCV). The method estimates energy depletion from the OCV curve and calculates equivalent short circuit current and resistance. Validation is performed through constant current discharge tests, which can simulate OCV profiles during thermal abuse by adjusting density of constant current discharging, and the density of discharging current can represent the value of equivalent short circuit current. Experimental results show that short circuit resistance decreases significantly as temperature increases, indicating more severe faults. The proposed method offers a practical tool for quantifying short circuit severity and contributes to improving battery safety analysis.

title: An Integrated Learning-Based Ai Mobile Platform for Autonomous Navigation and Hazardous Fire Intelligence
authors: Thu D. M. Le, Boi T. Ho, Hieu M. Tran, Ke Wang, Ly V. Tran, Bao Q. Vuong, Son V. T. Dao
publish: 2025 24th International Symposium on Communications and Information Technologies (ISCIT)
abstract: This study presents the design and implementation of an autonomous mobile robot that combines indoor navigation, real-time mapping, and intelligent fire detection using AI-based methods. Leveraging 2D SLAM algorithms, the robot constructs accurate occupancy grid maps and localizes itself in dynamic indoor environments. For fire detection, a multistage approach is introduced, combining deep learning-based feature extraction, metaheuristic feature selection, and ensemble boosting classifiers to improve accuracy and efficiency. The robot's ability to detect fires early and respond autonomously makes it well-suited for safety-critical environments such as warehouses. The proposed system demonstrates a scalable, real-time solution that bridges autonomous mobility with intelligent environmental monitoring.

title: MFCI-Net: A Multi-Scale Feature Extraction Interaction Network for Enhanced Remote Sensing Object Detection
authors: Ting Chen, Yanan Lin, Peng Zhao, Tao Gao, Qianjin Zhao, Jinyue Yang
publish: 2024 5th China International SAR Symposium (CISS)
abstract: Object detection in remote sensing is crucial for tasks such as military surveillance and disaster assessment. However, it faces challenges such as complex backgrounds, multi-scale objects, inter-class similarity. To overcome these challenges, this paper introduces a novel network for multi -scale feature extraction and interaction (MFCI-Net). We propose the Multi-scale Information Extraction Module (MIEM), which is designed to operate from both global and local perspectives. Local feature extraction module captures fine-grained features and local context of multi-scale objects, while the global semantic information module focuses on key regions and global semantics. MIEM effectively mitigates background interference and reduces inter-class similarity. Additionally, Multi-scale Feature Fusion Module (MFFM) is introduced, using cross-attention mechanisms to adaptively capture key information across different scale feature maps, achieving efficient feature fusion, improving robustness in complex backgrounds, and enhancing the ability to distinguish objects with significant intra-class variations. Furthermore, based on MFFM, Small Object Emphasis Module (SOEM) is proposed to enhance small object detection by excluding large-scale object information. MFCI-Net achieved a mean average precision (mAP) of 75.47% on the DIOR remote sensing dataset, outperforming existing detectors.

title: Modern Data Stack Demystified: A Strategic Framework for Scalable Adoption
authors: Chayma Tlemcani, Abou Zakaria Faroukhi, Youssef Gahi
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: The rapid growth of increasingly complex and extensive data is forcing organizations to adopt modern data stacks (MDS) as the privileged foundation for extracting value and informing strategic decisions. Despite their flexibility, however, MDS projects face major difficulties, particularly in terms of governance, interoperability, and scalability, which can seriously compromise the effectiveness of data stacks. To overcome these constraints, this paper explores key challenges and introduces a formal data stack adoption framework designed to guide organizations along their data modernization roadmap. By mapping transformation stages to key operational and strategic functions, the framework supports an incremental, evidence-based approach. It helps organizations stay aligned with their goals, enabling MDS to evolve at their appropriate pace while maintaining consistent strategic alignment.

title: Construction of power plant flue gas emission prediction model based on machine learning
authors: Xin Xing, Jun Zhu, Lincong Luo, Jie Han, Gaowu Jian
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: To accurately predict the emissions of carbon monoxide (CO) and nitrogen oxides (NOₓ) in the flue gas of coal-fired power plants, thereby aiding power plants in achieving environmental compliance and efficient operation, this study constructs CO and NOₓ prediction models based on Random Forest (RF) and Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP).By collecting, preprocessing, and performing feature engineering on operational and environmental data from power plants, both models are trained and optimized, followed by a comparative analysis of their performance. Experimental results demonstrate that the combined model outperforms single models in terms of prediction accuracy, effectively forecasting CO and NOₓ emissions in flue gas. This model provides a novel technical approach for monitoring flue gas emissions in power plants and holds significant practical application value.

title: Development of Drifting Data Logger With Solar Power for Long-Term Observation
authors: Shonosuke Ishida, Takeshi Kumaki, Yuta Kusunoki
publish: 2025 24th International Symposium on Communications and Information Technologies (ISCIT)
abstract: In recent years, lacks of dissolved oxygen in various water areas around the world has become a serious problem. These phenomena have significant impacts on aquatic ecosystems. In order to conserve several living things, it is necessary to conduct long-term observations in various water areas to determine factors related to changes in dissolved oxygen. Therefore, we have been proposing a drifting data logger capable of simultaneously measuring dissolved oxygen, water temperature, position information, and so on. By releasing the developed data logger into water currents, it can measure various data over a wide area. In this paper, we develop a drifting data logger with solar power. This logger will run continuously 24 hours a day using only solar power and storage batteries. From obtained experimental results, we expect to collect data for a longer period of time in the Lake Biwa in the future.

title: Sentiment Analysis of Twitter Data Related to HIV/AIDS Using CNN-BiGRU Algorithm Optimized with Genetic Algorithm Optimization
authors: Bellamy Bintang Pratama, Mahendra Dwifebri Purbolaksono, Adiwijaya
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Information Technology, Computer, and Electrical Engineering (ICITACEE)
abstract: The dissemination of HIV/AIDS-related information on social media, particularly Twitter, plays a vital role in shaping public perception and increasing societal awareness. The vast and diverse nature of such data requires effective analytical techniques to interpret the sentiments expressed in tweets. This study proposes a deep learning-based sentiment classification approach using hybrid CNN-BiGRU and BiGRUCNN models. These models combine the spatial feature extraction capabilities of Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) with the contextual understanding of Bidirectional Gated Recurrent Units (BiGRU). A Genetic Algorithm (GA) is employed to optimize the model's hyperparameters and enhance overall performance. Sentiments are categorized into positive, neutral, and negative classes. The model's effectiveness is measured using the F1score as the primary evaluation metric. Experimental results show that the GA-optimized BiGRU-CNN model achieves the best performance, reaching an F1-score of 85.70 % in the final scenario. These findings confirm the model's effectiveness in sentiment classification of HIV/AIDS-related Twitter data and highlight its potential to support public health communication strategies.

title: Two-input three-level boost converter
authors: Krittayot Sengsui, Srimongkhon Udomkaew, Nitchamon Poonnoy, Wiset Saksiri, Matheepot Phattanasak, Montree Siripruchyanun, Roghayeh Gavagsaz-Ghoachani, Jean-Philippe Martin, Serge Pierfederici
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Power Electronics and Renewable Energy (CPERE)
abstract: The paper presents a new topology of a modular converter. Three capacitors are connected in series at the output port. The capacitance of the top and bottom capacitors can be reduced compared to the conventional one. No additional energy sources are needed. The operation is modeled using switching and large-signal modeling to investigate it. The latter model is then used to design a controller to control the inductor currents and balance the output capacitor voltage. Simulation results are given to demonstrate the converter’s operation.

title: Modeling and Mechanism Analysis of Rotor Support Misalignment Fault
authors: Guo Chen, Zihao Zhao, Xiangxiang Shen, Mohan Yang, Xiyang Liu, Lunxu Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: In this paper, a general model of rotor support misalignment fault is proposed. The equivalent coupling model parameters are calculated by using the radial stiffness and angular stiffness of the coupling, and the mechanical model of the coupling is established which has left and right half couplings and multiple connecting pairs connected to each other. The total radial stiffness and angular stiffness of the equivalent coupling are equivalent to the actual coupling. And the model parameters of the equivalent coupling are calculated according to the stiffness of the actual coupling. Then the stiffness difference and the nonlinear stiffness problem, the excitation force model of the angle misalignment fault of the coupling is established according to the uneven distribution of the circumferential position of the connection pair. In addition, the rotor-support coupling dynamic model with the rotor bearing misalignment fault is established. The vibration response characteristics of the rotor under the misalignment fault are analyzed by numerical simulation. The generation mechanism of characteristic frequency of misalignment fault is revealed. Finally,the test of rotor support misalignment fault under various misalignment conditions at characteristic speed is completed. And the test results verify the correctness of the rotor support misalignment fault model proposed in this paper.

title: Next-Generation Condition Monitoring: Digital Twin in RUL Predictive Maintenance for Main Bearings of Semi-Direct Drive
authors: Da Lv, Chao Zhang, Wentao Zhao, Yongzhi Pang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: Against the backdrop of China's national strategic goals and supporting policies for carbon peak and carbon neutrality, For wind power enterprises, reducing actual operating costs has become a top priority. The main bearing's unexpected damage in Semi-Direct Drive Wind Turbines (SDDWT) due to delayed maintenance can affect the overall machine stability, even causing prolonged shutdowns. Excessive maintenance, however, also leads to a significant increase in operation and maintenance costs. High-precision remaining useful life (RUL) prediction for main bearings can effectively reduce the operation costs of SDDWT, but RUL research on large rotating machinery like SDDWT main bearings still faces critical challenges: unclear performance degradation mechanisms, limited valuable data samples, and severe lack of data labeling.To address the above issues, this paper takes the main bearings of SDDWTs as the research object. By integrating model-based Digital Twin technology with data-driven domain adaptation methods, it conducts studies on: (1) the analysis of performance degradation mechanisms for main bearings; (2) the theoretical methodology of model-data fusion for RUL prediction.

title: Vision-Based Learning for Cyberattack Detection in Blockchain Smart Contracts and Transactions
authors: Do Hai Son, Le Vu Hieu, Tran Viet Khoa, Yibeltal F. Alem, Hoang Trong Minh, Tran Thi Thuy Quynh, Nguyen Viet Ha, Nguyen Linh Trung
publish: 2025 24th International Symposium on Communications and Information Technologies (ISCIT)
abstract: Blockchain technology has experienced rapid growth and has been widely adopted across various sectors, including healthcare, finance, and energy. However, blockchain platforms remain vulnerable to a broad range of cyberattacks, particularly those aimed at exploiting transactions and smart contracts (SCs) to steal digital assets or compromise system integrity. To address this issue, we propose a novel and effective framework for detecting cyberattacks within blockchain systems. Our framework begins with a preprocessing tool that uses Natural Language Processing (NLP) techniques to transform key features of blockchain transactions into image representations. These images are then analyzed through vision-based analysis using Vision Transformers (ViT), a recent advancement in computer vision known for its superior ability to capture complex patterns and semantic relationships. By integrating NLP-based preprocessing with vision-based learning, our framework can detect a wide variety of attack types. Experimental evaluations on benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach significantly outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods in terms of both accuracy (achieving 99.5%) and robustness in cyberattack detection for blockchain transactions and SCs.

title: Home Compatible Labs Concept in Erasmus+ Conn’Cor Project
authors: Emilie Avignon-Meseldzija, Philippe Benabes, Hanane Meliani, Jaroslaw Makal, Jaroslaw Forenc, Iryna Moroz, Dejan N. Milic, Jelena A. Anastasov, Goran T. Djordjevic
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Technologies, Systems and Services in Telecommunications (TELSIKS)
abstract: This paper describes and discusses the concept of home-compatible lab exercises that are designed so that students of electrical engineering can do them on their own, at the leisure of their homes. The requirements for these labs are different than for the classical sets of lab exercises that are conducted in the laboratory environment. On the other hand, the labs have advantages over the remotely run lab exercises, and are more useful for the students, in comparison. A set of lab exercises has been developed within the framework of Erasmus+ Conn’Cor project, and evaluated by each of the partner institutions. The feedback received shows that the concept is a promising one, being embraced in special circumstances, but also as the general concept for specific courses.

title: Modulated MPC With Current Injection for Voltage Stabilization in Low-Capacitance DC Links
authors: Omar Nasser, Mostafa Bedir, Abdelmomen Mahgoub, Mohamed Rabah
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Power Electronics and Renewable Energy (CPERE)
abstract: In modern electric drive systems, reducing the size of the DC-link capacitor enhances reliability and enables the use of long-life film capacitors. However, this downsizing leads to voltage instability due to the negative incremental impedance introduced by constant power loads. This paper proposes a voltage stabilization method for low-capacitance DC-link systems using Modulated Model Predictive Control (M2PC) integrated with current injection-based active damping. The control scheme incorporates a discrete-time prediction model for the DC-link voltage and compensates predicted voltage deviations by dynamically modifying the current reference. Compared to conventional PI-based current injection methods, the proposed approach offers superior damping performance and reduced voltage ripple. Simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness of the M2PC architecture in improving stability and dynamic performance in low-capacitance drive applications.

title: Application of Asymmetrical Waffle Iron Filters in Dielectric Resonator Filter to Resolve Technological Issues at Higher Microwave and Millimeter Wave Frequencies
authors: Boro M. Reljic, Slobodan M. Simic, Aleksa J. Zejak, Zoran Golubicic
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Technologies, Systems and Services in Telecommunications (TELSIKS)
abstract: The paper demonstrates an idea and performances of a novel solution introduced to resolve technological issues that are particularly important at higher microwave and millimeter wave frequencies. The concept presented here combines two filter technologies in a single composite filter - these are dielectric resonator filter technology and asymmetrical waffle iron technology. Dielectric resonator filter technology is used to realize the main bandpass filter response at millimeter frequencies while asymmetrical waffle iron technology is used to confine electromagnetic waves within cavities but without any conductive (i.e. “low ohmic”) and mechanical contacts between functional filter parts which is commonly required in classical solutions.

title: Enhancing Short-Term Electricity Load Prediction via CNN-BiGRU and Autoformer Integration
authors: Ruijun Tie, Ming Li, Nanwei Ding, Cong Zhou
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: Against the backdrop of the global energy transition, short-term electricity load forecasting plays a critical role in intelligent power grid dispatch. To address the limitations of existing models in capturing local features and modeling bidirectional temporal dependencies, this paper proposes a hybrid model integrating CNN, BiGRU, and Autoformer. The front-end CNN-BiGRU module extracts local fluctuation features and bidirectional temporal dependencies, while the back-end Autoformer architecture captures long-term periodic patterns. Experiments conducted on a high-resolution dataset of power load and multiple meteorological factors from Chongqing demonstrate that the proposed model significantly outperforms the original Autoformer and its variants such as CNN-Autoformer and BiGRU-Autoformer across Mean Squared Error (MSE), Mean Absolute Error (MAE), and Mean Absolute Percentage Error (MAPE) metrics in a 48-step forecasting task. The study validates the effectiveness of the framework in modeling complex temporal dependencies, providing an improved solution for short-term load forecasting in power systems.

title: Study on Loading Method for Bench Testing of Wheeled Vehicle Transmission Systems
authors: Ximing Zhang, Yi Xu, Jinle Zhang, Mingcheng Wang, Qingfeng Wang, Liye Xie
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: To ensure that bench tests for wheeled vehicle transmission systems better reflect real-world operating conditions, this study proposes a bench test method for transmission system that is equivalent to actual vehicle load conditions. Focusing on a specific type of wheeled vehicle operating in six typical regional environments-cold regions, hot and humid climates, gravel roads, plateau areas, undulating terrain, and paved roads-the study conducts a statistical analysis of the distribution of gear position, speed, and torque load under these operating conditions. The one-dimensional distributions of gear position, speed with driving time, as well as the two-dimensional distributions of speed-torque with driving time, are obtained. Taking the gearbox gears-critical components of the transmission system-as the research subject, the accumulated fatigue damage under these six operational scenarios is analysed based on the rotating rainflow counting method. Furthermore, by observing the speed-torque distribution characteristics observed in actual vehicle tests and adopting the principle of damage equivalence between bench tests and field conditions, a set of bench test loading conditions for the transmission system is derived. This provides essential technical support for the reliability testing of wheeled vehicle transmission systems under bench conditions.

title: Intelligent Fault Diagnosis for Train Bogie Based on Multi-Scale Residual Attention
authors: Shengkai Mei, Xing’Ang Xu, Hongliang Qian
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: As the key bearing part of the train, the health state of the high-speed train bogie is directly related to the traffic safety. In order to deal with the problems of relying on manual experience and insufficient accuracy in previous methods, this paper proposes a bogie fault diagnosis model (MSRA-Net) combining multi-scale convolution, residual connection and channel attention mechanism. Therein, multi-scale convolution is used to extract features at different time scales, the channel attention mechanism (SE Attention) is used to enhance the fault feature expression, and cross-scale feature fusion is used to realize multi-scale information fusion. An actual case of train bogie bearing shows that the proposed method achieves accurate identification on four types of typical faults, and the recognition effect on small sample data sets is significantly better than that of traditional methods.

title: A Stochastic Model for the Bike-sharing Repositioning Problem
authors: Clement Mabileau, Leïla Horchani
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: Bike Sharing Systems (BSS) offer a sustainable and flexible solution to urban mobility, but their rapid growth as a viable and popular transportation alternative has exposed major challenges. Due to asymmetric user flows throughout the day they suffer from chronic imbalances in bike distribution, badly impacting both the system reliability and user satisfaction. In this paper, we address this issue with an optimized repositioning strategy that lowers environmental impact while improving operational efficiency and user satisfaction. After a data analysis phase, we present in detail a stochastic bike-sharing repositioning model that explicitly incorporates uncertainty on bike-demand prediction at each station, thereby improving the robustness of decision-making and the overall reliability of the system. To find the global optimum we then decompose the stochastic model into two manageable sub-problems and iteratively solve them to optimality with exact methods. We finally validates both our mathematical model and our algorithm by solving a synthetic instance, showing the potential of our method.

title: Revealing Hidden Dynamics: The Caputo Derivative’s Influence on Vesicle Behavior
authors: Hamza Azroul, Abdelkrim Barbara, Ghizlane Diki
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: This study explores the deformation of vesicles in a shear flow using fractional calculus, with a particular focus on the Caputo derivative. The motivation stems from the need to better understand memory effects in soft matter dynamics and to improve the modeling of time-dependent fluid–structure interactions. In earlier work, we used the Jumarie fractional derivative to derive exact analytical solutions. Here, we advance this investigation by employing the Caputo derivative, known for its suitability in modeling physical systems with initial conditions expressed in classical terms. Through numerical simulations, we perform a comparative analysis between the Caputo-based results and those obtained via the Jumarie framework. This comparison reveals both shared patterns and distinctive features, underscoring the sensitivity of vesicle dynamics to the choice of fractional operator. The novelty of our work lies in bridging the gap between two formulations of fractional derivatives, highlighting the Caputo operator’s capacity to capture memory-driven behaviors more realistically. Our findings contribute to a deeper understanding of vesicle mechanics in fluid environments and offer valuable insights for applications in biological physics, such as drug delivery systems and artificial cell modeling.

title: Data-Driven Voltage Stability Margin Search: Neural Network Criterion and Particle Swarm Cooperative Optimization
authors: Hongyue Zhen, Shiyang Li, Yun Yu, Xuexia Quan, Siting Zhu, Chao Fu, Kequan Lin
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: With the increasing integration of renewable energy sources and deep penetration of power electronic devices, modern power systems are facing increasingly complex operational conditions. Conventional mechanism-based voltage stability assessment methods suffer from low computational efficiency and insufficient adaptability, while purely data-driven approaches exhibit poor interpretability and low trustworthiness among operators. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a collaborative voltage stability assessment framework that synergizes data-driven techniques with intelligent optimization, integrating deep interpretable networks with an improved particle swarm algorithm to achieve high-accuracy stability discrimination and efficient margin calculation. First, we design a dual-branch decoupled deep neural network architecture that leverages value-advantage branches to separately capture global stability and local critical features, while incorporating physical constraints from the Jacobian matrix to enhance critical state identification. Second, an improved particle swarm optimization algorithm (DNN-PSO) is proposed, utilizing neural network gradient information to guide particle swarm search for fast and precise localization of stability boundaries. Finally, simulation results on the IEEE 39-bus system demonstrate that the proposed method achieves 100% stability discrimination accuracy and completes margin assessments within 0.205 seconds.

title: Review for "Strip-ViTAE: A Direction-Aware Transformer with Enhanced Feature Modeling for Remote Sensing Image Object Detection"
authors: N/A
publish: N/A

title: Quantifying Network Dissimilarity via Augmented Networks_supp1-3634079.pdf
authors: Pei Wang
publish: N/A
abstract: Quantifying structural dissimilarities between networks is a fundamental challenge. This paper introduces a novel measure, D*, that quantifies network dissimilarity by analyzing their augmented networks. The augmented network is constructed by adding a virtual leader node that is bidirectionally connected to all other nodes. D* relies on the node distance distributions of the augmented networks, which are essentially determined by the original networks' degree distributions and sizes. This characteristic makes it a simple and robust measure, insensitive to weighting parameters, and applicable to a wide range of networks–including regular networks and networks of any size, even those containing isolated nodes. D* actually utilizes the second-order truncated shortest-path distance matrix and demonstrates superior performance compared to higher order truncations. Numerical simulations show that D* accu rately quantifies structural differences between networks while overcoming the saturation growth effect induced by increasing edge connection probabilities in random networks. The versatility of D* is further demonstrated by applying it to four distinct scenarios. Specifically, D* is effective in determining optimal correlation cutoff thresholds when constructing bio-molecular co-expression networks, in identifying disease modules in gene disease and phenotype-disease networks, in performing clustering and layer aggregation for multilayer networks, and in distin guishing networks of different categories. Our findings enhance understanding of the construction and comparison of complex network structures.

title: Longitudinal and Lateral Synthesize Tracking Strategy for Connected Vehicle Platoon with Cyber Attacks
authors: Jianchuan Wang, Meng Li, Meng Zhang, Yong Chen, Haiyu Song
publish: IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology
abstract: In this paper, the problem of tracking control for connected vehicle platoon with cyber-attacks and time delays is developed, a longitudinal and lateral synthesize tracking strategy is proposed. Firstly, a leader-follower connected vehicle platoon spacing model is established. Then, an adaptive Kalman filter-based observer is presented to enhance control robustness under cyber-attacks by dynamically adjusting sensor weights and predicted values. Furthermore, a sliding window-based adaptive observer is introduced to mitigate vehicle-to-vehicle time delays. Additionally, a longitudinal distributed adaptive backstepping control algorithm and a lateral distributed nonlinear model prediction control algorithm are respectively designed to achieve cooperative platoon control. Finally, experimental results show the stable path tracking, and resilience to cyber-attacks during medium-low speed lane changes.

title: A Flexible Dual-Mode and Efficient RISC-V Coprocessor for On-Node FFT Acceleration in Edge Sensing
authors: Panpei Cao, Han Wang, Hen Cao, Zhipeng Wu, Yu Liu
publish: IEEE Embedded Systems Letters
abstract: Real-time spectral analysis of sensor data is critical for applications, such as wearable health monitoring and structural vibration analysis, but performing Fast Fourier Transforms (FFTs) on resource-constrained sensor nodes is a major challenge. This letter introduces a point-configurable FFT coprocessor, built on the RISC-V ISA, to facilitate efficient on-chip signal processing. Leveraging a mixed-radix algorithm and a dedicated custom instruction set, our architecture features a high-throughput Batch Mode and a low-latency Incremental Mode. Implemented on an FPGA, our design achieves a speedup of up to 109× (Batch Mode) and 7.06× (Incremental Mode) compared to a software-only implementation. This work presents a practical and balanced solution for FFT acceleration using RISC-V and a coprocessor, enabling the direct analysis of complex sensor data at the edge of sensing, thereby reducing data transmission costs and system latency.

title: Large-Signal Stability Analysis of Power Amplifiers Under Mismatch Conditions Based on Structured Singular Values Computation
authors: Aimar Mateo-Goni, Ibone Lizarraga, Aitziber Anakabe, Juan-Mari Collantes
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: There is a growing interest in assessing the stability of power amplifiers (PAs) under output mismatch conditions in large-signal regimes. This interest is driven by applications where output isolators are omitted to reduce system complexity and weight, such as in active phased-array antenna systems. Existing methods that extend <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$K$</tex-math> </inline-formula>-based or <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mu $</tex-math> </inline-formula>-based stability criteria to large-signal operation are typically limited to considering mismatch at no more than three-sideband frequencies, which restricts their applicability for more general scenarios. In this article, an efficient criterion is proposed to assess the unconditional stability of PAs under large-signal operation, enabling the consideration of mismatch effects at an arbitrary number of sideband frequencies. The method relies on the computation of the structured singular value of a scattering-type matrix defined with virtual ports at the relevant sideband frequencies. The proposed methodology is illustrated with an amplifier prototype specifically designed to highlight the impact of sideband mismatch on circuit stability. Its validity is confirmed through comparison with independent stability analysis techniques. Finally, experimental verification is performed on the fabricated prototype using a dedicated setup capable of synthesizing different load impedance profiles.
