title: Neural Representation for Wireless Radiation Field Reconstruction: A 3D Gaussian Splatting Approach
authors: Chaozheng Wen, Jingwen Tong, Yingdong Hu, Zehong Lin, Jun Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications
abstract: Wireless channel modeling plays a pivotal role in designing, analyzing, and optimizing wireless communication systems. Nevertheless, developing an effective channel modeling approach has been a long-standing challenge. This issue has been escalated due to denser network deployment, larger antenna arrays, and broader bandwidth in next-generation networks. To address this challenge, we put forth WRF-GS, a novel framework for channel modeling based on wireless radiation field (WRF) reconstruction using 3D Gaussian splatting (3D-GS). WRF-GS employs 3D Gaussian primitives and neural networks to capture the interactions between the environment and radio signals, enabling efficient WRF reconstruction and visualization of the propagation characteristics. The reconstructed WRF can then be used to synthesize the spatial spectrum for comprehensive wireless channel characterization. While WRF-GS demonstrates remarkable effectiveness, it faces limitations in capturing high-frequency signal variations caused by complex multipath effects. To overcome these limitations, we propose WRF-GS+, an enhanced framework that integrates electromagnetic wave physics into the neural network design. WRF-GS+ leverages deformable 3D Gaussians to model both static and dynamic components of the WRF, significantly improving its ability to characterize signal variations. In addition, WRF-GS+ accelerates the splatting process by simplifying the 3D-GS modeling operation and reducing sample complexity. Experimental results demonstrate that both WRF-GS and WRF-GS+ outperform baselines for spatial spectrum synthesis, including ray tracing and other deep-learning approaches. Notably, WRF-GS+ achieves state-of-the-art performance in the received signal strength indication (RSSI) and channel state information (CSI) prediction tasks, surpassing existing methods by more than 0.7 dB and 3.36 dB, respectively. The code is available at https://github.com/wenchaozheng/WRF-GSplus.

title: The Impact of E-learning Ability on Students’ Academic Performance: using Regression Analysis
authors: Bing Yu, Jing Gong, Yumei Shan
publish: IEEE Revista Iberoamericana de Tecnologias del Aprendizaje
abstract: In this paper, the E-learning ability (learners’ ability to efficiently utilize digital tools and resources) and academic performance of university students were investigated by means of a questionnaire survey. The E-learning ability was considered from five aspects, including conscious ability. A total of 689 questionnaires were distributed, and 646 questionnaires were recycled. The rationality of the questionnaire was verified by project analysis. According to the collected data, the differences in different aspects of E-learning ability and academic performance in terms of gender, age, and major were analyzed. The results showed that both the overall E-learning ability and academic performance of university students need to be improved. In terms of gender, only the technical ability had a significant difference (t = 3.947, p = 0.000). In terms of grade, there were significant differences in management ability, evaluation ability, and academic performance (p < 0.01). In terms of major, the E-learning ability and academic performance had significant differences (p < 0.01). The influence of E-learning ability on students’ academic performance was analyzed by regression analysis, and it was found that conscious, technical, and management abilities had positive predictive effects on academic performance. The results verify that E-learning ability has a positive impact on students’ academic performance, and university students should pay attention to improving E-learning ability.

title: D-DOSA:DPU-Based Dataflow Offloading and Sparse Allreduce Framework for Distributed Training
authors: Zhenqi Yu, Wenjing Li, Shaoyong Guo, Qingfeng Li, Feng Qi, Jiapeng Xiu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Cloud Computing
abstract: Communication overhead represents a primary bottleneck in distributed deep learning, impeding training scalability. Although existing gradient sparsification techniques reduce network traffic, they introduce critical limitations: they fail to optimize intra-node data paths and are incompatible with efficient, decentralized Allreduce operations. To address these issues, we propose D-DOSA, a DPU-based communication offloading framework. D-DOSA incorporates two key innovations: 1) D-DO, an architecture that establishes a direct GPU-DPU data path to offload data loading and intra-node communication from the host CPU; and 2) D-SA, a novel sparse Allreduce algorithm that, for the first time, enables compatibility between sparse tensors and high-performance, ring-based communication. We evaluated D-DOSA on a 8-node, DPU-enabled cluster using representative models including VGG, LSTM, and BERT. Experimental results demonstrate that our framework accelerates training by up to 1.32x compared to the state-of-the-art sparse training baseline, without compromising accuracy. Ultimately, D-DOSA shows that co-designing data-flow architectures and communication algorithms on the DPU resolves key bottlenecks in sparse training and presents a viable path toward scalable performance in larger systems.

title: Predictor Feedback Control of Discrete-Time Systems With Multiple State Delays and Distinct Input Delays
authors: Ai-Guo Wu, Shi-Long Shen, Jie Zhang, Jie Mei
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems I: Regular Papers
abstract: Predictor feedback control of discrete-time systems with multiple state delays and distinct input delays is investigated in this paper. At first, a prediction scheme for the considered system is developed step by step. Then, a predictor-based state feedback law is designed based on this prediction scheme. In addition, the property of the closed-loop system under the designed control law is analyzed. When the system state is unavailable for feedback, a full-order state observer is designed such that the current state can be estimated. With this estimated state, the stabilization for this class of time delay systems can also be achieved under the designed observer-based predictor feedback control law.

title: Strategic Patenting and Technological Evolution in Energy Utilization and Recovery_supp1-3633877.docx
authors: Entong Gao
publish: N/A
abstract: This study investigates the strategic evolution of patent technologies in energy utilization and recovery, focusing on current technological landscapes and predicting patent development trends. We identify key insights into the sector's growth and future potential by analyzing 30,196 patents from the Google Patents database (2008-2023) and applying machine learning techniques. Patents were retrieved using International Patent Classification (IPC) codes specific to energy utilization and recovery, then de-duplicated and screened by the main patent office. Patent quality was estimated by backward-citation impact. The findings show that the energy recovery field is expanding, with a lifecycle coefficient expected to reach maturity by 2025. Additionally, the results indicate that technological development accelerated after the 2015 Paris Agreement, peaking in 2016 and 2020. However, notable disparities exist across technological subfields, with uneven distribution, highlighting the need for increased collaboration and cross-disciplinary innovation. The “drum-type steam boilers” sector emerges as a key area for future growth, with high potential for cross-technology applications, but receives disproportionately low funding. A Convolutional Neural Network model trained with the Adam optimizer achieved 73.6% accuracy in predicting patent citation trends, demonstrating the effectiveness of machine learning in identifying high-quality patents and automating large-scale quality assessments. Furthermore, increasing patent citations and diversifying patent categories significantly enhance patent quality, with collaboration among patent teams playing a critical role in advancing cross-technology fields. These findings help optimize technological strategies, identify innovation gaps, and develop models for high-quality patent identification in energy utilization and recovery.

title: Explainable End-to-End Seizure Prediction via Stationary Wavelet Transform-Driven Dynamic Multiscale Fuzzy Clustering
authors: Jie Wang, Yingchao Wang, Weiwei Nie, Qi Yuan
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Epileptic seizure prediction holds critical clinical significance for enhancing the quality of life in patients. Despite technological advances, existing approaches face persistent challenges arising from inter-subject variability in electroencephalogram (EEG) dynamics and the complex spatiotemporal coupling associated with ictal transitions. These issues compromise both feature discriminability and model explainability. To address these dual limitations, we propose a novel stationary wavelet transform (SWT)-driven dynamic multiscale fuzzy clustering (SD-MFC) framework, an explainable prediction pipeline that integrates EEG signal analysis with transparent clinical decision-making. Methodologically, the spectral-temporal decomposition of EEG signals via SWT is combined with a geometric attention mechanism to model cross-channel dependencies. To capture the dynamic nature of EEG signals, we develop a Riemannian manifold-based fuzzy clustering algorithm through covariance matrix optimization and time-variant manifold metrics. Hierarchical feature fusion is achieved through multiscale convolutional kernels within a three-layer convolutional network. Model training incorporates contrastive learning with a hybrid supervised/self-supervised strategy to enhance robustness. Notably, two explainability methods: a joint feature visualization strategy and an efficient feature ablation study, are proposed to bridge the adaptation gap between the “black-box” nature of deep learning models and the requirements of clinical diagnostic. Experimental results on both intracranial and extracranial datasets demonstrate that SD-MFC framework not only exhibits superior predictive performance but also maintains a low FPR, offering a feasible scheme for clinical application of EEG-based seizure prediction. The code has been available at https://github.com/JW-Image/SD-MFC.

title: GPT Agent-Supported Edge Intelligence for Optimizing D2D Communications
authors: Zheng Yang, Jie Zeng, Wei Feng, Ni Wei, Jianping An
publish: IEEE Wireless Communications Letters
abstract: The sixth-generation (6G) network integrates communication, sensing, and computation into a synergetic system. Device-to-device (D2D) communication has also received widespread attention, and to improve the performance of D2D communications with limited network edge resources, we propose the use of the generative pretrained transformer (GPT) agent. Specifically, we use GPT to achieve resource-optimized quality of service (QoS) and energy consumption, forming the QoS-CNNGPT method. The simulation results show that the proposed system can support multiple edge users with a 28.7% improvement in spectral efficiency compared with the weighted minimum mean square error (WMMSE) method and a 79.8% reduction in computation time compared with the overhead of reinforcement learning (RL)-based techniques. The proposed system can also meet the deployment and individualization requirements of different users in resource-limited D2D systems with strong robustness, which will help improve 6G networks.

title: Channel Prediction in the Time-Frequency-Angle Domain
authors: Yihao Liu, Zhiyong Luo
publish: IEEE Wireless Communications Letters
abstract: In wireless communication systems, the acquisition of channel state information (CSI) is crucial. To reduce the communication resources overhead, channel prediction techniques are widely used in multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) systems. However, most of the existing channel prediction methods predict future CSI based on the time-space domain channel matrix, which is susceptible to multipath and Doppler shift. In this letter, we propose a pre-processing method for the time-space domain channel matrix. Through a two-step transformation, we transform the channel to the time-frequency-angle domain. Then, we theoretically prove the resilience of the time-frequency-angle channel matrix to multipath and Doppler shift. The simulation results show that without changing the existing neural network architecture, the accuracy of channel prediction can be improved by using the proposed pre-processing method, and the proposed method is generalizable to different neural networks and different antenna configurations.

title: Federated Learning for Phishing Detection and Protection in Wearable Health Networks
authors: Mosiur Rahaman, Kartik Vanna, Akshat Gaurav, Sunneng Sandino Berutu, Nadia Nedjah, Kwok Tai Chui, Brij B Gupta
publish: 2025 24th International Symposium on Communications and Information Technologies (ISCIT)
abstract: The security and privacy of users of Wearable Health Networks (WHNs) are under threat by phishing attacks because of the continuous transmission of sensitive health data in the environment of interconnected mobile and wearable devices. The obvious disadvantage is that the centralized detection methods used to identify phishing, which is common, are not compatible with such environments because of the danger of data aggregation and privacy leakage. The present paper has developed a Federated Learning (FL)-based privacy-preserving phishing detection framework adequately adapted to WHNs. The framework allows the machine learning models to be trained in a distributed fashion on wearable devices and does not require sending the raw data to a central server. The experiments were performed by applying Logistic Regression and Random Forest models in both federated and centralized. As results indicate, federated Random Forest model accuracy was 86.35%, which was very close to the centralized model which was 86.77, yet it maintained data privacy. Also, the federated Logistic Regression model also exhibited stability in performance throughout the rounds, proving that FL is a viable solution to lightweight wearable devices. The study points out that FL is both viable and effective to use on phishing detection of WHNs that provides excellent trade-off of vital aspects of privacy, scalability, and detection performance.

title: Cf-Yolo: Cross-Modal Fusion for Weakly Aligned Rgb-Ir Uav Object Detection
authors: Thi Lan Nguyen, Cao Truong Tran, Hai Van Nguyen Thi
publish: 2025 24th International Symposium on Communications and Information Technologies (ISCIT)
abstract: Multispectral object detection using RGB and infrared (IR) imagery captured by unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) has become increasingly important for surveillance and rescue missions under challenging lighting conditions. However, effective fusion of RGB and IR features remains a significant challenge due to weak spatial alignment-a common issue resulting from independent sensor placement, geometric misalignment caused by UAV motion, and imperfect temporal synchronization between modalities. To address this problem, we propose CFYOLO, a cross-modal fusion framework specifically designed for object detection in weakly aligned RGB-IR UAV imagery. CFYOLO employs a dual-stream backbone based on the YOLO architecture to extract modality-specific features and introduces an effective Cross-Modal Fusion (CMF) module that selectively aggregates complementary information through spatialand channel-wise attention mechanisms. This design enhances robustness to alignment issues while maintaining computational efficiency. Extensive experiments on the DroneVehicle dataset demonstrate that CF-YOLO achieves strong detection performance (82.3 % mAP@ 50), outperforming both unimodal and existing fusion-based methods. These results validate the effectiveness of our attention-guided fusion strategy in real-world UAV scenarios where weak alignment is prevalent.

title: Poverty and Inequalities in Mauritania : Regional Raning Using the Fyzzy TOPSIS Method
authors: Revie Jedou, Driss Gretete
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: This article applies the Fuzzy TOPSIS method (Technique for Order Préférence by Similarity to Ideal Solution) to rank the 13 wilayas (administrative region) of Mauritania using official data on poverty and inequalities. Following fuzzy normalization and weighting via the Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP), Manhattan distances are employed to rank regions based on their proximity to ideal solutions.The results reveal that the regions of Guidimaha, Tagant, and Assaba exhibit closeness scores below 0.3. These areas face compound challenges including recurrent droughts, limited infrastructure, and economic isolation. Their geographical remoteness restricts access to markets and public services, exacerbating multinational poverty cycles and hindering human development progress. Indicating urgent need for targeted policy interventions to address territorial disparities.

title: Restoring Weather-Degraded Vision with Dual-Decomposed Multi-Scale Parallel Transformer
authors: Lulu Xu, Tao Gao, Yuanbo Wen, Ting Chen, Yuxiu Chen, Peng Zhao
publish: 2024 5th China International SAR Symposium (CISS)
abstract: Existing approaches for all-in-one weather removal often suffer from compromised image fidelity and prolonged inference durations. To this end, we introduce a dual-decomposed multi-scale parallel Transformer (DMPFormer) for restoring vision degraded by adverse weather conditions. Specifically, we develop a domain-decomposed feature enhancement mechanism (DFEM) to address issues arising from the self-attention mechanism in modeling high-frequency dependencies. DFEM decomposes features into spatial, wavelet and frequency domains, enabling more targeted and accurate feature learning. Meanwhile, we present a dimension-decomposed latent feature interaction module (DLFIM), which segregates features along height, width and channel dimensions, thereby optimizing feature fusion with multi-dimension mutual attention and adaptive determining weights. Besides, we propose a cross-scale implicit neural representation (CINR) for obtaining standardized representations of various degradations, which can adjustably provide visual prompts for subsequent reconstruction. Furthermore, we curate a comprehensive dataset containing diverse traffic weather-degraded image pairs. Extensive experiments demonstrate the superiority of our proposed model over existing approaches in both single and adverse weather removal.

title: A Novel ASCON ECB with 64-Bit Block Size for Energy-Harvesting Beat Sensors
authors: Anh-Duc Mai, Xuan-Tu Tran, Duy-Hieu Bui, Koichiro Ishibashi
publish: 2025 24th International Symposium on Communications and Information Technologies (ISCIT)
abstract: With the rapid growth of Internet of Things (IoT) devices, particularly energy-harvesting sensors, ensuring data security while conserving power has become a critical challenge. Traditional encryption techniques often demand excessive energy, making them unsuitable for ultra-low-power devices. In this paper, we introduce a novel ASCON-based encryption scheme utilizing ECB mode, designed explicitly for Energy-Harvesting Beat Sensors that require minimal energy consumption. Our approach optimizes encryption efficiency, significantly reduces computational overhead, and enables secure communication within highly energy-constrained IoT environments.

title: Capacitive Wireless Power Transfer to Multiple Loads Using Repeaters
authors: Hamed Farbakhsh, Arthur Cloet, Michael Kleemann, Ben Minnaert
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Power Electronics and Renewable Energy (CPERE)
abstract: Capacitive wireless power transfer has emerged as a promising technology for various applications. In scenarios such as wireless sensor networks, transferring power to multiple loads over varying distances is often required. This paper introduces an interesting approach with repeaters to deliver equal power to multiple loads across different distances, where the repeater functions both as a power relay and receiver. A comprehensive mathematical model is developed to analyze the power transfer mechanism, incorporating four critical factors: source matching factor, load matching factor, transfer quality factor, and reflected admittance factor. The conditions for achieving uniform power delivery to all loads connected via the repeater are explored. Theoretical calculations and simulations with a single repeater validate the proposed model and its analysis.

title: Analysis of Naive Bayes and Support Vector Machine to Classify Thesis Based on Sustainable Development Goals
authors: Gloria Natasya Irene Sidebang, Putu Harry Gunawan, Suryo Adhi Wibowo
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Information Technology, Computer, and Electrical Engineering (ICITACEE)
abstract: Automated multilabel classification of large academic repositories presents a significant technical challenge, as scholarly works often align with multiple thematic categories. This study investigates this problem by evaluating Naïve Bayes and Support Vector Machine (SVM) models for categorizing <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 5, 3 0 9}$</tex> thesis abstracts from Telkom University (2020-2023) into the Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) framework. Three multilabel transformation methods (One-vs-Rest, Classifier Chain, and Label Powerset) and two word embedding techniques (FastText and Word2Vec) were systematically compared. The optimal configuration was found to be SVM combined with Word2Vec and the Label Powerset method, which achieved 93.94 % accuracy, 74.09 % precision, and a 47.28 % F1-score. Although Naive Bayes yielded lower precision, it offered superior consistency in label set prediction, evidenced by higher match ratios. The results confirm the viability of machine learning for automated SDG mapping, providing institutions with a scalable tool to enhance sustainability reporting and research visibility. Future work will explore deep learning architectures and explainable AI to further improve classification performance and interpretability.

title: Multi-Region Energy System Coordination Optimization Considering Rural Scenarios
authors: Weikang Lei, Yingjie Sun, Lixiang Ren, Tianci Ye
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: Rural areas serve as key drivers for achieving green energy transition and advancing rural revitalization, making them ideal pilot sites for constructing distributed low-carbon integrated energy networks. Current research primarily focuses on single-scenario optimization of integrated energy systems, neglecting the actual energy demands of rural areas and inter-regional energy interactions. To address this, this paper establishes three typical rural scenarios—agricultural production zones, livestock farming zones, and tourism zones—and develops a coordinated optimal dispatch model for multi-regional energy systems. The model enables optimized scheduling of electricity, gas, heat, and cooling energy while leveraging the distinct energy advantages of each scenario. Results demonstrate that without coordinated optimization, the total operating cost reaches 104.755 million yuan with pollutant emissions of 38,091 tons. In contrast, coordinated optimization reduces the total operating cost to 86.21 million yuan and cuts emissions to 30,515 tons. These findings highlight that incorporating rural scenarios and harnessing their energy synergies significantly lowers system-wide costs and environmental impacts.

title: Low Speed High Torque Motor Low Speed Stability Test System
authors: Rui Tong, Xingke Li
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: Based on the LabVIEW software development platform, a set of low-speed and high-torque motor test system is designed according to the relevant national standards and user standards for motor low-speed stability test. This paper mainly introduces the development of hydraulic system, electrical system and test software for the curve test of motor high pressure port pressure, motor speed and motor output torque [1]. By analyzing the influence of different pressures and different speeds on the experiment, the changes of the experimental curves under different working conditions are compared. At the same time, the experimental results of the user 's products and the international top products are compared to provide optimization ideas for the user 's products, and the hydraulic model is modeled and simulated. The motion characteristics of the roller of the plunger motor are analyzed, including the influence of the roller motion law on the torque and the simulation results of the motor internal curve are compared with the actual experiment.

title: Long-Term Traffic Forecasting With the Informer Model: Insights From Taiwan's Section
authors: Kuan-Ting Wu, Shinfeng Lin
publish: 2025 24th International Symposium on Communications and Information Technologies (ISCIT)
abstract: This study develops an innovative traffic forecasting framework for Taiwan's highways, utilizing the Informer model, a Transformer-based architecture designed for long-sequence time-series prediction. The model analyzes high, medium, and low-traffic sections, focusing on long-term patterns to address complex traffic dynamics. By leveraging historical data, it accurately predicts traffic flow and speed, supporting strategic traffic management and decision-making. Experimental results demonstrate high precision and robustness across various scenarios on highways in northern, central, and southern Taiwan, achieving low prediction errors and offering actionable insights for congestion mitigation and resource optimization. This research provides a foundation for integrating intelligent forecasting tools into Taiwan's smart traffic systems.

title: Sliding-Based Surface Material Recognition Using Flexible Magnetic Cilia Sensor for Intelligent Maintenance
authors: Yangqianhui Zhang, Dong Han, Huayong Yang, Qingyuan Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: Intelligent maintenance of equipment requires timely detection of surface condition changes, even when visual inspection is impossible. This paper presents a flexible, bioinspired magnetic tactile sensor system for non-visual surface condition monitoring. The sensor consists of vertically magnetized 3D micro-cilia arrays embedded in an elastomer and underlying Hall effect magnetic sensors. As the cilia slide across a surface, microscopic texture features bend the cilia, producing distinctive magnetic field fluctuations. The low-power sensor is highly flexible and durable, capable of enduring repeated contact. A sliding scan experiment was performed on eight different material surfaces, with multiple trials simulating human-like tactile exploration. The resulting magnetic field time-series were analyzed using a machine learning pipeline. After preprocessing and feature extraction, a supervised classification model was trained to recognize each material. The classifier achieved over 99% accuracy in identifying the surface textures. We further applied explainability techniques, i.e., feature importance analysis and SHAP values, to reveal which signal features differentiate textures. These results demonstrate that the magnetic cilia-based sensor can reliably "feel" and identify surface textures, enabling robust non-visual condition monitoring. This study highlights the potential of bioinspired magnetic tactile sensing for intelligent maintenance applications.

title: HCT-Net: Hybrid CNN-Transformer U-Net for Joint Segmentation of Multiple Retinal Structures
authors: Junxuan Liu
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Complex Medical Engineering (CME)
abstract: Retinal multi-structure segmentation is a critical technique for diagnosing diseases such as diabetic retinopathy. However, existing methods face significant challenges: conventional convolutional neural networks (CNNs) struggle to model long-range vascular dependencies due to limited local receptive fields, while pure Vision Transformers (ViTs) are hindered by high computational costs, limiting their real-time clinical application. To enhance the model’s discriminative capability, this study proposes a hybrid CNN-Transformer U-Net model (HCT-Net), which synergistically integrates CNN’s local feature extraction and Transformer’s global context modeling within a U-Net framework for efficient and accurate retinal multistructure segmentation. Evaluated on the DRIVE and CHASE DB1 datasets using mean Intersection over Union (mIoU), Dice coefficient, and Hausdorff Distance (HD) as metrics, the experimental results demonstrate that HCT-Net achieves superior performance in segmentation consistency of vascular trunks and fine branches, boundary clarity, and enhanced robustness in pathological regions (e.g., exudate interference) compared to existing baseline models. This study provides a novel paradigm balancing precision and efficiency for retinal image segmentation, advancing deployable intelligent ophthalmic systems that may support early detection of vascular abnormalities and assist nonspecialist clinicians in resource-limited settings.

title: AI-Driven Drilling in Mining: Systematic Review of Smart Technologies, Challenges, and Pathways to Sustainable Automation
authors: Abdelmounim Ed-Damnati, Safae Assif, Yasmina Hani, Adiba El Bouzekri El Idrissi
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: Drilling is at the heart of mining, shaping how we extract resources and understand the earth beneath us. As artificial intelligence (AI), machine learning (ML), and automation continue to evolve, they’re opening new possibilities for smarter, safer, and more efficient drilling. This study explores the latest advancements in mining drilling operations, uncovering both challenges and opportunities for innovationBased on the PRISMA model, we reviewed 458 studies articles from Scopus and Web of Science, showing how AI-driven analytics, real-time monitoring, and autonomous drilling technologies are transforming the industry. These innovations aren't only enhancing accuracy and productivity they're leading the way toward more sustainable and intelligent mining techniques. By introducing these cutting-edge solutions into focus, this research offers practical guidance for the future of drilling, ensuring mining operations are more secure, efficient, and aligned with the interests of both the people and the planet.

title: Fault Sample Generation Method for Industrial Processes with a Limited Number of Samples
authors: Jiarula Yasenjiang, Tian Gao, Jintao Xie, Lihua Xu, Pengfei Cui
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: Process industry serves as a pivotal sector in China's national economy and social development. To address the challenges of limited fault samples and difficulties in sample collection in this field, this paper proposes a fault sample generation method for process industries based on Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs). First, the random forest algorithm is employed to analyze fault feature importance. Subsequently, the original adversarial network is optimized by integrating deep convolution and maximum mean discrepancy (MMD). Finally, case validation is conducted using the Tennessee-Eastman simulation dataset and a collected compressor unit dataset. Experimental results demonstrate that the generated samples significantly improve diagnostic accuracy and outperform the original GANs in effectiveness.

title: Investigation of Torque Ripple Reduction in Vehicle Motors through Permanent Magnet Biasing
authors: Aimin Yuan, Wei Cai, Fei Liu, Xu Xiao
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: The continuous performance enhancement of permanent magnet synchronous motors for new energy vehicles has propelled high torque and power density to become predominant developmental trajectories. With increasing torque density requirements, manufacturers and designers increasingly focus on the torque ripple characteristics under peak torque conditions. In this paper, a novel rotor structure with asymmetric permanent magnet is proposed for torque ripple suppression. Through finite element analysis, the suppression effect of the asymmetric permanent magnet topology on the torque ripple is evaluated. Comparative analysis of electromagnetic performance and rotor structural strength demonstrates that the asymmetric permanent magnet effectively reduces motor torque ripple while maintaining torque density.

title: Two-bit Side Channel Attack Resistant Register in 350 nm CMOS Technology
authors: Milena J. Stanojlović Mirković, Dejan D. Mirković, Miljana Lj. Milić
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Technologies, Systems and Services in Telecommunications (TELSIKS)
abstract: This paper describes top down design of a two-bit encrypted register resistant to Side Channel Attack (SCA). As a measure of SCA resistivity a Normalized Standard Deviation (NSD) of the consumed energy is used. The schematic level and post-layout simulation results confirmed NSD $\leq 1 \%$ which ensures solid cryptographic protection. This encrypted block is designed for CMOS TSMC 035 um technology.

title: Dynamic QoS-Based Optimization Algorithms for MEC-Assisted Vehicular Networks
authors: Guo Zhinan, Maryam Cheraghy, Sun Yifei, Zuo Yitang, Zhang Yuyang, Lu Chang, Belal Abuhaija
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Information Technology, Computer, and Electrical Engineering (ICITACEE)
abstract: This study focuses on the optimization problem of task offloading in vehicular networks within a Mobile Edge Computing (MEC) environment. Due to dynamic network conditions and limited computational resources, task allocation presents significant challenges. Our focus lies in using four algorithms to optimize the offloading strategy for resource allocation, thereby comparing their impact on the system's performance and Quality of Service (QoS): Multi-Layer Dynamic Particle Optimization (MLDPO), Greedy Algorithm, Fair Resource Allocation (FRE), and Continuous Whale Optimization Algorithm (WOA). These Algorithms are compared in terms of computing latency, power consumption, and execution time under varying network conditions. In this study, resource allocation refers specifically to the CPU computing capacity at MEC servers, while bandwidth is assumed to be equally shared among all vehicles. Our simulation results show that WOA and FRE significantly outperform other algorithms in terms of QoS, particularly for scenarios with a large number of vehicles, making them suitable for massive connectivity. Notably, WOA and MLDPO exhibit almost similar behavior for lower vehicle numbers, while WOA outperforms FRE at medium vehicle densities. In contrast, the Greedy and FRE algorithms exhibit lower runtime, making them ideal for low-latency applications.

title: Heat exchanger structure Optimization of Vehicle thermoelectric Power Generation System Based on RSM and NSGA-II
authors: Mengyu Wang, Tong Zhang, Wei Wang, Gang Li
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: In recent years, energy shortages have been increasing due to the overuse of fuels. The thermoelectric generator (TEG) system can be used to recycle exhaust gases from driving vehicles. In this study, a novel heat exchanger structure is proposed, which is located in the middle of the whole TEG system, with thermoelectric pieces uniformly distributed on the top and bottom. Based on the developed TEG system, the design parameters (number of ribs located in different regions, distance between ribs and diameter of ribs) and responses (temperature difference at the heat exchanger surface, hot air pressure drop and power generation) were analyzed by the response surface method. Multi-objective optimization of the five design parameters using the Non-dominated Sorting Genetic Algorithm II (NSGA-II) algorithm produces a set of Pareto fronts. The results show that when the number of rib columns is 2, 6, and 7, respectively, the rib column spacing is 55.1 mm, and the rib column diameter is 9.66 mm, the three response variable weight parameters are 0.28, 0.37, and 0.35. Thus, resulting in the optimal TEG system with a heat exchanger temperature difference of 27 K, the pressure drop is 1069.14 Pa, and the power generation is 88.26 W.

title: A Multimodal Depression Diagnosis Model Inspired by Traditional Chinese Medicine’s Observation and Inquiry
authors: Haijun Che, Lu Xiao, Enhao Gu, Xinqi Fan, Shiguang Ni
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Complex Medical Engineering (CME)
abstract: The diagnosis of major depressive disorder (MDD) remains a significant challenge in the field of medicine. However, current diagnostic methods primarily rely on clinical diagnosis by physicians and scale scoring, which are subject to high levels of subjectivity, high costs, and high rates of misdiagnosis. To address these issues, this study draws inspiration from traditional Chinese medicine’s “observation, auscultation and olfaction, inquiry, and pulse” principles to propose a multimodal MDD diagnostic model combining ‘observation’ (facial data) with “inquiry” (PHQ-9 questionnaire data). In this study, facial data features were extracted using DeepFace to train the Facial expert; PHQ-9 questionnaire data were used to train the Scale expert; facial data features and questionnaire data features were fused to train the Concatenation expert; and the Facial expert, Scale expert, and Concatenation expert were combined to train the Meta expert. The training results of the four experts were then trained using the Cooperation of Experts (CoE) framework to ultimately construct the Fusion expert. The results showed that the Fusion expert model had a Log Loss value of 0.0529 and an MDD diagnostic accuracy rate of 100%, indicating that the Fusion expert model significantly outperformed traditional diagnostic methods. This study provides novel insights and methods for the precise diagnosis of depression, demonstrating that the integration of traditional Chinese medicine and multimodal data holds promise for improving the accuracy of MDD auxiliary diagnosis.

title: Predicting industrial accident causes from text descriptions: a Machine Learning-Based approach
authors: Kawtar Benderouach, Idriss Bennis, Khalifa Mansouri, Ali Siadat
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: Automatic identification of accident causes from textual reports is a major challenge for improving risk management in industrial systems. This article proposes an approach based on automatic natural language processing (ANLP) and machine learning to predict accident causes from textual descriptions. A database of real accident reports was used, containing textual summaries (SummaryCase) and their associated causes (Cause). After text pre-processing including cleaning, tokenization and vectorization (TF-IDF and Bag of Words), several supervised learning models were tested, including random forests (RF), logistic regression (LR), support vector machines (SVM), Decision tree (DT), Naive Bayes (NB) as well as XGBoost (Extreme Gradient Boosting). The performance of the model was examined in terms of the accuracy, precision, recall and F1-score. As a result those work demonstrate that an XGBoost combining with SMOTE (Synthetic Minority Over-Sampling Technique) are more effective when compared to traditional models especially in the situation of long and complex text description. The results of this study have proved the effectiveness of the application of machine learning techniques to the proactive analysis of accident causes and are expected to contribute to the adaptation of these approaches into the realm of industrial risk management systems.

title: Digital Twin-Driven Framework for Dynamic Modeling and Signal Generation for Rolling Bearing Fault Diagnosis
authors: Yulu Zhang, Juanjuan Shi, Changqing Shen, Zhongkui Zhu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: As a critical load-bearing component of railway vehicles, the performance of rolling bearings directly affects the operational safety and reliability of trains. To meet the requirements of health monitoring and fault diagnosis for rolling bearings, a digital twin-driven dynamic modeling and signal generation framework is proposed. This framework introduces a 4 degrees-of-freedom dynamic model of rolling bearings, combined with a joint parameter-noise optimization mechanism based on digital twin technology. In this mechanism, both model parameters and the signal-to-noise ratio of added noise are treated as optimization variables. A coherence function-based objective function guides the particle swarm optimization to update the parameters and SNR simultaneously. The purpose of the framework is to correct the dynamic model, reduce distribution differences, and generate twin signals under normal and faulty conditions to achieve realistic mapping of the twin signals. A convolutional neural network is then employed for multi-class fault identification. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework effectively enhances signal fidelity and improves the accuracy and robustness of fault diagnosis. This study provides a reliable solution for building a virtual-real fusion diagnostic model within bearing digital twin systems and offers important support for fault prediction and maintenance decision-making of railway vehicles.

title: DPT Circuit Design and Implementation for SiC MOSFET Characterization
authors: Abdelrahman Sobhy Qamr, Ahmed Sayed Soliman, Mohamed Taha
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Power Electronics and Renewable Energy (CPERE)
abstract: This paper introduces a complete design and implementation steps for a double-pulse test (DPT) circuit to characterize SiC MOSFETs. Different challenges have been addressed in the design steps, including the selection of the circuit components and a careful layout to minimize the circuit parasitics. The hardware circuit is used to measure the switching losses of Wolfspeed device number (C3M0040120K1). A detailed comparison between the Hardware (HW) results, Data-sheet values and spice simulation is introduced by highlighting the differences and the possible causes of these differences.

title: A GAN-Based Knowledge Distillation Framework for Robust Defect Detection on PCBs in Low-Light Conditions
authors: Thi-Hang Hoang, Trung-Hieu Le, Quoc-Viet Hoang, Ngoc-Thang Pham
publish: 2025 24th International Symposium on Communications and Information Technologies (ISCIT)
abstract: Although numerous lightweight methods for printed circuit board (PCB) defect detection have been extensively studied in recent years, most are designed for normal visibility conditions. Consequently, limited attention to low visibility scenarios has led to degraded performance in such environments. In this paper, we address the challenge of PCB defect detection under lowlight conditions by proposing a novel GAN-based knowledge distillation network (GKD-Net). The proposed framework consists of three integrated components: an Illumination enhancement (IL) subnetwork, a knowledge transfer (KT) subnetwork, and a defect detection (DD) subnetwork. GKD-Net enables end-to-end training for sequentially learning three tasks: Illumination enhancement, feature transmission, and object detection. In GKDNet, the IL subnetwork is responsible for producing clear feature representations from low-light input images. These enhanced features are then transmitted by the KT subnetwork to the DD subnetwork to facilitate learning and accurately define objects, thereby improving overall model performance. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed GKD-Net yields a mean average precision (mAP) of 94.87 % on the DD-PCB dataset, outperforming competing methods while maintaining the realtime inference speed of the baseline detector.

title: Structuring Ethical and Scalable Data Systems: Operational Models from Telecom, Healthcare, and Supply Chain
authors: Sara Goze
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Technologies, Systems and Services in Telecommunications (TELSIKS)
abstract: Telecommunications, healthcare, and global supply chains operate under constant pressure to process vast amounts of data while maintaining reliability, security, and regulatory compliance. When scalability is pursued without parallel ethical safeguards, the risk of privacy breaches, biased outcomes, and opaque automation increases. To address this, we propose a six- pillar framework that places human oversight, explainability, privacy-by-design, modularity, interoperability, and accessibility at the core of data system design. The framework draws on more than 17 years of practical experience across multinational programs and a self-funded research initiative in digital health. Its applicability is demonstrated through three operational contexts: the shift to paperless workflows and automated Key Performance Indicator (KPI) pipelines in telecom networks, the harmonization of performance models in supply chains, and a confidential decision-support assistant for Type 1 Diabetes (T1D). A conceptual simulation of the latter indicated a $\mathbf{1 5}-\mathbf{2 0} \boldsymbol{\%}$ reduction in insulin dosing errors when human oversight was preserved, with response times under two seconds. The findings show that embedding ethical design principles into system architecture strengthens transparency, trust, and adoption, and provides a transferable blueprint for responsible Artificial Intelligence (AI) deployment across regulated, data-intensive domains.

title: Implementing Machine Learning models in a Kubernetes cluster for a smart monitoring system
authors: Bouchra Kouach, Mohcin Mekhfioui, Azzedine El Mrabet, Rachid El Gouri
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: In order to increase the rent of resources (CPU and RAM) for nodes in a Kubernetes cluster to avoid over-provisioning or under-provisioning, we present a smart system dedicated to continuously monitoring of the infrastructure, using the power of Machine Learning in analyzing and predicting the utilization of node resources and thus guaranteeing high application availability for deployment. The models of machine learning such as Long Short-Term Memory and Recurrent Neural Networks are trained on the data collected from the cluster via Prometheus, to produce reliable predictions of future resource consumption. The results of our work are visualized in Grafana, providing a an interactive and a clear dashboard for monitoring performance. Our approach aims to improve the operational efficiency, resilience, and performance of applications running in a Kubernetes environment.

title: A Study on the Effect of Sunlight Spectrum Led for Saffron Growth
authors: Ryosuke Matsui, Muhammad Zharfan Bin Zulkifli, Takeshi Kumaki
publish: 2025 24th International Symposium on Communications and Information Technologies (ISCIT)
abstract: Saffron, one of the most expensive and labor-intensive spices, faces challenges in traditional cultivation due to its once-a-year harvest and vulnerability to pests like squirrels and chipmunks, which reduce yield and efficiency. To address these issues, indoor cultivation has been proposed as a viable alternative. This study focuses on evaluating saffron plant growth under three lighting conditions which is sunlight spectrum LED, conventional LED, and a dark environment. The results revealed significant differences in saffron plant growth and physiological activity depending on the lighting environment. Saffron plants grown using sunlight spectrum LED demonstrated the highest growth performance, producing 49 flowers, while those under conventional LED produced 38 flowers, and those in a dark environment produced only 10 flowers. This means saffron plants grown using sunlight spectrum LED produced 1.29 times higher (29 %) flowers compared to the conventional LED and 4.9 times higher (390 %) flowers compared to the dark environment. Conversely, saffron plants grown using the conventional LED produced 0.78 times lower (22 %) than the sunlight spectrum LED but still outperformed the dark environment by producing flowers 3.8 times higher (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 8 0 \%}$</tex>). The dark environment resulted in the lowest growth, producing flowers 4.9 times lower (80 %) than in the sunlight spectrum LED condition and 3.8 times lower (74 % less) than in the conventional LED condition. Saffron plants exposed to sunlight spectrum LED demonstrated enhanced growth performance, likely due to the spectral similarity of sunlight spectrum LED to natural sunlight.

title: Doubly-Fed Wind Turbine Nacelle Acoustic Vibration Fusion Monitoring and Fault Diagnosis
authors: Hongwei Xin, Hangjian Shang, Xuefei Zhang, Wei Liu, Wei Xu, Guoxing Wu, Haiming Niu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: The acoustic pattern monitoring of a wind turbine has the advantages of being intuitive and contactless, but it is susceptible to noise interference. For this reason, this paper proposes a drive train fault diagnosis method based on the fusion of acoustic and vibration information. First, three vibration sensors and three acoustic sensors are arranged in the nacelle of the doubly-fed wind turbine to collect vibration information from the main shaft, gearbox, and yaw reducer, as well as acoustic information in the nacelle and yaw platform, respectively. An acoustic-vibration information fusion method, based on drive train spectrum similarity, is constructed, combining time-domain, spectral, and envelope analyses to reveal the operational status and potential fault characteristics of each component. The results show that acoustic-vibration fusion monitoring improves drive train fault diagnosis reliability, laying the foundation for both continuous fault monitoring and independent acoustic pattern monitoring applications in similar units.

title: A CNN-BiLSTM-Based Evaluation Model for Steady-State Bearing Fault Diagnosis Method
authors: Jianwen Zeng, Boping Xiao, Lin Ma, Naichao Wang, Yanyan Jin
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: Accurate identification of rolling bearing faults is essential for ensuring the reliability of rotating machinery. This study introduces an evaluation model based on a Convolutional Neural Network-Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (CNN-BiLSTM) architecture to assess the performance of fault frequency diagnosis methods under steady-state operating conditions. The model focuses on envelope spectrum analysis and uses the Fault Feature Coefficient (FFC) to label signal data. The CNN extracts features from both time and frequency domains, while the BiLSTM captures sequential characteristics. These combined features enable binary classification of diagnostic success or failure. Experimental results show that the proposed model achieves high evaluation accuracy. Comparative analysis indicates that CNN-BiLSTM performs better than CNN-LSTM in terms of precision, recall, and F1-score. This approach provides a reliable framework for evaluating fault diagnosis techniques and supports the selection of appropriate methods for analyzing bearing vibration signals.

title: Design for Manufacturing and Measurements of a 1:3 Scale Wideband HF Antenna
authors: Songyi Yen, Ljubodrag B. Boskovic, Dejan S. Filipovic
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Technologies, Systems and Services in Telecommunications (TELSIKS)
abstract: Herein, the fabrication and measurement of $\mathbf{1: 3}$ scale wideband high-frequency (HF) antenna is discussed. The antenna is a combined TEM horn and loop antenna to provide directional radiation through combination of fundamental electric and magnetic dipole modes. Resistive terminations are applied to reduce the low-frequency turn-on at the expense of efficiency. Full size with image fits within a $3-\mathrm{m}$ sphere, giving $k a$ of 0.5 and 1 at 7.95 and 15.9 MHz, respectively. The impedance match is $\lt 2: 1$ over the entire extended HF band ($\mathbf{2 - 3 0 ~ M H z}$). The fabrication is a third of that for $1-\mathrm{m}$ tall. Additionally, the metal sheets used in the design are modified to be a wireframe structure to reduce cost, weight, and impact of wind loading with minimal RF impact. Measurements include impedance with and without resistive terminations as well as qualitative characterization of the radiation characteristics by using the low-power weak signal propagation reporter (WSPR) protocol in the HF band.

title: Research on Intelligent Coordinated AVC Control of Primary and Distribution Networks Based on Reinforcement Learning
authors: Yi Zhong, Qian Liu, Zhigang Peng, Peiyin Xu
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: Against the backdrop of rapid development of distributed renewable energy sources and the complexity of voltage regulation in primary and distribution networks, this paper proposes an intelligent coordinated AVC control strategy for primary and distribution networks based on an improved Double Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient (Double-DDPG) algorithm. The method constructs a unified primary-distribution network system model, designs a multidimensional state space and hierarchical action space, and employs a dual-agent structure to separately control the primary and distribution networks. Information sharing and coordinated optimization are realized through a low-latency communication protocol. Simulation results based on OpenDSS and deep reinforcement learning platforms show that the proposed strategy significantly improves voltage regulation accuracy and qualification rate under multiple operating conditions, reduces reactive power losses and equipment switching frequency, and enhances system robustness and response speed. Compared with traditional PID control and single-layer reinforcement learning control, the proposed method demonstrates superiority in improving voltage quality, energy efficiency, and equipment lifespan, exhibiting strong potential for practical engineering applications.

title: A Prompt-Driven Industrial Large Model for Intelligent Operation and Maintenance of High-End Equipment
authors: Zisheng Wang, Cong Peng, Yulong Xing, Leilei Zhang, Yunfei Shao, Jianping Xuan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (IO&M) of high-end equipment faces challenges such as a lack of annotated data, weak generalization capability, and insufficient integration of domain knowledge. To address these issues, we propose an Industrial Large Model (ILM) that unifies the time-frequency visual representation of sensor signals with textual maintenance knowledge within a large decoder-based language model framework. ILM uses a visual transformer as a visual encoder to extract semantic embeddings from the spectrograms generated by the sensor, which are then projected and merged into a prompt template together with the domain text. Through prompt engineering, ILM effectively fuses multimodal information to achieve flexible and explainable fault diagnosis without complex multi-stage training. Experiments on benchmark datasets and real industrial datasets show that ILM has higher accuracy, robustness, and reasoning ability than baseline methods, highlighting its potential as a next-generation intelligent IO&M solution.

title: Application of Damping in SAR Antenna Support Structure to Control Response at Vibration Test
authors: Chunyu Zhang, Cuijun Liu., Haixin Ding
publish: 2024 5th China International SAR Symposium (CISS)
abstract: The Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) is usually supported by the composite material struts on satellite and the satellite need to endure vibration test on ground before launch. The composite material struts are commonly lack of damping. As a result, the response of the SAR antenna can be very large which is not good to the SAR antenna. Some examples show that the SAR antenna can be broken after large vibration test or the accuracy will lose. Therefore, to control the vibration response at the vibration test period is very important. In this paper, a support structure is built with and without the viscous damper. The comparison is given between the two models in terms of the vibration response under the same excitation. The results show that the entire modal is decreased when the dampers are added. However, the peak response of the SAR antenna is greatly decreased which means the damper can performed well when the parameters are selected carefully. This paper provides a new idea for vibration suppression of large-scale SAR antenna, which has guiding significance for actual engineering.

title: Economic benefit analysis of the integrated hydrogen energy system park under optimized operation
authors: Hong Li, Lumin Li, Tao Wang, Rongwu Zhu, Ke Luo
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: In response to the low-carbon transition needs of industrial parks, a multi-energy complementary technology combination of "new energy generation + hydrogen storage" and "thermal power + carbon capture" has been established. This method refines the traditional two-stage operation process of power to gas (P2G), and establishes the coupling model of cogeneration and carbon capture system (CCS), electrolyzer (EL), methane reactor (MR), and hydrogen fuel cell (HFC). The system considers the direct participation of hydrogen energy in gas-fired hydrogen-doped power generation to achieve economic goals, and the inclusion of carbon trading to realize low-carbon goals. The low-carbon benefits of the system are quantified by three indicators: renewable energy penetration rate, wind and solar energy abandonment rate, and hydrogen participation rate. The results show that the system can not only increase the consumption of new wind and solar energy, reduce carbon emissions, but also reduce the daily operating costs of the system, which verifies the feasibility of the transition to a low-carbon carbon park.

title: Adaptive Control of Rail Pressure in High-Pressure Common Rail System Based on RBF-LADRC
authors: Yongdong Cui, Wenhui Li, Tianyuan Huo, Tai Guo
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: To address the challenges of rail pressure control in high-pressure common rail system (HPCRS), which often struggle to simultaneously meet the requirements of rapidity, accuracy, and stability under nonlinear dynamics, strong disturbances, and frequently changing operating conditions. This paper designs a closed-loop rail pressure controller based on the Radial Basis Function Neural Network (RBFNN) and Linear Active Disturbance Rejection Control (LADRC). The controller integrates RBFNN into the LADR, where Jacobian information generated by the neural network enhances the controller’s ability to perceive the system's dynamic characteristics. Moreover, the controller bandwidth parameter is adaptively tuned online. Co-simulation results based on the AMEsim-Simulink platform demonstrate that the proposed RBF-LADRC controller achieves significantly faster step response, near-zero overshoot, and improves steady-state control accuracy by 54% and 43% compared to PID and LADRC controllers, respectively. The proposed method effectively enhances the system’s robustness and dynamic responsiveness under complex operating conditions.

publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Technologies, Systems and Services in Telecommunications (TELSIKS)

title: Crop Classification with Multi-Frequency Multi-Temporal Polarimetric and Interferometric SAR Data
authors: Noelia Romero-Puig, Mario Busquier, Jiayin Luo, Juan M. Lopez-Sanchez, Francesca Ticconi, Irena Hajnsek
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: The combination of radar-derived features extracted from a dataset formed by multi-temporal polarimetric images and interferometric products acquired at various frequency bands has been evaluated for crop classification in this work. Fully polarimetric images acquired by the F-SAR airborne sensor at three frequency bands (L, C and X) and at three separate dates during the CROPEX14 campaign are exploited for this purpose. The images include consistent repeat-pass acquisitions with different baselines. Results show that all data dimensions contribute to improve the classification accuracy. The main novelty of this work is the joint use of different frequency bands (in groups of two and three) and specific interferometric data suitable for crops (short temporal baselines and large spatial baselines). The achieved performance with different combinations of input features is analysed both globally and for specific crops. Among other conclusions, L- and X-band show the best performance of all band pairs. Since they are the most extreme, their complementary sensitivity is maximised when used together.

title: Exploring the Need for Haptic Feedback and Improved Communication in Robotic-Assisted Surgery: A Surgeon-Centered Survey_supp1-3633553.xlsx
authors: Zeynep Akbal
publish: N/A
abstract: Robotic-assisted surgery (RAS) has fundamentally transformed surgical practice by expanding the boundaries of human motion, offering increased precision and dexterity. It has opened new opportunities for autonomous and remote surgery beyond traditional operating room settings. The repertoire of possibilities is currently limited by the absence of haptic feedback, challenges in intraoperative communication, and ergonomic constraints. In this study, we gathered insights from clinically active surgeons across multiple specialties to identify current limitations and unmet needs in RAS. We hereby aim to bridge real-world surgical challenges by facilitating interdisciplinary collaboration and advancing the field through focused technological and clinical development. This study underscores the critical need for enhanced haptic feedback, improved intraoperative communication tools, and ergonomic refinements in RAS. Addressing these issues is essential to optimize surgical performance and patient outcomes. Future developments of robotic-assisted systems should prioritize multimodal concepts of sensory integration in order to improve the sense of embodiment within the surgical environment.

title: Performance Analysis of OFDM-OAM Communications with Delay-Line Feeding Networks
authors: Wei Yu, Ding Chen, Bin Zhou
publish: IEEE Communications Letters
abstract: Current orbital angular momentum (OAM) communication systems using uniform circular arrays (UCAs) widely adopt delay-line-based feeding networks for high integration. While prototypes and experimental validations have been reported, theoretical analysis of the performance limits remains unexplored. This paper establishes baseband equivalent model for the delay-line-based orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (OFDM)-OAM communications and provides a systematic performance evaluation. The theoretical analysis demonstrates complete elimination of inter-carrier interference, while revealing that perfect mode orthogonality is preserved only at the central subcarrier (carrier frequency), with all other subcarriers experiencing inter-mode interference that scales with relative bandwidth. Extensive simulations are conducted to demonstrate the performance loss caused by the delay-line effect.

title: CPERE 2025 Index
authors: N/A
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Power Electronics and Renewable Energy (CPERE)

authors: N/A
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Technologies, Systems and Services in Telecommunications (TELSIKS)

title: Multimodal Cognitive Load Estimation with Radio Frequency Sensing and Pupillometry in Complex Auditory Environments
authors: Usman Anwar, Adeel Hussain, Mandar Gogate, Kia Dashtipour, Tughrul Arslan, Amir Hussain, Peter Lomax
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: The detection of listening effort or cognitive load (CL) has been a major research challenge in recent years. Most conventional techniques utilise physiological or audio-visual sensors and are privacy-invasive and computationally complex. The challenges of synchronization, data alignment and accessibility limitations potentially increase the noise and error probability, compromising the accuracy of CL estimates. This innovative work presents a multi-modal, non-invasive and privacy-preserving approach that combines Radio Frequency (RF) and pupillometry sensing to address these challenges. Custom RF sensors are first designed and developed to capture blood flow changes in specific brain regions with high spatial resolution. Next, multi-modal fusion with pupillometry sensing is proposed and shown to offer a robust assessment of cognitive and listening effort through pupil size and pupil dilation. Our novel approach evaluates RF sensing to estimate CL from cerebral blood flow variations utilizing pupillometry as a baseline. A first-of-its-kind, multi-modal dataset is collected as a new benchmark resource in a controlled environment with participants to comprehend target speech with varying background noise levels. The framework is statistically evaluated using intraclass correlation for pupillometry data (average ICC> 0.95). The correlation between pupillometry and RF data is established through Pearson's correlation (average PCC> 0.79). Further, CL is classified into high and low categories based on RF data using K-means clustering. Future work involves integrating RF sensors with glasses to estimate listening effort for hearing-aid users and utilising RF measurements to optimize speech enhancement based on individual's listening effort and complexity of acoustic environment.

title: Shared-Aperture Dual Circularly Polarized Phased Array Antenna with Small Frequency Ratio for Satellite-Assisted IoT Communications
authors: Wen Yu, Chunxu Mao, Junhui Ou, Xiu Yin Zhang
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: In satellite-assisted IoT communications, circularly polarized (CP) phased array antennas enable devices to directly connect with the satellites. This paper proposes a shared-aperture dual-CP antenna where low-band and high-band antennas are coaxially arranged for miniaturization. The low-band antenna is a dual-feed shorted ring patch loaded with small circles, whereas the high-band antenna is a compact single-probe-fed patch loaded with an oval parasitic patch. Both low-band and high-band antennas have broadband characteristics. Cross-band decoupling in the high-band is achieved by exciting the TM<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">21</sub> mode of the low-band antenna and loading a parasitic ring. Additionally, the shorted metallic vias of the low-band antenna form a metallic back-cavity for the high-band antenna to further suppress interference from the low-band, and a pair of stubs is loaded on the feed of the high-band antenna to improve the port isolation in the low-band. Four prototypes, each consisting of 2×8 dual-band antennas, are fabricated and measured. Broad overlapped impedance and axial ratio bandwidths from 12.2 to 14 GHz and from 16.1 to 17.8 GHz are achieved for the low-band and high-band operations. A small frequency ratio of 1.29 is realized while the cross-band isolation exceeds 38 dB in the low-band and 26 dB in the high-band. The proposed dual circularly polarized antenna can achieve a scanning range of ±50° in both bands. As a result, the proposed compact dual-CP phased array antenna supports integration with small IoT terminals, while enabling stable connections for mobile devices or satellite terminals.

title: FAASTRACKER: Efficient Cross-Layer Provenance Tracking of Serverless Applications with Multi-Source Correlation
authors: Qingyang Zeng, Lianjie Wu, Kaiyu Hou, Xue Leng, Yan Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: Serverless computing, also known as Function-as-a-Service (FaaS), has gained popularity due to its flexibility, scala bility, and transparent development. However, attacks against serverless are also increasing. Unfortunately, complex multi-layer FaaS architecture and frequently launched lightweight functions help attackers conceal their tracks. Specifically, (i) fully tracking the behavior of a function requires crossing multiple layers of FaaS. (ii) Intrusive auditing components in functions affect function startup latency and performance. (iii) Accurately provenance cross-layer function invocations require integrating data from multiple sources. In this paper, we propose FAASTRACKER, a cross-layer, non-intrusive, efficient provenance framework for accurately tracking user function behaviors in FaaS. FAASTRACKER tracks function behaviors across layers using a non-intrusive agent without any modifications to the function. In addition, it correlates data from multiple sources to construct a provenance graph of function workflows to locate attackers. We implement FAASTRACKER on the OpenFaaS platform and evaluate its performance using real-world serverless applications. Compared with state-of-the-art serverless provenance systems, FAASTRACKER provides a more accurate and complete view of provenance graphs and reduces 54.0% CPU and 48.9% memory resources.

title: ASAP-ML: Antibiotic Susceptibility and Antibiogram Prediction with Machine Learning Methods_supp1-3634090.pdf
authors: Doruk Topcu
publish: N/A
abstract: Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) is a global health problem that poses a threat for now and poses an even greater threat for the future. Since the discovery of the first antibiotics, pathogens have developed different mechanisms of resistance against antibiotics. Today, the technology to understand the mechanisms of AMR and their genomics is more competent than ever. This paper provides a wide range of information about using genomic data combined with machine learning for predicting antibiotic resistance and proposes a multi-model approach ASAP (Antibiotic Susceptibility and Antibiogram Pre diction) for creating antibiograms. In this work, 10 different machine learning models, including Convolutional Neural Network, Nearest Neighbor, Random Forest, XGBoost, CatBoost, Naive Bayes, Support Vector Machines, Light Gradient Boosting Machine, Gradient Boost, and Logistic Regression, have been tested, evaluated, and compared for their predictive capabilities. For data preprocessing, different methods of feature extraction through n-gram encoding have been tested. For the evaluation of the models, accuracy, recall, precision, and F1 scores are used. Experiments show that models can predict the antibiotic resistance of a given pathogen sequence with up to 0.99 accuracy and 0.90+ macro average recall. The best performing model for this work has been XGBoost with 0.99 accuracy, and the least predictive model has been Naive Bayes with 0.89 accuracy. Our proposed method results shows that machine learning with gene sequences are promising tools to improve the current manual antibiogram creation, maintenance process and can provide healthcare professionals with valuable insights for less empirical antibiotic prescribing

title: AffectNet+: A Database for Enhancing Facial Expression Recognition With Soft-Labels
authors: Ali Pourramezan Fard, Mohammad Mehdi Hosseini, Timothy D. Sweeny, Mohammad H. Mahoor
publish: IEEE Transactions on Affective Computing
abstract: Automated Facial Expression Recognition (FER) is challenging due to intra-class variations and inter-class similarities. FER can be especially difficult when facial expressions reflect a mixture of various emotions (aka compound expressions). Existing FER datasets, such as AffectNet, provide discrete emotion labels (hard-labels), where a single category of emotion is assigned to an expression. To alleviate inter- and intra-class challenges, as well as provide a better facial expression descriptor, we propose a new approach to create FER datasets through a labeling method in which an image is labeled with more than one emotion (called soft-labels), each with a different confidence. Specifically, we introduce the notion of soft-labels for facial expression datasets, a new approach to affective computing for more realistic recognition of facial expressions. To achieve this goal, we propose a novel methodology to accurately calculate soft-labels: a vector representing the extent to which multiple categories of emotion are simultaneously present within a single facial expression. Finding smoother decision boundaries, enabling multi-labeling, and mitigating bias and imbalanced data are some of the advantages of our proposed method. Building upon AffectNet, we introduce AffectNet+, the next-generation facial expression dataset. This dataset contains soft-labels, three categories of data complexity subsets, and additional metadata such as age, gender, race, head pose, facial landmarks, valence, and arousal. AffectNet+ will be made publicly accessible to researchers.

title: Low-Latency DFE Error Propagation Correction and Partial-Response Filter-based Threshold Estimation for High-Speed Wireline Receivers
authors: Se-Ung Park, Yun-Kuk Park, MinSu Park, Byungwook Cho, Jung-Hoon Chun
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: In analog-to-digital converter (ADC)- and digital signal processing (DSP)-based long-reach PAM-4 wireline receivers, incorrect initial threshold settings can hinder equalizer coefficient convergence and degrade signal integrity. While maximum-likelihood sequence detection mitigates decision feedback equalizer (DFE) error propagation and improves bit error rate (BER), its high latency makes it unsuitable for latency-sensitive applications. This paper proposes two circuit techniques that enhance threshold estimation and suppress DFE error propagation with minimal latency. First, a 1−D partial-response (PR) filter is introduced to reshape the received signal, inducing negative autocorrelation that improves initial threshold estimation, even when the transmitted symbols are originally uncorrelated. Second, a low-latency DFE-CURE (Correction under Uncertainty with Reverse-decision Evaluation) architecture evaluates two candidate sequences—one based on the original decision and the other based on an alternative symbol—and selects the path with the lower accumulated metric. This avoids full-sequence decoding while adding only three DSP clock cycles of latency beyond the conventional DFE, resulting in a total of five cycles after feed-forward equalization. A 56-Gb/s PAM-4 ADC/DSP-based receiver, fabricated in a 28-nm process, is evaluated under 23.1-dB channel loss. Simulations show that the 1−D PR filter reduces threshold estimation error by 83%, and DFE-CURE lowers BER from 10−5 to 10−6, achieving a 10× improvement.

title: Multi-objective optimization of DC microgrids under stability constraints
authors: Zifan ZHANG, Diyang HU, Xiangyu YANG, Shiwei ZHAO, Qi Zeng, Lina LUO, Yuan Tang
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Power Electronics
abstract: DC microgrids are vital for renewable energy integration and distributed energy management, but their expanding scale and complex operation with diverse topologies expose critical limitations. These methods, primarily designed for simple single-bus structures, fail to coordinate voltage deviation suppression, system stability enhancement, and economic optimization effectively in multi-bus scenarios. To address this, a multi-objective optimization approach for DC microgrids (DCMG) with complex topologies is proposed. It integrates small-signal stability, bus voltage deviation, and operational economy into a unified framework, incorporates randomness of power generation and loads, and adapts to mesh topology with diverse node types. Case studies verify the method exhibits strong adaptability and robustness under stochastic scenarios, achieving balanced improvements in stability and economic efficiency: the system small-signal stability index is reduced by 19.3%, bus voltage deviation is lowered by 71.2%, and system power loss is decreased by 2.1%.  This work provides key technical support for the efficient and reliable operation of DC microgrids with complex topologies, advancing their practical application in complex energy systems.

title: Bayesian Deep Learning for Remaining Useful Life Estimation via Stein Variational Gradient Descent
authors: Luca Della Libera, Jacopo Andreoli, Davide Dalle Pezze, Mirco Ravanelli, Gian Antonio Susto
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: A crucial task in predictive maintenance is estimating the remaining useful life of physical systems. In the last decade, deep learning has improved considerably upon traditional model-based and statistical approaches in terms of predictive performance. However, in order to optimally plan maintenance operations, it is also important to quantify the uncertainty inherent in the predictions. This issue can be addressed by turning standard frequentist neural networks into Bayesian neural networks, which are naturally capable of providing confidence intervals around the estimates. Several methods exist for training those models. Researchers have focused mostly on parametric variational inference and sampling-based techniques, which notoriously suffer from limited approximation power and large computational burden, respectively. In this work, we use Stein variational gradient descent, a recently proposed algorithm for approximating intractable distributions that overcomes the drawbacks of the aforementioned techniques. In particular, we show through experimental studies on both simulated run-to-failure turbofan engine degradation data and real industrial battery degradation data that Bayesian deep learning models trained via Stein variational gradient descent consistently outperform with respect to convergence speed and predictive performance both the same models trained via parametric variational inference and their frequentist counterparts trained via backpropagation. Furthermore, we propose a method to enhance performance based on the uncertainty information provided by the Bayesian models.

title: Ultra-Tightly Coupled GNSS/INS/Vision Integrated System for Centimeter-Level Vehicle Positioning in Challenging Environments
