authors: Xin Feng, Tisheng Zhang, Liqiang Wang, Xiaoji Niu, Mohamed Bochkati, Thomas Pany, Jingnan Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: High-precision positioning plays a pivotal role in intelligent transportation systems by enabling reliable navigation, automated intersection management and high-precision platooning for autonomous vehicles in large-scale, unfamiliar environments. However, existing loosely or tightly coupled integration solutions of Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS), Inertial Navigation System (INS), and Visual System can be challenged by the limited availability of GNSS signals, which will affect their ability to consistently achieve robust high-precision positioning in harsh environments. In this work, we propose a multi-sensor (GNSS/INS/Vision) ultra-tightly coupled system with GNSS carrier phase long coherent integration tracking (MUT-LCI). At the signal processing level, MUT-LCI utilizes the multi-sensor sensed dynamics to assist GNSS signal tracking loops and realizes extended coherent integration periods up to 300 milliseconds, improving the availability of GNSS carrier phase observations in highly challenging environments significantly. The data fusion of the GNSS RTK/INS/Vision is conducted using a Multi-state Constraint Kalman Filter (MSCKF). To evaluate the performance of the proposed MUT-LCI system, we conducted experiments using an intelligent transportation wheeled robot platform in harsh environments, including areas covered by dense tree canopies and surrounded by tall buildings. The results demonstrate that the proposed MUT-LCI system achieves precise GNSS carrier phase signal tracking in highly challenging environments, enabling continuous RTK fixed solutions and providing reliable centimeter-level positioning accuracy.

title: Adaptive Optimal Prescribed Performance Tracking Solutions for Multiplayer Systems With Error Constraints
authors: Yongfeng Lv, Huimin Chang, Jun Zhao, Yuteng Tian
publish: IEEE Transactions on Neural Networks and Learning Systems
abstract: This brief presents the adaptive optimal prescribed performance tracking solutions for the multiplayer nonlinear systems based on the adaptive critic learning scheme, where the tracking errors are constrained to a predefined bounded set. First, the general optimal tracking solutions of multiplayer nonlinear systems are presented. Every optimal tracking solution of multiple players consists of the steady-state part and the adaptive feedback part. The steady-state part can be obtained directly according to the tracking signal and system dynamics. Then, the adaptive feedback part can be studied with the prescribed performance constraints and adaptive critic learning such that multiple value functions achieve a Nash equilibrium with error constraints. Moreover, the convergence of the critic network weight is analyzed by the Lyapunov algorithm. Finally, simulation results and experiments are presented to demonstrate the satisfactory performance of the proposed method.

title: Direct Routing Solution for Microsoft Teams Calling Service (PoC)
authors: Jelena Grozdanović
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Technologies, Systems and Services in Telecommunications (TELSIKS)
abstract: Document covers a short overview of activities needed to adopt MS Teams Direct Routing solution as a calling service for PSTN telcos, e.g. Telekom Serbia. Direct Routing scenario for PSTN connectivity through Teams Phone provides the opportunity for client companies to connect existing SIP trunking services and legacy voice platforms to Microsoft Teams Phone via session border controllers (SBCs). This document systematizes requirements, tests, and validation procedures for the Direct Routing solution in Telekom Serbia (MTS) in the PoC phase. Concept developed for MTS is planned for a multitenant environment, where it can support many customers of MS Office 365 and traditional services that are unified: calling plans, voice services, SIP trunks, Internet etc.

title: A Feature Enhancement Method for Microphone Array Signals Based on Wavelet Domain Polynomial Eigenvalue Decomposition
authors: Shichao Zhang, Gang Tang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: Acoustic signals contain critical information about the operating condition of rotating machinery. Due to their ease of installation and minimal environment constraints, microphone arrays have become an important non-contact monitoring technology. However, traditional beamforming methods rely on the accurate estimation of the target signal direction and often exhibit low diagnostic accuracy and limited adaptability in complex noise environments. To tackle this issue, a fault diagnosis approach based on wavelet-domain polynomial eigenvalue decomposition (PEVD) is proposed for microphone array signal. This method eliminates the need for direction of arrival (DOA) estimation and enables fault diagnosis without relying on any prior information. First, the acquired time-domain array signals are converted to wavelet domain using wavelet decomposition. Subsequently, PEVD is applied to the wavelet coefficients at each decomposition layer, and the Gini index (GI) is used to evaluate signal characteristics. Finally, the reconstructed signal undergoes analysis to extract fault features from its envelope spectrum. The comparative analysis indicates that the proposed approach demonstrates superior capability in fault identification.

title: Double-Path Residual Network with Attention Mechanism and Bidirectional Gated Recurrent Unit and its Application in Planetary Gear Fault Classification
authors: Zhilin Dong, Dezun Zhao, Dongdong Liu, Hongli Sun, Lingli Cui
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: The DCAM-BGRU architecture, combining double-path convolution with an attention mechanism (AM) and a bidirectional gated recurrent unit (BGRU), encounters challenges with gradient vanishing or exploding as the network expands, impacting fault classification accuracy and stability. To address this, we introduce the DRAM-BGRU model. Initially, two optimized parallel one-dimensional residual networks (1D-ResNet) are designed to extract spatial features while mitigating gradient issues. Subsequently, an AM is incorporated to capture significant fault features. Following this, a BGRU is positioned after the 1D-ResNet and AM to explore temporal characteristics of the sample signals. Ultimately, global average pooling consolidates information from these hybrid modules, with a fully connected layer outputting the final classification. Testing our approach on planetary gear data yields a perfect classification accuracy of 100%. Compared to five other advanced techniques, our method demonstrates superior planetary gear fault detection capabilities.

title: Imitation Learning-Based Mobile Robot Navigation Using Semantic Segmentation and Depth Estimation
authors: Thai-Viet Dang, Nhu-Nghia Bui, Phan Xuan Tan
publish: 2025 24th International Symposium on Communications and Information Technologies (ISCIT)
abstract: The inherent complexity of diverse environments imposes substantial processing requirements, which can lead to excessively high costs for navigation systems. This study employs a model for imitation learning specifically tailored for mobile robot (MR) navigation, utilizing environmental data sourced from a monocular camera. Two models, KD-SegNet and ELDE-Net, are integrated to create an intelligent knowledge system that serves as input, leveraging predictions derived from semantic segmentation and depth mapping. The architecture of the imitation learning framework incorporates the ResNet18 network alongside a mixture of expert's strategy. The actions executed within the environment are trained to align with the specialization of the expert blocks. The effectiveness of each module has undergone rigorous testing and validation. Notable features of this framework include high accuracy with the trained data and rapid inference speed, characterized by optimal latency and throughput. Importantly, the model consists of only 1.5 million parameters, facilitating effective adaptation to the hardware configuration. Additionally, the latency and throughput of each integrated module are optimized for real-time inference, thereby enhancing navigation efficiency. The inference results demonstrate a close alignment with the ideal parameters established during training, achieving a loss index of only 0.014.

title: Nudge Driven Decision Suite
authors: Jihad Satri, Hanaa Hachimi, Chakib El Mokhi
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: This paper explores the evolution of traditional Decision Support Systems (DSS) toward Nudge-Driven Decision Suites (NDDS), which integrate behavioral economics principles to better support decision-making in cognitively biased environments. A conceptual and analytical approach is adopted, combining a review of existing literature on DSS, digital nudging (DN), and behavioral decision theory, with illustrative case examples highlighting how nudging mechanisms can be embedded in intelligent decision interfaces. The integration of DN into DSS enhances user engagement and improves decision quality by mitigating cognitive biases. NDDS leverage user-centered interfaces, AI-driven personalization, and behavioral triggers to subtly influence choices aligned with organizational objectives, without restricting autonomy. NDDS offer significant potential for both public and private organizations seeking to optimize strategic and operational decisions. Their implementation can lead to smarter decision environments, particularly in digital services, policy design, and complex operational systems. This study proposes a novel framework for NDDS, positioning them as an evolutionary step beyond traditional DSS. It bridges decision science, behavioral economics, and digital design to reimagine how decision support technologies can be made more adaptive, intelligent, and behaviorally aware.

title: Study on Diabetes Screening Algorithm Based on PKIBlock Multi-Scale Convolution Combined with MobileVIT
authors: Mingxiao Xiao, Fei Wang, Shidong Fang
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Complex Medical Engineering (CME)
abstract: Diabetes is a metabolic disorder. Diabetes screening refers to the systematic identification of individuals who may have diabetes or be in the pre-diabetic stage among seemingly healthy populations without obvious diabetic symptoms through specific detection methods and procedures. This enables early detection, intervention, and management of the disease, thereby reducing the risk of diabetes and its complications. Studies have shown that photoplethysmography (PPG) signals can reflect vascular blood flow fluctuations and are associated with hyperglycemia and atherosclerosis. Focusing on the blood flow fluctuation characteristics contained in pulse waves, this experiment utilizes three algorithms: Spatial Position Encoding (SPE), Gramian Angular Field (GAF), and Recurrence Plot (RP) to convert PPG signal segments into dynamic fused images. Subsequently, a Mobile Vision Transformer (MobileVIT) model embedded with PKIblock multi-scale convolution is used to extract multi-scale features and conduct classification experiments. The effectiveness of the method was verified on a self-collected PPG medical dataset. Different deep learning models were employed for image modeling and analysis to validate the classification performance, and comparisons were made with the results of other related diabetes research. The results showed that the classification accuracy of the proposed model reached $\mathbf{9 8. 3 3 \%}$, which can accurately classify normal and diabetic populations. This provides a novel and convenient solution for the initial screening and daily monitoring of diabetes.

title: Low-Light Face Recognition: A Systematic Literature Review
authors: Agustiyar, R. Rizal Isnanto, Catur Edi Widodo
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Information Technology, Computer, and Electrical Engineering (ICITACEE)
abstract: Face recognition under low-light conditions presents major challenges due to low visibility, poor contrast, color bias, and image noise, all of which degrade recognition performance. To overcome these limitations, Low-Light Image Enhancement (LLIE) techniques have been applied, ranging from traditional methods such as Fisherface and CLAHE to deep learning approaches including feature reconstruction networks and generative adversarial networks (GANs). Recent studies also explore hybrid methods, such as YOLO-Eigenfaces, YOLO-HMMs, and MSRCR combined with PyramidBox, which show promising results in extreme low-light settings. This paper presents a Systematic Literature Review (SLR) of lowlight face recognition (LLFR) research published between 2019 and September 2024. The review is based on 40 selected studies retrieved from ScienceDirect, Scopus, and SpringerLink using predefined inclusion and exclusion criteria. The analysis reveals that the LOL dataset is the most widely used, with PSNR and SSIM serving as standard evaluation metrics. Deep learning has emerged as the dominant and state-of-the-art approach in LLFR research, offering substantial improvements in both image enhancement and recognition performance.

title: Paramtetric Analysis of Ice purity in a freezing based preatement for Reverse Osmosis Desalination
authors: Mohamed Ezzokaki, Oumaima Rhandari, Aurelie Gallfre, Denis Mangin, Driss Khomsi, Naoual Semlali Aouragh Hassani
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: This study presents an experimental investigation of key operating parameters in a freeze-based pretreatment process designed to improve reverse osmosis (RO) desalination efficiency. Using a dynamic-layer crystallizer, the effects of cooling finger temperature (-7 to -11 °C) and initial salt concentration (20 to 50 g/kg) on ice purity were examined. The results confirm that higher initial salinity increases salt entrapment in the ice, while less negative refrigerant temperatures promote the formation of purer ice by favoring solute exclusion. These findings align with known crystallization phenomena and highlight the potential of freezing as an effective pretreatment step in hybrid desalination systems.

title: Stochastic Portfolio Optimization and Market Behavior: A Comparative Study of Islamic and Developed Equity Indices
authors: El Khattabi Mohammed, Saoudi Youness, El Mehdi Falloul, Zahid Abdelkahar, Hachimi Hanaa
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: This paper aims to comprehensively compare the risk-return profiles of Islamic and conventional equity markets, providing valuable insights into the financial performance of stock market indices in Islamic countries as compared to those in developed nations. The objective is to delve into the intricate dynamics of these markets, shedding light on how they respond to various economic and financial factors. By focusing on the performance metrics of stock market indices in both Islamic and developed countries, this study intends to analyze not only the overall returns generated but also the associated risks involved. In doing so, it seeks to unearth the nuances in investment opportunities, uncovering potential patterns of divergence or convergence between these two market segments. Furthermore, this research endeavors to discern how different economic and regulatory environments impact these markets, contributing to a more profound understanding of global investment.

title: Architecture, Engineering, and Artificial Intelligence in Agricultural Technology
authors: Olga Elina
publish: 2025 6th International Workshop on Engineering Technologies and Computer Science (EnT)
abstract: The paper analyzes the application of architectural innovations, engineering technologies, and artificial intelligence (AI) in plant cultivation. Its goal is to trace the developments in design and equipment of buildings and appliances for indoor plant growing under controlled environments in greenhouses, conservatories, and specially constructed chambers, phytotrons. The focus of the paper is on diverse research objectives of plant cultivation: studying individual plants and plant communities, breeding new varieties, as well as space plant programs, including those involving AI. The Soviet / Russian case receives special attention. The paper argues the interrelationship between architectural, engineering, and technological trends that have influenced the cultivation of plants under artificial climate conditions: the modular greenhouse designs, the creation of phytotrons, the integration of artificial intelligence into indoor plant growing, including in space programs.

title: AI as a source of increased danger (risk to loss life)
authors: Yuri M. Baturin
publish: 2025 6th International Workshop on Engineering Technologies and Computer Science (EnT)
abstract: The article examines the negative psychological impact of artificial intelligence (chat bots) on teenagers and people with unstable psyches, taken to extreme forms. In 2025, cases of murder and suicide under the influence of chatbots were recorded. Such phenomena indicate the need for serious legal decisions regarding responsibility for causing harm to individuals. One possible solution is to classify AI as a source of increased danger. It is also advisable to discuss the problem in medical terms as a special case of AI-induced psychoses.

title: AI Assistants and the Transformation of Scientific Authorship: A Comparative Analysis of Regulatory Approaches
authors: Anna Fedorova
publish: 2025 6th International Workshop on Engineering Technologies and Computer Science (EnT)
abstract: The rapid proliferation of generative AI tools since late 2022 has challenged traditional notions of authorship in scientific research. This paper examines how major publishers and academic institutions worldwide are responding to AI-assisted manuscript preparation through policy development. By analyzing policies from Springer Nature, Elsevier, Taylor & Francis, PLOS, and positions from national accreditation bodies in Russia and Belarus, we identify three distinct regulatory models: prohibition, mandatory disclosure, and liberal approaches. Our comparative analysis reveals tensions between maintaining academic integrity and embracing technological innovation. We argue that current policies reflect broader transformations in the social construction of authorship, where responsibility and accountability remain uniquely human attributes while AI tools increasingly participate in knowledge production. The paper concludes with recommendations for developing differentiated policies that balance transparency requirements with practical research needs, particularly for dissertation research where demonstration of independent scholarly capability remains paramount.

title: Design and Implement of a Network Log Analysis System for Intelligent Operations and Maintenance
authors: Yun Lan, Junpeng Zhang, Peng Chen, Chenxuan Li, Liang Jia, Meng Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: In response to the intricate management demands of network devices and the proliferation of massive log data, this paper proposes a four-tier architecture for a network device log analysis platform. It delves into the functional requirements encompassing data collection, storage, processing, and application, with a focal point on data processing technology implementation. Employing big data techniques, such as k-means cluster analysis and trend analysis, this study showcases the network log situation and forecast results through a network health analysis instance, furnishing a pragmatic solution for intelligent operations and maintenance.

title: Research on Transient Stability Critical Clearing Time Assessment and Correction Control Based on Bayesian optimization LightGBM
authors: Fu Yang, Guosong Wang, Su An, Huaying Su, Qingqing Zhang, Junquan Chen
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: With the expansion of power grid scale and the vigorous development of new energy, the power grid has become increasingly complex. An instability fault can cause extensive impact and enormous losses. Thus, developing a transient stability control strategy for new energy-integrated grids is urgently needed. This paper proposes a data-driven critical clearing time (CCT) evaluation and corrective control method for transient stability based on the BO-LightGBM (Bayesian optimized LightGBM) model. The feasibility of applying BO-LightGBM to power system transient stability is analyzed through CCT prediction and evaluation. Based on the BO-LightGBM predicted CCT results, the sensitivity of CCT corresponding to different generators is calculated. Meanwhile, the BO-LightGBM corrective model adjusts CCT to exceed the relay protection operation time with minimal generator power variation, enhancing system stability. Simulation results in new energy-integrated grids show that the proposed method accurately achieves transient stability assessment and rapid emergency control after instability, verifying its effectiveness.

title: Quantification of Human Postural Positions During Work Based on the Data from the IMU Sensor
authors: Jelena Ilić, Marija Radmilović, Đorđe Urukalo, Uroš Ilić, Miloš Jevtić, Sonja Dimitrijević, Nikola Zogović
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Technologies, Systems and Services in Telecommunications (TELSIKS)
abstract: This paper presents an analysis the posture of the human body in a sitting position while working at the computer. Poses of the human body were captured using 9 inertial sensors placed on the torso and arms. We identified ten major incorrect sitting postures of the human body. The difference between incorrect and correct body posture is quantified through the angles of rotation of the sensor in 3 axes. The results show that the subject maintained an incorrect body position for more than $70 \%$ of the time, with the greatest deviation observed in the lower back area, indicating an increased risk of lower back pain.

title: Proposal of Pulse Wave Extraction Method Based on Pulse Wave Selection Method Using Adaptively Computed Higher-Order Statistics
authors: Yamato Imai, Haruto Sakurai, Minoru Komatsu, Hiroki Matsumoto
publish: 2025 24th International Symposium on Communications and Information Technologies (ISCIT)
abstract: There is a pulse wave extraction method based on the separation of Pulse Wave (PW) and Stationary Noise (SNoise) from two observation signals containing PW and SNoise. In this method, PW is selected from two series of separation signals. In the conventional PW extraction method, the PW is selected from the separation signals using their kurtosis and skewness. In the conventional method, the procedure for selecting PW from the separation signals is as follows. First, block processing is performed for the separation signals. Next, the kurtosis and skewness are computed from each block of the separation signals. Finally, PW is selected for each block using these values. By using this method, PW selection is performed with high accuracy for the separation signals reproducing the source signals with high accuracy. In this selection, only information from each block is used. Therefore, the conventional method cannot select with high accuracy for separation signals reproducing the source signals with low accuracy. In this paper, we use information of all previous separation signals for PW selection based on adaptive computation of kurtosis and skewness. Then, we propose PW extraction method to select the PW with high accuracy, even if separation signals reproducing the source signals are low accuracy.

title: Generating Transmission Line Fault Waveforms Using an Improved Conditional GAN
authors: Hongzhi Su, Gaoxiang Shi, Xucheng Fu, Tong Wang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: Class imbalance in transmission line fault data hinders accurate fault diagnosis, as rare faults (e.g. lightning strikes or pollution flashovers) are underrepresented. We propose an enhanced conditional generative adversarial network (cGAN) to synthesize realistic and diverse fault waveforms for six fault types (lightning strike, foreign object, wildfire, icing, wind deviation, pollution flashover), thereby augmenting minority classes. Our model extends the basic cGAN by embedding class labels into both generator and discriminator, and by adding regularization losses (auxiliary classification and diversity losses) to improve sample variety. We detail the network architectures, conditioning strategy, and loss functions. Training uses normalized time-series segments of waveform data, optimizing via Adam with tuned hyperparameters. In experiments, synthetic waveforms closely match real ones in shape (illustrated visually) and statistical metrics. Quantitatively, the improved cGAN achieves much lower Fréchet Distance and higher diversity scores than a baseline, demonstrating its ability to generate high-fidelity, varied samples. This approach can alleviate data scarcity for rare faults. Future work will integrate these synthetic signals into fault-classifiers and explore other domain constraints.

title: Optimal Design of Hybrid Wind/Fuel Cell Microgrid Using Starfish Optimization Algorithm
authors: Atef Abdelfatah, Salah Kamel, Hoda Abd El-Sattar, Loai Nasrat, Francisco Jurado
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Power Electronics and Renewable Energy (CPERE)
abstract: This paper presents the application of the Starfish Optimization Algorithm (SFOA) for the optimal design of hybrid microgrid comprising solar cells (SCs), wind generators (WGs), fuel cells (FCs), electrolyzer units (ELECs), and a hydrogen storage tank (HT). The proposed microgrid is intended to supply electricity to a group of buildings in New Alamein City, Egypt, using local meteorological data-including temperature, solar radiation, and wind speed-for system evaluation and design. SFOA is employed to determine the optimal configuration that minimizes the net present cost (NPC), reduces the cost of energy (COE), and lowers the loss of power supply probability (LPSP), while enhancing system stability under varying climatic conditions. An energy management system (EMS) is also implemented to coordinate energy flow from the multiple hybrid microgrid elements (HMGE), ensuring continuous load coverage and achieving optimal system sizing. The effectiveness of SFOA is validated through comparison with other metaheuristic algorithms, including Grey Wolf Optimization (GWO), the Sine Cosine Algorithm (SCA), and the Bird Natural Life-based COOT algorithm. According to the MATLAB simulation results, the suggested SFOA-based CHMG design performs better than the alternative approaches in terms of COE, NPC, and LPSP. Attained COE is at least $0.2305 \mathrm{USD} / \mathrm{kWh}$, and NPC is 67,629,02.26 USD.

title: LEASGgram: An Adaptive Detection Method of Locomotive Bearing Repetitive Transient Impulses with Automatic Frequency Band Segmentation
authors: Binghuan Cai, Gang Tang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: Repetitive transient impulses detection methods are often hindered under the severe operating conditions of locomotive real-world engineering applications. One of the primary challenges in existing approaches is the use of fixed spectral segmentation strategies, which fail to account for the unique characteristics of the spectrum, often leading to the loss of critical fault signatures. Additionally, current state-of-the-art indicators are highly sensitive to strong background noise and depend heavily on prior knowledge of fault-related frequencies. Aiming to overcome the aforementioned constraints, this study introduces an innovative methodology for fault detection called LEASGgram, specifically designed to identify repetitive transient impulses under severe disturbance conditions. The proposed method develops an adaptive segmentation strategy for frequency bands, leveraging multi-scale spectral analysis, enabling automatic partitioning of the frequency domain according to its intrinsic distribution features. Moreover, a novel evaluation metric is formulated based on the log envelope autocorrelation spectrum, enabling the simultaneous characterization of signal sparsity and cyclostationarity attributes. This allows for accurate localization of the resonance bands excited by repetitive fault-induced transients. Compared with conventional signal processing techniques, the proposed LEASGgram demonstrates superior performance in extracting informative frequency bands with enhanced fault relevance and reduced noise interference, even under harsh operational conditions.

title: Automated, Interpretable and Efficient ML Models for Real-World Lightpaths’ Quality of Transmission Estimation
authors: Sandra Aladin, Lena Wosinska, Christine Tremblay
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Communications Society
abstract: Fast and accurate estimation of lightpaths’ quality of transmission (QoT) is crucial for ensuring quality of service (QoS) and seamless operation in real-world optical networks. Machine learning (ML) algorithms are promising tools for QoT estimation of lightpaths before their establishment. In multi-domain optical networks, where learned QoT estimation models must be transferred between heterogeneous environments with limited target data, deep neural networks (DNNs) have shown promising results. However, DNN-based transfer learning (TL) approaches using fine-tuned artificial neural networks (ANNs) and convolutional neural networks (CNNs), offer limited interpretability. Consequently, little insight into the decision-making process is provided, and large labeled datasets as well as high computational resources are required, limiting their suitability for real-time, large-scale deployment in production networks. To address these challenges, we propose a novel lightweight and interpretable TL framework that integrates the Boruta-SHAP algorithm for automated feature selection (FS) together with two domain adaptation (DA) techniques: Feature Augmentation and Correlation Alignment. In contrast to the existing approaches based on DNN, our strategy leverages interpretable and efficient ML models to enhance the adaptability across diverse datasets in real-world network environments. We show that our random forest (RF)-based models achieve better performance than the ANN-based models, without sacrificing the classification accuracy. The FS via Boruta-SHAP allows for reducing dimensionality as well as training and inference times up to 70.68%, and 41.64%, respectively. Our proposed framework outperforms DA baseline models achieving 99.35% accuracy improvement in domain shift. Moreover, it offers 86% accuracy with a 99.83% reduction in the size of the target domain.

title: Collision-free Circular Formation Control for Nonholonomic Vehicles under Obstacle Occlusion with Relative Measurement
authors: Xiuhui Peng, Zhengyang Pan, Yongxiao Tian, Yuezu Lv
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: This paper addresses the problem of circular formation control for nonholonomic vehicles in communication-free and GPS-free mode under obstacle occlusion with relative measurement. Firstly, an attractive vector is constructed based on relative position between vehicles and target. The constructed vector, combined with the angular deviation of the trajectory’s circular center associated with nonholonomic vehicles, is used to design circular formation controllers. The collisions during the formation process are effectively prevented by the control laws. Subsequently, a more applicable circular formation control law ensuring collision avoidance is proposed for a scenario with onboard sensor occlusion. The proposed control laws eliminate the need for the uniform angular spacing between vehicles and are completely independent of the number nonholonomic vehicles. Finally, the validation of the designed controllers are carried out through both numerical simulations and physical experiments.

title: An RF Energy Harvesting Scheme Based on Phase-Gradient Metasurface and Hybrid Dipole–Dielectric Resonator Antenna
authors: Zhong Yu, Wenxin Wang, Hao Pan, Zhimin Chen, Dong Chen
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: This letter proposes a design scheme that combines a quantized phase-gradient focusing metasurface with a rectifying antenna to enhance the power conversion efficiency (PCE) in radio frequency energy harvesting (RFEH) systems. The metasurface consists of 23×23 Fractal-Based Phase Gradient (FBPG) units with a three-layer structure to generate quasi-Bessel beams. These beams enable uniform energy transmission while achieving energy focusing. Positioned at the focal point, the rectifying antenna captures the focused energy, converting it into direct current output. The antenna adopts a hybrid structure, coupling a parallel dipole with a dielectric resonator (PDi-DR) to enhance reception efficiency and directivity. Experimental results show that the metasurface achieves a focal length of 500 mm at 5.8 GHz. The PDi-DR antenna has a bandwidth of 4.6–7.1 GHz, a gain of 8.1 dBi, and a front-to-back ratio of 21 dB at 5.8GHz. The antenna gain can be increased to 16.1 dBi through the placement of the metasurface in front of the rectifying antenna. This design scheme achieves a PCE of 73.74% at an input power of 15 dBm, indicating its viability as a green energy source for low-power electronics and its potential for wide-ranging applications.

title: Gradient-Based Co-Design of Nonlinear Optimal Regulators With Stability Guarantee
authors: Hikaru Hoshino
publish: IEEE Control Systems Letters
abstract: This letter proposes a gradient-based control co-design method for nonlinear optimal regulator problems, where physical design parameters and feedback controllers are optimized simultaneously. The proposed method is based on Galerkin approximations of the Hamilton–Jacobi–Bellman equation in a policy iteration framework. The key idea is to evaluate closed-loop performance as the expected cost over a prescribed distribution of initial states, which enables sensitivity analysis and gradient-based updates of the design parameters, while the controller is improved through policy iteration. As a result, the proposed method overcomes restrictive structural assumptions such as system equivalence, thereby avoiding conservatism and allowing flexible incorporation of design-dependent costs. Moreover, closed-loop stability is ensured at every iteration of the co-design procedure by embedding a recursive admissibility verification that combines two complementary Lyapunov conditions. The effectiveness of the proposed method is demonstrated through an example of a load positioning system.

title: Learning to Detect Sleep Micro-Events from Coarse Sleep Stage Annotations
authors: Chenhao Wang, Yan Pei, Jing Hu, Chengyang Han, Jiahui Xu, Lisan Zhang, Feng Yu, Bo Jin, Wei Luo
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Sleep micro-events, such as sleep spindles and K-complexes, are closely associated with neurological cognitive functions. While artificial intelligence (AI)-assisted sleep micro-event detection provides automated annotation to reduce reliance on labor-intensive expert labeling, current supervised approaches require precisely annotated datasets that remain scarce in clinical practice. To overcome this data bottleneck, this paper introduces a Weakly Supervised Sleep Micro-Event Detector (WSSMED) that leverages readily available coarse sleep stage annotations. The proposed WSSMED features a dual-branch architecture, consisting of a wave prototype module and a cluster module, designed to capture the fine-grained sleep micro-event patterns experts rely on for sleep staging. This framework infers expert logic from coarse annotations while mitigating performance degradation caused by annotation inconsistencies arising from inter-rater variability. Experiments conducted on two public datasets and one clinical dataset demonstrate that WSSMED achieves state-of-the-art performance in detecting sleep spindles and K-complexes, as evaluated at both sample-level and event-level in terms of precision, recall and F1-score metrics. Furthermore, subject-level evaluation demonstrates that the density and duration of micro-events detected by WSSMED-key metrics linked to cognitive function and neurological status-align more closely with expert annotations than those of other reported methods. These results highlight the clinical potential of WSSMED for reliable sleep micro-event analysis.

title: CWPS: Efficient Channel-Wise Parameter Sharing for Knowledge Transfer
authors: Mingxuan Cui, Tao Wu, Xuewei Li, Cunzheng Wang, Gaoang Wang, Chenyi Zhuang, Jinjie Gu, Xiubo Liang, Xi Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Image Processing
abstract: Knowledge transfer aims to apply existing knowledge to different tasks or new data, and it has extensive applications in multi-domain and Multi-Task Learning. The key to this task is quickly identifying a fine-grained object for knowledge sharing and efficiently transferring knowledge. Current methods, such as fine-tuning, layer-wise parameter sharing, and task-specific adapters, only offer coarse-grained sharing solutions and struggle to effectively search for shared parameters, thus hindering the performance and efficiency of knowledge transfer. To address these issues, we propose Channel-Wise Parameter Sharing (CWPS), a novel fine-grained parameter-sharing method for knowledge transfer, which is efficient for parameter sharing, comprehensive, and plug-and-play. For the coarse-grained problem, we first achieve fine-grained parameter sharing by refining the granularity of shared parameters from the level of layers to the level of neurons. The knowledge learned from previous tasks can be utilized through the explicit composition of the model neurons. Besides, we promote an effective search strategy to minimize computational costs, simplifying the selection of shared weights. In addition, our CWPS has strong composability and generalization ability, which theoretically can be applied to any network consisting of linear and convolution layers. We introduce several datasets in both Incremental Learning and Multi-Task Learning scenarios. Our method has achieved state-of-the-art precision-to-parameter ratio performance with various backbones, demonstrating its efficiency and versatility.

title: An Adaptive Optimization Regulation Method for Neutron Spectrum Based on Reinforcement Learning
authors: Chenglong Cao, Pei Cao, Xin Xu, Hongdou Yao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Nuclear Science
abstract: The regulation and control of neutron transport behavior is crucial to the design and development of nuclear energy systems and the application of nuclear technology. The accurate and efficient regulation of neutrons to satisfy the specific needs of neutron experimental environments is an urgent challenge to be solved. The traditional forward neutron spectrum regulation method based on artificial designing could hardly meet the demands of high accuracy and high efficiency at the same time. In this research, an adaptive optimization regulation method for neutron spectrum based on reinforcement learning was developed. The proposed method designed different types of standardized response modules and calibrated it with their corresponding multi-dimensional response matrix calculated by the Monte Carlo program. Through the proximal policy optimization (PPO) algorithm outputs the selection and layout of the response module, and generates the optimal scheme that conforms to the target neutron spectrum by the process of continuous interaction with the environment and self-game. The 14MeV single-energy neutron source was used to verify the regulated results of the proposed method on the tritium breeder blanket of a fusion reactor (ITER) whose results showed that the accuracy of the proposed method was improved by 39.31% compared to the forward manual experiment.

title: OwnershipTracker: a Visual Analytics Approach to Uncovering Historical Book Ownership Patterns
authors: Yiwen Xing, Meilai Ji, Cristina Dondi, Alfie Abdul-Rahman
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: Ownership relationships of early printed books from the 15th century reveal complex patterns of distribution and possession, offering valuable insights for historical research. This paper presents OwnershipTracker, a visual analytics application developed to explore and trace these relationships using data from the Material Evidence in Incunabula (MEI) database. OwnershipTracker integrates bibliographic records, copy-specific data, and book provenance and ownership details, enabling users to uncover intricate ownership sequences over time. The application combines several visualization techniques, including network graphs to map connections between owners, timelines for temporal analysis, chord diagrams to quantify transfer patterns, and a distinctive, collaboratively designed spiderweb-like diagram highlighting converging and dispersing ownership transfers through specific owners. Developed iteratively with input from historical book researchers, the application underwent multiple refinements to align with domain research requirements. A summative evaluation with domain experts showcased the tool's ability to address the defined requirements and tasks. The final version of OwnershipTracker is deployed and accessible at: https://booktracker.nms.kcl.ac.uk/ownership.

title: Design of Wideband Real-time Decimation Filter for Spectrum Analysis in 20GSPS Mixed Domain Oscilloscope
authors: Ruiyuan Ming, Peng Ye, Kuojun Yang, Zhixiang Pan, Xuetao Liu, Wuhuang Huang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Spectrum analysis is widely used in the communication and radar areas, it plays a great role in ensuring the operational reliability of these systems. The traditional spectrum analysis method is based on analog mixing and digital fast Fourier transform (FFT), which has the problem of incompatibility between wide analysis bandwidth and high frequency resolution due to the bandwidth restriction of analog devices and operation speed of digital circuits. It is a challenge to achieve wideband spectrum analysis and high frequency resolution simultaneously for high sampling rate signals of tens of gigabit samples per second (GSPS). First, high-throughput is required to process the high sampling rate signals. Second, massive resource consumption is required to perform long-length FFT when high frequency resolution is required. To overcome these problems, a spectrum analysis structure based on high-speed acquisition and parallel hierarchical decimation filter is proposed. High speed acquisition provides wide Nyquist bandwidth, by processing the sampled signals in parallel way, wide analysis band can be achieved. Moreover, parallel decimation filter is designed to perform high-ratio decimation and anti-aliasing process, which is utilized to effectively improves the frequency resolution. A parallel feedforward cascaded integrator comb (PFCIC) method is proposed to improve the throughput of the decimation filter, and a reconstructed polyphase halfband (RPH) method is designed to reduce the resource consumption. Experimental results demonstrate that an analysis bandwidth of 8 GHz is achieved, and the maximal frequency resolution is 17 Hz. The designed PFCIC filter achieves a throughput of 20 GSPS, which is 2.7 times higher than the existing methods, and no multiplier resources are consumed. The multiplier resource consumption of the designed decimation filter based on the RPH method has been reduced by 75%.

title: Co-Optimization Technology for Nonlinear Behavior Consistency and Efficiency/Linearity of Power Amplifiers
authors: Zhenyu Li, Zhijiang Dai, Zhiqing Liu, Zhipeng Hu, Junchao Wang, Weimin Shi, Jingzhou Pang, Shengdong Hu, Mingyu Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: In massive multiple-input–multiple-output (MIMO) systems, circuit differences among power amplifiers (PAs) lead to poor nonlinear behavior consistency. This makes it difficult to linearize multiple PAs with shared digital predistortion (DPD). Pre-tuning circuit differences and improving circuit performance with low-power, low-cost analog devices is a desirable method. This article proposes a technology for the co-optimization of nonlinear behavior consistency and efficiency/linearity of PAs. This technology uses the passive adjustable mismatch network to fine-tune the load impedance of PAs. Two strategies are proposed for configuring network parameters. Their contribution is to achieve co-optimization, as well as fast selection of network parameters. In the theoretical part, a numerical model is presented to demonstrate the mechanism of tuning circuit differences. Based on simulation and test, the relationship between nonlinear behavior consistency, efficiency, and linearity, as well as the impact of circuit differences on them, is pointed out. At the same time, an efficient co-optimization method is proposed. The feasibility of this method is verified by numerical simulation and test of nine Doherty PAs from the same batch. In the test, when the shared DPD signal excites multiple PAs, the maximum improvement in adjacent channel power ratio (ACPR) is 7.73 dB; when the original signal excites multiple PAs, the maximum improvement in efficiency and normalized mean square error (NMSE) is 7.25% and 4.12 dB, respectively. In addition, this technology shows excellent adaptability in the dynamic carrier frequency range of 2340–2480 MHz.

title: Restoring-free Transposable eDRAM-based Computing-In-Memory System for SNN On-chip Unsupervised STDP Learning
authors: Chanyeong Choi, Novi Prihatiningrum, Yeongkyo Seo
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: This paper proposes an embedded dynamic random-access memory (eDRAM) computing-in-memory (CIM)-based spiking neural network (SNN) processor for on-chip unsupervised learning. First, a novel transposable 3T-1C eDRAM bitcell was presented, offering a reduced area footprint with respect to previously reported CIM bitcells. The proposed bitcell enhances energy efficiency by leveraging its compatibility with the spike-timing-dependent plasticity (STDP) algorithm. Second, restoring-free access technique can be implemented through the instant weight-update operation, enabled by the read-calculate-write sequence in the learning operation. Third, to maximize the property of restoring-free accesses, a novel sense amplifier was employed, enhancing energy efficiency by 27% during the learning operation. Finally, a leaky integrate-and-fire bitline (LIF_BL) was proposed, eliminating the need for power-hungry ADCs by exploiting the characteristics of an SNN. The mixed-signal neuron model was implemented through a simple subtraction and counting method, increasing accuracy and energy efficiency. The proposed computing-in-eDRAM-based SNN processor was implemented using the 28 nm CMOS process, and 89.4% classification accuracy was achieved using the MNIST dataset, consuming 0.15 nJ/pixel of energy with an area of 0.57 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>.

title: ICOA 2025 Cover Page
authors: N/A
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)

title: Imitation Learning for Multiobjective Optimization&#x2014;AlphaMOEA_supp1-3630825.pdf
authors: Gary G Yen
publish: N/A
abstract: In the last decade, a variety of multiobjective evolutionary algorithms (MOEAs) with specific enhancements have been developed for solving multiobjective optimization problems (MOPs). In this article, unlike MOEAs, we provide a new artificial intelligence approach to solve MOPs, which adopts an imitation learning-based end-to-end method, namely AlphaMOEA. AlphaMOEA is entirely a model composed of neural networks that mainly follow the architecture of multitask learning (MTL). It has two training stages: the supervised learning (SL) stage and the reinforcement learning (RL) stage. In the SL stage, AlphaMOEA fits the solutions in the decision space provided by a number of selected MOEAs. Since neural networks in AlphaMOEA are composed of parameters with high dimensions, the fitting process can be viewed as a transformation of the solutions from a low-dimensional space into a high-dimensional space. This allows AlphaMOEA to obtain different valuable knowledge from a perspective of high dimensionality. Then, AlphaMOEA is trained in the RL stage to obtain good performance for MOPs with various problem characteristics in a self-driven manner. The RL stage relies on several designed components, including a similarity-based state design to measure the distance between solutions, an evolution operator-based action set to provide exploration behavior, and an indicator-guided reward to produce an incremental evaluation. Experimental results demonstrate that AlphaMOEA can learn valuable information about the decision space in high-dimensional representations, thereby achieving a desirable balance between exploration and exploitation. AlphaMOEA can further improve the performance for solving MOPs with various problem characteristics in a reasonable time.

title: Federated Learning-Enabled Digital Twins for Privacy-Preserving Cardiovascular Disease Detection in Consumer Electronics
authors: Soufiane Ben Othman, Chinmay Chakraborty, Saranjit Singh, Mohamed Amine Frikha
publish: IEEE Transactions on Consumer Electronics
abstract: Digital Twins (DTs) hold transformative potential for precision cardiology by enabling patient-specific modeling of coronary hemodynamics, electrophysiological dynamics, and myocardial mechanics through multi-modal data fusion. However, their clinical deployment is impeded by critical challenges: privacy vulnerabilities in centralized data aggregation, computational inefficiency of high-fidelity simulations, algorithmic bias across demographic cohorts, and lack of robustness in distributed environments. To address these limitations, we propose QuantumFedDT-CVD, a quantum-enhanced, federated learning-enabled digital twin framework for privacy-preserving cardiovascular disease detection using consumer-grade electronics. The framework enables decentralized training across edge and clinical systems, integrating real-time physiological signals with electronic health records, genomic profiles, and medical imaging, without exchanging raw patient data. At its core, QuantumFedDT-CVD employs physics-informed quantum-variational neural operators to model non-Markovian cardiovascular dynamics with O(n log n) spectral efficiency. Evaluated on the UK Biobank cohort augmented with real-world data from 500 CVD patients, QuantumFedDT-CVD achieves an AUC-ROC of 0.94 for early adverse event prediction and a Dice score of 0.92 for cardiac segmentation. It operates at 4.2 × 108 FLOPs/round, 0.8 MB/round communication overhead, and 550 J/round energy consumption under-differential privacy. The system scales to 200 institutions, tolerates up to 40% Byzantine clients, and demonstrates a measured quantum advantage factor of 3.8, paving the way for efficient, secure, and equitable remote cardiovascular monitoring.

title: CPERE 2025 Contributor Page
authors: N/A
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Power Electronics and Renewable Energy (CPERE)

title: Vehicle and Human Classifications Based on FMCW Radar Using Point Cloud Data with a PointCNN Approach
authors: Alif Rizky Dimandani, Fiky Y. Suratman, Istiqomah
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Information Technology, Computer, and Electrical Engineering (ICITACEE)
abstract: Traditional camera-based object recognition has limitations for traffic monitoring due to environmental conditions and privacy concerns. Although radar technology offers a promising alternative, conventional systems often focus on tracking object movement rather than classifying object types. This study addresses these challenges by utilizing point cloud data generated by FMCW radar, processed using the PointCNN deep learning model, to improve the simultaneous classification of humans, cars, and motorcycles, achieving an overall accuracy of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 8. 8 1 \%}$</tex>. The key components of this study include data standardization through the bootstrap method, which ensures consistent input for the PointCNN architecture. Additionally, a 20 -timestamp windowing technique is employed to capture temporal dependencies in the point cloud data. The results demonstrate a significant improvement in the robustness and accuracy of radar-based classification in real-world environments, making the PointCNN model suitable for traffic monitoring.

title: Parameter Sensitivity Analysis of Dynamic Response of Vibration Receiving Structure of Encased Differential Planetary Train
authors: Miaomiao Li, Bingbing Qin, Xiaojie Yuan, Xuehui Yang, Qinwen Liu, Rupeng Zhu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: The reducer housing will experience the vibration produced by the gear meshing in the encased differential planetary train. Determining the vibration receiving structure of vibration transmission and analyzing the sensitivity of its parameters can enable researchers to control the parameters with high sensitivity. In this paper, the time-varying meshing stiffness and error equivalent displacement generated during gear meshing are used as intrinsic excitations to systematically analyse the vibration-receiving structure of the encased differential planetary gear to reveal its dynamic characteristics and vibration response mechanism. The state equation of the encased differential planetary train is then used to create the first-order trajectory sensitivity model. The first-order trajectory sensitivity function amplitude is defined as the first sensitivity indicator S1, and the sensitivity change corresponding to the increase in the percentage of the parameter is defined as the peak sensitivity indicator S2 and the mean sensitivity indicator S3, respectively. Based on this, the sensitivity histograms of each parameter concerning the response of the vibration receiving mechanism under the three indicators are obtained. The results show that the sensitivity index of the system mesh damping parameter is much larger compared with the mesh stiffness parameter when the parameter unit value is changed, the peak sensitivity index and the mean sensitivity index have high similarity when the parameter percentage is changed.

title: Disentangled Cycle-Translation Framework for Medical Image Anomaly Detection
authors: Yiyang Zhou, Zhifeng Hao, Yonglin Xu, Yuguang Yan, Ruichu Cai
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Complex Medical Engineering (CME)
abstract: Anomaly detection in medical imaging is essential but often limited by the need for costly, pixel-level annotations. Weakly-supervised methods using sample-level labels offer a scalable alternative and have gained traction, especially with the use of generative models for image synthesis and distribution learning. These models typically convert abnormal samples into healthy ones and identify anomalies via residuals, but they often miss disease-specific features and distort anatomical structures. To address this, we propose a novel weakly-supervised approach that disentangles anatomical and disease-related features using an encoder and reconstructs images with a conditional decoder, allowing precise control over both aspects. Our method achieves superior results on the BraTS2021 and MSLUB datasets, outperforming existing models in anomaly detection.

title: Extraction of Microvibration Signals from Ultra-High Voltage Transformer Structure Based on Fast Template Matching Technique
authors: Qingtai Fu, Jian Qin, Taiping Wang, Hongqiang Gao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: The development of high-speed camera and computer technology enables the vision-based displacement extraction technique to be used for vibration signal acquisition of UHV transformer body. In this study, a contactless vibration monitoring technology for UHV transformers is innovatively proposed to meet the demand of non-destructive testing of the mechanical condition of UHV transformers. The hardware part of the system is centered on a high-speed camera equipped with a zoom lens and is equipped with a computer to form a complete monitoring unit. At the algorithmic level, firstly, based on the template matching fusion rhombus search strategy, the computation amount of each picture matching is reduced by a dozen times to dozens of times compared with the traditional global search, and secondly, the surface fitting method is adopted to realize the sub-pixel accuracy displacement resolution calculation. After MATLAB simulation verification, the proposed technique can realize accurate sub-pixel accuracy displacement measurement, with the advantages of high detection accuracy, fast speed and strong robustness. Field tests show that the method successfully captures the axial vibration signals of UHV transformer bushings, and its Fourier spectrum accurately analyzes the characteristic harmonic components such as 100Hz, 200Hz and 300Hz. Compared with the traditional detection methods, this technology can realize the long-distance, full-field, real-time online monitoring of UHV transformers, and provide a new way for intelligent substation equipment condition assessment.

title: Modular Multilevel Converter Submodule Protection Scheme Based on Pulse Signal Accumulation Values
authors: Yajin Wang, Dahai Zhang, Xiaochen Hu, Jiahong Lai
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: Modular multilevel converter has a large number of submodules, and the submodule protection and its fault location scheme are less studied. Aiming at this problem, this paper proposes a Modular multilevel converter submodule protection scheme based on the cumulative value of pulse signals. First, the characteristics of different types of submodule faults are analysed. On this basis, a fault detection scheme is constructed using the cumulative value of the number of pulse signal changes of the submodule switching tube. Subsequently, a switching tube fault type identification and fault localisation scheme is constructed using the submodule capacitance voltage and pulse signals. Finally, a double-ended flexible direct current transmission system model is constructed in Matlab/Simulink, and the simulation results show that the proposed protection scheme can quickly identify various submodule faults, and the protection scheme has high reliability and sensitivity.

title: Machine Learning-Based Classification of SSVEP at 40Hz Induced by Diverse Optical Parameters
authors: Xiaokun Jin, Yong Zhou, Mingzhe Fei, Yue Zhao, Fuze Tian, Bin Hu, Yizhou Tan, Lixian Zhu
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Complex Medical Engineering (CME)
abstract: Steady-state visual evoked potentials (SSVEP) have been extensively employed in brain-computer interfaces (BCI) using frequency modulation. While low-frequency SSVEP boasts a high signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) and robust stability, it is associated with poor visual comfort. Conversely, high-frequency SSVEP offers enhanced visual comfort but suffers from a lower SNR. In this study, we record and analyze 50 instances of high-frequency SSVEP at $\mathbf{4 0 H z}$, varying optical parameters such as illuminance, color temperature, and light source area. To achieve a precise classification of the electroencephalogram (EEG) signal, we test nine machine learning (ML) classifiers. Notably, the extreme random tree (ERT) classifier demonstrated an impressive classification accuracy of $\mathbf{9 2. 8 3 \%}$. Additionally, we employee SHapley Additive exPlanation (SHAP) for interpretability analysis of the ML results. Our findings indicate that the $\boldsymbol{\beta}$ band of the power spectral density (PSD) predominantly contributes to the classification accuracy. These results reveal the SSVEP response characteristics of different light parameters at 40 Hz. The interpretability analysis helps to build a more efficient stimulation paradigm and parameter selection mechanism, providing theoretical support for the individualization and high robustness of the BCI system.

title: A Data Segmentation Method for Airborne Bistatic SAR Based on Spatial Variability Analysis
authors: Feng Ye, Jing Ding, Yufeng Wu, Yuchen Lin, Shuangxi Zhang
publish: 2024 5th China International SAR Symposium (CISS)
abstract: The range-azimuth two-dimensional spatial variability of airborne bistatic SAR echo data increases the complexity of echo data processing. Data block processing can reduce the spatial variability within each block, allowing the simplification of imaging algorithms by neglecting the variability during the imaging process. Based on the general geometric configuration of airborne bistatic SAR, this paper first derives the range walk and range curvature of any point in the observed scene. Distance displacement correction is performed at any point in the scene relative to a reference point. Then, based on the residual range displacement, second -order phase errors, and their impact on imaging, the criteria for data block segmentation of airborne bistatic SAR echo data are determined. Finally, through simulation, the data block segmentation results for airborne bistatic SAR with different configurations are obtained. Compared with data block methods proposed for specific configurations, the method presented in this paper can be applied to airborne bistatic SAR of any configuration, thus offering a broader range of applications.

title: From Engineering Electromagnetics to Electromagnetic Engineering
authors: L. Sevgi
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Technologies, Systems and Services in Telecommunications (TELSIKS)
abstract: Electromagnetic (EM) fields/waves play critical and significant roles in our lives. Systems such as communication, remote sensing, integrated command/ control/surveillance, intelligent & fast transportation use EM waves. Also, EM waves are used in medicine, environment, education, marketing, and defense. Among many others, EM engineering deals with broad range of problems from antenna design to EM scattering, indoor-outdoor radiowave propagation to wireless communication ($4 \mathrm{G}, 5 \mathrm{G}, 6 \mathrm{G}, \ldots$), radar systems, subsurface imaging, novel materials, EM compatibility, electroacoustic and/or electro-optical systems, etc. The frequencies vary from DC to Terahertz, even above, systems’ sizes vary from kilometers-large to nanometers-small. Most of these systems are broadband and digital, and they have to function close to many others therefore they create severe EM interference (EMI) and EM Compatibility (EMC) problems. As many others, EMC problems also must be taken into account by engineers from the earliest possible design stages. Establishing an intelligent balance among theory, practice, and modeling and numerical simulation has become essential.

title: Fault Diagnosis Method for Harmonic Reducer Based on Federated Prototype Domain Adaptation
authors: Yulin Sun, Shouqiang Kang, Hongyuan Zhu, Yujing Wang, Wenmin Lv
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: To tackle the issue of significant variations in harmonic reducer data distribution across multiple users under different operating conditions, as well as the sparsity of labeled data under certain working conditions, a federated prototype domain adaptation approach is proposed for harmonic reducer fault diagnosis. Class prototypes are employed as carriers for feature alignment, and a prototype interaction mechanism is proposed in this method. It ensures efficient knowledge transfer across all users while preserving user data privacy. This enhances the model diagnostic performance across multiple operating conditions. Additionally, a prototype-guided training strategy is designed to optimize user local model training. Finally, multiple comparative experiments are conducted on a self-built experimental platform using harmonic reducer data. The results illustrate that the federated prototype domain adaptation improves diagnostic accuracy on target domain by at least 6.81% compared to existing federated domain adaptation methods.

title: An Electromagnetic Induction Sensor with Load-Bearing and Structural Crack Monitoring Capabilities
authors: Shuyang He, Biao Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: In response to the need for monitoring cracks around aircraft bolt and rivet holes, this study proposes and develops an electromagnetic induction sensor that combines load-bearing and structural crack monitoring capabilities. The sensor's layout is designed, and its working principle is explained. Using laser engraving, anodic oxidation and physical vapor deposition (PVD) processes, the sensor is fabricated. Experimental results demonstrate that the sensor can detect fatigue cracks of 0.8 mm in length around structural holes under bolt assembly and structural fatigue loads, confirming its effectiveness.

title: Four Port Converter for Electric Vehicle Charging Stations
authors: Nader Younis, Tarek Younis, Mahmoud A. Gaafar, Mohamed Orabi, Omar Abdel-Rahim
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Power Electronics and Renewable Energy (CPERE)
abstract: The rapid adoption of electric vehicles (EVs) necessitates efficient and scalable charging station architectures. This paper presents a comprehensive comparative analysis of three structures for EV charging stations: a microgrid-based solution, an isolated four-port converter with separate photovoltaic (PV) and battery energy storage (BES) ports, and an integrated fourport solution featuring two dedicated ports for EVs. The comparison focuses on the number of components, isolation requirements, and operational efficiency, with particular emphasis on ensuring compliance with international safety standards for port isolation. A detailed discussion of the isolation requirements for each port is provided to highlight their implications for safety and system design. Simulation results validate the operational feasibility of each topology, demonstrating the trade-offs among component count, isolation strategies, and system performance. This analysis provides actionable insights into designing compact and costeffective EV charging stations with dual EV connectivity.

title: Analysis of Space Configuration of the Same Orbit on Positioning Performance in Bistatic SAR Satellites
authors: Qing Lu, Junjian Wen, Yanyang Liu
publish: 2024 5th China International SAR Symposium (CISS)
abstract: This article presents a comprehensive analysis of the influence of spatial configuration on the positioning performance of space-based bistatic synthetic aperture radar (BiSAR) satellites. Given the significance of Bistatic SAR systems in applications such as target recognition, ground moving target indication (GMTI), and digital elevation measurement (DEM), geometric positioning accuracy has emerged as a critical metric for evaluating system performance. The study initially establishes a Bistatic SAR earth observation modell, encompassing the range equation, Doppler equation, and Earth's ellipsoid model, thereby establishing a foundation for the subsequent analysis of positioning accuracy. Furthermore, this paper delineates and scrutinizes the impact of various error sources across the entire link on the geometric positioning accuracy of Bistatic SAR. These sources include the position and velocity measurement errors of the transmitting and receiving satellites, signal propagation delay errors, Doppler central frequency errors, and ground elevation errors. Through theoretical analysis and simulation calculations, this paper employs the LuTan-l satellite as the transmitting satellite to assess the geometric positioning accuracy of the Bistatic SAR system under different spatial configurations of the receiving satellite in the same orbit. It also discusses the impact of different error sources on positioning accuracy. The research findings suggest that elevation errors have a substantial impact on positioning accuracy, followed by signal propagation delay errors and Doppler central frequency errors. Additionally, the study reveals that when the target point is in the direct lateral view and the oblique side view of the transmitting satellite, the difference in the mean anomaly angle between the receiving satellite and the transmitting satellite has minimal effect on positioning accuracy. Furthermore, the farther the target point is from the transmitting satellite, the poorer the positioning accuracy becomes. The accuracy of the theoretical model is further corroborated through simulation analysis, offering invaluable insights for the subsequent design and optimization of Bistatic SAR systems.

title: Research and Application of Multi-dimensional Data Statistical Analysis Method for Multi-energy Complementary Integrated Dispatching System
authors: Ruiheng Wang, Weijie Wang, Ling Ji, Tingfang Tan
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: In response to the complex dispatching demands of new energy bases under the new power system, this study designs a multi-dimensional data statistical analysis method for a multi-energy complementary integrated dispatching system based on energy internet theory and system optimization theory. This method achieves coordinated dispatching of multiple energy forms such as wind, solar, hydro, thermal, and storage by constructing a full-chain analysis system covering data modeling, functional application, and visualization display. Specifically, it establishes a three-level statistical model for annual, monthly, and daily time dimensions, and a three-layer analysis framework for base-level, resource-level, and station-level spatial dimensions. Data quality is ensured through data cleaning, standardized conversion, and distributed storage technologies. Five core functions, including power generation statistics and real-time load monitoring, are realized using cumulative algorithms and confidence interval analysis.Empirical analysis shows that after applying this method at the Qinghai Delingha New Energy Base, the wind curtailment rate dropped from 15% to 5%, the solar curtailment rate dropped from 12% to 3%, the overall energy utilization efficiency increased by 13 percentage points, and the dispatching decision response time was shortened by 40%, validating the scientific and engineering practicality of the method.

title: Innovative design of frequency reconfigurable antenna using metaheuristic algorithms based on neural networks
authors: Rajaa Amellal, Abdelkader Hadjoudja
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: In this paper, a novel method of optimization is achieved to determine the optimal design of a reconfigurable antenna inspired by methodology to design frequency reconfigurable patch antennas using multi-objective genetic algorithms (MOGA) and recurrent neural networks trained by genetic algorithm applied to ensure efficient performance of antenna parameters (reflection coefficient S11 and gain G). Cost function of nondominated sorting genetic algorithm II (NGSA- II) operate global optimization and resolve the complication due to diversity of multiple solutions in order to surrogate a model optimized concerning different resonant frequencies. Experimental validation of the Pareto-optimal set to reduce the spread of solutions of performant parameters is also provided, the comparison of simulated and optimized results demonstrating a new optimization technique applied to recon figurate patch antenna.

title: 3D Landmarks and Dynamic Emotions for Classroom Engagement Analysis: A Unified GNN-Transformer Model with FLAME Blendshapes
authors: Fatima Zahra Jobbid, Aissam Berrahou, Hassan Berbia
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: Student engagement analysis remains pivotal for enhancing educational outcomes, yet existing methods struggle with holistic assessment in classroom environments. This paper introduces a unified GNN-Transformer architecture leveraging FLAME 3D facial landmarks and dynamic emotion modeling for multidimensional engagement analysis. Our approach processes 5,023 vertices from FLAME blendshapes through graph attention networks to capture spatial relationships, while transformer encoders model temporal engagement dynamics. A novel cross-modal attention mechanism fuses spatial-temporal representations to jointly predict behavioral engagement, affective states, and cognitive load. The central idea introduced in this work is the development of a deep learning pipeline that integrates FLAME-based 3D facial dynamics with a joint GNN-Transformer and cross-modal attention framework to enable accurate, robust, and simultaneous, physiologically-grounded prediction of multiple diverse student engagement dimensions. Validated on the DAD-3DHeads dataset, our method demonstrates strong generalization and performance in real-world classroom scenarios, offering significant improvements over conventional 2D approaches through its physiologically-grounded 3D representation.

title: An Analysis of Powertrain Efficiency Using a Two-Level and a Three-Level Inverter
authors: Ahmed Sayed Soliman, Abdelrahman Sobhy Qamr, Amr Abbas, Hadhiq Khan, Mohamed Taha
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Power Electronics and Renewable Energy (CPERE)
abstract: This study evaluates the efficiency of an electric vehicle powertrain using both 2-level and 3-level voltage source inverters. A brushless electrically excited synchronous machine (EESM) is used as the traction motor, and the comparison is conducted across a wide range of operating conditions. The motor’s copper losses were found to be nearly identical under both inverter topologies. However, the core losses were significantly lower when operating with the 3-level inverter. This reduction is attributed to the decreased harmonic content in the machine’s line current, which is a characteristic advantage of the 3-level topology. On the inverter side, the 2-level topology exhibited lower losses compared to the 3-level, primarily due to the fewer switching devices involved. When evaluating the overall system efficiency, including both the motor and the inverter, the 3-level inverter demonstrated slightly higher powertrain efficiency across most of the operating range, with the exception of low-speed regions where the 2-level inverter showed marginally better performance.

title: Optimizing Inter-Provincial Power Transmission Efficiency Scheduling Strategies under Triple-Market Dynamics: An NSGA-II-Based Model Integrating Electricity, Carbon, and Green Certificate Policies
authors: Zhiyun Hu, Yunpeng Xiao, Haiqiong Yi, Lang Zhao, Xueying Wang, Hongyang Liu, Zhiyu Wang, Ruixiang Li, Fengying Yang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: Establishing an optimal decision-making model for inter-provincial power delivery based on internal and external market dynamics to maximize the energy utilization rate of cross-provincial/cross-regional transmission channels represents a research objective of significant importance. Integrating the policy requirements of carbon quota and green certificate markets, an optimization model for inter-provincial power delivery decisions is formulated with the dual objectives of maximizing renewable energy delivery power and maximizing transmission channel utilization. The Non-dominated Sorting Genetic Algorithm II (NSGA-II) is subsequently employed to solve this optimization model. Case study validation demonstrates that the proposed model effectively captures the influence of market policies and measures on the operational efficiency of power generation enterprises and inter-provincial transmission channels.

title: Design and Analysis of Harmonic Tag with RF Energy Harvesting Circuit
authors: Aleksandra B. Đorić, Aleksandar S. Atanasković, Tijana Ž. Dimitrijević, Nataša P. Maleš Ilić
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Technologies, Systems and Services in Telecommunications (TELSIKS)
abstract: In this paper, the design and analysis of a harmonic tag with an RF energy harvesting circuit is performed. In the first research stage, a low power passive harmonic tag has been designed at $\mathbf{2. 4 5 / 4. 9 ~ G H z}$ whose main function is to receive the fundamental signal and transmit harmonics. In the second stage, an RF energy harvesting circuit is designed at 2.45 GHz by using voltage doubler RF rectifier. Additionally, a diplexer was inserted between the harmonic tag and the RF energy harvesting circuit to separate the fundamental signal from the second harmonic. Impedance matching is performed between the antennas and the harmonic tag, as well as between the harmonic tag and the RF rectifier, with aim to obtain maximum power transfer. Results accomplished by ADS simulations for different input power levels provide a performance evaluation of the harmonic tag and the RF energy harvesting circuit in terms of RF-DC conversion efficiency, DC power, and second harmonic power. For the observed input power levels (-20 dBm to 10 dBm), the gained RF-DC conversion efficiency varies between $7 \%$ and $17 \%$, the output DC voltage varies between 0.1 V and 3.6 V, while the second harmonic power goes from $\mathbf{- 6 1} \mathbf{~ d B m}$ to $\mathbf{- 3} \mathbf{~ d B m}$.

title: Research on Sensor Fault Isolation Method for Transmission Systems Based on Convolutional Autoencoder
authors: Rui Li, Ran Jia, Tao Chen, Ao Wu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: Transmission systems are typically employed in industrial scenarios characterized by high loads, prolonged continuous operation, or complex environmental interference. Under such conditions, internal sensors are prone to faults such as stuck, constant deviation, constant gain, and mutation faults during long-term operation. These faults can distort monitoring data and pose significant threats to system reliability.
