To address the limitations of traditional methods in isolating faults under high-dimensional, nonlinear dynamic data and concurrent multi-type failures, this paper proposes a sensor fault isolation method that integrates a Convolutional Autoencoder (CAE), attention mechanism, and Support Vector Machine (SVM). Specifically, the CAE is first employed to autonomously extract spatiotemporal features from sensor time-series data through unsupervised learning. Then, an attention mechanism is incorporated to dynamically enhance critical fault-related features while suppressing noise, thereby significantly improving feature discriminability. Finally, the SVM is utilized for precise classification and isolation of sensor faults owing to its strong nonlinear decision capabilities. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves an average accuracy of 98% and an F1-score of 0.96 in detecting typical faults of pressure, temperature, and rotational speed sensors. Compared to mainstream models such as CNN, SVM, and LSTM, the proposed method improves accuracy by 3.4% to 19.5%, exhibiting clear advantages in both detection accuracy and robustness. This approach offers an effective solution for sensor fault isolation in transmission systems operating under complex conditions.

title: Detection of Auricular Reflex Zones with MultiResUNet-DPDA
authors: Zihao Zhao, Yi Zheng, Qiang He
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Complex Medical Engineering (CME)
abstract: Image segmentation is a key area in computer vision and plays a crucial role in medical image analysis. However, medical images often exhibit complex structures, blurred boundaries, and unevenly distributed tiny targets, which pose greater challenges for segmentation models. To address the task of automatic recognition and detection of auricular reflex zones, this paper proposes an improved medical image segmentation model—MultiResUNet-DPDA. Based on the traditional MultiResUNet, the proposed model introduces dilated convolutions to expand the receptive field, employs ASPP to enhance both global and local feature extraction capabilities, and integrates cross-layer features to optimize semantic transmission in skip connections. Additionally, the ECA attention mechanism is incorporated in the decoder stage to strengthen key feature responses. A combined loss function-DiceCE Loss-that integrates Dice Loss and CrossEntropy Loss is also designed to improve boundary recognition and fine-grained segmentation.The model is evaluated using mIoU, mean accuracy (MA), and F1 score. Experimental results show that compared to YOLOv11, UNet, and MultiResUNet, the proposed model improves mIoU by $12.69 \%, 4.83 \%$, and $1.38 \%$, respectively. These improvements demonstrate enhanced boundary modeling, small object recognition, and generalization in complex backgrounds, validating the model’s superior segmentation performance and application potential.

title: Physics-Informed Neural Networks for Pharmacodynamic Compartment Models of Animal Cell Culture
authors: Yang Liu, Yichen Zhang, Jiaqi Liu, Zhiqiang Ma
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Complex Medical Engineering (CME)
abstract: We apply a physics-informed neural network (PINN) to the classical three-state pharmacodynamic compartment model of animal cell culture, using digitized time-series of vital (V), apoptotic (A), and necrotic (N) cells. The PINN is an eight-layer fully connected network (width 64, tanh) that minimizes a composite loss enforcing data fidelity, ODE residuals, and mass conservation ($\mathbf{V}+\mathbf{A}+\mathbf{N}=\mathbf{1}$), while treating the four transition rates as trainable parameters via automatic differentiation. Literature data (HSB-2 cells under $\mathbf{1 0}^{\mathbf{- 6}} \mathbf{~ M}$ Ara-C) are split $\mathbf{8 0} \boldsymbol{/} \mathbf{2 0}$ into training ($0-56 \mathrm{~h}$) and test ($57-70 \mathrm{~h}$). Trained for $\sim 3$ minutes on an NVIDIA RTX 3080, the PINN achieves a total test MSE of $4.9 \times 10^{-4}$-about $72 \%$ lower than a Runge-Kutta integrator plus Levenberg-Marquardt optimizer (RK-LM)-with $\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}=\mathbf{0. 9 9 5}$ across all states. All four kinetic parameters are recovered within $6 \%$ relative error. Extrapolations to $t \in[70,100]$ h remain physically consistent (non-negativity and conservation), with monotonic increase of N, stabilization of A, and decay of V, and feature $\mathbf{9 5 \%}$ MC-Dropout bands of $\boldsymbol{\pm} \mathbf{2. 5 \%}$ absolute fraction. These results demonstrate that PINNs provide a fast, data-efficient, and robust approach to parameter identification and prediction in multi-state pharmacodynamic systems under small, noisy datasets.

title: A Design of Moving Target Imaging Technology for Distributed SAR with Geosynchronous Illuminator
authors: Yuchen Lin, Min Zhu, Yang Zhang, Shaohui Mei, Shuangxi Zhang, Yuanjie Zhi
publish: 2024 5th China International SAR Symposium (CISS)
abstract: In this paper, an imaging method of distributed synthetic aperture radar (SAR) system with geostationary orbit (GEO) as the transmitting source and near-space orbit (NEO) as the receiving end is proposed to achieve high precision imaging of moving targets. The system uses a single geostationary orbit transmitting platform to transmit signals, and multiple distributed near-space receiving platforms to receive echoes. The radar echoes of different receiving platforms are reconstructed by phase compensation processing, and the reconstructed signals are focused with high precision through RCM correction and compressed sensing (CS). A complete design scheme is proposed from the aspects of configuration design, echo synthesis and imaging algorithm design. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed method is verified by simulation.

title: Design of a Superconducting Sector Dipole Magnet for the High Rigidity Spectrometer at the Facility for Rare Isotope Beams
authors: Junseong Kim, Yoonhyuck Choi, Xiaoji Du, Danlu Zhang, Hengkang Zheng, Shumpei Noji, Mohit Patil, John Wenstrom, Bryan Tousignant, Jeff Hulbert, Hai Nguyen, Yamen Al-Mahmoud, Courtney Smith, Samuel Miller, Nusair Hasan, Jonathon Howard, Rao Ganni, Jie Wei, Ting Xu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Applied Superconductivity
abstract: The High Rigidity Spectrometer (HRS) at the Facility for Rare Isotope Beams (FRIB) requires superconducting magnets to perform momentum analysis of rare isotopes at high beam energies. A key element of the HRS is the superferric Sector dipole magnet called DS2, specifically designed to bend particle beams by 60° with a peak magnetic field of 2 T, enabling operations at a magnetic rigidity of up to 8 Tm, which is essential to support the scientific program at FRIB. The DS2 utilizes a NbTi superconducting conductor embedded within a copper channel and features a robust passive quench protection scheme incorporating cold diodes. Its mechanical structure consists of a warm iron yoke and a 20° pole-face angle, which enables horizontal beam focusing without supplementary quadrupole magnets. This paper details DS2’s electromagnetic performance, coil mechanical forces, conductor stability analysis, quench protection characteristics, and structural considerations, highlighting the critical design methodologies adopted to ensure reliable operation.

title: Solving At-Least Sequence Constraints in Nurse Rostering Problem Using SAT
authors: Hieu Truong Xuan, Quan Nguyen Hong, Nghia Dao Xuan, Tuyen Kieu Van, Khanh To Van
publish: 2025 24th International Symposium on Communications and Information Technologies (ISCIT)
abstract: This paper presents an efficient SAT encoding designed to address “at least” sequence constraints. These constraints are a type of global constraint that have been effectively handled in constraint programming (CP), but remain challenging for SAT-based approaches. Instead of encoding each “at least” cardinality constraint individually, our method encodes sets of these constraints by creating reusable encoding blocks and systematically linking adjacent blocks. This block-based strategy leads to more compact encoding and improves the solver performance for problems with sequence constraints. We evaluated our approach through an experiment on the Nurse Rostering problem. The results demonstrate that our SAT encoding consistently surpasses existing methods in terms of solving time and encoding size. Our work highlights the potential of SATbased techniques for effectively addressing sequence constraints and introduces new possibilities for SAT modeling of sequence constraints.

title: Advanced Multi-Waveform KA-Band Lightweight Multi-Rotor UAV SAR System
authors: Yihai Wei, Pei Wang, Yang Liu, Jinsong Qiu, Yiwei Yue, Kaijiang Xu
publish: 2024 5th China International SAR Symposium (CISS)
abstract: SAR is typically mounted on large aircraft or satellites to obtain remote sensing data. With the rapid development of UAV technology and radar miniaturization, installing SAR on multi-rotor lightweight UAV platforms has gradually become an alternative method for acquiring high-resolution remote sensing data. This paper presents an advanced multi-waveform Ka-band SAR system for lightweight multi-rotor UAV, with waveforms directly generated at intermediate frequency and a maximum bandwidth of 1.2 GHz. The system employs a lightweight passive waveguide slot array antenna, which not only generates high-precision linear frequency modulated signals in real time but also, for the first time, achieves real-time generation of nonlinear frequency modulated signals on a UAV platform. Additionally, it can transmit pre-stored waveforms of interest. The use of advanced technology ensures the radar system's miniaturization and lightweight characteristics. Ground experiments have verified the signal quality and performance of the SAR system.

title: Research and Development of Power Communication Resource Management System Based on Big Data Mining Technology
authors: Chao Chai, Licheng Guo, Shaokun Jia, Songyang Liu, Weikang Kong
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: This paper proposes a big data mining-based power communication resource management system to tackle low scheduling efficiency, slow fault response, and reliability issues in power grids. It builds a unified data platform via multi-source heterogeneous data processing, integrates Spark/Flink frameworks with clustering/fault warning algorithms for link state identification, and adopts optimization scheduling/self-healing strategies to form a "sensing-mining-decision-execution" closed loop. Pilot results show improved resource utilization, response speed, and stability, verifying its application value.

title: Causal Inference-Based Fault Diagnosis and Abnormal Degradation Detection for Aero-Engine
authors: Kunyu Dong, Dan Xu, Zhaoyang Zeng, Qingyu Zhu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: Aero-engine fault diagnosis faces challenges such as low accuracy and weak physical interpretability. Additionally, early anomalies are difficult to identify due to complex thermodynamic couplings and nonlinear degradation patterns. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a causal inference-based method. Physically meaningful derived variables are constructed to reflect the status of subsystems, enabling accurate fault diagnosis with machine learning algorithms. Meanwhile, after computing the Conditional Average Treatment Effect (CATE) of variables related to the performance of engine subsystems, abnormal degradation onsets are detected via the Dynamic Sliding-Window Threshold (DSWT) algorithm. Experiments on the N-CMAPSS dataset validate the effectiveness of the proposed method, demonstrating its capability to accurately identify fault modes with high interpretability and enable early identification of abnormal degradation onsets.

title: Bifurcation-Based Phase Control for Constant-Frequency Operation of a Capacitive Wireless Power Transfer System with Two Receivers
authors: Aris van Ieperen, Stijn Derammelaere, Ben Minnaert
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Power Electronics and Renewable Energy (CPERE)
abstract: This paper presents a control strategy, based on the bifurcation phenomenon, for achieving coupling-independent operation in a capacitive wireless power transfer system with one transmitter and two receivers while maintaining a constant operating frequency. The proposed method relies on dynamically adjusting the compensation capacitances based on the phase angle between the input voltage and current, ensuring the system operates at the desired bifurcation resonance without requiring frequency tuning. The effectiveness of the method is validated through circuit simulations in Simulink, demonstrating that the system maintains stable power transfer and efficiency across a range of coupling coefficients.

title: Mass Imbalance Identification of Wind Turbine Blades Based on Information Fusion of Tower and Main Shaft Vibration Signals
authors: Lei Song, Shiming Wu, Zhixue Cheng, Jinsheng Ren, Xinwei Huang, Yibing Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: Blade mass imbalance in wind turbines generates significant additional centrifugal loads, severely impacting the safety, reliability, and operational lifespan of the units. Current vibration signal-based monitoring methods for rotor mass imbalance, whether using main bearing vibration signals or tower vibration signals, suffer from weak effective information reflecting mass imbalance in the signals, which compromises the monitoring and detection accuracy of blade mass imbalance conditions. To address this issue, this paper proposes a method that combines main bearing vibration and tower vibration information. By calculating the coherent cepstrum of these two signals, interference noise is suppressed, and mass imbalance information within both vibration signals is enhanced, thereby improving the monitoring and detection effectiveness for abnormal blade conditions. Analysis of actual wind turbine monitoring data validates the application efficacy of the proposed method.

title: Research on Data Mining and Analysis of Hydropower Station Monitoring Based on Intelligent System
authors: Rongdi Li, Defang Zheng
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: This study focuses on data mining and analysis of hydropower station monitoring based on intelligent system, aiming to overcome the difficulties of traditional analysis methods in processing complex data. The quantum-inspired neural network algorithm (QNNA) is introduced. The algorithm adopts the concept of quantum bits, expands the neuron state, and strengthens the network parallel processing and information expression capabilities by virtue of the superposition and entanglement of quantum bits. The study selected one year of monitoring data of a large hydropower station, covering multisource information such as equipment operation status and environmental parameters. After pre-processing such as data cleaning, noise reduction and normalization, the training set was divided into 7: 3. The experiment is carried out using Intel Core i7 processor and 16 GB memory. Using Python and TensorFlow, the simulation environment is built. Compared with traditional BP neural network and Decision Tree algorithm, QNNA algorithm is superior in accuracy, recall rate and F1 value. In complex fault prediction scenarios, the QNNA algorithm has an accuracy rate of 93%, a recall rate of 89%, and an F1 value of 91%, effectively mining the complex patterns and potential relationships in the data, providing strong support for the efficient operation and maintenance of hydropower stations.

title: A Matching Method for Unmanned Aerial Vehicle Images and Spaceborne Images Based on LightGlue
authors: Peng Li, Hongwei Xu, Wenqiang Ji, Chuanshuo Cao
publish: 2024 5th China International SAR Symposium (CISS)
abstract: Under conditions where satellite navigation is denied, there is an increased difficulty in matching images from a UAV perspective with spaceborne remote sensing images due to issues such as rotation and scaling. This leads to higher error rates, longer matching processing times, and increased complexity. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a LightGlue-based method for matching UAV images with spaceborne images. The method employs SuperPoint for feature extraction and LightGlue for matching the extracted key point features. Experimental results demonstrate that this method has improved accuracy by 6.69% over the SuperPoint+SuperGlue combination and by 20.89% over traditional SIFT algorithms, proving its validity and effectiveness.

title: MAST: A Multi-Scale Adaptive Swin Transformer for Enhanced Fetal Heart Disease Classification
authors: Luo Jia, Shuyu Hu, Yuhua Zhong, Yi Ding
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Complex Medical Engineering (CME)
abstract: Fetal heart disease diagnosis remains a significant challenge in prenatal medical care, necessitating high-precision and efficient imaging analysis techniques. This study proposes a novel Multi-scale Adaptive Swin Transformer (MAST) framework to address the complexities of fetal cardiac ultrasound image classification. By integrating advanced deep learning strategies, the research introduces a comprehensive approach to automated heart disease identification.The MAST framework combines multi-scale pooling fusion strategies with an adaptive Squeeze-and-Excitation (SE) attention enhancement module, effectively capturing intricate feature representations in cardiac ultrasound images. Experimental validation on a dataset of $\mathbf{1, 6 1 9}$ samples demonstrates the framework’s exceptional performance, achieving $95 \%$ overall accuracy and a macro-averaged F1-score of 0.95. It particularly excels in challenging diagnostic categories, such as single ventricle and left-right ventricular inconsistency, with F1-scores of 0.94 and 0.90, respectively. Compared to existing Vision Transformer and Swin Transformer baselines, this approach significantly advances the state-of-the-art in fetal heart disease image classification.This research not only provides a robust technical solution for intelligent prenatal cardiac diagnosis but also opens new avenues for artificial intelligence applications in medical image analysis.

title: Standardized Virtual Power Plant Dispatch Method for Central Air Conditioning Systems Based on Thermal Modeling
authors: Zhe Li, Huaxiao Yang, Gaoxiang Wu, Yu Zhao, Qian Ai
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: This paper proposes a thermal modeling-based virtual power plant (VPP) dispatch method for central air conditioning systems. Initially, by leveraging the thermal inertia characteristics of air conditioning systems, a virtual energy storage model is constructed to decouple electrical power from cooling load demand. This enables central air conditioning systems to rapidly respond to grid dispatch while maintaining user comfort. Subsequently, a three-tier control architecture comprising dispatch, management, and user layers is established. A two-stage control strategy is implemented for edge terminals: global optimization pre-sets chilled water temperature parameters, while local optimization dynamically adjusts terminal fan power. Finally, targeting grid peak-shaving scenarios, a virtual generation unit (VGU) screening mechanism based on capacity reserve and response duration is proposed to optimize resource allocation. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method effectively enhances the grid interaction capabilities of air conditioning loads, validating the feasibility of aggregating central air conditioning systems as virtual energy storage units for peak-shaving services.

title: A Rolling Bearing Fault Diagnosis Method Based on Multi-scale Feature Extraction and Transfer Learning
authors: Siying Xie, Liang Mei, Shuo Li, Caixia Zhang, Zhifeng Liu, Qiang Qin
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: Intelligent diagnostic algorithms based on deep learning have opened up a new way for rolling bearing fault diagnosis and the effect is obvious, but it is undeniable that most of the research now focuses on the homologous data (i.e., the same working conditions, the same equipment). However, considering the normal working scenarios in actual workshops and factories, the difficulty of implementing intelligent diagnostic algorithms will increase, because in workshops and factories, working conditions and equipment change frequently, and it is difficult to realize the training of intelligent diagnostic algorithms with the same source of data. And in some cases, the collected data is difficult to be labeled resulting in insufficient labels, which requires the intelligent diagnostic algorithm to be able to diagnose faults under different working conditions and equipment. To address the above factors, this research designs a Two-Way One-Dimensional Convolutional Neural Network (2C-1DCNN) based on transfer learning (TL) technique with a Bidirectional Gated Recurrent Unit (BiGRU) and an Attention mechanism (Attention) combined fault diagnosis model (2C-1DCNN-BiGRU-Attention). The model can be directly input the vibration signals of the captured bearings and pre-trained using the source domain data, followed by using the Multiple Kernel Maximum Mean Discrepancy (MK-MMD) to measure the feature distribution distance between the layers of the network in the source and target domains, to determine the migrating and freezing layers of the model, and finally, using a small amount of labeled target domain data for re-training to complete the task of classifying the target domain fault data. labeled target domain data for re-training to complete the task of classifying the fault data in the target domain. After experimental verification, the algorithm has a high diagnostic accuracy and effectively solves the problem of increased difficulty in diagnosing faults in the target domain due to the different distribution of data in the target domain and the source domain and the fact that there is only a very small amount of labeled data due to the difficulty in labeling the data.

title: Transaction Processing in Blockchain Sharding: Current Trends and Future Research Directions
authors: Ramesh Adhikari, Costas Busch, Dariusz R. Kowalski, Abdullah Al-Mamun
publish: Distributed Ledger Technologies: Research and Practice
abstract: Blockchain is known for its promising features, such as decentralization, fault tolerance, transparency, and immutability. Thus, it has been used in many industries and applications, including cryptocurrency, finance, smart cities, healthcare, and manufacturing. However, blockchain suffers from scalability issues and provides low transaction throughput and high latency. Sharding is used to solve these scalability and performance issues by dividing the blockchain network into smaller clusters of nodes called shards, and each shard processes transactions in parallel. However, the sharding protocol is still in its early stages and encounters multiple challenges. In this paper, we survey cutting-edge blockchain sharding papers, mainly focusing on transaction processing aspects such as intra-shard transaction processing, cross-shard communication, and cross-shard transaction processing. We also examine security vulnerabilities and attack vectors associated with sharded blockchain systems. We review existing techniques, highlight key challenges and problems, and suggest potential future research directions.

title: A classification framework for concealed weapon detection using sub-terahertz images: LSTM-based optimized deep neural network
authors: Ebru Efeoğlu, Bahattin Türetken
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Terahertz imaging technology is a promising method for preventing terrorist attacks due to its ability to penetrate various materials and reveal hidden objects without emitting harmful radiation. This study proposes a fast classification framework with high detection accuracy for terahertz imaging systems that can be used to detect hidden weapons on people at airports and other checkpoints. The proposed framework is a hybrid of a deep neural network based on Color Layout Filter (CLF) and LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory). The performance of this neural network, combined with different optimization methods, was compared with classical machine learning techniques. In the performance evaluation, it was found that the deep neural network model using the Adam optimization algorithm outperformed classical machine learning techniques. This proposed neural network achieved 0.8890 accuracy, 0.8992precision, 0.8890recall, 0.8874F-score, and an ROC area of 0.9675after cross-validation.

title: Data-driven Control Optimization on Frequency Response for Fast and Precise Motion of Flexible Joint Robots
authors: Deokjin Lee, Junho Song, Sehoon Oh
publish: IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters
abstract: This paper presents a data-driven control optimization framework for flexible joint robots (FJR) based on frequency response function (FRF) data, enabling automated controller synthesis without explicit model identification. Unlike conventional model-based approaches that rely on accurate parameter estimation, the proposed method directly utilizes measured FRF data and formulates the controller design as a convex optimization problem. The controller maximizes control bandwidth while ensuring stability across a wide range of configurations. Experimental validation on a FJR demonstrates superior tracking accuracy, vibration suppression, and robustness compared to model-based methods. Furthermore, a high-speed drumming task demonstrates the ability of the controller to handle repeated impacts and inertia variations, highlighting the potential of FRF-based control for the fast and precise operation of flexible robotic systems.

title: TELSIKS 2025 Committees
authors: N/A
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Technologies, Systems and Services in Telecommunications (TELSIKS)

authors: Massimo Alioto
publish: 2025 24th International Symposium on Communications and Information Technologies (ISCIT)
abstract: Next-generation AI will be predictive, proactive and agentic, anticipating needs and necessary actions based on context rather than waiting for instructions. This requires tight cooperation of sensing and intelligence, and a hence new generation of sensory intelligence at the edge for always-on monitoring (e.g., surveillance, assistive technologies, security). Indeed, it is now well understood that highly-distributed AI outside the cloud is a necessity in view of the infeasibility of raw data transmission to the cloud, latency challenges, data deluge and network bottleneck, high consumption of continuous wireless streaming, and privacy sensitivities. As a remarkable convergence, highly-distributed AI will also help address the daunting challenge posed by the ludicrously high levels of power consumption that next-generation datacenters are expected to require. In this talk, intriguing trends and brand new technologies from our Green IC group at NUS are illustrated to show how (incredibly) pervasive AI can be, while simultaneously addressing environmental and energy sustainability challenges. Several enabling silicon chip technologies for sensory intelligence and AI will be discussed, sharing the latest disruptive innovation in applications such as monitoring, surveillance, security and context awareness. Everywhere and continuously, with no physical boundaries.

title: Post-Quantum Traceable Anonymous Cross-Domain Authentication for Blockchain-based IoT
authors: Deepak Kumar Khare, Dharmendra Dangi, Amit Bhagat, Sunil Malviya, Dheeraj Kumar Dixit
publish: IEEE Transactions on Consumer Electronics
abstract: With the proliferation of Internet of Things (IoT) applications, secure and efficient cross-domain information sharing has become essential. Traditional cross-domain authentication approaches that rely on real device identities pose significant privacy risks, while fully anonymous schemes often lack accountability for malicious behavior. Additionally, emerging quantum computing capabilities threaten the security of classical cryptographic systems. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a post-quantum secure, traceable anonymous cross-domain authentication scheme based on blockchain technology. The scheme incorporates lattice-based certificateless cryptography and quantum-resistant hash functions to ensure resilience against quantum attacks. Devices are assigned multiple unlinkable pseudonymous identities with corresponding post-quantum public-private key pairs. A dynamic accumulator is employed to update domain information, and distinct pseudonyms are used for each authentication. Cross-domain credentials issued by a key generation center enable identity verification without exposing real identities. The system ensures both device privacy and traceability of malicious actors. Formal security proofs and BAN logic analysis confirm the scheme’s robustness against classical and quantum-era threats. Compared with existing classical approaches, the proposed scheme achieves strong post-quantum security with reduced computational and communication overhead during the authentication process.

title: MADDPG-Based Resource Allocation for Integrated Communication, Sensing and Computing in UAV-Assisted IoV Networks
authors: Pengfei Du, Tingyue Xiao, Haotong Cao, Chaojin Qing, Shahid Mumtaz
publish: IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology
abstract: The integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) has emerged as a pivotal technology in the internet of vehicles (IoV) domain, particularly due to its rapid advancements. However, as IoV networks expand, they encounter numerous challenges, including the increased communication traffic, ele vated communication latency, and insufficient sensing capabilities in critical emergency scenarios. To tackle these challenges, we propose a multi-unmanned aerial vehicle (Multi-UAV) assisted ISAC framework that synergistically combines the UAV-assisted mobile edge computing (MEC) and radar sensing technologies. This framework allows for a comprehensive investigation into the interactions among sensing, communication and computation through a joint optimization approach. First, to achieve a balance between communication performance, economic expenditure and radar mutual information (MI), we propose a Cobb-Douglas utility function and integrate it with a multi-agent deep reinforcement learning algorithm, which jointly takes the access control, instance selection, task offloading, UAV transmit power, and computational resource into consideration. Second, we reformulate this mixed-integer nonlinear programming (MINLP) problem as a markov decision process (MDP), and then propose a multi-agent deep deterministic policy gradient (MADDPG)-based resource allocation algorithm, which focuses on the simultaneous improvement of both communication quality and sensing accuracy. Finally, extensive simulation results demonstrate that the proposed algorithm markedly outperforms the existing baseline algorithms, achieving reductions of 73% in processing delay and 44% in total cost. This work not only fills a critical gap in current UAV-assisted IoV networks but also sets a foundation for future research into integrated sensing and communication systems in large-scale vehicular networks.

title: Noninvasive Measurement of Radial Artery Pulse Wave and Arterial Stiffness Evaluation Based on Portable Device_supp1-3629871.pdf
authors: Zhidong zhang
publish: N/A
abstract: The risk of atherosclerosis increases with age and existing diagnostic methods are expensive and complex, requiring effective, convenient and rapid screening methods in modern medical practice. In this study, we designed an arterial stiffness assessment method based on a Backpropagation Neural Network and integrated it into a portable radial pulse detection system. Pulse signals were acquired from 232 healthy volunteers and 28 hypertensive patients using a self-designed three-probe portable device. Healthy individuals were grouped by age, and five time-domain features positively correlated with age were screened out: main wave angle, pulse duration, rise time, systolic peak amplitude, and pulse contour area. Subsequently, an established was used to compute arterial elasticity reference values for all volunteers. Using the aforementioned five time-domain features as inputs and computed arterial elasticity reference values of healthy individuals as targets, we developed a BP neural network-based model for arterial elasticity assessment. The prediction accuracy of the trained model on the test set reached 93.13%. Local PWV(Pulse Wave Velocity) and radial artery AI(Augmentation Index) were used to validate the prediction results, with correlation coefficients reaching r = -0.71 (p < 0.001) and r = -0.63 (p < 0.001), respectively. Given that the vascular system of hypertensive patients is chronically subjected to elevated hemodynamic load, often resulting in impaired arterial elasticity, this model was clinically validated in a hypertensive cohort. The evaluation results are generally consistent with hypertension grading and comorbidity distribution, and the degree of agreement is higher than that of the reference method, confirming its utility in detecting hypertension-driven arterial stiffening progression.

title: Thank You for Your Authorship
authors: N/A
publish: IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics: Systems

title: Identify As A Human Does: A Pathfinder of Next-Generation Anti-Cheat Framework for First-Person Shooter Games
authors: Jiayi Zhang, Chenxin Sun, Yue Gu, Qingyu Zhang, Jiayi Lin, Xiaojiang Du, Chenxiong Qian
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: The gaming industry has experienced substantial growth, but cheating in online games poses a significant threat to the integrity of the gaming experience. Cheating, particularly in first-person shooter (FPS) games, can lead to substantial losses for the game industry. Existing anti-cheat solutions have limitations, such as client-side hardware constraints, security risks, server-side unreliable methods, and both-sides suffer from a lack of comprehensive real-world datasets. To address these limitations, the paper proposes HAWK, a server-side FPS anti-cheat framework for the popular game CS:GO. HAWK utilizes machine learning techniques to mimic human experts’ identification process, leverages novel multi-view features, and is equipped with a well-defined workflow. HAWK is evaluated with the first large and real-world datasets containing multiple cheat types and cheating sophistication, and it exhibits promising efficiency and acceptable overheads, shorter ban times, higher recall and similar false positive rate compared to the in-use anti-cheat, and the ability to capture cheaters who evaded official inspections.

title: On-Device Intent Reasoning for Smart Home Agents via Ontology-Augmented sLLMs
authors: Donghwan Jeong, Honguk Woo
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Large language model (LLM)-based agents offer powerful natural language understanding for smart home intent interpretation but typically require cloud deployment, raising concerns over privacy, latency, and resource usage. While sLLM can run on-device, they lack the structured contextual knowledge needed to handle ambiguous intents and complex device interactions effectively. To address this limitation, we present CIDER, an ontology-augmented, on-device intent reasoning framework that combines an sLLM with common-sense device knowledge and user-specific context, organized within a structured ontology-based knowledge graph. Specifically, we develop an ontology construction pipeline for smart homes, which leverages cloud-based LLMs to extract and organize common-sense knowledge about smart home devices and integrates user-specific context from a smart home service. The resulting ontology serves as an external knowledge source that augments the sLLM’s intent reasoning process in a retrieval-augmented manner, enabling context-aware inference for autonomous, orchestrated device operation. In evaluations with SmartThings-based testbeds, CIDER achieves a success rate of 82.2% in general scenarios and 76.6% in highly complex home environments, outperforming strong cloud-based baselines by up to 17.7 percentage points, despite relying on a compact on-device sLLM. These results demonstrate that combining the domain-specific efficiency of symbolic knowledge representations with the flexible semantic processing of an sLLM, empowered by an ontology distilled from cloud-based LLMs, provides an effective approach to intent understanding in smart homes.

title: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
authors: N/A
publish: N/A

title:
A 3-mm
                    <sup>2</sup>
                    , Multi-Data-Rate, Low-Power IR-UWB Transmitter With On-Chip Antenna for Distributed, Free-Floating Neural Implants
authors: Cong Ding, Mingxiang Gao, Anja K. Skrivervik, Mahsa Shoaran
publish: IEEE Journal of Solid-State Circuits
abstract: Distributed, high-density neural implants enable multi-region, high-fidelity neural recording and targeted stimulation, advancing both the treatment of neurological disorders and the development of brain–machine interfaces. While recent uplink transmitters (TXs) have achieved high data rates, high energy efficiency, and mm-scale footprints suitable for distributed systems, they struggle to maintain a balanced performance across these metrics. This article introduces a mm-scale wireless TX to overcome this limitation. To support high-density neural recording with flexible channel counts and various signal modalities, the TX offers energy-efficient data transmission from 50 Mb/s to 1.2 Gb/s, enabled by a novel dual-modulation technique. At high data rates, the TX employs a hybrid modulation scheme combining 4-PPM and 2-PSK, while at low data rates, it switches to simple on-off keying (OOK) modulation. To enable this modulation strategy, we introduce a twin-oscillator-based wideband phase-locked loop (PLL) for RF carrier generation within the ultra-wideband (UWB) range. At high data rates, the PLL directly generates a low-jitter UWB carrier. At low data rates, leveraging OOK modulation’s relaxed phase noise requirements, a duty-cycled <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$5{\times }$</tex-math> </inline-formula> frequency multiplier upconverts the PLL’s low output frequency to the UWB band. This approach bypasses the power-hungry RF oscillators and dividers, facilitating energy-efficient, duty-cycled carrier generation and supporting frequency-division multiple access (FDMA). In addition, we employ a hybrid strategy combining time-division multiple access (TDMA) and FDMA to enhance scalability for untethered, distributed neural implants. A custom on-chip antenna replaces the conventional printed circuit board (PCB) antenna, establishing a wireless link between the implant and the external system. The proposed TX, fabricated in 65-nm CMOS, occupies a compact footprint of only 3 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> and consumes 1.49–7.26 mW across all supported data rates (50–1200 Mb/s). In in vitro wireless testing, it achieved a record transcutaneous transmission range of 60 cm through 15-mm thick pork tissue, without the need for a subcranial repeater.

title: Human-in-The-Loop Adaptive Fault-Tolerant Control for Quadrotor UAVs in Distributed Formation With Fast Finite-Time Convergence
authors: Rui Shang, Wei Sun, Shun-Feng Su, You-Gang Sun
publish: IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology
abstract: This paper focuses on the formation control problem of distributed quadrotor unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), and proposes a consensus control method based on fast finite-time convergence to achieve coordinated flight. First, a novel virtual control law based on a piecewise function is designed, achieving fast finite-time convergence while effectively addressing the challenges posed by internal actuator faults and external disturbances, including measurement errors in Global Positioning System velocity caused by wind-induced variations in UAV motion. Second, a human-in-the-loop mechanism is integrated with gesture prediction technology, enabling the non-autonomous leader to receive control commands through a gesture recognition system, while the followers are indirectly controlled via the communication network, thereby enhancing the naturalness of the UAVs' response to commands. Moreover, this paper incorporates dynamic surface control to overcome the complexity explosion problem in controller design, ensuring the stability of the system. Finally, simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method guarantees boundedness of all closed-loop signals and achieves accurate consensus tracking under unidirectional communication topologies, with faster convergence compared to conventional finite-time methods.

title: GDRNet: A deep learning framework for dynamic sliding window determination and improved prediction accuracy in online IIoT systems
authors: Supriya Guha, Amitava Datta
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: The application of machine learning (ML) on IoT data is pivotal for developing intelligent industrial systems. This involves using a sliding window to extract time slices for ML prediction models. Existing methods rely on empirical, statistical, and optimisation or heuristic-based approaches to determine optimal sliding window size. Recent deep learning methods adaptively adjust or internally restructure windows, but they do not explicitly predict window size as a supervised target, particularly in multivariate IIoT contexts. In this paper, we introduce GDRNet, a novel deep learning-based approach for dynamically determining the optimal sliding window size to achieve improved prediction accuracy in multivariate Industrial IoT (IIoT) systems. The generative component (G) of GDRNet employs an LSTM-based variational autoencoder model to generate a large labeled multivariate dataset. The deep regression (DR) component employs a multi-layer perceptron (MLP) that is trained offline and predicts common optimal sliding window online. Unlike transformer-based or self-supervised forecasting models that assume large fixed contexts, GDRNet frames sliding window determination as a regression problem, enabling explicit and efficient prediction of optimal window sizes. Through extensive experimentation with multiple machine learning models and real-world IIoT datasets, we demonstrate that GDRNet achieves competitive or superior prediction accuracy with substantially higher computational efficiency and scalability as compared to the traditional methods, making it suitable for online IIoT systems. We also establish the generalisability of GDRNet through applying it across three real world IIoT datasets of different domains and contexts.

title: Testing Methods for Ultra-High Altitude Environmental Adaptability of Power Transmission and Transformation Sensing Terminals
authors: Tongbo He, Shizeng Liu, Qiang Li, Zonghua Hu, Shihong Zhang, Yue Ma
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: As core equipment for grid condition monitoring, power transmission and transformation sensing terminals face critical challenges in ultra-high altitude extreme environments, including material performance degradation, abnormal electrical characteristics, and inadequate operational adaptability. Existing environmental testing standards demonstrate limitations in simulating multi-stress coupled scenarios due to insufficient simulation capabilities and outdated control strategies. This paper proposes an ultra-high altitude adaptability testing methodology for power transmission sensing terminals based on multidimensional environmental coupling loading and dynamic gradient control. Through retrofitting a comprehensive test chamber with integrated ultraviolet irradiation, air circulation, and low-pressure control modules, we established a synchronized multi-environmental factor loading system. The implementation of a pressure-temperature-ultraviolet linkage algorithm coupled with a dynamic gradient control model enables precise simulation of altitude gradient variations. Experimental results demonstrate the method's effectiveness in replicating multidimensional extreme conditions: low pressure (≤70 kPa), intense ultraviolet radiation (≥1000 W/m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>), wide temperature fluctuations (-40°C to 70°C), and strong winds (≥15 m/s), while significantly reducing testing cycle duration. This research provides technical support for reliability evaluation of power transmission equipment in ultra-high altitude regions such as the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, demonstrating substantial engineering application value.

title: Research on RUL Prediction Method of Lithium-ion Battery Based on EIS
authors: Yizeng Wu, Huicong Liu, Zhonghang Li, Tiande Lai
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: Accurate prediction of the remaining useful life (RUL) of lithium-ion batteries is of great significance for improving the utilization efficiency and safety performance of batteries. Since the time-domain voltage and current data are difficult to reflect the changes in the characteristics of lithium-ion batteries, this paper proposes a RUL prediction method for lithium-ion batteries based on the integration of time convolution network (TCN) and long-term and short-term memory model (LSTM) based on electrochemical impedance spectroscopy(EIS). Bayes optimization algorithm based on tree structure is used to select the super parameters of the model. The TCN network is used to automatically extract the aging characteristics of lithium-ion batteries from the impedance data. The LSTM network is used to capture the long-term and short-term dependencies in the time series of lithium-ion batteries, and the final life prediction is carried out through the full connection layer. The experimental results show that the proposed method based on TPE-TCN-LSTM model can not only accurately grasp the overall degradation trend of the battery, but also quickly capture and respond to the fluctuations, so as to effectively improve the prediction performance.

title: Combining ARDL and Tree-based Machine Learning Methods to Assess the Impact of Exchange Rate Volatility on Moroccan Foreign Trade
authors: Amine El Kadri, Mohammed El-Khodary, Omar Rifki
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: This study examines the impact of USD/MAD exchange rate volatility on Morocco's foreign trade, specifically on exports and imports, focusing on exchange rate stability as well as the appreciation or depreciation of the dirham. We use foreign exchange market data, including opening, high, low, and closing prices (OHLC). To refine the analysis, we optimized the ARDL model using the Grid Search algorithm to identify the best parameters for the model. Additionally, we applied these optimal lag combinations to interpretable machine learning such as Decision Tree, Random Forest, XGBoost, CatBoost, and Gradient Boosting. The results reveal that a stable exchange rate promotes exports (+8.06 billion USD) while reducing imports (-9.24 billion USD). A 1 MAD appreciation decreases exports by 3.84 billion USD and increases imports by 4.60 billion USD, while a depreciation reduces exports by 3.78 billion USD and increases imports by 3.75 billion USD. Additionally, a 1% increase in imports leads to a 0.69% increase in exports and Exports itself exert a strong influence on imports (+134.10%), The machine learning (ML) models provide further insights into this nexus, by capturing complex and non-linear relationships that ARDL could not handle. In particular, Gradient Boosting model demonstrated high predictive accuracy. Model performance is exceptional, with high R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> and adjusted R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> values, confirming their robustness and demonstrating the effectiveness of the Grid Search algorithm in optimizing the ARDL models. This combination improves the predictive accuracy and robustness of the analysis, and highlighting the potential of machine learning in economic modeling and volatility.

title: Spectral Characterstics of Active Wide-Band Acoustic Emission Signals for Lithium-Ion Battery Monitoring
authors: Lei Fu, Li Zhen, Rongfeng Deng, Haiyan Miao, Wenhan Zeng, Fengshou Gu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: The performance and safety of lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) critically depend on dynamic structural and interfacial changes within constituent materials (electrodes, electrolyte, separator) during electrochemical cycling. Understanding the evolution of microstructures and interfaces—particularly as functions of State of Charge (SOC) and State of Health (SOH) is essential for advancing Battery Management Systems (BMS). This study introduces a novel non-destructive method for inspecting LIB material properties using active acoustic interrogation and spectral analysis. The approach transmits swept-frequency acoustic waves into both parametrically designed 3D-printed samples (with controlled microstructural variations) and operational pouch-cell LIBs, analyzing the resulting acoustic emissions. Extracted spectral features reveal distinct correlations with specific material conditions in both sample types and pouch cells. These findings establish a frequency-domain framework for precise battery diagnostics, enabling potential visualization of dynamic material-property evolution throughout charge-discharge cycles.

title: Simulation research on transmission line sag high-precision monitoring system based on millimeter-wave radar
authors: Su Zhang, Jun Liu, Wenwen Li, Haoqi Shi, Hui Zhao
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: In this paper, an intelligent monitoring system for transmission line sag based on 77GHz millimeter-wave radar is proposed, which solves the key problem of insufficient arc sag measurement accuracy in complex environments through multidisciplinary theoretical innovation and algorithm optimization. The system adopts 4GHz bandwidth FMCW radar, which achieves an arc sag measurement accuracy of 0.1m (theoretical resolution of 0.0375m) and an angular resolution of 0.125° under the conditions of 300m range, -10°C and 10mm icing, which is 46% higher than the existing technology. The temperature-icing joint compensation model was innovatively proposed, which reduced the sag calculation error from >12% to <1.5% in extreme environments (-40°C 30mm ice). The dynamic equation of wind vibration-sag is established, and the vibration and noise are suppressed by 80% (±0.2m→±0.05m) through Kalman filtering, the response time is < 50ms, and the real-time monitoring refresh rate of 20Hz is realized. The verification shows that the system can ≥ 30 minutes in advance to warn the risk of sag overrun (± 10% safety threshold), provide ≥ 2-hour early warning (detection accuracy ±1mm) when the icing > is 5mm, and reduce manual inspection by 70% (saving 560,000 yuan per year for a single line). The multi-objective separation algorithm successfully distinguishes the 1.5° interval target points, and the four-dimensional visualization platform integrates distance-velocity spectrum, catenary shape, dynamic sag curve and icing impact analysis to provide minute-level risk decision support for smart grids. This technology has passed the test of 12 strong winds and - 40°C extreme cold, providing an innovative solution for the safe operation of high-voltage/ultra-high-voltage transmission lines.

title: Imputing Missing Values Using a Machine Learning Model Approach for Flood Prediction
authors: Muhammad Abdul Hakim, Alfarelzi, Muhammad Rafi Ediananta, Brahmantya Aji Pramudita, Felix Corputty, Dhoni Putra Setiawan
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Information Technology, Computer, and Electrical Engineering (ICITACEE)
abstract: Comprehensive hydrometeorological data is essential to ensure accurate flood predictions, effective water resources management and strategic disaster mitigation strategies. High-quality and intact meteorological and hydrological data enable precise modeling of hydrological processes, which facilitates early warning systems that help protect communities from the devastating impacts of extreme weather events. However, missing data is common in hydrological time series, especially in long-term observations of rainfall and river levels, and can significantly reduce modeling accuracy and decision-making quality. Therefore, a suitable method is required to process the data effectively. This study compared three imputation techniques: K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), Linear Interpolation, and Multivariate Imputation by Chained Equations (MICE). The dataset used in this study consists of daily rainfall and river discharge data from the Citarum River, covering the period from 2015 to 2023. The performance is evaluated using Mean Absolute Error (MAE) and Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) with a complete reference dataset. Results show that Linear Interpolation has better performance than other methods with 10.359 MAE and 18.086 RMSE, meanwhile, KNN and MICE have 17.312 and 16.936 MAE and 34.706 and 34.778 RMSE. The result shows the Linear Interpolation can handle missing values of the dataset and produces lower errors.

title: Capacity configuration of zero-carbon hydrogen metallurgy system coupled with underground salt cavern hydrogen storage
authors: Qiang Ji, Lin Cheng, Pengfei He
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: Hydrogen metallurgy process offers significant benefits in terms of energy conservation and emission reduction, emerging as a promising paradigm in direct reduction iron (DRI) production. However, transitioning from the conventional blast furnace-basic oxygen furnace (BF-BOF) process to hydrogen metallurgy undoubtedly involves substantial capital investment and higher operational costs. Consequently, a well-planned capacity configuration for ZCHMS is critical to boost its economic viability. In this study, we propose a novel planning strategy for ZCHMS, which aims at maximizing profitability. Detailed models of the energy and mass balance, as well as the operational characteristics of the shaft furnace, are developed. Furthermore, a novel ZCHMS that integrates low- and high-temperature waste heat recovery, underground salt cavern and an organic rankine circle (ORC) is proposed. Numerical analyses of both the peaking-shaving and grid-friendly of ZCHMS are discussed, offering valuable insights for the development of grid-friendly systems of ZCHMS.

title: Comparative Study of Battery Back-up Units (BBUs) Configurations for Data Centers
authors: Samer Said, Mahmoud A. Gaafar, Tarek Younis, Mostafa Mosa, Mohamed Orabi
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Power Electronics and Renewable Energy (CPERE)
abstract: This paper presents the possible configurations of battery back-up units (BBUs) used in modern data centers. Three configurations are examined: central, string, and distributed. In accordance with the Open Compute Project-Open Rack (OCPOR) specification V3, the study compares these configurations in terms of cost, efficiency, and reliability. Simulation results for the distributed configuration are presented to verify its ability to achieve batteries’ state-of-charge (SoC) balancing and loadvoltage regulation.

title: Precoded Stbc With Beamforming for Secure Next-Generation Networks
authors: Cong-Hoang Diem, Duc-Tho Mai
publish: 2025 24th International Symposium on Communications and Information Technologies (ISCIT)
abstract: System security is an important issue in the contemporary digital era and continues to be a key area of interest for the global research community. This paper presents a novel approach that integrates the STBC encoding scheme with Beamforming technology to enhance physical layer security in next-generation networks. In the proposed method, the conventional Alamouti STBC patterns are modified into 16 alternative orthogonal patterns by rearranging the positions and signs of complex signal components, while preserving the benefits of traditional STBC scheme. At each transmission instance, one pattern is selected based on the Channel State Information (CSI) and the Received Signal Strength Indicator (RSSI) between the transmitter and the legitimate receiver. These values are exchanged via beacon packets prior to data transmission and are unknown to eavesdroppers, allowing the RSSI value to serve as a shared secret key. This dynamic and random pattern selection complicates interception, thereby strengthening system security. After STBC encoding, Beamforming is applied using available CSI to adjust the phase and amplitude across transmit antennas, directing the signal energy toward the legitimate receiver. Simulation and analytical results show that the proposed method maintains a low bit error rate (BER) for the legitimate receiver, while significantly increasing the BER for eavesdroppers, demonstrating its effectiveness in improving physical layer security. Furthermore, the secrecy rate of the proposed method is significantly higher than that of conventional Beamforming and STBC scheme.

title: Optimization of FSAE Vehicle Dimensional Parameters Based on Three-Degree-Of-Freedom Double-Track Model and Optimal Control
authors: Zehao Yin, Qinghua Su, Jiaheng Guan, Yang Shi, Liyong Wang, Yue Song
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: In Formula Student Automotive Engineering (FSAE) competition, traditional empirical design methods face challenges in quantifying the influence of vehicle geometric parameters on lap times, hindering precise optimization of dynamic performance. This study develops a lap time prediction methodology grounded in optimal control theory by establishing a three-degree-of-freedom (3-DOF) double-track vehicle dynamics model coupled with track constraints and nonlinear programming techniques. The minimum-lap-time optimal control problem is reformulated as a nonlinear programming problem and numerically resolved using the CasADi framework with the IPOPT solver, enabling systematic evaluation of track width, wheelbase, and front-to-rear axle load distribution on figure-eight skid pad performance. Results indicate that the proposed computational approach demonstrates a 10% deviation from empirical performance data yet effectively captures performance trends. A track width of 1,240 mm yields the shortest lap time (4.590 s), achieving a 1.6% improvement over the baseline configuration. Optimal steering agility emerges at a 1,580 mm wheelbase with a lap time of 4.557 s, while a 40% front axle load ratio facilitates the fastest lap (4.547s) through controlled oversteer strategies. These findings reveal the underlying mechanisms through which dimensional parameters govern figure-eight maneuverability, providing theoretical guidance for parameter optimization in FSAE vehicle design.

title: Intrusion Detection for Smart City Security by Boosting Algorithms Optimized by Metaheuristics Algorithm
authors: Nebojsa Bacanin, Tamara Zivkovic, Miodrag Zivkovic, Vladimir Simic, Milos Grubjesic, Aleksandr Kravtsov, Luka Anicin
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Technologies, Systems and Services in Telecommunications (TELSIKS)
abstract: The flourishing of smart cities has introduced complex and mutually connected cyber-physical systems depending on IoT devices, making them extremely vulnerable to sophisticated cyber attacks. Efficient intrusion detection systems are essential to safeguard these environments, since traditional security solutions fall short in these circumstances. This study explores the integration of XGBoost, a powerful ensemble learning algorithm, with an adapted implementation of a well-known metaheuristic algorithm to improve the detection of network intrusions. Metaheuristics algorithm is employed to fine-tune XGBoost’s hyperparameters, improving classification acuracy and reducing computational overhead. Experimental assessment on benchmark intrusion detection dataset demonstrates that the metaheuristicoptimized XGBoost models significantly outperform baseline models in terms of accuracy, precision, recall, and $\mathbf{F 1}$-score. The introduced methodology presents a robust and scalable IDS framework appropriate for the complex and resource-constrained infrastructure of smart cities.

title: An LLM-Agent and Knowledge Graph–Integrated Framework for Collaborative Optimization of Hydropower Maintenance Resources Scheduling
authors: Xinyang Yi, Min Feng, Ruozhen Cheng, Ran Duan, Ye Yang, Jie Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: Efficient scheduling of maintenance resources for hydropower units is crucial for improving maintenance efficiency and reducing costs. However, traditional methods often rely on manual experience and static scheduling rules, lacking dynamic optimization mechanisms. To address these limitations, this paper proposes an LLM-Agent and knowledge graph-integrated framework for collaborative optimization of hydropower maintenance resources scheduling. First, an LLM-assisted approach is employed to construct a maintenance knowledge graph. Then, a query-aware subgraph retrieval method is designed to extract relevant triplets by identifying core entities in user queries and leveraging semantic alignment strategies for multi-hop subgraph retrieval. Subsequently, a three-stage resource allocation generation mechanism based on prompt engineering is proposed. This mechanism utilizes the retrieved knowledge subgraphs to guide the generation of diverse and structured maintenance plans. Finally, an LLM-Agent-based optimization module, incorporating a genetic algorithm, is developed to dynamically manage resource constraints and reduce costs across multiple planning alternatives. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework significantly enhances the efficiency of maintenance resource allocation, offering a novel paradigm for advancing the intelligent hydropower equipment maintenance.

title: Testing Different Models for Brain Tissue Segmentation on ISBR18 Dataset
authors: Stela Lila, Dino Arnaut, Samed Jukic, Bekir Karlik
publish: 2025 6th International Workshop on Engineering Technologies and Computer Science (EnT)
abstract: Segmentation of brain tissue is an essential task in medical image analysis, particularly in neuroimaging and disease diagnosis. This study evaluates and compares three major segmentation approaches in the ISBR18 dataset: atlas-based methods, machine learning techniques, and deep learning architectures. The atlas-based Majority Voting method achieved the highest performance within its category with a dice similarity coefficient of 0.8477, utilizing anatomical templates for segmentation. Among machine learning techniques, K-means clustering demonstrated robust performance with 96% classification accuracy, offering computational efficiency despite limitations in spatial resolution. The deep learning U-Net model trained for binary segmentation achieved 93% accuracy, benefiting from its encoder-decoder architecture for precise boundary detection. While traditional atlas-based approaches provide robust anatomical consistency and machine learning methods offer computational advantages, deep learning models show promise in handling complex segmentation tasks. Future research could integrate these approaches to enhance segmentation performance in the ISBR18 dataset and lead to more accurate and reliable brain tissue segmentation for clinical applications.

title: Advanced Machine Learning for Optical Network Fault Detection: A Comprehensive Benchmarking Review of Performance, Generalizability, Innovation, and Real-World Applicability
authors: Mohamed E.M Elhaj-Abdou, Heba A. Fayed, Moustafa H. Aly
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Power Electronics and Renewable Energy (CPERE)
abstract: The increasing complexity of optical networks necessitates intelligent fault detection solutions that balance accuracy, efficiency, scalability, and adaptability. This study provides a comprehensive evaluation of Machine Learning (ML)-based fault detection models, assessing their performance, generalizability, innovations, and real-world applicability. Deep Learning (DL) approaches, particularly AutoML-CNN + Data Fusion and VAE-GAN, demonstrate superior accuracy and adaptability, yet face challenges related to computational overhead and sensitivity to noise. Federated Learning enables privacy-preserving Artificial Intelligence (AI), but requires latency optimizations. In contrast, traditional ML models (SVM, Decision Trees) remain computationally efficient but struggle with generalization. This review introduces a comparative framework, integrating quantitative benchmarking, sensitivity analysis, and real-world validation to evaluate scalability and deployment feasibility. The study not only highlights existing limitations, but also proposes enhancements through hybrid DL, Transfer Learning (TL), and noise-aware training strategies, providing a roadmap for developing robust, scalable, and efficient ML-based fault detection solutions for optical networks.

title: Research on Global Optimization Scheduling Strategy for Virtual Power Plants Based on Cloud-Edge Collaboration
authors: Ciwei Gao, Liang Yin, Xiaoli Wang, Fang Wang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: With the advancement of new power system construction and the massive integration of distributed energy resources (DER), traditional centralized dispatch modes are facing severe challenges. As an important technical means for aggregating DER, virtual power plants (VPP) encounter challenges in optimization scheduling under multi-level coupling constraints, including high complexity and difficulty in balancing real-time performance with global optimality. This paper proposes a global optimization scheduling strategy for VPPs based on cloud-edge collaboration, constructs a cloud-edge collaborative control framework oriented toward global optimization, establishes a global optimization scheduling model across three levels of transmission network-distribution network-microgrid, and employs the Alternating Direction Method of Multipliers (ADMM) algorithm to solve the distributed collaborative optimization problem. The case study analysis shows that the ADMM algorithm converges within 15 iterations, reducing system operating costs by 4.6%, which validates the effectiveness and practicality of the proposed strategy.

title: Structural Optimization and Verification of a Permanent Magnet Dynamic Vibration Absorber Based on Gradient Descent Method
authors: Yunpeng Guo, Hao Wu, Xin Pan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: Dynamic vibration absorbers with additional permanent magnets are widely used for vibration suppression in the industrial field, but irrational structural design affects the electromagnetic performance of the absorber, and too low electromagnetic performance affects the amplitude of the driving force, thus making it difficult to effectively suppress vibration. In order to optimise the design of the permanent magnet power absorber structure, the average magnetic susceptibility of the air gap between the moving and static masses is increased, thus raising the upper limit of the electromagnetic performance. The theoretical derivation of the mechanical formula of the permanent magnet model, the design of the full factorial test and the evaluation of each structural parameter through simulation, and the application of the gradient descent method to find the optimal parameters of the structure are experimentally verified that the effect of the increase in effect before and after the optimisation is more satisfactory.

title: Experimental Analysis of RV Reducer Angular Contact Ball Bearing Failure Based on Different Preload Conditions
authors: Dongqin Li, Bing Li, Huanqing Han, Kunzuo Zhong, Zhexiang Zou, Fengshou Gu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: In this study, the failure behavior of angular contact ball bearing in RV reducer under different preload conditions is experimentally analyzed. Through the design of two experimental schemes, the axial assembly tightness and preload unevenness of the bearing outer ring are adjusted separately, and their effects on bearing failure frequency, sliding friction trend and motor load are studied. The experiment uses a combination of envelope spectrum analysis and motor current RMS value monitoring to extract and analyze the characteristic frequency of failures caused by artificially manufactured bearing outer ring defects. The results show that as the tightness of the assembly decreases or the degree of unevenness of the preload increases, the frequency of failure shifts to varying degrees, and the motor load changes significantly, reflecting the dynamic evolution of rolling-to-sliding friction. The research verifies the inherent coupling relationship between the signal characteristics and the assembly state, which provides an important reference for the online monitoring of the bearing state of RV reducer and the evaluation of assembly quality.

title: Research on the Joint Satellite-Ground Mission Planning Method of D-InSAR Satellite
authors: Chuheng Tang, Junjian Wen, Yanyang Liu, Nan Li, Junli Chen
publish: 2024 5th China International SAR Symposium (CISS)
abstract: InSAR technology adopts the phase information of two or more SAR images covering the same area to rapidly acquire elevation information and deformation information. However, in current differential interferometric SAR (D-InSAR) operations for surveying and mapping missions, the ground system typically generates and transmits SAR payload commands one day in advance. This practice often leads to partial dislocation between the two D-InSAR images, thereby diminishing the efficiency of differential interferometry application. To address this issue, this paper introduces a joint satellite-ground mission planning method for D-InSAR satellite. This novel appraoach integrates ground mission planning of strict regression orbit satellites based on true anomaly with on-board autonomous planning for the activation and deactivation time of SAR payload. By adopting this method, timely earth observation can be achieved and the overlapping regions of the two D-InSAR images can be optimized, thus effectively enriching user experience and enhancing the operational efficiency of D-InSAR satellite application.

title: Design of Controllable Ceramic Sealing Ring Structure
authors: Xue Wen, Fengming Hu, Yizhuo Sun, Quanchao Yang, Yuan Yin, Weifeng Huang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: This paper investigates and proposes a controllable static sealing ring structure designed for intelligent sealing applications. A stacked piezoelectric ceramic actuator is selected to modulate the deformation of the sealing face. By actuating the piezoelectric elements, the conicity of the static ring surface is dynamically adjusted. This study provides valuable insights into the real-time control of sealing performance, with the goal of preventing sudden sealing failures and extending the operational lifespan of sealing systems.

title: Research on Thresholds for Power Quality Indicator Early Warning Based on Load Forecasting and Composite Weighting
authors: Chen Chen, Yao Shi, Lidong Ye, Kai Liu, Fang Liu, Junwei Yang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: In response to the increasing demands for power quality from the user side, the existing management system within the Zero Carbon Industrial Park exhibits insufficient fine-grained perception of user-end conditions and struggles to accurately identify and address power quality risks such as voltage sags, harmonic distortions, and three-phase imbalances. This study proposes a method for setting warning thresholds of power quality indices by integrating load forecasting with composite weighting techniques. The core approach involves: first, utilizing historical data and Temporal Convolutional Networks (TCN) to accurately predict the trend of critical load variations on the user side, thereby understanding future operational states; second, applying the entropy weight method to determine the comprehensive weights of various power quality indicators in reflecting user-side risks, establishing their priority processing order; finally, dynamically combining the predicted load states with the composite weights of indicators and constructing a warning threshold calculation model aimed at minimizing the cost associated with adjustments across the Zero Carbon Industrial Park. To solve this model, the Kepler Optimization Algorithm (KOA) is employed to obtain optimal warning thresholds. Experimental results demonstrate that this algorithm offers higher search accuracy in complex scenarios and faster convergence in simpler cases.

title: A Single-stage Single-phase Five-level Common Ground Inverter with Boosting Ability and CCM Operation
authors: Ahmed Ibrahim Mohamed, Mahmoud A. Gaafar, Mohamed Orabi, M. Salem Ahmed, Mingsan Ouyang, Weimin Wu, Eltaib Abdeen
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Power Electronics and Renewable Energy (CPERE)
abstract: In this paper, a five-level common ground inverter topology with voltage boosting is proposed for photovoltaic (PV) applications. The features of this topology are: 1) the CG configuration between the negative of the DC side and the neutral of the AC side. This eliminates leakage current. 2) The current input operates in continuous conduction mode (CCM). 3) High voltage boosting capability, 4) the proposed inverter offers single-stage configuration, leading to higher overall efficiency and fewer components. The proposed topology consists of eight power switches, one input inductor, and two flying capacitors. The operation of the proposed topology is explained and validated using MATLAB/Simulink.

title: Effect of Titanium Mesh Cranioplasty on Magnetic Field Distribution from Mobile Phone within the User’s Head
authors: Dejan B. Jovanović, Vladimir B. Stanković, Dragana U. Živaljević, Nenad N. Cvetković, Dragan D. Vučković, Bojana R. Petković
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Technologies, Systems and Services in Telecommunications (TELSIKS)
abstract: This study aims to assess how titanium mesh used in cranial reconstruction affect the magnetic field distribution from a cellphone within the biological tissues and organs in the user’s head. This evaluation involves developing accurate threedimensional models of the user’s head, titanium mesh implant and a cellphone, along with solving the electromagnetic propagation equation numerically. Calculations have been caried out for the mobile network frequency of 1800 MHz. Ultimately, a comparative assessment was conducted for both models, with and without the titanium mesh.

title: Lotus: A Hybrid Cross-Chain Framework for Privacy-Preserving Digital Identity
authors: Tuan-Dung Tran, Huynh Phan Gia Bao, Tra Minh Trong, Nguyen Tan Cam, Van-Hau Pham
publish: 2025 24th International Symposium on Communications and Information Technologies (ISCIT)
abstract: Integrating decentralized identity (DID) systems with state authorities introduces complex challenges related to trust, privacy, and auditability. The Lotus Bridge framework addresses these by proposing a hybrid digital identity architecture suitable for national-scale deployment. It integrates a permissioned Proof-of-Authority (PoA) blockchain for sovereign credential issuance with a cross-chain verification bridge that utilizes zero-knowledge proofs to enable privacy-preserving selective disclosure. This architecture is one of the first to combine state-backed issuance with interoperable, private cross-chain verification in a unified system. Two core protocols—state-anchored issuance and cross-chain verification—are formally defined and implemented in a working prototype. Experimental results demonstrate strong performance: cryptographic proofs remain under 600 bytes and end-to-end verification latency consistently stays below 2 seconds, enabling real-time applicability. Additionally, parallelization reduces proof generation time by over 90%, and the system achieves significant cost efficiency, with on-chain verification starting at 244 Gwei per credential and scaling to 14K Gwei for 1,000, offering up to 75% cost savings compared to existing Ethereum and Polygon solutions. These findings establish Lotus Bridge as a scalable and costeffective foundation for sovereign digital identity in cross-chain ecosystems.

title: A Method for Improving the Short-Circuit Ratio of New Energy Stations Based on Virtual Synchronous Control
authors: Qingxin Pu, Xingjia Zeng, Jie Cao, Qinfeng Ma, Zhongrun Xie
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: To address the issue of insufficient SCR caused by the integration of a high proportion of renewable energy into weak grids, this paper proposes an approach to enhance the SCR for renewable power plants based on virtual synchronous generator control. Firstly, the SCR metric for the renewable station is calculated in real-time, and a subset of grid-connected converters is configured with virtual synchronous control. Subsequently, the equivalent impedance at the PCC is adjusted by dynamically regulating the virtual impedance, thereby reducing the system's critical short-circuit ratio requirement. Finally, during voltage dips at the PCC, a virtual excitation mechanism is employed to deliver quick voltage support, consequently improving the system's equivalent short-circuit ratio. Simulation and experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method effectively enhances the SCR of renewable energy stations and significantly strengthens the grid's disturbance resistance capability.

title: Domain-Generalized Prognostics of Rotating Machinery via Multi-Task Foundation Model with Sparse Experts
authors: Mingzhe Li, Zhigang Xue, Fucai Li
