publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: Rotating machinery operates under diverse conditions, resulting in domain shifts and non-stationary degradation patterns that complicate robust fault diagnosis. Existing models typically focus on classification or regression tasks within a single domain, limiting their generalization ability. To address these issues, this paper proposes a unified multi-task learning framework based on a Mixture of Experts (MoE) architecture and adversarial domain training. The model integrates multiple expert networks with dynamic gating mechanisms to extract discriminative features from various signal modalities, enabling effective fault classification. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that the proposed method achieves superior cross-device fault diagnosis accuracy. This work highlights the potential of combining modular sparse representations with adversarial domain adaptation to build scalable and transferable prognostic health management (PHM) models for industrial rotating machinery.

title: Introducing Energy Efficient Routing in UAV-Satellite NTNs for Dynamic 6G Interconnectivity
authors: George Amponis, Thomas Lagkas, Pavlos Bouzinis, Panagiotis Radoglou-Grammatikis, Antonios Sarigiannidis, Panagiotis Sarigiannidis, Vasileios Argyriou
publish: IEEE Transactions on Communications
abstract: The integration of Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) and Low-Earth Orbit (LEO) satellites as aerial nodes in non-terrestrial networks (NTNs) presents both opportunities and challenges for on-demand 6G interconnectivity. This paper presents a new Composite Cost Metric (CCM) which improves energy-efficient routing performance in combined UAV-satellite constellations. We consider incorporating cumulative Free Space Path Loss (FSPL) and residual energy into the route selection process for both proactive and reactive protocols, our approach refines the routing decisions of classical protocols. The proposed CCM-driven modifications and protocol-specific integration typologies can improve overall route stability, reduce energy consumption per delivered packet, and optimize network reliability by dynamically selecting relays with lower attenuation and higher energy availability. We develop an NS-3-based simulation framework that integrates realistic satellite orbital mechanics, UAV mobility models, and a hybrid energy model that includes solar energy harvesting for satellites. Simulation results demonstrate that our enhancements can indeed outperform baseline implementations in packet delivery ratio, energy efficiency, and end-to-end delay which makes them viable for next-generation NTN-supported 6G networks, at the expense of some additional control overhead. With this set of developments we aim to pave the way for global-optimum and energy-aware emergency and disaster relief communications.

title: PLEX: Perturbation-free Local Explanations for LLM-Based Text Classification
authors: Yogachandran Rahulamathavan, Misbah Farooq, Varuna De Silva
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Signal Processing
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) excel in text classi f ication, but their complexity hinders interpretability, making it difficult to understand the reasoning behind their predictions. Explainable AI (XAI) methods like LIME and SHAP offer local explanations by identifying influential words, but they rely on computationally expensive perturbations. These methods typically generate thousands of perturbed sentences and perform inferences on each, incurring a substantial computational burden, especially with LLMs. To address this, we propose Perturbation free Local Explanation (PLEX), a novel method that leverages the contextual embeddings extracted from the LLM and a “Siamese network” style neural network trained to align with feature importance scores. This one-off training eliminates the need for subsequent perturbations, enabling efficient explanations for any new sentence. We demonstrate PLEX's effectiveness on four different classification tasks (sentiment, fake news, fake COVID 19 news and depression), showing more than 92% agreement with LIME and SHAP. Our evaluation using a “stress test” reveals that PLEX accurately identifies influential words, leading to a similar decline in classification accuracy as observed with LIME and SHAP when these words are removed. Notably, in some cases, PLEX demonstrates superior performance in capturing the impact of key features. PLEX dramatically accelerates explanation, reducing time and computational overhead by two and four orders of magnitude, respectively. This work offers a promising solution for explainable LLM-based text classification.

title: Expressive Keypoints for Skeleton-based Action Recognition via Progressive Skeleton Evolution
authors: Yijie Yang, Jinlu Zhang, Jiaxu Zhang, Bo Du, Zhigang Tu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Image Processing
abstract: In the realm of skeleton-based human action recognition, the traditional methods which rely on coarse body keypoints fall short of capturing subtle human actions. In this work, we propose Expressive Keypoints that incorporates hand and foot details to form a fine-grained skeletal representation, to improve the discriminative ability for existing models in discerning intricate human actions. However, the increased computational cost from processing nearly three times more joints becomes a new challenge. To address this, we present the Progressive Skeleton Evolution strategy, which significantly improves efficiency while preserving the benefits of fine-grained keypoints. The core idea involves utilizing learnable mapping matrices, semantically initialized to progressively downsample keypoints and prioritize prominent joints by allocating importance weights. Additionally, a plug-and-play Instance Pooling module is exploited to extend our approach to multi-person scenarios without surging computation cost. Extensive experimental results over seven datasets demonstrate the superiority of our method compared to the state-of-the-arts for skeleton-based human action recognition. Code has been made available at https://github.com/YijieYang23/PSE-GCN.

title: Frequency-Aware B-Line and Pleural Line Analysis in Lung Ultrasound Videos
authors: Kaihui Yang, Guangyu Guo, Ying Zhang, Linxuan Pang, Zhaohui Zheng, Ruyu Liu, Jin Ding, Dingwen Zhang, Junwei Han
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Accurately identifying B-lines and pleural line (P-line) in lung ultrasound (LUS) videos is valuable for evaluating certain lung conditions. However, manual interpretation remains subjective and highly dependent on operator expertise. Existing deep learning methods often suffer from performance degradation due to speckle noise and motion artifacts. Moreover, the limited availability of LUS video data annotated for multiple diagnostic features such as B-lines and the P-line limits model development. Therefore, this paper introduces ILD-LUS, a new clinical LUS database designed based on interstitial lung disease (ILD) analysis by category labeling, comprising 2,149 ultrasound videos (193,410 frames). Also, we construct an external test set based on the public Covid-BLUES dataset for the evaluation of B-lines and P-line recognition in different pulmonary pathologies. Then, we propose a novel video analysis framework that integrates wavelet enhancement with temporal attention modeling. Specifically, we employ a dual-component frequency feature enhancement method using the Discrete Wavelet Transform (DWT), which effectively suppresses noise while preserving important landmarks. Subsequently, an adaptive attention module is introduced to model long-range temporal dependencies and improve dynamic feature representation across consecutive frames. Experimental results show that the proposed method achieves over 94% AUC and 82% ACC for both B-lines and P-line classification on both the ILD-LUS and Covid-BLUES datasets, outperforming existing methods. These findings demonstrate the robustness and generalizability of our approach across different pathological conditions. Overall, the proposed framework shows strong potential for supporting clinical decision-making in LUS analysis. The code is available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/KaIi-github/WaveLUS</uri>.

title: Secure and Privacy-Preserving Multi-Source Optimization for UAV-Assisted Intelligent Transportation Systems
authors: Chao Chen, Xiaolong Xu, Guangming Cui, Haolong Xiang, Jiale Wu, Muhammad Bilal
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Uncrewed Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) are increasingly integrated into Intelligent Transportation Systems (ITS) to process multi-source data, thereby enhancing overall efficiency. As ITS relies increasingly on multi-source data for decision-making, new challenges arise in terms of secure data integration, user privacy protection, and communication latency. Most current UAV optimization methods only look at certain things, including planning the flight path or scheduling resources. However, these solutions don’t have a way to optimize all of these important parameters at the same time, which leads to higher latency and energy use. We suggest a secure and privacy-preserving multi-UAV optimization technique based on the Twin Delayed Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient (TD3) with Prioritized Experience Replay (PER) to solve these problems. This algorithm jointly optimizes UAV trajectories, resource scheduling, and task allocation in a multi-UAV and multi-edge servers system to reduce energy consumption and system latency while preserving user data privacy. A blockchain-based mechanism is added to make UAV data even more secure and open by recording task execution records in a way that can’t be changed. The proposed approach works, as shown by the outcomes of the experiments. The proposed solution cuts down on system latency and energy use by a lot compared to current optimization methods, even when the system is under a lot of stress or needs to keep data private.

title: Artificial Intelligence Development and Sharing Policy in An Agriculture Platform with Self-Built Farm_supp1-3634269.pdf
authors: Yanhong Gan
publish: N/A
abstract: As artificial intelligence (AI) technology continues to advance, an increasing number of platforms are integrating AI into their agricultural investments to manage pests and diseases. However, the complexity of AI application may increase the planting costs for farms. Meanwhile, platforms building their own farms is becoming a common practice in agriculture. This study presents a contract farming supply chain involving a platform and a farmer, where the platform resells the farmer's products and introduces its own farm's products as competitors. Unlike improving consumer utility, AI is developed to increase agricultural yields in this study. We use game theory to analyze and compare three AI technology policies of the platform: no AI, only developing AI in the self-built farm, and sharing AI with the farmer. Results show that the platform benefits from AI and shares the technology only if AI technology increases the efficiency of agricultural planting or slightly reduces it. Interestingly, the higher the AI technology effect, the less likely the farmer is to accept AI sharing policy. Additionally, when the farmer accepts it, the higher its efficacy, the less advantageous it may become. Through extended analysis, we find that these conclusions are stable regardless of whether the platform charges technology fees to the farmer or whether the role of AI is restricted. These insights contribute to a deeper understanding of AI technology policies for platforms in agricultural production.

title: Noise-Robust Generative Hashing for Cross-Modal Retrieval
authors: Zequn Wang, Tianshi Wang, Fengling Li, Jingjing Li, Lei Zhu
publish: ACM Transactions on Multimedia Computing, Communications, and Applications

title: Cooperative Air-Ground Instant Delivery by UAVs and Crowdsourced Taxis: Joint UAV Station Deployment and Delivery Scheduling
authors: Junhui Gao, Qianru Wang, Xin Zhang, Juan Shi, Xiang Zhao, Yunji Liang, Bin Guo, Qingye Han, Yan Pan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: Instant delivery has become an essential service in daily life, requiring strict delivery timelines. However, traditional delivery methods that employ human couriers struggle to meet the soaring delivery demands due to labor shortages. While researchers have explored alternative solutions using ground vehicles (e.g., crowdsourced taxis) and Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs), their inherent limitations, such as constrained delivery detour for crowdsourced taxis and limited battery capacity of UAVs, greatly constrain their effectiveness. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a novel air-ground delivery paradigm that cooperatively integrates UAVs and crowdsourced taxis. First, UAV stations are strategically deployed based on delivery gaps between the delivery demands and taxis' delivery capacity, instead of delivery demands only; Then, a predictive UAV repositioning strategy is designed to bridge instantaneously dynamic delivery gaps. Thereafter, a transfer learning-based (TL-based) algorithm that mines the delivery knowledge of human couriers is designed to optimize the cooperative performance. This algorithm extracts behavioral insights from human couriers and transfers them to enhance the delivery capabilities of UAVs and taxis. Finally, parcel assignment is formulated as optimization problems aimed at maximizing total preferences of UAVs and taxis, and maximizing delivery number while minimizing cost, respectively. Evaluations on real-world datasets demonstrate that the proposed method delivers 27.4% more parcels, saves 19.2% delivery cost, and preserves 36.3% more of the travel experience of taxi passengers than the state-of-the-art (SOTA) air-ground cooperative approach for instant delivery.

title: Design of a Hydraulic Prosthetic Knee With Control Moment for Adjustable Stance-Phase Knee Flexion
authors: Jiranut Manui, Chanyaphan Virulsri, Pattarapol Yotnuengnit, Manunchaya Samala, Pairat Tangpornprasert
publish: IEEE Transactions on Neural Systems and Rehabilitation Engineering
abstract: Lower-limb amputees worldwide have been increasing continuously in recent years. Hydraulic knees are suitable for active transfemoral amputees in developing countries due to their adaptability to various walking speeds and greater accessibility compared to high-end prosthetics. However, most hydraulic prosthetic knees operate via ground reaction force control, which exhibits a double-peak characteristic, causing slight flexion during the early stance phase, leading to unnatural and asymmetrical gait patterns for amputees. This study proposes a novel technique that expands the concept of the two-axis for application in a hydraulic prosthetic knee, utilizing the control moment to achieve stance-phase control (CMSPC knee). The control moment exhibits only one positive peak during the stance phase, allowing for adjustment of suitable stance-phase knee flexion by varying the spring stiffness. The single-subject walking experiment was conducted in the gait laboratory with one transfemoral amputee to evaluate the conceptual design. The subject walked on a treadmill at a constant velocity of 0.9 m/s, a self-selected walking speed, for 30 seconds, repeated four times for each spring stiffness. The results showed that the CMSPC knee can adjust the maximum stance-phase knee flexion from approximately 4.15° to 13.89°, which is roughly the same range observed in non-disabled individuals. Finally, most gait symmetry in temporal variables was significantly improved, with comparable results between the best condition, at a spring stiffness of 12.2 N/mm, and the condition without a spring (Mann-Whitney, p < 0.05). The condition without a spring is represented by hydraulic knees that offer slight stance-phase knee flexion.

title: Author response for "Strip-ViTAE: A Direction-Aware Transformer with Enhanced Feature Modeling for Remote Sensing Image Object Detection"
authors: Minqi Lin, Hongzhen Chen, Chenzheng Li, Guangyuan Liu, Chunjiang Bian

title: Human Capital in Organizational Culture: Comparing Serbian and Foreign Companies Using AI models
authors: Snezana Kirin, Ivana Vucetic, Gordana Gavric
publish: 2025 6th International Workshop on Engineering Technologies and Computer Science (EnT)
abstract: In the context of rapid technological development that enables worker mobility, remote and online work, as well as economic pressures that drive companies to relocate across borders in pursuit of higher profits and growth, organizational culture—and, consequently, the role of people as a source of competitive advantage—emerges as a critical challenge for both practitioners and researchers. Organizational culture shapes behavior, teamwork, leadership, and innovation. Human capital includes technical competence, adaptability, and knowledgesharing. Together, they form the backbone of competitive advantage. This study investigates the impact of organizational culture on human capital in domestic and foreign companies operating in Serbia, i.e., within the same national cultural environment using Multilayer Perceptron (MLP) and Radial Basis Function (RBF) neural network models, the analysis assesses factor significance and ranks their relative importance, thus capturing both linear and nonlinear relationships. The results show that domestic firms prioritize teamwork and technical competence, reflecting more collectivist and “feminine” cultural values, whereas foreign firms emphasize innovation, leadership, and strategic goal balancing, consistent with more individualistic and proactive approaches. The integrated use of regression and AI models provides comprehensive insights into cultural influences on human capital and offers practical implications for management and HR strategies in increasingly globalized and mobile business environments.

title: Analysis of the Effect of Vibration on Interferometric SAR Imaging with Satellite-Mounted Dual Antennas
authors: Zhibin Wang, Qingjun Zhang, Yan Li, Jiuli Liu
publish: 2024 5th China International SAR Symposium (CISS)
abstract: The dual-antenna interferometric Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) satellite primarily centers on high-precision Digital Elevation Model (DEM) mapping. The satellite employs the interferometric system of a single satellite with double mast, presenting stable interferometric baselines and high mapping efficiency. Given that the SAR antenna is installed at the extremity of the long support arm, the phenomenon of mast vibration exists for the satellite in orbit. In this paper, the performance influence on SAR imaging induced by the vibration of the support arm is analyzed. Firstly, the on-orbit imaging geometric model of the satellite is established, and the analyses are respectively conducted from the position error of the antenna phase center and the attitude error of the SAR antenna on imaging. The correctness of the analyses in this paper is verified through simulation analysis. A preliminary compensation approach is proposed to mitigate the impact of support arm vibration on imaging, which can furnish a technical basis for imaging processing subsequent to the satellite's entry into orbit.

title: EEG-TransNet: An Ensemble Transformer Framework with Multi-Stream Feature Extraction for Automated Epilepsy Risk Assessment
authors: Zhe Shi, Niandong Chen, Xuefeng Shi, Yanming Han
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Complex Medical Engineering (CME)
abstract: This paper presents EEG-TransNet, a novel ensemble transformer framework for automated epilepsy risk assessment through electroencephalogram (EEG) analysis. The framework introduces three key innovations: a preprocessing pipeline with ICA-based artifact removal, a multi-stream feature extraction architecture processing wavelet transforms and frequency bands ($\delta-\gamma$), and an ensemble transformer model with modified attention mechanisms optimized for EEG signals. Experimental results demonstrate superior performance (sensitivity: $\mathbf{9 2. 3 \%}$, specificity: $\mathbf{8 9. 7 \%}$) compared to LSTM and CNN baselines, with successful preictal detection averaging 15.3 seconds before seizure onset. The framework’s attention visualization mechanism provides interpretable insights while maintaining computational efficiency, offering a promising solution for clinical applications.

title: Integration of IoT and Machine Learning for Monitoring Rubber Latex Stirrer Motor Systems Using PCA and K-Means Techniques
authors: Tanakorn Inthasuth, Theerawat Petdee, Thanwit Naemsai, Kritsana Sureeya, Siti Zuraidah Ibrahim
publish: 2025 24th International Symposium on Communications and Information Technologies (ISCIT)
abstract: In rubber latex stirrer production systems, monitoring and analyzing multiple variables such as electric current and temperature from three-phase industrial motors is essential for detecting abnormal operating conditions. This paper proposes a method for classifying the operating states of heating motors by applying Principal Component Analysis (PCA) for dimensionality reduction and K-Means clustering for unsupervised state classification. The data were collected via an Internet of Things (IoT)-based monitoring system that recorded 13 sensor parameters. PCA was used to reduce the dimensionality of the feature space, and K-Means clustering identified three distinct motor states: idle, normal, and overheating. The analysis revealed that Motor 2 frequently entered an overheating state, with current surges above 10 A and temperatures exceeding 90° C, while Motors 1 and 3 remained in stable operating zones. Clustering performance was validated using silhouette analysis, with most samples achieving scores above 0.7. This approach enhances predictive maintenance by enabling automated state identification through low-cost IoT hardware and unsupervised machine learning techniques.

title: Theta rTMS Enhances Verbal Memory Encoding by Modulating Fronto-Parietal Dynamics
authors: Xiao Yang, Chunyu Zhang, Han Liu, Guangying Pei
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Complex Medical Engineering (CME)
abstract: This study investigated frequency-specific effects of left parietal rhythmic transcranial magnetic stimulation(rTMS) on verbal memory encoding by combining 5 Hz and 20 Hz stimulation with concurrent electroencephalogram (EEG) in three healthy subjects. Behaviorally, 5 Hz stimulation significantly enhanced memory accuracy compared to $20 \mathrm{~Hz}(t=7.141, p=0.019)$. Neural oscillations revealed that while both frequencies increased power in their respective bands, 5 Hz stimulation produced stronger enhancement. Frontal-central $\boldsymbol{\theta}$ power positively correlated with memory performance during 5 Hz stimulation, whereas frontotemporal $\beta$ power predicted recall under 20 Hz stimulation. These findings demonstrate that 5 Hz parietal rTMS optimizes memory encoding through $\boldsymbol{\theta}$ oscillation enhancement and frontal-parietal network synchronization, while 20 Hz stimulation yields weaker behavioral effects with distinct neural correlates. These findings establish a novel concurrent TMS-EEG paradigm for real-time observation of frequency-specific entrainment effects during cognition, surpassing traditional pre/post designs. Critically, prefrontal theta power emerged as a neurophysiological predictor of memory enhancement under theta-rhythmic stimulation, providing a biomarker for personalized neuromodulation.

title: Correlating Artificial Intelligence and Sustainable Development in Africa
authors: Ayoub Ouboumlik, Hassan Khafif, Naoual Ouazzani Touhami
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: The empirical relationship between Artificial Intelligence (AI) readiness and Sustainable Development Goal (SDGs) achievement in Africa is explored. Using secondary 2024 Government AI Readiness Index and United Nations SDG database data, Pearson and Spearman correlation analysis, supported by multiple linear regressions, are used in an analysis of relationships between AI readiness drivers (government strategy, maturity of the tech sector, and data infrastructure) and SDG pillars (economy, society, environment, and partnerships). Significant positive correlation (r = 0.792) is found between AI readiness and SDG performance. Technological maturity and data infrastructure are found to have strong positive impacts on economic outcomes as well as societal outcomes, with small trade-offs against environmental measures. Regression models verify that data infrastructure and technology as leading predictors of SDG advancement, whereas government strategic vision has variable influence. The results demonstrate AI’s potential for transformative sustainable development in Africa but emphasize the importance of responsible governance, cross-industrial partnerships, and capacity development to leverage its full socio-economic potential while overcoming risks. This work fills an empirical gap in the literature and provides actionable recommendations for policymakers, technologists, and development stakeholders aiming to harness AI for faster SDG attainment in Africa.

title: A Gaussian Mixture Model-based Decomposition Approach for State of Health Estimation in Lithium-ion Batteries
authors: Jiarui Zhang, Kun Yu, Peng Liu, Lei Mao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: Accurate assessment of battery degradation remains crucial for the reliable operation of lithium-ion battery systems. This study presents a novel approach using Gaussian mixture models (GMM) as a mathematical framework for decomposing incremental capacity curves and extracting features for state of health estimation. The GMM decomposition transforms complex IC curves into a compact parametric representation, with each Gaussian component characterized by position, width, amplitude, and area parameters. These parameters systematically evolve with battery aging, providing rich information for health assessment. We evaluate three machine learning approaches—Gaussian process regression, random forests, and support vector regression—to establish the relationship between GMM parameters and state of health. Using the Oxford Battery Degradation Dataset, Gaussian process regression achieves the best performance with RMSE of 0.64, followed by random forests (1.40) and support vector regression (1.86). The method demonstrates robust performance across different cells with computational efficiency suitable for real-time applications (~0.03s per curve). The systematic feature extraction framework offers a valuable tool for battery diagnostics, balancing accuracy with practical implementation requirements.

title: Classification of Body Constitution of Traditional Chinese Medicine Using Iris Images Based on YOLOv5-CBAM
authors: Sheng Zhang
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Complex Medical Engineering (CME)
abstract: Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) employs a holistic framework grounded in the philosophical principles of Yin-Yang theory and the Five Phases (Wu Xing) for constitutional classification and analysis. Western iridology associates the textures and colors of the iris with the body’s physical constitution, innate vulnerabilities, overall health condition, and physiological changes. With the combination of TCM with western iridology, the objective of this study is to provide an accurate and lightweight iris image recognition and detection framework to realize TCM constitution identification. The method combined the image processing technology with the improved YOLOv5 by introducing attention mechanism convolutional block attention module (CBAM). In this study, the data from the public accessible database CASIA-Iris-Thousand was applied to perform the experiments. The optimal performance of the method is as follows: precision is 97.5%, recall is 94.6%, mean average precision is 98.5 %, loss is 0.5 %. It surpasses current state-of-the-art deep learning algorithms in iris detection performance. Experimental results indicate that the proposed model achieves relatively high precision and low loss, demonstrating potential for deployment in real-time iris recognition systems or mobile devices. Additionally, it offers a novel approach and practical solution for TCM constitution differentiation.

title: An Objective Evaluation Method for "Vehicle-Grid" Coordinated Planning Schemes Based on Entropy-Weighted CRITIC Combined Weighting and Improved TOPSIS
authors: Tianlu Luo, Feipeng Huang, Yaxiong Wu, Yongquan Gan, Shikai Liao
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: The rapid growth of electric vehicles (EVs) introduces new challenges for distribution network planning, including both "load surge" and "interactive regulation." Traditional evaluation methods often rely on subjective weights or a single distance metric, limiting objectivity and accuracy. This study develops a comprehensive evaluation system with 12 indicators across five dimensions—safety, economy, interaction, environmental impact, and user experience. An objective method is proposed, integrating entropy-weighted CRITIC weighting and a dual-distance TOPSIS model (Euclidean and cosine). This approach combines indicator dispersion and inter-criterion conflict, achieving balanced weighting and enhanced discrimination for high-dimensional evaluations.

title: Research on deep learning compression algorithm and embedded deployment of power infrastructure monitoring data for weak signal areas
authors: Zhikan Lin, Guosheng Zhou, Chaozhang Yu, Wenxin Li, Di Jin, Cheng Lin, Yuzheng Liu, Wei Chen, Jinshan Wu, Yujie Lin, Junjie Lin, Peng Qiu
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: In weak signal areas of power infrastructure, surveillance video data suffers from unstable transmission and low compression efficiency, urgently requiring high-performance compression solutions to support effective data downlink. This paper proposes a video image compression model based on deep convolutional neural networks and Transformer structures and analyzes key algorithmic mechanisms such as spatial redundancy compression and temporal frame interpolation, constructs a video training dataset and end-to-end compression model adapted to power scenarios, and explores parameter optimization and lightweight deployment paths for the compression model in embedded devices. This research helps improve the quality of compressed transmission of on-site surveillance images and provides deep learning technology support for data communication in edge intelligent devices.

title: A DC continuous commutation failure suppression method considering reactive power compensation
authors: Chenyu Yan, Yi Lu, Guopeng Zhu, Yanping Li, Li Mu, Xinyi Zhang, Tao Jia, Shuai Liu, Yanjie Zhang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: To address the severity of continuous commutation failure in ultra-high voltage direct current (UHVDC) system and the limitations of existing emergency control methods, this paper proposes a coordinated control strategy integrating synchronous condenser strong excitation and the DC power rapid reduction. Leveraging the characteristics of mechanism of continuous commutation failure is analyzed. Leveraging the characteristics of synchronous condenser, the spontaneous reactive response are used to suppress continuous commutation failure. The DC power rapid reduction control method is employed to compensate for the insufficient response time. And a coordinated continuous commutation failure emergency control method is proposed. Simulation results of the UHVDC transmission system demonstrate that the proposed control method can effectively reduce voltage fluctuations and suppress continuous commutation failure.

title: Research on Improved Droop Control Strategy Based on Superconducting-Electrochemical Hybrid Energy Storage Converter
authors: Hanbin Sun, Liuwei Xu, Pengfei Wang, Jing Lu, Yanan Wu, Hao Yin, Nan Liu, Baocan He
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: The integration of nuclear fusion and superconducting technology promotes energy transformation. High temperature superconductivity is widely used in the field of nuclear fusion and energy storage. Superconducting-battery energy storage system improves the stability of microgrid, especially plays a key role in off-grid islands. Droop control is often used in energy storage converter systems. Aiming at the power coupling and voltage frequency fluctuation of traditional droop control in resistance-inductance lines, an improved droop control strategy is proposed. Firstly, based on the principle of droop control, a general power decoupling droop control formula is proposed. Then, on this basis, the output frequency and voltage amplitude of the droop control are compensated twice to obtain the improved droop control, so as to realize the secondary regulation of voltage and frequency. Finally, based on the Matlab/Simulink platform, a superconducting-electrochemical hybrid energy storage converter model is established. The simulation results show that the improved droop control strategy significantly improves the dynamic response and steady-state performance through power decoupling and secondary compensation to achieve voltage and frequency self-recovery and enhance system adaptability.

title: Evaluation of the Health Condition of CNC Machine Tools Based on Grey Theory
authors: Weichen Liu, Jizhuang Hui, Shaowei Zhi, Shihao Gao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: The health status of CNC machining tools plays a critical role in ensuring enterprise production safety and efficient equipment operation. Timely evaluation of equipment health status facilitates early fault detection and response. This paper proposes a comprehensive evaluation method: first, CNC machine tools is divided into eight major systems based on their characteristics; second, the importance of each system is analyzed through a judgment matrix to clarify the mapping relationships among equipment, systems, and factors, as well as the information sources of these factors; third, a whitening weight function is constructed using grey fuzzy clustering theory to establish an equipment evaluation system based on grey clustering; finally, the universality and effectiveness of this method are verified through a case study on CNC machine tools.

title: MetaContrast-GNN: Meta-Contrastive Learning for Cross-City Travel Time Estimation
authors: Do Thanh Thai, Quang Tran Minh
publish: 2025 24th International Symposium on Communications and Information Technologies (ISCIT)
abstract: Accurate Travel Time Estimation (TTE) is essential in Intelligent Transportation Systems (ITS), supporting tasks such as vehicle dispatching, routing, and traffic management. However, existing models often generalize poorly across cities due to diverse urban dynamics. We propose MetaContrast-GNN, a framework that combines Graph Neural Networks (GNNs), contrastive learning, and Model-Agnostic Meta-Learning (MAML) for robust cross-city TTE under limited data. Evaluated on taxi datasets from New York, Chicago, Washington D.C., and Ho Chi Minh City, our model outperforms baselines. A GNN trained only on Ho Chi Minh City yields a Mean Absolute Error (MAE) of 204.27 seconds (around 3.4 minutes) and Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) of 209.62 seconds (around 3.5 minutes), while MetaContrast-GNN reduces error to 3.01 and 3.32 minutes, respectively. These results highlight the benefits of meta-learning and contrastive pretraining for scalable, transferable TTE. Though not solving the full vehicle dispatching problem, our method offers a generalizable TTE module to support broader ITS applications.

title: Constructing new loss functions for machine learning using strict continuous Archimedean t-norms
authors: Mohamed Hssini, Mustapha Atraoui
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: We propose a unified approach to integrating reasoning and deep learning by introducing Strict Differentiable Fuzzy Logics, a family of logics built on first-order fuzzy logic and driven only by strict continuous Archimedean t-norms. By employing the selected t-norm generator, the available first-order logic-based knowledge is translated into a differentiable loss function. The satisfiability computation for this developed novel class of loss functions is simplifiable. A representative example showing how the presented framework can be applied is given and loss functions are explicitly constructed.

title: Optimal Load Scheduling in Residential Nanogrids Using Artificial Bee Colony Algorithm
authors: Sarah S. Negm, Abdelrahman M. Alshehawy, Doaa M. Yehia, Gamal E. Ali
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Power Electronics and Renewable Energy (CPERE)
abstract: As global electricity demand grows and reducing CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> emissions becomes increasingly urgent, renewable energy sources are being integrated into smart grids at an increasing rate. However, the intermittent nature of these resources necessitates applying energy management techniques for efficient and reliable system operation. This paper presents a demand side management (DSM) program for grid-connected residential nanogrids, providing price-based optimal load scheduling using the Artificial Bee Colony algorithm. The optimization aims to minimize both electricity consumption cost and CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> emissions by efficiently managing the energy among photovoltaic generation, batteries, and various residential loads. A Simulink model was developed to validate the proposed DSM approach. Simulation results demonstrated the proposed program’s effectiveness in generating optimal load profiles and reducing the consumption cost of the nanogrid.

title: Design and Comparison of Beamforming Algorithms for Integrated Sensing and Communication
authors: Zhequn Mao, Songlin Sun, Lingyu Shi
publish: 2025 24th International Symposium on Communications and Information Technologies (ISCIT)
abstract: Wireless systems are increasingly exploring radar-occupied spectral bands to mitigate congestion in traditional communication bands. This thesis proposes a joint transmit beamforming model for dual-function MIMO radar and multi-user communication systems, sharing antenna arrays and spectrum. The system transmits a weighted composite of radar waveforms and communication symbols, optimized to enhance radar beamforming while ensuring each user's SINR meets a minimum threshold. Although the problem is non-convex, it is reformulated as a convex optimization via tight semi-definite relaxation. A low-complexity zero-forcing interference suppression method is also introduced, alongside a deep learning-based solution for weight optimization. Compared to existing approaches—separate deployment or communication-only radar beam synthesis—the proposed method achieves superior radar performance, with higher beam peaks and better antenna DoF utilization, as validated by simulations.

title: Optimal Power Flow Prediction with GWO-CNN-XGBOOST Model in New Energy Scenarios
authors: Fu Yang, Guosong Wang, Qinfeng Ma, Junquan Chen, Qingqing Zhang, Huaying Su
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: To address the problem of fast calculation of optimal power flow (OPF) under uncertain scenarios of load and output caused by large-scale integration of new energy, a hybrid model combining Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) and eXtreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost) optimized by Grey Wolf Optimizer (GWO) is proposed for OPF prediction in power systems. By leveraging the high-dimensional feature extraction capability of CNN, integrating the gradient boosting learning advantage of XGBoost, and optimizing model parameters via GWO, efficient prediction of key state variables is achieved. Experiments on typical power system cases show that compared with traditional machine learning methods, the proposed model significantly improves prediction accuracy, especially demonstrating stronger adaptability in high-proportion new energy scenarios. This provides a reliable technical path for real-time optimal scheduling of power systems.

title: Suppression of Ultra-Low Frequency Oscillations in An Island Hydropower-HVDC Power System with A Coordinated Damping Control
authors: Zhifei Guo, Yong Zhao, Wei Liu, Wantong Cai
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: With the growing application of modular multilevel converter-based high voltage direct current (MMC-HVDC) systems in asynchronous interconnections, new challenges related to frequency stability have been observed. Ultra-low-frequency oscillations (ULFO) are often introduced by a high proportion of hydropower. To mitigate these issues, a damping control strategy based on coordinated source-grid actions is presented. A frequency response model including hydropower units is first established. The mechanism of ULFO is investigated through damping torque analysis, and the effects of various governor parameters are examined. A comprehensive performance index is defined to evaluate both frequency regulation and oscillation damping. Considering the limited damping capability of hydropower alone, a multi-band additional damping control strategy for the MMC is developed. Through this approach, positive damping is jointly provided by the MMC and hydropower units. Finally, a simulation model is constructed on the CloudPSS platform to validate the effectiveness of the suppression strategy of ULFO. The effectiveness of the proposed strategy is verified through comparative case studies, demonstrating improved suppression capacity of both ULFO.

title: FPGA-Based 16-Channel Parallel Large-Point Pipeline FFT Design
authors: Xiuyuan Yang, Ao Zhu, Guang-Cai Sun, Chi He, Jiao Tian, Mengdao Xing
publish: 2024 5th China International SAR Symposium (CISS)
abstract: As a necessary tool for SAR imaging, FFT operation speed greatly affects the timeliness of SAR imaging. In order to meet the demand for high real-time performance and large data volume of satellite-borne SAR imaging, this paper designs a 16-channel parallel streaming FFT architecture with any quadratic powerpoint number within 131072 points. The architecture is based on the frequency domain extraction FFT algorithm, which changes the data input point by point to 16-point by 16-point, and accelerates the FFT calculation speed by 16 times compared with the traditional single-channel FFT. For the situation where the large-point FFT algorithm consumes a lot of storage resources, the SDF-FFT computational structure is adopted to reduce the use of BRAM resources step by step. Compared with Xilinx's FFT IP core, the bandwidth and operation speed of this architecture are increased by 16 times under the same clock frequency, which can be deployed on a single XC7VX690 chip without external storage to meet the requirements of real-time computation for large data, and the correctness of the results is verified by the on-board verification.

title: Analysis of the Labour Market for IT Leadership Competences in the Field of AI and IoT
authors: I. Kostadinova, N. Yanev, G. Dimitrov, V. Martsenyuk, M. Figueiredo, O. Bychkov
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Technologies, Systems and Services in Telecommunications (TELSIKS)
abstract: Researching the competencies of IT leaders in the field of artificial intelligence (AI) and the Internet of Things (IoT) is key and necessitated by global changes in the labour market. It will allow to highlight of emerging skills and guide the development of the workforce, thereby supporting the growth of innovation. This article presents a labour market study of job openings in the AI and IoT field and the competencies required of candidates for the advertised jobs. The research includes tracking advertised job positions and analysing what specialists are in demand, as well as the skills and competencies they need to possess. The research questions are addressed, like a what kind of job position, what type of employment and education are required for the sought-after position, and what experience should people applying for such a position have. Also, what are the key skills, competencies (organisational, leadership, personal), technical knowledge, soft skills, and main responsibilities required for an IT business leader is needed. The conducted study and analysis provide an overview of the types of job postings available for IT specialists in the fields of AI and IoT. The data from it will give a clear picture of what specialists, in what field and at what working hours are sought by business organisations. In addition, it was analysed what education, competencies and skills for working with AI and IoT the job candidates should have. The analysis prepared in this way will be useful for students and novice specialists, working specialists who want a career transition or growth, HR teams and companies and start-ups and entrepreneurs. This analysis will also be useful for educational organisations, where it will guide them in what areas to organise future practical training in the field of AI and IoT.

title: Research on Low Current Leakage Detection Based on Extended Kalman Filtering
authors: Yang Zhang, Shenghu Tao, Weidong Dou, Dongfeng Zheng, Zhiping Li, Xiaoliang Kang, Rui Xu
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: The tiny leakage currents that occur in low-voltage distribution systems are often difficult to be detected in time by traditional protection devices. In this paper, the Extended Kalman Filter (EKF) is innovatively applied to low-current leakage detection, achieving accurate estimation of leakage current. Compared with the traditional fixed threshold detection method, EKF utilizes time series measurement data and system models, and can still detect low leakage currents far below the threshold in a strong noise background, improving the detection accuracy and response speed. The simulation and experimental results show that this method can effectively detect leakage currents of only fifteen mA in single-phase distribution networks, verifying the effectiveness and application potential of EKF in leakage detection.

title: A Method for Bearing Fault Diagnosis Based on Image Fusion and Dual-Channel Convolutional Neural Networks
authors: Yue Cao, Yanxue Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: In practical industrial processes, the limitation of fault data collection leads to a decline in feature extraction capability and causes issues of incomplete data interpretation when using a single-channel approach. To overcome this issue, this paper introduces a diagnostic framework that leverages image fusion and a dual-channel convolutional neural network. First, the MTF-GADF-GASF image conversion method is employed to transform time-series signals into three types of images, which are then encoded into the red, green, and blue (RGB) channels of an image for fusion. Subsequently, one-dimensional signals and two-dimensional images are simultaneously fed into a parallel dual-channel model, where the first channel utilizes a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) to extract spatial information, while the second channel employs Gated Recurrent Units (GRU) to capture temporal features from vibration signals. Finally, the spatiotemporal features extracted from both channels are fused and trained using a multi-head self-attention mechanism. Experimental results based on public and real-measured datasets indicate that the proposed diagnostic method achieves an average accuracy of 98.75% in fault type diagnosis under various operating conditions. Comparisons with other methods further demonstrate that this approach offers higher accuracy and robustness.

title: RFID Access Control for Underground Optical Distribution Cabinets with Real-Time Monitoring via Google Sheets
authors: Megan Ananta Putriasih, Uke Kurniawan Usman, Akhamad Hambali
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Information Technology, Computer, and Electrical Engineering (ICITACEE)
abstract: The security of Optical Distribution Cabinets (ODCs) remains heavily dependent on conventional key mechanisms, which are prone to vandalism, unauthorized access, and environmental threats. This paper presents the development of a secure access control system using Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) technology integrated with a solenoid lock. The system leverages Internet of Things (IoT) architecture for real-time access logging using Google Sheets via Google Apps Script, enabling lightweight and centralized monitoring. Experimental results based on 10 distinct RFID UID entries showed 100 % detection accuracy with an average system response time of 910 milliseconds, and stable performance under rapid consecutive scans. These findings demonstrate the feasibility of implementing a low-cost, scalable, and cloudconnected access control solution to enhance the physical security and remote supervision of underground ODCs.

title: Reduced Stresses Common Ground Five-Level Boost F-type Inverter with Continuous Input Current
authors: Mokhtar Aly, Eltaib Abdeen D. Ibrahim, Fernanda Carnielutti, Margarita Norambuena, Ahmed Elsanabary, Mohamed Abdelrahem, Samir Kouro, José Rodriguez
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Power Electronics and Renewable Energy (CPERE)
abstract: Leakage currents, resulting from common-mode voltages, represent a serious problem in photovoltaic (PV) inverter systems for personnel, equipment, and compliance with grid codes. The common grounded leg-based inverter topology proved to be a viable solution for addressing the leakage current problem. However, existing topologies suffer from the increased number of switches, a high number of passive components, high voltage stresses, and being diode-based, among other issues. The drawbacks become more apparent in the development of multilevel-based CG inverters. Therefore, this paper proposes a new five-level, F-type-based CG inverter for leakage current-free PV inverters. The proposed topology preserves the continuous PV side current and maximizes power extraction from PV systems. The employment of F-type legs enables multilevel diode-free with reduced voltage stresses compared to NPC and T-NPC inverter legs. Furthermore, a predictive control algorithm is proposed in this paper for controlling both the input and output sides with a single objective function, and eliminating the need for a modulator. Simulation results, enhanced with comparative results, are provided in the paper, which demonstrate the superior merits and performance metrics of the new proposed inverter and control method.

title:
Simulation Study of Steady-state Temperature Rise Characteristics of Large-Capacity SF
                    <sub>6</sub>
                    Inflatable Bushing
authors: Fusheng Zhou, Yao Zheng, Chao Gao, Ruodong Huang, Yi Zhang, Zhi Ye
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: This paper takes 550kV/8kA large-capacity SF<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</inf> inflatable bushing as an example, analyses the steady state temperature field distribution characteristics inside the inflatable bushing, takes into full consideration the influence of the flow of insulating gas on the temperature distribution, and researches the influences of the VES (voltage equalisation shielding) and the internal electrical connection parts on the distribution of the temperature field. The results show that: the gas flow inside the inflatable bushing is very limited, and the heat loss through heat conduction and heat convection is 1:9; the existence of VES mainly affects the temperature field and flow field distribution on the lower side of the inflatable bushing, the influence on the location of high temperature zone and the maximum temperature value is negligible, then when evaluating the performance of temperature rise in the optimisation stage of the product design iteration, the VES can be ignored in order to simplify the calculations; when there is an electrical connection inside the inflatable bushing, the maximum temperature occurs at the location of the internal electrical connection, and the maximum temperature value can be approximated as a constant and the superposition of the temperature value at this location when there is no electrical connection. The above rules can be used as a reference for the simplification of the simulation model at the product design stage.

title: Testing Open Ring as a Microwave Microstrip Pressure Sensor on Textiles
authors: D. Nesic
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Technologies, Systems and Services in Telecommunications (TELSIKS)
abstract: Open Ring resonator as a Microwave Microstrip Pressure Sensors on Textiles was tested in the range around 2.5 GHz. Rubber foam was used to apply pressure to the entire resonator. The measurement was performed for three cases of rubber foam: Two thicknesses and metallization of the upper part. The metallization on the textile is made of copper tape with a non-conductive adhesive so that it can be removed and shortened without damaging the textile. Also, the rubber foam is glued to the oscillator and can be removed. With this, an attempt was made to meet the sustainable development goals. The sensor is still in the experimental phase.

title: Modeling of Stator Current Signals and Drive Train Fault Monitoring Applications in Doubly-Fed Induction Generator Wind Turbines
authors: Xinrui Yin, Yanjie Shen, Yingjie Wu, Yue Liu, Pengfei Li, Qiming Ma
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: In the field of Doubly-Fed Induction Generator (DFIG) wind turbine drive train condition monitoring, the stator current signal exhibits global anomaly detection capability. This paper proposes a novel drive train condition monitoring method based on the amplitude ratio of DFIG stator current signals. First, MATLAB/Simulink is employed to simulate DFIG wind turbine operation. By comparing simulated stator current signals with measured signals, the theoretical and practical differences in their composition and variation patterns are analyzed. Subsequently, a current amplitude ratio algorithm is developed by leveraging the distinct characteristics of stator current signals under healthy operation versus fault conditions. Furthermore, experimental validation is conducted using a DFIG wind turbine simulation test platform, where stator current signals are collected under both healthy and various fault states. The results demonstrate that the proposed method can effectively identify drive train faults, showing significant engineering practicality for DFIG wind turbine condition monitoring.

title: Multi-objective Optimization for Virtual Power Plant Based on Carbon Flow Tracing
authors: Shucan Zhou, Hao Yu, Xin Huang, Weijie Wu, Minjia Zheng, Yixin Li, Yu Cai, Xiangyang Su
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: To simultaneously enhance the environmental and economic benefits of virtual power plant (VPP) scheduling, a multi-objective optimization approach based on carbon flow tracing is proposed. First, a nodal carbon potential calculation model is constructed based on optimal power flow results and carbon flow tracing theory, quantifying the carbon emission intensity of flexible loads. Subsequently, an electricity pricing mechanism based on nodal carbon potential is introduced, establishing a hybrid optimization algorithm through a hierarchical iterative algorithm that achieves closed-loop feedback between electricity price signals and carbon potential distribution. Finally, a case study is simulated, with results demonstrating that the proposed strategy reduces carbon emissions by 17.7% at the same profit level and increases profit by 30.4% under identical carbon emissions, validating its synergistic enhancement effect on grid operation.

title: MOAM: A Cross-Attention Fusion and Multi-Head Attention Learning for Multi-Omics Cancer Recurrence Prediction Framework
authors: Xiaofei Liu, Haiyan Cui, Sujuan Zhao, Yanling Hu
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Complex Medical Engineering (CME)
abstract: Cancer recurrence prediction is critical for precision medicine and personalized treatment. However, existing methods exhibit limitations in modeling the complex relationships among multi-omics data (mRNA, SNV, miRNA), capturing intersample correlations, and handling data imbalance, thereby constraining predictive performance. To address these issues, we propose a cancer recurrence prediction model MOAM, which incorporates cross-attention fusion and multi-head attention learning. The model integrates prior biological pathway knowledge, utilizes a cross-attention mechanism to capture interomics dependencies, applies a multi-head attention mechanism to extract key features, and performs classification through a multilayer perceptron (MLP). Results from five-fold cross-validation on the BRCA and LIHC datasets demonstrate that MOAM outperforms existing methods in both prediction accuracy and robustness, achieving AUC values of 0.843 and 0.918 and F1-scores of 0.777 and 0.919, respectively, confirming its effectiveness in multi-omics integration and recurrence prediction.

title: Fixed and Predefined-time Control to Synchronize DMDNNs With Unknown Nonlinearity Parameters under Adaptive Identification
authors: Fei Tan, Lili Zhou, Quanxin Zhu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: Adaptive fixed/predefined-time control to synchronize discontinuous multiple delay neural networks (DMDNNs) under unknown parameters identification is studied in this paper. To overcome the influence under uncertain factors in the DMDNNs, adaptive control technology is introduced into the design of controllers. In order to identify unknown parameters for state dependent switching in the DMDNNs within a fixed/predefined settling time, a fixed/predefined time identification method is derived. Under the premise that fixed time synchronization (FTS) is implemented in DMDNNs, adaptive fixed time identifier and controller are redesigned to achieve synchronization and identify unknown parameters in the DMDNNs within a predefined settling time. By the Lyapunov stability method, the corresponding synchronization criteria under FTS and predefined-time synchronization (PTS) are derived. FTS/PTS and identification of parameters under DMDNNs have potential applications in secure communication, pattern recognition, and other fields.

title: Decentralized Swarm Control via SO(3) Embeddings for 3D Trajectories
authors: Dimitria Silveria, Kleber Cabral, Peter T. Jardine, Sidney Givigi
publish: IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters
abstract: This paper presents a novel decentralized approach for achieving emergent behavior in multi-agent systems with minimal information sharing. Based on prior work in simple orbits, our method produces a broad class of stable, periodic trajectories by stabilizing the system around a Lie group-based geometric embedding. Employing the Lie group SO(3), we generate a wider range of periodic curves than existing quaternion-based methods. Furthermore, we exploit SO(3) properties to eliminate the need for velocity inputs, allowing agents to receive only position inputs. We also propose a novel phase controller that ensures uniform agent separation, along with a formal stability proof. Validation through simulations and experiments showcases the method's adaptability to complex low-level dynamics and disturbances.

title: Covert Free-Space Optical Communications with SLM-Based Beam Steering
authors: Ivan B. Djordjevic, Ignacio A. Rojas
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Technologies, Systems and Services in Telecommunications (TELSIKS)
abstract: In secure communications, the focus is on protecting the content of the message. In contrast, low probability of intercept (LPI) communication prioritizes the privacy of the communication process itself. The most restrictive form of LPI communication, where the adversary shuts down the communication as soon as the presence of the transmission is detected, is known as covert communication. To conceal the transmitted signal within solar radiation, we propose using an incoherent Gaussian source modulated with phase-shift keying (PSK). To facilitate detection of the transmitted signal, we propose transmitting a portion of the unmodulated carrier. For establishing the link, we employ a spatial light modulator (SLM)based beam steering approach. To explore these concepts, we have developed a 1.5 km free-space optical link at the University of Arizona campus. Our results demonstrate the record number of covert bits transmitted in the saturation turbulence regime.

title: Driving Innovations and Pioneering Advancements in Solar Tracker Systems: An In Depth Review of Technological Breakthroughs and Future Directions
authors: Alyaa Abdo Hassan, Mohamed El-Sayed M. Essa, E. E. El-Kholy, Mohamed Mustafa Ramadan, Amir Raouf
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Power Electronics and Renewable Energy (CPERE)
abstract: This paper focuses on the importance of solar trackers through distinct control the orientation of solar panel toward the sun to increase solar energy production efficiency. Besides, a variety of solar tracking system types are examined in this paper, including active and passive tracking systems, singleaxis (SAST) and dual-axis (DAST) with introducing different control strategies which are utilized in sun tracking systems. The review also looks at how different environmental elements and mechanical forces affect solar tracking systems’ efficiency. The distinct role of artificial intelligence (AI) and Internet of Things (IoT) in improving the solar trackers technology are discussed in this paper. To give a thorough and trustworthy study and provide a fair viewpoint on the developments and difficulties in solar tracking technology, prior research both contemporary and historical has been evaluated.

title: Fault Diagnosis of Hydraulic Cylinders Based on Hybrid Kernel Support Vector Machine
authors: Bowen Duan, Muhetaer Kelimu, Rongchun Chen, Qisong Liu, Chao Chen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: The primary purpose of a hydraulic cylinder-type hydraulic system is to transform the hydraulic energy of the system into mechanical energy and enable the hydraulic cylinders linear reciprocating motion. The stability and effectiveness of the hydraulic system will be significantly impacted by hydraulic cylinder leaks, which are a common issue with these devices. In order to solve this issue, this paper suggests a weighted support vector machine with genetic algorithm optimized linear kernel and Gaussian kernel approach for diagnosing hydraulic cylinder leakage faults. Afterwards, this method is coupled with the One vs Rest approach to achieve multi-classification of hydraulic cylinder leakage faults. According to the experimental results, the method significantly improves the accuracy of fault classification and has good applicability in multi-classification tasks compared to the single-core support vector machine (SVM) model as well as the LDA model.

title: Analysis of Metallic Return Line Ground Faults in Three-Terminal Hybrid HVDC Systems
authors: Kang Guo, Xiang Ju, Han Zhang, Yuan Zhou, Junjie Lan, Jinlin Wei
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: Multi-terminal High-Voltage Direct Current System (MTDC) is a HVDC system composed of at least three converter stations connected by high voltage DC transmission line. This paper analyzes the structure of three terminal Hybrid HVDC system, the conversion process of three terminal Ground-to-Metallic Transition (GMT) and the characteristics of Metallic Return Line (MRL) ground fault in the transition process, expounds the characteristics of MRL ground fault in the transition process of three terminal GMT, and points out the influence of MRL ground fault in the transition process on three terminal Hybrid HVDC system. The protection configuration for this type of fault is introduced.

title: Blockchain-driven Gamification Model to Enhance Student Participation
authors: Ignatius Valentino Kurniawan, Ridwan Sanjaya, Bernardinus Harnadi
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Information Technology, Computer, and Electrical Engineering (ICITACEE)
abstract: In the field of higher education, students do not become involved in extracurricular activities due to low incentive to submit their achievements in the form of certificates. This is a problem that impacts more than just the students themselves, because in the absence of such elements, academic institutions would have no way to incorporate performance evaluation into their operating strategies, which could also impact the accreditation process. While students tend to procrastinate or skip away with their certificates, gamification can be the answer as the tedious, monotonous documentation procedure can be a participatory activity when game design elements such as badges and leaderboards are integrated into it. This paradigm provides in turn the authentication of the record that accompanies the record of intellectual achievements that are made in a succinct manner, by linking it to the blockchain that provides the immutable and transparent environment for these citations input_documents. Our model combines gamification techniques and blockchain credentialing in a nudging approach for timely submissions without compromising the process integrity that blockchain technology guarantees. The framework presented attempts to use game-based quests rewarding with verification to motivate students and enhance their academic relevancy. We expect this scheme to allow better student participation and overall performance with a more interactive and dependable learning environment.

title: ICEEPS 2025 Copyright Page
authors: N/A
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)

title: TELSIKS 2025 Breaker Page
authors: N/A
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Technologies, Systems and Services in Telecommunications (TELSIKS)

title: Boosting Energy Harvesting Efficiency: Innovations in CMOS Rectifier Techniques for Enhanced Power Conversion, Sensitivity, and Dynamic Range
authors: Harikrishnan Ramiah
publish: 2025 24th International Symposium on Communications and Information Technologies (ISCIT)
abstract: The increasing adoption of large-scale IoT networks and the saturation of ambient Radio Frequencies (RF) signals have made ambient RF Energy Harvesting (RFEH) a compelling solution for powering low-energy electronics. As manufacturers seek alternatives to battery-dependent systems, ambient RFEH offers a scalable and maintenance-free energy source. This presentation introduces the motivation behind the growing interest in ambient RFEH, its potential applications across various domains and the current limitations of existing works. To address these limitations, our lab has developed a series of enhanced rectifier techniques incorporating Gate Biasing, Body Biasing, Hybrid Biasing, and Reconfigurable designs which aim to improve harvesting efficiency across a wider range of operating conditions and input power levels. The effectiveness of these techniques are demonstrated with experimental results and design insights. The presentation concludes with a summary of our contributions and a discussion on future directions.

title: A Millimeter-Wave Antenna with Tunable OAM Multiplexing Orders
authors: Bo Hu, Feng Qi, Yelong Wang, Nairui Hu, Tianhao Liu, Zhaoyang Liu
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: This letter presents a novel OAM antenna with a small aperture designed to enable tunable orbital angular momentum (OAM) multiplexing orders in the millimeter-wave (MMW) band. The transmission mechanism of vortex multiplexed beams carrying arbitrary opposite topological charges is analyzed, and an OAM order tuning scheme is developed based on a reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS) with a shared aperture. The measurement results indicate that the combined purity of the tunable OAM multiplexing modes generated by the proposed antenna exceeds 68%. Moreover, the isolation between different OAM modes at the receiving end is close to 15 dB. Both simulation and experimental results confirm that the OAM antenna offers reliable transmission performance for vortex multiplexed beams and supports flexible adjustment of OAM multiplexing orders. This work provides an effective approach to enhance spatial utilization efficiency in overlapped propagation directions, offering new possibilities for high-data-rate wireless communications.

title: A Scalable Large-Array M-QAM Direct-RF Transmitter Topology With Integrated Physical Layer Security—A Proof of Concept
authors: Yasser Bigdeli, Pascal Burasa, Ke Wu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: This article introduces a transmitter (TX) array topology that employs QPSK direct-RF TX units for realizing scalable large-array wireless communication and multifunction systems. By leveraging spatial power combination, the TX units are set to synthesize an extended M-QAM constellation, enabling flexible and high-order modulation. The QPSK modulation, when transmitted in an array, bolsters physical layer security by confining the constellation retrieval to the intended radiation angle, exhibiting high selectivity. Additionally, its low-dynamic-range (DR) waveform supports high-power output and improves the efficiency of power amplifiers (PAs) compared to higher-order constellations, thus significantly enhancing the array’s overall power–performance ratio. A comprehensive analysis is conducted on key performance factors, including location-dependent antenna gain variations, beamforming effectiveness, and phase front flatness. To validate the proposed technique, a <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$2\times 4$</tex-math> </inline-formula> array proof-of-concept (PoC) implementation is presented. Measurement results demonstrate robust performance across modulation orders ranging from 16-QAM to 256-QAM, aligning with theoretical predictions. This topology effectively integrates spatial constellation formation with the requirements of large-array systems, offering superior power efficiency. Its scalable building blocks, reconfigurability, and inherent secure communication capabilities make it a strong candidate for next-generation high-data-rate large-array TX systems.

title: Experimental study of Tamm plasmon polariton based hollow-core fiber sensor with one-dimensional photonic crystal/spacer/Ag structure
authors: Jinghui Ding, Jiachen Zhang, Xian Zhang, Zhen Wang, Yi Zhang, Xiao-Song Zhu, Yi-Wei Shi
publish: Journal of Lightwave Technology
abstract: To address the lack of experimental validation of Tamm plasmon polariton (TPP) in hollow fiber (HF) sensor research, this work proposes and experimentally demonstrates for the first time a HF TPP sensor based on a one-dimensional photonic crystal/spacer layer/Ag (1DPC/spacer/Ag) composite structure. System modeling and parameter optimization of the photonic crystal were conducted using a ray transmission model, theoretically confirming that this structure can efficiently excite TPP mode. Combined with the analysis of the tangential electric field distribution at the resonance wavelength, the formation mechanism of the resonance dip in the transmission spectrum was revealed to originate from the local field enhancement effect of TPP. Further in-depth analysis of the influence of the thickness of each layer on the TPP mode led to the successful fabrication of the designed fiber sensor. Experimental results reveal the excitation of TPP mode in the HF sensor system, which has not been verified by experiments up to now. Compared to traditional HF surface plasmon resonance sensor limitations, which can only detect refractive index (RI) higher than the cladding material, this sensor enables sensitive detection of low RI media. This work not only enriches the experimental research on fiber TPP sensor, but also establishes the theoretical and technical foundation for developing fiber sensors with a wide dynamic range.

title: Quantum-Accelerated Feature Selection for Edge-Enabled Perception in Connected and Autonomous Vehicles
authors: Vikas Hassija, Avishikta Bhattacharjee, Aradhya Chakrabarti, Qaiser Razi, M Adhitya, GSS Chalapathi
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: The growing complexity and volume of traffic and sensory data in Connected and Autonomous Vehicles (CAVs) make it crucial to develop more effective methods for selecting and extracting features from high-dimensional images and videos. This paper proposes a novel quantum-accelerated feature selection framework utilising the Variational Quantum Eigensolver (VQE) to enhance perception tasks in CAV environments. By decomposing high-dimensional traffic images into compact patches encoded as quantum Hamiltonians, the proposed design aims to support Intelligent Transportation Systems (ITS) tasks such as object detection, vehicle classification, and traffic monitoring in CAVs.The quantum hybrid method serves as a pipeline for extracting selective features that have been optimised using gradient-aware parameter pruning and conditional principal component analysis (PCA). The implementation of this quantum hybrid approach facilitates addressing computational challenges at the edge in embedded vehicular systems, reducing data dimensionality while preserving key discriminative spatial patterns necessary for object detection and traffic monitoring. Although the quantum method currently underperforms in certain clustering and separability metrics, it demonstrates potential as a viable alternative for advanced perception in CAVs.This work lays a foundation for integrating quantum computing into edge-based autonomous vehicle perception, highlighting both opportunities and challenges with near-term quantum hardware.

title: A Persistent and Secure Publish-Subscriber Architecture for Low-Latency IoT Communications
authors: Giovanni Pettorru, Marco Martalò
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network and Service Management
abstract: Secure and low-latency data exchange is gaining more and more attention in Internet of Things (IoT) applications. To achieve such stringent requirements, we propose to combine persistent connections and TLS session ticket resumption, as in WebSocket (WS) and QUIC, respectively. Considering the nodes of an IoT cluster as a single virtual entity, we propose to integrate an innovative network management strategy, which employs a publish-subscribe (Pub/Sub) architecture based on the Message Queuing Telemetry Transport (MQTT) protocol, for TLS session tickets sharing between cluster nodes to mitigate the session initialization latency. The proposed system is referred to as WS over QUIC and MQTT (WSQM) and its performance is experimentally assessed with IoT-compliant devices. Our results show that WSQM reduces the latency if compared with similar alternatives that rely on Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) and Transport Layer Security (TLS), as well as other QUIC-based protocols such as the HyperText Transfer Protocol version 3 (HTTP/3). Moreover, WSQM achieves minimal resource utilization in terms of percentage of RAM and CPU usage, thus highlighting its ability to meet the critical requirements of IoT applications.

title: Aucom: Extreme Compression for Real-Time Edge-to-Server Universal Audio Streaming
authors: Yu Lu, Ran Wang, Dian Ding, Yijie Li, Longyuan Ge, Juntao Zhou, Yongzhao Zhang, Yi-Chao Chen, Jiannong Cao, Guangtao Xue
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: Real-time audio streaming transmission and processing play a crucial role in time-sensitive applications such as food delivery services and ride-hailing platforms, where rapid response is essential. However, existing server-based audio streaming architectures struggle to handle the high concurrency of massive mobile devices efficiently. Traditional compression methods like MP3 and AAC offer limited compression ratios, while deep learning-based approaches often fail to meet the real-time transmission demands of edge computing environments. In this paper, we propose a novel edge-to-server audio streaming architecture that leverages Mel filter bank spectral features to achieve ultra-high compression efficiency. Our system integrates audio denoising, Mel feature extraction, and quantization-based compression at the edge, effectively suppressing environmental and device-induced noise while achieving an extreme compression ratio of 0.39% relative to the original uncompressed audio. Compared to conventional methods like MP3, our approach further reduces the file size by 96.1%. The decompressed Mel features remain task-independent, enabling seamless support for various general-purpose audio processing tasks in the server. We evaluate our system across three key audio tasks: speech recognition, speech emotion recognition, and audio classification. Extensive experiments on five different mobile devices demonstrate a 93.10% reduction in transmission latency at 1 Mbps bandwidth compared to 64 kbps MP3 audio, while maintaining task performance within a 5% deviation from state-of-the-art (SOTA) models across six mainstream audio datasets. These results highlight the efficiency, robustness, and scalability of our approach for real-time edge-to-server audio processing.

title: Nondimensional Analysis of Particle Behavior in a T-Type Optofluidic Chip
authors: Yao Zhang, Heng Zhao, Yanyan Zhang, Shiyu Ge, Sipu Zhang, Ruofei Wang
publish: Journal of Microelectromechanical Systems
abstract: With the worsening of air pollution, the variety of airborne pollutants has significantly increased. Accurate monitoring of particulate matter (PM) in the atmosphere requires sensors with enhanced precision. If suspended particles in the airflow can be pre-sorted using microfluidic chips, the performance of most existing microfluidic PM detection systems could be significantly improved.
