In this study, a T-type optofluidic chip (TOPC) for particle sorting and collection was theoretically designed based on optical principles, and an analytical solution for the particle offset distance within the TOPC was derived. Building upon this, a dimensionless parameter S was introduced by incorporating characteristic parameters of the microfluidic chip to describe particle motion within the TOPC. Particle trajectories under varying conditions were calculated using numerical simulations and compared with theoretical predictions to validate the model. In parallel, an experimental platform was constructed. The results demonstrated that the particle offset errors were <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$4.2\mu $</tex-math> </inline-formula>m and <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$1.4\mu $</tex-math> </inline-formula> m when compared with the theoretical calculations and numerical simulations, respectively. Furthermore, the particle sorting efficiency obtained from experiments showed strong agreement with the simulation results, confirming that the dimensionless parameter S effectively characterizes particle behavior in the TOPC. The innovation of this work lies in the novel introduction of the dimensionless parameter S and its experimental and numerical validation, providing a robust framework for optimizing TOPC design and enhancing PM sorting precision.

title: Template matching-based nanoscale visual tracking for out-of-plane rotations inside SEM
authors: Ying Li, Xiang Fu, Yanqin Ma, Hu Su, Song Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: Visual tracking is crucial in nanomanipulation inside scanning electron microscopy (SEM), especially for complex 3D manipulation tasks. However, tracking the micro- and nanoscale objects and manipulators under different rotational angles, especially out-of-plane rotation, remains challenging due to significant changes in their appearance in the image space. In this paper, we propose a template matching-based method for nanoscale tracking, particularly addressing challenges from out-of-plane rotation. By leveraging the image Jacobian matrix, we establish the relationships between image and Cartesian coordinates, enabling dynamic generation of templates for specified rotation angles. Then, a visual tracking pipeline is proposed, consisting of an offline preparation stage and an online tracking stage. Based on the proposed template generation method, the pipeline dynamically generates appropriate templates as rotational angles vary and performs accurate tracking using template matching. Further, the templates can be conveniently generated for specified magnifications using the image Jacobian matrix, enabling adaptation to changes in SEM magnification. Extensive experiments, including tracking under various SEM magnifications, complex trajectories, and different types of end-effectors, are conducted to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method. Comparisons with widely used tracking approaches further highlight its superiority in both tracking accuracy and real-time performance. Finally, the successful deployment of the proposed method in a real nanomanipulation task confirms its practical applicability.

title: Credit Card Dashboard Factors That Affect User Satisfaction and Loyalty Using D&M Model (Study Case at Indonesian Government Bank)
authors: Drajad Wiryawan, Fajar Syamsul Hadi, Adinata Wistara Goutama, Dafa Prakoso Putra Lukman
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Information Technology, Computer, and Electrical Engineering (ICITACEE)
abstract: The purpose and objective of this study are to determine the factors influencing user satisfaction and loyalty when using the dashboard on the credit card application. The model used in this study is DeLone & McLean (D&M) with the Krejeie sampling calculation formula. The main variables studied are Information Quality, which includes Consistency (CY) and Completeness (CP), then Service Quality, which includes Responsiveness (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R}$</tex>) and Accessibility (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{A}$</tex>), and System Quality, which includes Functionality (F) and Performance (P). The validity and reliability tests showed that all variables were declared valid and reliable. It is indicated by a value above 0.7 The results of the analysis obtained using SmartPLS v4 software showed that the Consistency (CY) (2.593) and Functionality (F) (4.496) factors have a significant influence on User Satisfaction and Loyalty of the Application Dashboard in question. Meanwhile, the Completeness (CP) (0.342), Responsiveness (R) (1.724), Accessibility (A) (0.247), and Performance (P) (0.586) factors do not influence it.

title: Irregularities of the JPEG Compression Rate Distortion Curves for Grayscale Images
authors: Boban P. Bondžulić, Vladimir V. Lukin, Dimitrije M. Bujaković, Oleksandr V. Prysiazhniuk
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Technologies, Systems and Services in Telecommunications (TELSIKS)
abstract: Rate-distortion curves are a fundamental tool in image compression for evaluating the trade-off between the compressed file size and the resulting image quality. However, these curves can exhibit unexpected irregularities, such as nonmonotonic behavior or “wiggles”, which challenge the conventional rate-distortion theory. In JPEG compression, these irregularities are primarily a consequence of the quantization process and are particularly pronounced in images containing large uniform regions. So, this paper investigates these irregularities firstly for uniform colorless blocks by analyzing the JPEG quantization error, and then for grayscale JPEG compressed images employing a range of objective image quality assessment measures. Our experimental results demonstrate that for such irregular images, selecting a lower quality factor that controls JPEG compression can paradoxically yield better visual quality than a higher quality factor, as the latter can introduce more noticeable blocking artifacts. This finding highlights the critical importance of quality factor selection in JPEG compression for images with uniform areas.

title: Proposing Two Novel Optimization Algorithms with Consideration of Energy Storage System for Optimal Energy Management System for Microgrids
authors: Karim M. Hassanin, Diaa-Eldin A. Mansour, Takeyoshi Kato, Tamer F. Megahed
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Power Electronics and Renewable Energy (CPERE)
abstract: Conventional Diesel Generators (CDGs) have traditionally been used as the main source of electricity. However, they caused an increase in harmful emissions as well as a decrease in the availability of traditional non-renewable fossil fuels. Hence, the integration of Renewable Energy Sources (RESs) is an important and effective way to convert the system to a clean and environmentally friendly operation. However, the intermittent nature of these RERs is a challenge to be handled effectively. So, Energy Management System (EMS) is crucial for managing energy supply to the loads from many sources that have different operational natures and characteristics. In this work, two novel optimization algorithms, which are Pelican Optimization Algorithm (POA) and Political Optimizer (PO), were introduced for achieving an optimal EMS for an MG containing RERs, such as Wind Turbines (WTs), Photovoltaics (PVs), and Combined Heat and Power units (CHP). Also, Energy Storage System (ESS) is included for more system’s reliability through charging while the existence of surplus power and discharge in case of deficit power. The main objective is minimizing total operational cost through optimally dispatching load among different available power sources. The problem objective is achieved while ensuring supply-load balance. The efficacy and effectiveness of proposed POA an PO were proved through obtained numerical results. They were able to reduce the total operational cost by about $25 \%$ in some cases compared to recently used optimization algorithms.

title: Technical Research on the Adaptive Selection Method of Communication Links under the Inter-Module Communication Technology of VSC-HVDC Converter Valve Submodules
authors: Zhenyu He, Lei Yu, Chenghao Wang, Yi Wang, Chong Gao, Yaoling Huang, Jianliang Lu
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: The converter valve serves as the 'heart' of the flexible HVDC transmission system, where the communication reliability of submodules is crucial for stable system operation. The networked interactive communication architecture of converter valve submodules has become key to reducing the quantity of long-distance optical fibers, lowering equipment costs, and enhancing communication reliability. This paper introduces the working principles of submodule networked communication in flexible HVDC converter valves and their valve control systems. It designs a transmission mechanism featuring the integrated downstream transmission of control commands and time-multiplexed upstream transmission of submodule fault statuses. A submodule communication passthrough method and a rapid data link selection approach are proposed, which ensure data frame integrity while significantly reducing communication latency in networked topologies. Final practical testing has fully verified the effectiveness of the methods presented in this research.

title: Research on transient unbalanced power propagation characteristics after fault in AC/DC parallel system
authors: Zhongwei Meng, Zhengpu Chen, Wenhua Hu, Wenman Gao
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: The AC/DC parallel structure is that the converter stations at the DC sending and receiving ends are in the same AC network, which corresponds to the AC/DC hybrid structure grid with the DC sending and receiving ends not in the same AC network. In order to study the distribution and propagation characteristics of transient unbalanced power of AC and DC current faults in AC/DC parallel system and its impact on the security and stability of the system, this paper takes a real power grid as an example, uses BPA to build a 500 kV AC/DC parallel system simulation model, and simulates and analyzes the interaction between AC and DC faults and the interaction between DC and AC, and the interaction between DC and AC and the interaction between different DC under AC/DC fault are analyzed by example simulation.

title: Retinal Image Segmentation Based on Computer Vision and Data Augmentation
authors: Kexin Xing
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Complex Medical Engineering (CME)
abstract: Retinal image segmentation is of key significance in clinical diagnosis and disease detection, however, the traditional manual segmentation is time-consuming and prone to segmentation errors by humans. In order to improve the efficiency and accuracy, this study utilizes computer vision technology and data augmentation methods, and conducts experiments on the DRIVE dataset using a U-Net model. Data augmentation techniques significantly improve the model’s generalization ability. In the test set, the model achieves an IoU of 0.5286, which improves the accuracy of retinal image segmentation. The results of this study show that computer vision technology can effectively automate the process of retinal image segmentation, resulting in improved segmentation accuracy

title: Classification of Stress States from PPG Signals using Ensemble Classifier
authors: Katarina Vujić, Marija Novičić, Dražen Drašković, Milica M. Janković
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Technologies, Systems and Services in Telecommunications (TELSIKS)
abstract: This paper presents an ensemble learning-based framework for the recognition of stress states using IoT-based wearable photoplethysmography (PPG) device. Pulse rate variability (PRV) features were extracted from recorded PPG signals of $\mathbf{1 0}$ healthy subjects during the controlled experiment that included cognitive and rest tasks. Stacking and Voting ensemble classification approaches were applied for cognitive stress state recognition. Stacking classifier outperformed the Voting classifier, achieving $72 \%$ accuracy. This work confirms the feasibility of using IoT-based wearable PPG devices for automated stress detection.

title: Enhancing CNN-Based Speech Emotion Recognition with Data Augmentation: A Reproducibility Study
authors: Nouhaila Farajy, Aniss Moumen
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: A new area of emotional computing called voice Emotion Recognition (SER) aims to extract human emotions from voice data. This study looks into classifying emotions using Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) based on voice audio data. To increase dataset diversity, we applied several data augmentation techniques, including pitch shifting, time-stretching, noise addition, and time-shifting. We used Mel-Frequency Cepstral Coefficients (MFCCs) and wave plots to capture important features. A CNN model was trained on the processed data, showing promising accuracy in telling apart different emotional states. We assess the model’s usefulness with confusion matrices and performance metrics, though we still face challenges in distinguishing between acoustically similar emotions. This paper demonstrates how deep learning techniques can help create emotion-aware systems that enhance human-computer interaction.

title: Blockchain-Based Transformer Monitoring Prototype for Data Security
authors: Nurqalbi, Ardiaty Arief, Ady Wahyudi Paundu, Muhammad Bachtiar Nappu
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Information Technology, Computer, and Electrical Engineering (ICITACEE)
abstract: Continuous monitoring of distribution transformer data is crucial for maintaining power system stability; however, data validation on IoT devices remains a challenge in terms of security and integrity. This study creates and deploys a smart contract on the Base Sepolia Testnet to store transformer anomaly data, such as current and voltage. Unlike previous studies that focused solely on blockchain cryptocurrency, this study provides novel contributions in data integrity testing using blockchain technology and smart contract-based transformer sensor data validation through cryptographic hashing. The test results show that this approach achieves a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0 0 \%}$</tex> success rate in detecting data manipulation, proving its effectiveness in maintaining information authenticity and improving the reliability of the monitoring system, particularly against threats of infrastructure failure and data manipulation.

title: Identification and analysis of neurophysiological markers of disorders of consciousness based on auditory ERPs
authors: Jianming Chen, Fang Duan, Zheng Yan, Fang Li, Guangyu Xiong
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Complex Medical Engineering (CME)
abstract: The identification and exploration of reliable features of conscious processing is a key area of research that is integral to the study of disorders of consciousness. In this study, two different auditory ERP paradigms were designed: the semantic paradigm, which focuses on brain activities related to language comprehension, and the non-semantic paradigm, which focuses on non-verbal sound processing. Data from the two paradigms were integrated and analyzed through a joint paradigm analysis approach to more comprehensively assess the level of consciousness in patients with disorders of consciousness. Based on a review of current theories, such as information theory and brain network theory, we identified three feature dimensions, namely, power spectral density metrics, brain network graph theory metrics, and entropy-like metrics, to explore the feature differences among patients with different levels of consciousness. Entropy class metrics play an important role in distinguishing patients with different levels of consciousness. Through data fusion and feature synergy, the joint paradigm analysis method can more comprehensively assess the level of consciousness of patients with disorders of consciousness than the single paradigm analysis method, providing a more accurate and reliable neurophysiological basis for the diagnosis of disorders of consciousness.

title: Fine-Tuning Bert for Scientific Document Classification in Computer and Informatics Fields
authors: Muhammad Deagama Surya Antariksa, Aris Sugiharto, Bayu Surarso
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Information Technology, Computer, and Electrical Engineering (ICITACEE)
abstract: Document classification of scientific texts plays a critical role in supporting academic information systems. This study proposes a classification model based on Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers (BERT), finetuned on a dataset of 2,000 scientific documents in the field of computer and informatics, composed of titles, abstracts, and keywords. Each document is categorized into one of three laboratory classes: Intelligent System, Embedded System, and Enterprise System. The bert-base-uncased model was trained with various hyperparameter settings and evaluated using accuracy, F1-score, and loss metrics. The best performance was achieved using a learning rate of 3 e-5, batch size of 32, and the AdamW optimizer, yielding a training accuracy of 89.50 % and a validation <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{F 1}$</tex>-score of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{8 9. 4 8 \%}$</tex>. On the testing data, the model achieved an accuracy of 91 %. This optimized configuration also outperformed traditional approaches based on comparisons using test data evaluations, further demonstrating the effectiveness of BERT fine-tuning for scientific document classification.

title: Improved Grey Wolf Optimizer (I-GWO) Based Optimization of PI Controllers for Power Flow in PV-Battery Microgrid Inverters
authors: Ilhame Abbada, Ahmed Abbou, Abdessamade Bouaddi
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: This work introduces an advanced control method for microgrid systems, which includes the use of independent DC/AC converters to link photovoltaic system and battery energy storage system. The research project focuses on enhancing proportional-integrator (PI) controllers, which manage power, voltage, and current levels. The Improved Grey Wolf Optimizer (I-GWO) functions as a metaheuristic algorithm to optimize controller gains, which decreases control errors while improving the system dynamics. The analysis of performance under solar irradiation changes uses MATLAB and Simulink tools to simulate real-world operating scenarios. The optimized controllers receive evaluation against traditional PI controllers through performance metrics that include settling time, overshoot, and the Integral of Time-weighted Absolute Error (ITAE). The I-GWO-tuned controllers demonstrate better performance through reduced overshoot, shorter settling time, and enhanced tracking accuracy. The study demonstrates how metaheuristic optimization techniques enhance the performance of smart microgrids through better power distribution and voltage control, stable energy management, and improved dynamic responses.

title: Analysis of Discharge Characteristics of Tower-Head Gaps in High-Altitude Transmission Lines
authors: Maoheng Jing, Chun Li, Xiaoxing Wei, Xiong Xiao, Wenhao Lu
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
abstract: To address deviations in lightning protection assessment for tower-head gaps in high-altitude transmission lines, a full-scale impulse discharge test platform was constructed under varying altitude conditions. The study focused on leader characteristics, high-speed imaging, and gap response behavior. Results show that as the gap distance decreases, the breakdown transition time shortens from 180.78 μs to 134.54 μs. The initiation time of upward leaders remains relatively stable at approximately 65 μ s, while downward leaders initiate significantly earlier. Leader propagation velocity increases from 10.9 cm/μs in the initial stage to a peak of 67.2 cm/μs prior to breakdown. These findings provide essential data support for the lightning protection design of tower-head structures in high-altitude environments.

title: A Lightweight Multi-Scale Fusion Network for Object Detection in Remote Sensing Images
authors: Ting Chen, Haijun Zhao, Peng Zhao, Tao Gao, Jinyue Yang, Yanan Lin
publish: 2024 5th China International SAR Symposium (CISS)
abstract: Remote sensing image object detection (RSOD) is crucial in multiple fields, but its complexity and small targets characteristics increase the detection difficulty. Despite the proposal of various high-performance algorithms, their complex models and large computational requirements make it difficult to meet real-time detection and deployment needs. To tackle these challenges, we introduce the Multi-scale Fusion Lightweight Network (MFLNet). Initially, to minimize parameter quantity and computational expenses while simplifying the feature fusion network, we introduce a Lightweight Cross-Scale Feature Fusion (CSFF) module. Subsequently, we propose a Multi-Scale Feature Enhancement (MSFE) module to improve the capability of the network to extract features from different receptive fields and enhance the adaptability of the network to variable objects. Experimental results indicate that the mean average precision (mAP) on the public datasets RSOD and DIOR is 93.2% and 69.4%, respectively. Meanwhile, compared with the initial model, the number of parameters and calculation amount of MFLNet are reduced by 5% and 7.4% respectively, while simultaneously increasing inference speed by 11%.

title: Robust Anomaly Detection in Human Actions Via Pose, Interaction, and Motion Cues
authors: Duc-Tho Mai, Thuan Bui
publish: 2025 24th International Symposium on Communications and Information Technologies (ISCIT)
abstract: Anomaly detection in Human Action Recognition (HAR) plays a crucial role in modern surveillance systems, where the timely identification of contextually unusual behaviors is essential for ensuring security. However, existing methods primarily designed for generic action classification - often fail to distinguish visually similar actions that differ in intent, and they lack sensitivity to subtle object interactions and motion patterns. To address these limitations, a multi-stream framework is proposed, integrating pose estimation, object interaction modeling, and motion dynamics analysis to enhance anomaly detection in real-world surveillance scenarios. In addition, a temporal smoothing mechanism is introduced to mitigate transient misclassifications and improve temporal consistency. Experimental results on the HAR dataset demonstrate that this approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods such as VideoMAE and MoViNet across all major evaluation metrics, achieving 96.51 % accuracy and 97.3 % F1-Score. These results underscore the framework's effectiveness for accurate and real-time anomaly detection in complex surveillance environments.

title: A Simple Model Predictive Control for Dual Active Bridge Converter to Improve Dynamic Response
authors: Tianhao Mao, Zhiqiang Guo, Suli Zou
publish: IEEE Journal of Emerging and Selected Topics in Power Electronics
abstract: In this article, a model predictive control (MPC) strategy for dual active bridge (DAB) converters under triple phase shift (TPS) is proposed. Traditional single-loop control cannot provide a satisfactory dynamic response under TPS in DAB converters. Although MPC offers good dynamic performance, conventional MPC for DAB converters under TPS control suffers from high computational complexity, which limits the achievable switching frequency and degrades the dynamic response. To address these issues, an improved MPC strategy is proposed to achieve a fast dynamic performance for the DAB converter by eliminating the effect of control delay, while also enabling higher switching frequencies. The proposed control method is derived from an expression for the phase shift angle based on the output current, which is analyzed by the modulation strategy under TPS. In addition, a parameter identification method based on a discrete integrator is introduced to ensure parameter accuracy while requiring lower computational complexity than model-based identification methods. The stability of the system is analyzed through small-signal modeling, which demonstrates good frequency response. Finally, experimental results confirm the effectiveness of the proposed control method in improving dynamic response.

title: Differential Privacy Enabled Federated LSTM Model for Decentralized Active User Detection in 6G Cell-Free mMIMO Networks
authors: Abhishek Kumar, Ayush Chaudhary, Bablu Kumar Singh
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: The proliferation of 6G, cell-free massive multiple input and multiple output (CF-mMIMO) networks demands scalable, accurate, and privacy-preserving solutions for active user detection (AUD). One of the significant challenge in CF-mMIMO is that it should support a large number of devices over the same time and frequency resources. In CF-mMIMO the K number of user devices is served through the M arbitrarily distributed access points (APs). Each AP is assumed to be equipped with N antennas. Due to the limited channel coherence interval length, assigning orthogonal pilot sequences to each user device is not feasible. Hence, the users are given unique non orthogonal pilot sequences. Therefore, in the massive random-access scenario, the probability of multiple active devices selecting the same sequence is quite high. Thus, activity detection is a challenging problem in grant-free massive random-access schemes. Traditional centralized approaches are hindered by communication bottlenecks and privacy risks, especially in ultra-dense deployments. This paper presents a federated learning (FL) framework that leverages Long-Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks to distribute and preserve privacy in AUD across access points (AP). Each AP acts as an FL client, locally training on synthetic pilot-signal data generated under a Rician fading model with Gaussian noise to emulate realistic SNR conditions. Model updates are aggregated via FedAvg and FedProx, with differential privacy (DP) enforced through adaptive Gaussian noise on gradients. K-Means clustering and Voronoi tessellation are used for dynamic user AP association and interference mitigation. A thorough simulation-based performance analysis is performed to evaluate the CF-mMIMO system using metrics such as detection accuracy, SNR analysis, clustering efficiency, and privacy-accuracy trade-offs. Experimental evaluation through simulations are performed in two configurations (A) 100 users, 300 APs; (B) 100 users, 1000 APs) demonstrates robust detection accuracy (85–88%), stable convergence within 75–100 rounds, and resilience to SNR variations (0–27 dB). The framework maintains high utility under strong privacy guarantees (ϵ = 1.8 –3.2, δ = 1e−5), with only a drop in precision of 1.2 to 2.8%. Advanced AP clustering reduces interference by up to 37%, supporting efficient service in dense and dynamic environments. These results establish the proposed FL-LSTM approach as a scalable, secure, and high-performance solution for AUD in next-generation CF-mMIMO networks, with practical relevance for smart cities, IoT, and privacy-sensitive applications.

title: SSF4VSU: A Self Supervised Synergetic Framework for Visual Scene Understanding
authors: Saif Hassan, Ghulam Mujtaba, Habib Ullah, Ali Shariq Imran, Ahmet Soylu, Mohib Ullah
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Visual scene understanding involves multiple tasks, including single-object tracking (SOT), multi-object tracking (MOT), video object segmentation (VOS), and its Multi-Object Tracking and Segmentation (MOTS) variant, which have traditionally been studied in isolation. Such fragmentation leads to task-specific architectures that must be retrained for each new scenario and rely heavily on annotated data. Thiswork proposes a synergetic model called SSF4VSU that simultaneously addresses SOT,MOT,VOS, and MOTS. SSF4VSU employs a shared backbone with a unified embedding space for different tasks, a Temporal Attention Module (TAM) to align features across frames and resist occlusions, a Temporal Consistency Module (TCM) to enforce smooth identity preservation, and a self-supervised learning (SSL) branch that leverages unlabeled video sequences for improved generalization. Training follows a multi-task curriculum with dynamic loss balancing, demonstrating efficiency and scalability. A comprehensive evaluation across six public benchmarks shows that SSF4VSU surpasses specialised and unified state-of-the-art models. On SOT benchmarks it achieves 74.7% success AUC and 80.4% precision on LaSOT, and 85.8% AUC and 84.3% precision on TrackingNet, matching or exceeding recent specialised trackers. For MOT, it records 82.9% MOTA and 83.3% IDF1 on the MOT17 dataset, while on BDD100K it generalises to driving scenes without task-specific tuning. On VOS benchmarks, SSF4VSU delivers 93.3% J&F on DAVIS-2016 and 89.0% J&F on DAVIS-2017, surpassing strong segmentation methods and unified baselines. In the MOTS setting it achieves 69.0% sMOTSA on MOTS20 and 31.2% mMOTSA on BDD100K MOTS. Ablation studies reveal that TAM is critical for accurate localisation, TCM is indispensable for identity stability, and SSL consistently improves generalization. The results demonstrate that a single unified model can perform diverse tracking and segmentation tasks without sacrificing accuracy or efficiency. By reducing reliance on labelled data, improving temporal reasoning, and ensuring interpretability, SSF4VSU advances the state of visual scene understanding and lays the foundation for general-purpose, multi-task video analysis.

title: LLM-Assisted Security Vulnerability Analysis for Educational Websites: Risk Identification via LLM-EduAttackGraph
authors: Chao Liu, Jiaxing Liu, Boxi Chen, Daxin Zhu, Ching-Chun Chang, Chin-Chen Chang
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: The digital transformation of educational systems has significantly optimized administrative workflows and enhanced the user experience for educators and learners. However, the accumulation of sensitive personal data on educational websites has made them prime targets for cyber threats. Despite growing awareness of these security challenges, the technical roots of vulnerabilities within such platforms remain insufficiently explored. To address this gap, we introduce LLM-EduAttackGraph, a specialized tool designed to assist in vulnerability detection by leveraging large language models (LLMs). Rather than serving as a fully automated monitoring system, LLM-EduAttackGraph operates as a human-in-the-loop assistant, combining expert knowledge with the analytical capabilities of LLMs to help identify potential penetration paths based on network fingerprint information. Using LLM-EduAttackGraph, we have so far identified 961 penetration vulnerabilities across educational websites in mainland China—a number that continues to grow as analysis progresses. These findings demonstrate the tool’s practical value in augmenting cybersecurity research and efforts. Our in-depth analysis of the discovered vulnerabilities reveals that limited developer experience and a heavy dependence on outsourced website development are key contributing factors. By shedding light on these root causes, our research offers actionable strategies and insights aimed at improving the cybersecurity posture of educational platforms and ensuring the sustainable development of online education. Furthermore, we have compared LLM-EduAttackGraph with several existing large model penetration tools to demonstrate the performance of LLM-EduAttackGraph. Such strengths include its low demand for hardware resources and having undergone empirical verification.

title: Unlocking the Metaverse: A Gateway to Multiplayer Game via 3D Object Security Technologies_supp1-3626576.pdf
authors: Xiangli Xiao
publish: N/A
abstract: Due to the widespread use of 3D objects, they gradually matter in various fields. Selective encryption and secret sharing are common methods to protect 3D objects. However, currently, there is no existing work that integrates these two methods into a unified scheme for 3D objects. This paper proposes a technological scheme tailored for the initial stage of metaverse games, serving as a gateway for players to embark on their game adventure. In this scheme, encryption and secret sharing technologies are harmoniously integrated, not only exploring innovative applications in the realm of 3D object security but also potentially paving the way for future research that bridges the metaverse games and 3D object security domains. Experimental results confirm the feasibility and effectiveness of the proposed scheme, further highlighting its robust adaptability across diverse representations of 3D objects without incurring any additional ciphertext expansion during its processing.

title: Bi-static Sensing in 6G Perceptive Mobile Networks
authors: Andrew Zhang
publish: 2025 24th International Symposium on Communications and Information Technologies (ISCIT)
abstract: Empowered by integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) technologies, 6G Perceptive Mobile Network (PMN) is expected to offer ubiquitous sensing capability, leveraging the communications infrastructure. Bistatic sensing can bypass the stringent full-duplex requirement in mono-static sensing and is more practical for (nearterm) implementation. Clock asynchronism, which naturally exists between spatially separated communication nodes, is a central and challenging problem in bi-static sensing. It can cause ranging ambiguity and prevent coherent processing of (discontinuous) measurements (e.g., for Doppler frequency estimation). Should it be resolved, sensing can be efficiently realised in communication networks, requiring little network infrastructure and hardware changes. This talk delves into advanced techniques for addressing the clock asynchronism challenge in the integration, with a particular focus on efficient solutions requiring only a single receiver. First, this issue will be introduced in the context of 6G perceptive mobile networks. Following this, a comprehensive review will be provided for the latest singlereceiver-based solutions, applicable to both multi-antenna and single-antenna configurations. Additionally, I will showcase our cutting-edge sensing applications developed using these techniques, including moving object tracking, localization, and environmental sensing including rainfall and water level detection. The talk concludes by highlighting unresolved challenges and exploring future research directions in this evolving field

title: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Technologies, Systems and Services in Telecommunications (TELSIKS)
authors: N/A
publish: N/A

title: DIDLM: A SLAM Dataset for Difficult Scenarios Featuring Infrared, Depth Cameras, LiDAR, 4D Radar, and Others Under Adverse Weather, Low Light Conditions, and Rough Roads
authors: Weisheng Gong, Chen He, Kaijie Su, Qingyong Li, Tong Wu, Z. Jane Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Adverse weather conditions, low-light environments, and bumpy road surfaces pose significant challenges to SLAM in robotic navigation and autonomous driving. Existing datasets in this field predominantly rely on single sensors or combinations of LiDAR, cameras, and IMUs. However, 4D millimeter-wave radar demonstrates robustness in adverse weather, infrared cameras excel in capturing details under low-light conditions, and depth images provide richer spatial information. Multi-sensor fusion methods also show potential for better adaptation to bumpy roads. Despite some SLAM studies incorporating these sensors and conditions, there remains a lack of comprehensive datasets addressing low-light environments and bumpy road conditions, or featuring a sufficiently diverse range of sensor data. In this study, we introduce a multi-sensor dataset covering challenging scenarios such as snowy weather, rainy weather, nighttime conditions, speed bumps, and rough terrains. The dataset includes rarely utilized sensors for extreme conditions, such as 4D millimeter-wave radar, infrared cameras, and depth cameras, alongside 3D LiDAR, RGB cameras, GPS, and IMU. It supports both autonomous driving and ground robot applications and provides reliable GPS/INS ground truth data, covering structured and semi-structured terrains. We evaluated various SLAM algorithms using this dataset, including RGB images, infrared images, depth images, LiDAR, and 4D millimeter-wave radar. The dataset spans a total of 18.5 km, 69 minutes, and approximately 660 GB, offering a valuable resource for advancing SLAM research under complex and extreme conditions. Our dataset is available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://gongweisheng.github.io/DIDLM.github.io/</uri>

title: Compute-Forward Multiple Access for Gaussian MIMO Channels
authors: Lanwei Zhang, Jamie Evans, Jingge Zhu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Theory
abstract: Compute-Forward Multiple Access (CFMA) is a multiple access transmission scheme based on Compute-and-Forward (CF), which allows the receiver to first decode linear combinations of the transmitted signals and then solve for individual messages. This paper extends the CFMA scheme to a two-user Gaussian multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) multiple access channel (MAC). We propose the CFMA Serial Coding Scheme (SCS) and the CFMA Parallel Coding Scheme (PCS) with nested lattice codes. We first derive the expression of the achievable rate pair for MIMO MAC with CFMA-SCS. We prove a general condition under which CFMA-SCS can achieve the sum capacity of the channel. Furthermore, this result is specialized to single-input multiple-output (SIMO) and 2-by-2 diagonal MIMO multiple access channels, for which more explicit sum capacity-achieving conditions on power and channel matrices are derived. We then study the achievable rate of CFMA-PCS by using an equivalent SIMO model, and analyze its sum capacity-achieving conditions. Numerical results are provided for the performance of CFMA-SCS and CFMA-PCS in different channel conditions. In general, CFMA-PCS has better sum capacity achievability, although with a higher computational complexity for encoding and decoding.

title: Partial Volume Correction of SPECT Images With Deep Learning Trained on Synthetic Data_supp1-3634484.pdf
authors: Theo Kaprelian
publish: N/A
abstract: Partial Volume Effects (PVEs) cause blurring and inaccuracies in activity measurements in SPECT imaging. They are a major challenge, especially for SPECT-based dosimetry in radionuclide therapies using 177 Lu. This study aims to develop and evaluate new deep learning methods to correct PVEs. The proposed methods aim to enhance the accuracy of SPECT quantification by applying deep learning techniques trained on synthetic data. We developed three distinct deep learning approaches to correct PVEs: PVCNet-sino which operates in the projection domain, PVCNet-img that works in the image domain and PVCNet-hybrid that combines information from both domains. The training data included a variety of organ shapes, lesions, and activity distributions. The performance of these networks was compared to Resolution Modeling (RM) and the iterative-Yang (iY) methods, using a large synthetic test dataset, real phantom measurements, Monte Carlo simulations, and patient data. We showed that all of the proposed deep learning methods allowed to reduce PVEs compared to RM. Under some conditions on the inputs and training framework, PVCNet-sino was the most capable of quantifying the activity in the 22/28/37 mm spheres on real NEMA IEC phantom measurements (with Recovery coefficients of 0.97/0.99/1.08) close to or better than iY (1.02/1.02/1.09) and better than PVCNet-img (0.78/0.86/1.07) and RM (0.53/0.65/0.76). But this method leads to noisy images and reconstruction artifacts, mitigated by the PVCNet-hybrid framework, also leading to improved RCs (0.78/0.86/1.07). The better noise/resolution trade-off obtained by the PVCNet-hybrid approach was confirmed on the patient MC simulation, where normalized root mean squared error was reduced by 33% and background noise by 80%. We demonstrate that deep-learning based PVC trained on synthetic data can reduce PVE in SPECT images without any segmentation requirement. This work also shows that using both the sinogram and the image domain is a suitable alternative to post-reconstruction PVC. While applied to 177 Lu, the method is generic and can be used with other radionuclides.

title: IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics: Systems Information for Authors
authors: N/A
publish: IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics: Systems

title: Chrono: Efficient Serverless Analytics With Adaptive Fine-Grained Partitioning and Shadow Execution
authors: Zhaorui Wu, Yuhui Deng, Jiande Huang, Qifen Yang, Peng Zhou, Geyong Min
publish: IEEE Transactions on Cloud Computing
abstract: Serverless computing has been widely adopted in large-scale data analytics. However, a critical challenge in data analytics is the substantial variability in the volume of data assigned to individual function invocations across executions. This high degree of inter-invocation variability introduces performance unpredictability and complicates efficient resource utilization. Existing approaches attempt to address this issue through vertical scaling, but their effectiveness is inherently limited, as function performance quickly saturates with increased resource allocation. To address these limitations, we propose Chrono, an adaptive serverless analytics framework designed to reduce latency and mitigate cold start overhead under high concurrency. Chrono incorporates three key components: (1) continuous monitoring of function execution to proactively detect risks of SLO violations; (2) dynamic partitioning of unprocessed data among parallel execution instances, aiming to reduce the end-to-end latency; and (3) the integration of lightweight shadow functions running in shared environments, effectively reducing cold start latency. Experimental evaluations on real-world datasets indicate that Chrono outperforms existing methods by reducing average latency by up to 43.16% and 45.42% in 99th percentile latency. Regarding resource utilization, Chrono improves multi-core CPU utilization by 60.6%, and decreases maximum memory usage by 27.2%.

title: A Blockchain-Enabled Quantum Encryption Scheme for Securing Consumer-Centric Digital Twin Healthcare Networks
authors: Sunil Prajapat, Seong Oun Hwang, Pankaj Kumar, Mohammad Shabaz
publish: IEEE Transactions on Consumer Electronics
abstract: The integration of consumer-centric digital twin (CCDT) technology is set to transform healthcare systems, enabling blockchain-based solutions for enhanced medical services. By precisely simulating patients and medical processes, CCDT establish a link to the virtual healthcare environment, supporting improved diagnosis, real-time monitoring, and predictive analytics. Blockchain technology is critical in connecting the physical and virtual health care worlds, providing secure storage, efficient communication, reduced computational costs, and reliable hosting services. However, the security of patient data and its digital twin counterpart stored on the blockchain remains a potential vulnerability, as any alteration or unauthorized access to this information could pose significant risks. To address this challenge, we propose a blockchain-enabled quantum encryption protocol for CCDT healthcare networks to ensure secure communication. The proposed protocol leverages blockchain to authenticate patients without relying on third-party entities. At the same time, a secure quantum encryption mechanism ensures that CCDT do not need to authenticate repeatedly when interacting with multiple healthcare providers. A performance evaluation demonstrates the effectiveness of the proposed scheme compared to existing encryption methods. The results indicate that the suggested protocol is resilient against various security threats, showcasing its significant potential for enhancing communication security within CCDT healthcare networks.

title: Requirement-Driven Adaptive Differential Evolution for Many-Task Optimization
authors: Zhi-Fan Tang, Zhi-Hui Zhan, Yun Li, Jun Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Evolutionary Computation
abstract: The major challenge in evolutionary many-task optimization (EMaTO) is to transfer knowledge among the tasks effectively. Moving on existing EMaTO algorithms, which mainly focus on what kind of knowledge to select and how to transfer the selected knowledge, this article focuses on a novel perspective to tackle the issue of when to transfer knowledge. This gives rise to a requirement-driven adaptive differential evolution (RADE) algorithm. Specifically, the RADE introduces a dual-scale evolutionary state estimator (ESE) to evaluate the state of evolution from both temporal and spatial scales, obtaining the real optimization requirement of the population and thus adaptively controlling the timing of knowledge transfer. This way, RADE not only leads to efficiently dealing with the when issue, but also drives two adaptive strategies for knowledge selection and knowledge transfer, leading to more efficient dealing with the what and the how issues, respectively. In particular, a requirement-driven adaptive knowledge selection strategy merges the evolutionary state similarity and the population distribution similarity for enhancing the selection of relevant source knowledge. Then, a requirement-driven adaptive knowledge transfer strategy is executed based on adaptive parameters and operators, thus significantly improving the efficiency of knowledge transfer. Experimental results on the CEC19 and WCCI22 benchmarks show that RADE outperforms the compared state-of-the-art EMaTO algorithms in both effectiveness and efficiency.

title: Virtual Reality with Sensory Feedback Gloves: A Pedagogical Strategy for Medical Training
authors: Benjamín Maraza-Quispe, Juan Abdon Palo-Rosas
publish: IEEE Revista Iberoamericana de Tecnologias del Aprendizaje
abstract: This study explores the pedagogical potential of integrating haptic glove technology within immersive virtual reality environments for medical training. A quasi-experimental design was conducted with 50 second-year medical students from a private university in Arequipa, randomly assigned to control and experimental groups. The experimental group participated in three 90-minute sessions over two weeks, using Hi5 Noitom 2.0 gloves and VR platforms (Hand Physics Lab and VR Surgery Simulator) to perform tasks such as suturing, forceps manipulation, and anatomical palpation. Three validated instruments were employed, a psychomotor rubric, a self-assessment questionnaire, and an observation checklist, all demonstrating strong reliability (α = 0.83–0.88). Statistical analyses (independent samples t-tests, ANCOVA, and repeated-measures ANOVA) revealed significant improvements (p < 0.001) in movement precision, visuomotor coordination, technical sequencing, execution time, safety, and feedback in the experimental group, supported by large effect sizes (η² up to 0.86). Students also reported higher confidence and motivation, reflecting both objective and perceived benefits. Under controlled exploratory conditions, these findings suggest that haptic-feedback VR environments can foster realistic, safe, and engaging learning experiences that support the development of psychomotor competencies. The study highlights the pedagogical promise of immersive simulation as a complementary tool to traditional instruction and recommends future longitudinal and multi-site research to validate and generalize the results.

title: CME 2025 TOC
authors: N/A
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Complex Medical Engineering (CME)

title: Metaheuristic-Based Task Assignment and Scheduling to Minimize Coordination Risks in Modular Software Projects
authors: Fadwa Rhorba, Driss Allaki, Mohamed Dahchour
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: Assigning tasks to developers and scheduling them under constraints is a core challenge in the Software Project Scheduling Problem (SPSP) research. Although modular architectures reduce team dependencies, task interdependencies persist, creating coordination needs that emerge after task assignment and scheduling. These coordination needs introduce a risk of breakdowns, which can lead to delays, rework, and productivity loss. While sequential task scheduling could help mitigate these risks by reducing coordination needs, it is often impractical in real projects where tight deadlines or parallel task execution are required. Existing SPSP approaches often overlook coordination risks, focusing instead on optimizing cost, makespan, or skill-task fit. We address this gap by modeling task assignment and scheduling in modular projects as a multi-objective optimization problem to minimize coordination breakdown risks, project makespan, and workload imbalance. To solve this problem, we apply NSGA-II, NSGA-III, and SMS-EMOA, and compare their performance across loosely and tightly coupled task scenarios. Our results revealed that NSGA-III provides balanced performance across objectives, SMS-EMOA suits tightly coupled scenarios where solution diversity matters, and NSGA-II works best for loosely coupled scenarios despite its inconsistency, making the choice of the algorithm to use context-specific.

title: Characterization of RADFETs as Radiation Sensors for Telecommunication Satellite Applications
authors: Miloš Marjanović, Stefan Ilić, Sandra Miljković, Sandra Veljković, Danijel Danković, Ercan Yilmaz, Goran Ristić
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Technologies, Systems and Services in Telecommunications (TELSIKS)
abstract: This paper presents an experimental characterization of RADFET sensors. Two irradiation campaigns were carried out at TENMAK (Turkey) and the Vinča Institute (Serbia), employing Co-60 gamma sources with dose rates of $4.813 \mathrm{~Gy} / \mathrm{h}$ and $17.04 \mathrm{~Gy} / \mathrm{h}$, respectively. RADFETs with different gate oxide thicknesses, including dual-gate high-k dielectric structures, were tested by monitoring threshold voltage shifts in response to accumulated radiation dose. The results indicate that devices with thicker oxide layers demonstrate greater sensitivity due to enhanced charge trapping. Moreover, lower dose rates were found to increase sensor sensitivity, particularly in devices with thinner oxides. These findings contribute to the optimization of RADFET design for reliable and accurate total ionizing dose measurements in space environments.

title: Fatigue Crack Extension Test and Reliability Analysis of Bolt Structure
authors: X. Wang, F. Chen, S. Zhou
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: Regarding the damage evolution and reliability design of underwater connection structures, high-strength bolts were selected for tensile fatigue life testing. The crack propagation laws were analyzed using static stress intensity factor calculations and the Paris formula, and the simulation results were compared with the experimental results to verify the accuracy of the simulation model. For bolt-base connection structures, a reliability influence parameter analysis was conducted. The central composite design method was used to design the test points, and a response surface surrogate model was established to further optimize the design parameters. The optimized design results were verified using the Monte Carlo random sampling method, revealing that the optimized parameter combinations significantly reduced the maximum stress value of the structure and improved the reliability of the connection structure. The expected research results are expected to provide fundamental theoretical support for the safe and reliable operation of underwater vehicles.

title: Evidence-Based Multidisease Prediction via Dynamic Knowledge Evolution and Multimodal Reasoning in EMRs
authors: Yu Xie, Chenxi Zhang, Aolan Hu
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Complex Medical Engineering (CME)
abstract: The integration of heterogeneous EMRs for multidisease prediction faces critical challenges, including knowledge stagnation, modality fragmentation, and opaque decision-making. This study proposes ED-KEMR, an evidencebased diagnostic framework integrating Dynamic Knowledge Evolution and Multimodal Reasoning. ED-KEMR incorporates three synergistic modules: 1) A Dynamic Knowledge Evolution Module that constructs patient-specific medical subgraphs via dual-channel knowledge injection and causality-driven temporal pruning; 2) A Multimodal Evidence Reasoning Network employing cross-modal alignment with Dynamic Prompt Fusion to unify textual, imaging, and time-series features; and 3) An Evidence-Based Diagnostic Engine generating interpretable disease pathways with uncertainty quantification. Evaluated on MIMIC-III, ChineseEMR-50, and CMDC datasets, ED-KEMR achieves state-of-the-art performance, improving mortality prediction AUROC to 0.912 and rare disease recall by 17.3%. The framework reduces inference latency by 62.5% through dynamic subgraph optimization and enhances interpretability via traceable evidence chains. Clinical validations confirm a $\mathbf{4 0 \%}$ reduction in knowledge-lag-induced misdiagnoses and $\gt80 \%$ clinician adoption compliance, demonstrating significant potential for complex multimorbidity management.

title: On-Board Emergency Response Mission Planning Technology of D-Insar Satellite Based on Internet Plus
authors: Chuheng Tang, Gaoxiong Zhang, Yanyang Liu, Ruifeng Lu, Junli Chen
publish: 2024 5th China International SAR Symposium (CISS)
abstract: The LuTan-1 satellite has established China's first L-band constellation dedicated to differential interferometric measurement of surface deformation. However, in the application of satellite in orbit, when an emergency occurs, the traditional method of ground system command can result in missed opportunities of the fastest time window for acquiring differential interference data in disaster area. To address this issue, this paper introduces an on-board emergency response mission planning technology of D-InSAR satellite based on Internet plus. Utilizing the Internet, the satellite can swiftly obtain emergency information and autonomously prioritize and schedule both emergency and planned missions in accordance with their severity and potential conflicts. After autonomously acquiring images based on Internet information, the satellite interacts with the ground system to request data transmission resources and facilitate data downloading. This innovative approach effectively overcomes the response speed challenges associated with current emergency situations that require human intervention, thereby significantly enhancing the satellite's emergency response capabilities.

title: Methods for Constructing the Health Status Evaluation Index System of Spacecrafts
authors: Ti Zhou, Qing Tang, Siyuan Liang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Equipment Intelligent Operation and Maintenance (ICEIOM)
abstract: In the realm of aerospace missions, there exists an urgent requirement for constructing a health status evaluation index system for spacecrafts. This paper undertakes a comprehensive analysis of the global development status of related technologies. It clarifies the principles for grading the health of spacecrafts, categorizing their health status into three distinct states: healthy, sub - healthy, and faulty. The faulty state is further subdivided into minor, emergency, and serious faults. Subsequently, the paper elaborates on the essential elements involved in constructing the health evaluation index system, which encompasses diverse information such as telemetry data. A hierarchical architecture is meticulously designed, consisting of a target layer, an element layer, and an index layer. And then, multiple evaluation indicators are proposed. Based on these designs, an evaluation system is put forward, constructed from two aspects: expert-knowledge-based subsystem assessment and intelligent analysis. Moreover, calculation methods for health scores at all levels are provided. Experimental evaluations of the health status of multiple spacecrafts are conducted. The results demonstrate that this method can effectively establish a health status evaluation system for spacecrafts, thereby assisting operators in accurately determining the health status of spacecrafts.

title: Outer-Iterative Approximation of Semidefinite Programming for Limit Analysis
authors: Youssef Essousy, Mohammed Khalil Ferradi
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: This paper presents an alternative approach for solving high-dimensional semidefinite programs (SDPs) arising in plastic analysis of mechanical systems. The method relies on a sequence of outer approximations using second-order cone programs (SOCPs) to approximate the feasible set of the SDP. At each iteration, the second-order cones are updated based on the previous solution, gradually improving the approximation. The convergence of the method is illustrated through a numerical example in limit analysis, highlighting the iterative improvement in solution quality.

title: Automated Fabric Defect Detection Using Unsupervised Feature Learning with Deep Autoencoders
authors: Loubna Belaidi, Aafaf Beljadid, Adil Tannouche
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: Ensuring consistent quality in textile manufacturing requires reliable defect detection systems. This paper presents an unsupervised method using convolutional autoencoders to identify surface anomalies in woven fabrics. The model is trained purely on normal fabric samples and learns to reconstruct typical textures. Any significant reconstruction error indicates the possible presence of a defect. Three common defect types; holes, spots, and bars are used to evaluate the model's efficiency. The images were converted to grayscale to simplify processing and accelerate training. Experimental tests show that the model achieves high detection accuracy, especially for structurally pronounced defects such as holes. While the results are promising, some limitations remain, particularly for the detection of low-contrast or subtle defects such as spots. The proposed system can be useful in industrial inspection settings where annotated data is scarce. In future work, we plan to investigate more advanced structures and evaluate the impact of using color channels. The goal is to develop a lightweight and flexible solution for real-time deployment in small and medium-sized manufacturing environments.

title: A Comparative Study of Different SiC Technologies For A 3-Phase PFC Application
authors: Ehab Gamaleldin Ahmed, Hassan Hussameldin Hassan, Mohamed Taha
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Power Electronics and Renewable Energy (CPERE)
abstract: The advancement of SiC MOSFET technology has significantly enhanced efficiency in electric vehicle (EV) applications, particularly in EV charging circuits. This paper evaluates and compares different SiC MOSFET technologies to assess their impact on system efficiency and performance. Power factor correction (PFC) is a critical stage in on-board chargers, ensuring a high power factor across various loads and operating conditions. A three-phase (3 ph) totem-pole PFC system is chosen for its advantages, including a simple structure, high efficiency, low common-mode noise, and straightforward gate driving. A SPICE simulation is developed to incorporate control and modulation techniques, enabling precise sizing and design of hardware components while assessing system performance under different operating conditions. This approach facilitates early-stage decisions on control parameters, switching frequency, operating ranges, and the optimal switching device technology to maximize system efficiency and performance.

title: ResNet50V2-Based Feature Extraction and MLP Classification with Oversampling for Biometric Student Attendance Systems
authors: Slimane Ennajar, Walid Bouarifi, Kamal Bella, Khalid Ait Ben Hamou
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: In the context of biometric attendance monitoring for students, this work presents an approach based on biometric fingerprint recognition by combining deep feature extraction and a Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP) classifier. We employed random oversampling techniques to address the common problem of class imbalance in biometric datasets. We used the ResNet50V2 model, which had been trained on ImageNet and then fine-tuned on data from the domain, to get strong and unique features from fingerprint images. Then, a fully connected MLP used these features to make the final classification. The proposed pipeline works well in experiments, with a classification accuracy of 98.2%. This shows that this method is good for biometric identification tasks in the real world.

title: High Precision Pointing and Positional Measurement Technology for LT-1 SAR Antenna
authors: Bingliang Zhang, Ruifeng Lu, Yanyang Liu, Shenxin Xu, Xin Lin
publish: 2024 5th China International SAR Symposium (CISS)
abstract: As a quantitative cartographic satellite, the LT-1 satellite system proposes high-precision measurement requirements for SAR antenna pointing, SAR antenna radiation surface geometric center position, GNSS antenna phase center position, etc. to meet the needs of high-precision deformation and elevation measurement. It is necessary to accurately obtain the absolute positions of SAR and GNSS antenna pointing, geometric center or phase center in the satellite body layout coordinate system. To this end, a method was proposed to design satellite reference blocks and reference prisms, set up the prism of the object being measured, and then determine its orientation and positional accuracy by measuring the relative position and angle relationship between the prism of the object being measured and the reference block and reference prism. This solved the problem that the origin of the reference coordinate system and the measured target point cannot be directly measured.

title: Improved Selection Criteria for Finite Control Set Model Predictive Control of Five-Phase PMSM Drives
authors: Mahmoud S. R. Saeed, Mokhtar Aly, Mohamed Abdelrahem, Jose Rodriguez
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Power Electronics and Renewable Energy (CPERE)
abstract: Emerging finite control set (FCS) model predictive control (MPC) methods for multiphase, especially five-phase, drive systems are recommended and increased to improve the controllability and the general performance. However, due to the complexity of these methods, the conventional selection criteria for the standard FCS-MPC require extensive and complex arithmetic processes to select the optimal control action, increasing the controller hardware requirements. Hence, this paper presents a simplified new criterion to select the optimal control action for FCS-MPC of five-phase PMSM drives. Unlike the conventional schemes, the proposed selection method is based on the location of the reference voltage vector components in the two orthogonal control subspaces, namely $\alpha-\beta$ and $x-y$ subspaces. Ten candidates are selected as the best vectors for achieving the control objective. Furthermore, two linear systems of five equations are constructed and solved to solve the control objectives without the enumeration process. The best voltage vector can be selected and applied in the next control interval from the obtained solution. The proposed selection strategy exhibits a compromise between complexity and performance compared to the existing schemes, as given by MATLAB simulation results.

title: Denoising Diffusion with Enhanced Dual-granularity Prior for Diabetic Retinopathy Grading
authors: Qiyuan Chen
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Complex Medical Engineering (CME)
abstract: Diffusion models have exhibited remarkable capabilities in computer vision tasks. Yet, their application to diabetic retinopathy classification- a crucial medical image analysis domain- remains limited. This paper introduces EDDiff, an innovative denoising diffusion model applied to the task of diabetic retinopathy classification. Central to EDDiff is the Enhanced Dual - granularity Prior Module (EDPM), engineered to intensify focus on critical features and capture intricate key - region dependencies within fundus images. Experimental results on the APTOS 2019 dataset demonstrate that EDDiff achieves state-of-the-art performance, significantly outperforming existing CNN-based and diffusion models in classification accuracy and F1-score, indicating the effectiveness of the proposed model.

title: Hybrid Deepfake Detection Using ResNet50 and Vision Transformer for Enhanced Feature Extraction
authors: Amal Naitali, Mohammed Ridouani, Fatima Salahdine, Naima Kaabouch
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: Deepfakes create a digital content verification problem that is difficult to solve, with a pressing demand for trustworthy detection mechanisms. In this paper, we review a deepfake detection approach based on complementary characteristics of convolutions and transformers. In particular, we employ ResNet50, a convolutional neural network (CNN) that extracts rich spatial features and local textures from images, and the Vision Transformer (ViT) which learns long-range dependencies and global context by treating images as sequences of patches. Concatenated representations derived from the two models are fed into classification algorithms. In this work, we experiment with the OpenForensics dataset which contains both real and fake images. The results show that features from both ResNet50 and ViT provide significantly improved classification performance when the features are combined together to form a new feature vector; than when either model is used alone. Furthermore, we evaluate the performance of these features using a Random Forest classifier and dense layers, and show that the feature representations on their own extracted from both of the models can generalize and perform well using both classification methods.

title: A Fusion Method Combining LSTM and MLP for Predicting Mortality Risk in Critically Ill Coronary Artery Disease Patients
authors: Rongren Xu, Haoran Zheng
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Complex Medical Engineering (CME)
abstract: Coronary artery disease (CAD) is one of the leading causes of death worldwide, and assessment of its prognosis remains challenging, especially in the intensive care unit (ICU). Existing tools for assessment often rely on static data, which cannot capture the dynamic physiological changes that are critical for timely risk stratification. To overcome this limitation, we extracted relevant patient data from the MIMIC-IV database and proposed a novel machine learning model to predict the $\mathbf{3 0}$-day mortality risk of patients. We constructed an end-to-end fusion model that uses Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks to process timeseries clinical data while using Multilayer Perceptron (MLP) to process static baseline features. The model’s performance was primarily evaluated using the Area Under the Precision-Recall Curve (AU-PRC) and compared with traditional clinical scoring systems (SOFA, SAPS II, LODS, OASIS) and conventional machine learning models (logistic regression, random forest, LightGBM and XGBoost). The proposed fusion model achieved an AU-PRC of 0.5816 on the test set, significantly outperforming established clinical scoring systems such as SAPS II (AU-PRC = 0.3127) and the strongest traditional machine learning model, LightGBM (AU-PRC $\boldsymbol{=} \mathbf{0. 5 6 1 4}$). Our findings suggest that by integrating patients’ dynamic data, this fusion model provides a more powerful tool for predicting mortality risk in critically ill patients with CAD, potentially improving clinical decision-making quality by identifying high-risk individuals earlier.

title: Optimal Beam Scanning Strategy Based on Mechanic-Electronic Joint for Spaceborne Radar
authors: Nuobei Zhang, Aifang Liu, Chaowei Zhou, Long Huang
publish: 2024 5th China International SAR Symposium (CISS)
abstract: Spaceborne Radar has gained widespread attention for its ability to provide wide-area detection under all-weather and all-time conditions. However, in the scenario of multi-target aggregation at sea, it is most of the traditional mechanical scanning or electronic scanning that is difficult to meet the practical requirements. To solve above problem, this paper proposed optimal beam scanning strategy based on mechanic-electronic joint for spaceborne radar. Firstly, this paper describes and illustrates the satellite attitude and antenna pointing of spaceborne radar, and then the superiority of the Mechanic-Electronic Joint Scanning method is theoretically analysed, finally a real-time optimization model for beam angle control based on Mechanic- Electronic Joint Scanning is proposed. In the model, the K-means clustering algorithm is used in the model to calculate the mechanical scanning preset points and the beam control angle is calculated. According to the real scene simulation, the results show that the proposed method effectively improves the detection capability of the spaceborne radar.

title: Optimization Techniques in YOLOv8 for Acne Detection
authors: Aqilah Fedura Ilahi, Putu Harry Gunawan
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Information Technology, Computer, and Electrical Engineering (ICITACEE)
abstract: Acne detection remains a challenge in dermatology due to visual similarity between lesion types and the scarcity of balanced datasets. This study addresses this gap by comparing five widely used optimizers: SGD, Adam, AdamW, NAdam, and RAdam on the YOLOv8s model for detecting four acne types: blackheads, whiteheads, papules, and pustules. We constructed a balanced dataset from Skin 90 and DermNet sources through re-annotation, mild augmentation, and combined over-undersampling. Experiments were conducted under identical conditions, and model performance was evaluated using precision, recall, mean Average Precision at IoU 0.5, and training time. Results showed that NAdam achieved the highest precision (0.823) and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{mAP} {@} 0.5(0.735)$</tex>, while SGD produced the highest recall (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 6 7 6}$</tex>). RAdam delivered competitive accuracy with the shortest training time (0.588 hours). Papules remained the most challenging class across all models due to their subtle features. These findings demonstrate that optimizer choice significantly influences detection performance, offering practical insights for developing accurate and efficient AI-driven dermatology tools, particularly for real-time and telemedicine applications.

title: Artificial Intelligence and automation: How AI shapes the digital culture and its implications for jobs and work organization
authors: Ghizlane Diab, Khalid Lahyani, Ghizlane Moukhliss
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) and automation are profoundly reshaping professional environments and organizational dynamics. By taking charge of both repetitive and cognitively demanding tasks, AI is contributing to a reconfiguration of work structures and a redefinition of roles within organizations. These technological developments do not merely affect productivity; they also reshape the culture of work by influencing skills requirements, modes of collaboration, and the relationship between humans and digital systems.AI is increasingly integrated into business operations through intelligent tools designed to streamline processes, optimize resource use, and support strategic decision-making. While these innovations often lead to gains in efficiency and cost reduction, they also entail a gradual shift in the nature of work. In several sectors—such as data processing, forecasting, and industrial automation—human tasks are being reduced or radically altered, raising essential questions about the future of employment, the emergence of new professions, and the need for large-scale reskilling.At the same time, AI plays a central role in shaping the digital culture of organizations. It enables new forms of communication and coordination through smart platforms, facilitates real-time decision-making, and encourages more agile, data-informed approaches to project management. In this context, digital culture becomes increasingly marked by adaptability, continuous learning, and an openness to innovation.However, this integration is not without ethical and social implications. Issues such as data privacy, algorithmic transparency, and the risks of job displacement call for critical reflection. The evolution of work in the age of AI requires hybrid competencies—combining technical know-how and digital literacy with human qualities such as creativity, emotional intelligence, and ethical judgment.

title: Optimized Rotor Design For A New Double-Stack Axial Flux Switching Generator For Wind Energy Systems
authors: Hager S. Awad, Kotb B. Tawfiq, S.M.R Tahoun, M.M. ElShanawany
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Power Electronics and Renewable Energy (CPERE)
abstract: The increasing emphasis on renewable energy, particularly wind energy systems, is highly motivating to introduce and use alternative generators for wind turbines. A new axial flux switching generator (AFSG) that can be used in wind energy systems was proposed and discussed in previous researches. The present paper is concerned with achieving the optimized design of the rotor in a new AFSG considering number of poles, pole arc, poles height and shape. After choosing the suitable stator and rotor poles combination with suitable pole arc of each part, a comparison is provided between the performance of the proposed designs of AFSG with rotor pole shoe and without it. The comparison is concerned with different variables such as output voltage waveforms, total harmonic distortion (THD), no-load and load characteristics. The theoretical results were carried out using finite element analysis software (ANSYS Maxwell software). The prototype for the new AFSG design has been built in a collaboration with the Arab Organization of Industrialization. The results were examined experimentally where a good agreement between the theoretical and measured performance has been obtained.

title: Predicting Magnetic Field Distribution Near Trapezoidal Permanent Ring Magnet Using Machine Learning
authors: Natalija V. Ivković, Isidora N. Jovanović, Ana N. Vučković, Dragana B. Vukić, Dušan M. Vučković
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Technologies, Systems and Services in Telecommunications (TELSIKS)
abstract: Kernel ridge regression is applied to predict normalized magnetic field values around a ring-shaped permanent magnet with a trapezoidal cross-section. Results are compared with a semi-numerical method based on fictitious magnetic charges. The close agreement between methods confirms the accuracy and potential of machine learning for magnetic field prediction.

title: Research on Automatic Exposure Algorithm Based on Chemiluminescence Imaging
authors: Zhiyong Ren, Zhaoliang Wang, Zhipeng Zhang
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Complex Medical Engineering (CME)
abstract: Dark field imaging is an important research method in the field of biological sciences. Certain biological samples emit transient, low-intensity luminescence when treated with chemical reagents, so cameras are needed to obtain high-definition luminescent images within a limited time. Traditional dark field imaging techniques rely on fixed exposure duration or empirical manual adjustment, often resulting in signal loss or image saturation due to insufficient exposure or overexposure. This article studies the imaging performance of a cooled CCD camera in dark fields using an automatic exposure algorithm. Compared with traditional imaging algorithms, it achieves higher precision exposure duration control. Combined with the OpenCV image recognition algorithm, it realizes automatic recognition of synchronized western blot, providing a technical platform for life science research.

title: A Cost-Effective EOG Acquisition Front-End for Laboratory Exercises
authors: Milica S. Stojanović, Jelena R. Djordjević-Kozarov, Jelena A. Anastasov, Dejan N. Milić, Emilie Avignon-Meseldzija
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Advanced Technologies, Systems and Services in Telecommunications (TELSIKS)
abstract: Electrooculography (EOG) is a non-invasive technique used to measure eye movements by detecting corneoretinal potential differences. In addition to its wide application in medicine, EOG is increasingly used for practical applications such as assistive device control (artificial arms, wheelchairs, virtual keyboards, etc), driver monitoring (fatigue and sleepiness detection, pilot training, etc), and gaze-based human-computer interaction (HCI) systems. A cost-effective acquisition front-end incorporating lightweight hardware has been developed. The proposed system is suitable for use in student laboratory exercises for educational and training purposes, as well as for further research and development. A model of such an acquisition front-end that fulfills the requirements is proposed in this paper. The results obtained so far are presented, and directions for further research are proposed.

title: Optimization Analysis of 5G Network Receiver Deployment in Substations
authors: Zhaojie Liang, Jie Tian, Chaoqun Jiao, Xueqian Gu, Yidi Zhang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy and Electrical Power Systems (ICEEPS)
